label: RHETORIC

label: RHETORIC

label: RHETORIC

text: Appellees in the Davis case have called attention to the similarity between it and the Briggs and Brown cases; by motion *3 they have asked the Court to take necessary action to have all three cases argued together.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: This Court takes judicial notice of a fourth case, which is pending in the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, Bolling et al.

text: In that case, the appellants challenge the appellees' refusal to admit certain Negro appellants to a segregated white school in the District of Columbia; they allege that appellees have taken such action pursuant to certain Acts of Congress; they allege that such action is a violation of the Fifth Amendment of the Constitution.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Court is of the opinion that the nature of the issue posed in those appeals now before the Court involving the Fourteenth Amendment, and also the effect of any decision which it may render in those cases, are such that it would be well to consider, simultaneously, the constitutional issue posed in the case of Bolling et al.

author: per_curiam
text: v. Sharpe et al., in the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: These cases were decided on May 17, 1954.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The opinions of that date,[1] declaring the fundamental principle that racial discrimination in public education is unconstitutional, are incorporated herein by reference.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: All provisions of federal, state, or local law requiring or permitting such discrimination must yield to this principle.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: There remains for consideration the manner in which relief is to be accorded.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Because these cases arose under different local conditions and their disposition will involve a variety of local problems, we requested further argument on the question of relief.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [2] In view of the nationwide importance of the decision, we invited the Attorney General of the United *299 States and the Attorneys General of all states requiring or permitting racial discrimination in public education to present their views on that question.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The parties, the United States, and the States of Florida, North Carolina, Arkansas, Oklahoma, Maryland, and Texas filed briefs and participated in the oral argument.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: These presentations were informative and helpful to the Court in its consideration of the complexities arising from the transition to a system of public education freed of racial discrimination.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The presentations also demonstrated that substantial steps to eliminate racial discrimination in public schools have already been taken, not only in some of the communities in which these cases arose, but in some of the states appearing as amici curiae, and in other states as well.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Substantial progress has been made in the District of Columbia and in the communities in Kansas and Delaware involved in this litigation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The defendants in the cases coming to us from South Carolina and Virginia are awaiting the decision of this Court concerning relief.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Full implementation of these constitutional principles may require solution of varied local school problems.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: School authorities have the primary responsibility for elucidating, assessing, and solving these problems; courts will have to consider whether the action of school authorities constitutes good faith implementation of the governing constitutional principles.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Because of their proximity to local conditions and the possible need for further hearings, the courts which originally heard these cases can best perform this judicial appraisal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Accordingly, we believe it appropriate to remand the cases to those courts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[3]
*300 In fashioning and effectuating the decrees, the courts will be guided by equitable principles.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Traditionally, equity has been characterized by a practical flexibility in shaping its remedies[4] and by a facility for adjusting and reconciling public and private needs.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [5] These cases call for the exercise of these traditional attributes of equity power.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At stake is the personal interest of the plaintiffs in admission to public schools as soon as practicable on a nondiscriminatory basis.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: To effectuate this interest may call for elimination of a variety of obstacles in making the transition to school systems operated in accordance with the constitutional principles set forth in our May 17, 1954, decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Courts of equity may properly take into account the public interest in the elimination of such obstacles in a systematic and effective manner.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: But it should go without saying that the vitality of these constitutional principles cannot be allowed to yield simply because of disagreement with them.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: While giving weight to these public and private considerations, the courts will require that the defendants make a prompt and reasonable start toward full compliance with our May 17, 1954, ruling.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Once such a start has been made, the courts may find that additional time is necessary to carry out the ruling in an effective manner.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The burden rests upon the defendants to establish that such time is necessary in the public interest and is consistent with good faith compliance at the earliest practicable date.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: To that end, the courts may consider problems related to administration, arising from the physical condition of the school plant, the school transportation system, personnel, revision of school districts and attendance areas into compact units to achieve a system of determining admission to the public schools *301 on a nonracial basis, and revision of local laws and regulations which may be necessary in solving the foregoing problems.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: They will also consider the adequacy of any plans the defendants may propose to meet these problems and to effectuate a transition to a racially nondiscriminatory school system.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: During this period of transition, the courts will retain jurisdiction of these cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The judgments below, except that in the Delaware case, are accordingly reversed and the cases are remanded to the District Courts to take such proceedings and enter such orders and decrees consistent with this opinion as are necessary and proper to admit to public schools on a racially nondiscriminatory basis with all deliberate speed the parties to these cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The judgment in the Delaware caseordering the immediate admission of the plaintiffs to schools previously attended only by white childrenis affirmed on the basis of the principles stated in our May 17, 1954, opinion, but the case is remanded to the Supreme Court of Delaware for such further proceedings as that Court may deem necessary in light of this opinion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: These cases come to us from the States of Kansas, South Carolina, Virginia, and Delaware.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: They are premised on different facts and different local conditions, but a common legal question justifies their consideration together in this consolidated opinion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[1]
*487 In each of the cases, minors of the Negro race, through their legal representatives, seek the aid of the courts in obtaining admission to the public schools of their community on a nonsegregated basis.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In each instance, *488 they had been denied admission to schools attended by white children under laws requiring or permitting segregation according to race.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This segregation was alleged to deprive the plaintiffs of the equal protection of the laws under the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In each of the cases other than the Delaware case, a three-judge federal district court denied relief to the plaintiffs on the so-called "separate but equal" doctrine announced by this Court in Plessy v. Ferguson, 163 U.S. 537.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Under that doctrine, equality of treatment is accorded when the races are provided substantially equal facilities, even though these facilities be separate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In the Delaware case, the Supreme Court of Delaware adhered to that doctrine, but ordered that the plaintiffs be admitted to the white schools because of their superiority to the Negro schools.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The plaintiffs contend that segregated public schools are not "equal" and cannot be made "equal," and that hence they are deprived of the equal protection of the laws.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Because of the obvious importance of the question presented, the Court took jurisdiction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [2] Argument was heard in the 1952 Term, and reargument was heard this Term on certain questions propounded by the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[3]
*489 Reargument was largely devoted to the circumstances surrounding the adoption of the Fourteenth Amendment in 1868.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It covered exhaustively consideration of the Amendment in Congress, ratification by the states, then existing practices in racial segregation, and the views of proponents and opponents of the Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This discussion and our own investigation convince us that, although these sources cast some light, it is not enough to resolve the problem with which we are faced.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At best, they are inconclusive.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The most avid proponents of the post-War Amendments undoubtedly intended them to remove all legal distinctions among "all persons born or naturalized in the United States."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Their opponents, just as certainly, were antagonistic to both the letter and the spirit of the Amendments and wished them to have the most limited effect.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: What others in Congress and the state legislatures had in mind cannot be determined with any degree of certainty.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: An additional reason for the inconclusive nature of the Amendment's history, with respect to segregated schools, is the status of public education at that time.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [4] In the South, the movement toward free common schools, supported *490 by general taxation, had not yet taken hold.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Education of white children was largely in the hands of private groups.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Education of Negroes was almost nonexistent, and practically all of the race were illiterate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In fact, any education of Negroes was forbidden by law in some states.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Today, in contrast, many Negroes have achieved outstanding success in the arts and sciences as well as in the business and professional world.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is true that public school education at the time of the Amendment had advanced further in the North, but the effect of the Amendment on Northern States was generally ignored in the congressional debates.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Even in the North, the conditions of public education did not approximate those existing today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The curriculum was usually rudimentary; ungraded schools were common in rural areas; the school term was but three months a year in many states; and compulsory school attendance was virtually unknown.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: As a consequence, it is not surprising that there should be so little in the history of the Fourteenth Amendment relating to its intended effect on public education.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In the first cases in this Court construing the Fourteenth Amendment, decided shortly after its adoption, the Court interpreted it as proscribing all state-imposed discriminations against the Negro race.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [5] The doctrine of *491 "separate but equal" did not make its appearance in this Court until 1896 in the case of Plessy v. Ferguson, supra, involving not education but transportation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [6] American courts have since labored with the doctrine for over half a century.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In this Court, there have been six cases involving the "separate but equal" doctrine in the field of public education.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [7] In Cumming v. County Board of Education, 175 U.S. 528, and Gong Lum v. Rice, 275 U.S. 78, the validity of the doctrine itself was not challenged.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [8] In more recent cases, all on the graduate school *492 level, inequality was found in that specific benefits enjoyed by white students were denied to Negro students of the same educational qualifications.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Missouri ex rel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Gaines v. Canada, 305 U.S. 337; Sipuel v. Oklahoma, 332 U.S. 631; Sweatt v. Painter, 339 U.S. 629; McLaurin v. Oklahoma State Regents, 339 U.S. 637.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In none of these cases was it necessary to re-examine the doctrine to grant relief to the Negro plaintiff.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: And in Sweatt v. Painter, supra, the Court expressly reserved decision on the question whether Plessy v. Ferguson should be held inapplicable to public education.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In the instant cases, that question is directly presented.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Here, unlike Sweatt v. Painter, there are findings below that the Negro and white schools involved have been equalized, or are being equalized, with respect to buildings, curricula, qualifications and salaries of teachers, and other "tangible" factors.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [9] Our decision, therefore, cannot turn on merely a comparison of these tangible factors in the Negro and white schools involved in each of the cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We must look instead to the effect of segregation itself on public education.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In approaching this problem, we cannot turn the clock back to 1868 when the Amendment was adopted, or even to 1896 when Plessy v. Ferguson was written.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We must consider public education in the light of its full development and its present place in American life throughout *493 the Nation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Only in this way can it be determined if segregation in public schools deprives these plaintiffs of the equal protection of the laws.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Today, education is perhaps the most important function of state and local governments.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Compulsory school attendance laws and the great expenditures for education both demonstrate our recognition of the importance of education to our democratic society.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is required in the performance of our most basic public responsibilities, even service in the armed forces.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is the very foundation of good citizenship.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Today it is a principal instrument in awakening the child to cultural values, in preparing him for later professional training, and in helping him to adjust normally to his environment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In these days, it is doubtful that any child may reasonably be expected to succeed in life if he is denied the opportunity of an education.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Such an opportunity, where the state has undertaken to provide it, is a right which must be made available to all on equal terms.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We come then to the question presented: Does segregation of children in public schools solely on the basis of race, even though the physical facilities and other "tangible" factors may be equal, deprive the children of the minority group of equal educational opportunities?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We believe that it does.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In Sweatt v. Painter, supra, in finding that a segregated law school for Negroes could not provide them equal educational opportunities, this Court relied in large part on "those qualities which are incapable of objective measurement but which make for greatness in a law school."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In McLaurin v. Oklahoma State Regents, supra, the Court, in requiring that a Negro admitted to a white graduate school be treated like all other students, again resorted to intangible considerations: ".
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: his ability to study, to engage in discussions and exchange views with other students, and, in general, to learn his profession."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: *494 Such considerations apply with added force to children in grade and high schools.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: To separate them from others of similar age and qualifications solely because of their race generates a feeling of inferiority as to their status in the community that may affect their hearts and minds in a way unlikely ever to be undone.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
The effect of this separation on their educational opportunities was well stated by a finding in the Kansas case by a court which nevertheless felt compelled to rule against the Negro plaintiffs:
"Segregation of white and colored children in public schools has a detrimental effect upon the colored children.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The impact is greater when it has the sanction of the law; for the policy of separating the races is usually interpreted as denoting the inferiority of the negro group.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: A sense of inferiority affects the motivation of a child to learn.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Segregation with the sanction of law, therefore, has a tendency to [retard] the educational and mental development of negro children and to deprive them of some of the benefits they would receive in a racial[ly] integrated school system.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[10]
Whatever may have been the extent of psychological knowledge at the time of Plessy v. Ferguson, this finding is amply supported by modern authority.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [11] Any language *495 in Plessy v. Ferguson contrary to this finding is rejected.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We conclude that in the field of public education the doctrine of "separate but equal" has no place.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Separate educational facilities are inherently unequal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Therefore, we hold that the plaintiffs and others similarly situated for whom the actions have been brought are, by reason of the segregation complained of, deprived of the equal protection of the laws guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This disposition makes unnecessary any discussion whether such segregation also violates the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[12]
Because these are class actions, because of the wide applicability of this decision, and because of the great variety of local conditions, the formulation of decrees in these cases presents problems of considerable complexity.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: On reargument, the consideration of appropriate relief was necessarily subordinated to the primary question the constitutionality of segregation in public education.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We have now announced that such segregation is a denial of the equal protection of the laws.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In order that we may have the full assistance of the parties in formulating decrees, the cases will be restored to the docket, and the parties are requested to present further argument on Questions 4 and 5 previously propounded by the Court for the reargument this Term.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [13] The Attorney General *496 of the United States is again invited to participate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The Attorneys General of the states requiring or permitting segregation in public education will also be permitted to appear as amici curiae upon request to do so by September 15, 1954, and submission of briefs by October 1, 1954.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[14]
It is so ordered.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: This action was instituted by the appellants attacking a Kansas statute which authorized segregation in the schools of that State.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: It was urged that the State of Kansas was without power to enact such legislation, claimed by appellants to be in contravention of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: In the District Court, the State, by its Governor and Attorney General, intervened and defended the constitutionality of the statute.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The court upheld its validity.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: In this Court, the appellants continue their constitutional attack.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: No appearance has been entered here by *142 the State of Kansas, the Board of Education of Topeka, and the other appellees; nor have they presented any brief in support of the statute's validity.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Court has been advised by counsel for the Board of Education that it does not propose to appear in oral argument or present a brief.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Because of the national importance of the issue presented and because of its importance to the State of Kansas, we request that the State present its views at oral argument.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: If the State does not desire to appear, we request the Attorney General to advise whether the State's default shall be construed as a concession of invalidity
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This case presents a constitutional question never addressed by this Court: whether a statutory scheme adopted by the State of Virginia to prevent marriages between persons solely on the basis of racial classifications violates the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [1] For reasons which seem to us to reflect the central meaning of those constitutional commands, we conclude that these statutes cannot stand consistently with the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In June 1958, two residents of Virginia, Mildred Jeter, a Negro woman, and Richard Loving, a white man, were married in the District of Columbia pursuant to its laws.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Shortly after their marriage, the Lovings returned to Virginia and established their marital abode in Caroline County.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At the October Term, 1958, of the Circuit Court *3 of Caroline County, a grand jury issued an indictment charging the Lovings with violating Virginia's ban on interracial marriages.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: On January 6, 1959, the Lovings pleaded guilty to the charge and were sentenced to one year in jail; however, the trial judge suspended the sentence for a period of 25 years on the condition that the Lovings leave the State and not return to Virginia together for 25 years.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
He stated in an opinion that:
"Almighty God created the races white, black, yellow, malay and red, and he placed them on separate continents.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: And but for the interference with his arrangement there would be no cause for such marriages.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The fact that he separated the races shows that he did not intend for the races to mix."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: After their convictions, the Lovings took up residence in the District of Columbia.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: On November 6, 1963, they filed a motion in the state trial court to vacate the judgment and set aside the sentence on the ground that the statutes which they had violated were repugnant to the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The motion not having been decided by October 28, 1964, the Lovings instituted a class action in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia requesting that a three-judge court be convened to declare the Virginia antimiscegenation statutes unconstitutional and to enjoin state officials from enforcing their convictions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: On January 22, 1965, the state trial judge denied the motion to vacate the sentences, and the Lovings perfected an appeal to the Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: On February 11, 1965, the three-judge District Court continued the case to allow the Lovings to present their constitutional claims to the highest state court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The Supreme Court of Appeals upheld the constitutionality of the antimiscegenation statutes and, after *4 modifying the sentence, affirmed the convictions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [2] The Lovings appealed this decision, and we noted probable jurisdiction on December 12, 1966, 385 U.S. 986.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The two statutes under which appellants were convicted and sentenced are part of a comprehensive statutory scheme aimed at prohibiting and punishing interracial marriages.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
The Lovings were convicted of violating § 20-58 of the Virginia Code:
"Leaving State to evade law.If any white person and colored person shall go out of this State, for the purpose of being married, and with the intention of returning, and be married out of it, and afterwards return to and reside in it, cohabiting as man and wife, they shall be punished as provided in § 20-59, and the marriage shall be governed by the same law as if it had been solemnized in this State.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The fact of their cohabitation here as man and wife shall be evidence of their marriage."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
Section 20-59, which defines the penalty for miscegenation, provides:
"Punishment for marriage.If any white person intermarry with a colored person, or any colored person intermarry with a white person, he shall be guilty of a felony and shall be punished by confinement in the penitentiary for not less than one nor more than five years."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Other central provisions in the Virginia statutory scheme are § 20-57, which automatically voids all marriages between "a white person and a colored person" without any judicial proceeding,[3] and §§ 20-54 and 1-14 which, *5 respectively, define "white persons" and "colored persons and Indians" for purposes of the statutory prohibitions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [4] The Lovings have never disputed in the course of this litigation that Mrs. Loving is a "colored person" or that Mr. Loving is a "white person" within the meanings given those terms by the Virginia statutes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: *6 Virginia is now one of 16 States which prohibit and punish marriages on the basis of racial classifications.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [5] Penalties for miscegenation arose as an incident to slavery and have been common in Virginia since the colonial period.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [6] The present statutory scheme dates from the adoption of the Racial Integrity Act of 1924, passed during the period of extreme nativism which followed the end of the First World War.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The central features of this Act, and current Virginia law, are the absolute prohibition of a "white person" marrying other than another "white person,"[7] a prohibition against issuing marriage licenses until the issuing official is satisfied that *7 the applicants' statements as to their race are correct,[8] certificates of "racial composition" to be kept by both local and state registrars,[9] and the carrying forward of earlier prohibitions against racial intermarriage.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In upholding the constitutionality of these provisions in the decision below, the Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia referred to its 1955 decision in Naim v. Naim, 197 Va. 80, 87 S.E.2d 749, as stating the reasons supporting the validity of these laws.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In Naim, the state court concluded that the State's legitimate purposes were "to preserve the racial integrity of its citizens," and to prevent "the corruption of blood," "a mongrel breed of citizens," and "the obliteration of racial pride," obviously an endorsement of the doctrine of White Supremacy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The court also reasoned that marriage has traditionally been subject to state regulation without federal intervention, and, consequently, the regulation of marriage should be left to exclusive state control by the Tenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: While the state court is no doubt correct in asserting that marriage is a social relation subject to the State's police power, Maynard v. Hill, 125 U.S. 190 (1888), the State does not contend in its argument before this Court that its powers to regulate marriage are unlimited notwithstanding the commands of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Nor could it do so in light of Meyer v. Nebraska, 262 U.S. 390 (1923), and Skinner v. Oklahoma, 316 U.S. 535 (1942).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Instead, the State argues that the meaning of the Equal Protection Clause, as illuminated by the statements of the Framers, is only that state penal laws containing an interracial element *8 as part of the definition of the offense must apply equally to whites and Negroes in the sense that members of each race are punished to the same degree.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Thus, the State contends that, because its miscegenation statutes punish equally both the white and the Negro participants in an interracial marriage, these statutes, despite their reliance on racial classifications, do not constitute an invidious discrimination based upon race.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The second argument advanced by the State assumes the validity of its equal application theory.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The argument is that, if the Equal Protection Clause does not outlaw miscegenation statutes because of their reliance on racial classifications, the question of constitutionality would thus become whether there was any rational basis for a State to treat interracial marriages differently from other marriages.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: On this question, the State argues, the scientific evidence is substantially in doubt and, consequently, this Court should defer to the wisdom of the state legislature in adopting its policy of discouraging interracial marriages.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Because we reject the notion that the mere "equal application" of a statute containing racial classifications is enough to remove the classifications from the Fourteenth Amendment's proscription of all invidious racial discriminations, we do not accept the State's contention that these statutes should be upheld if there is any possible basis for concluding that they serve a rational purpose.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The mere fact of equal application does not mean that our analysis of these statutes should follow the approach we have taken in cases involving no racial discrimination where the Equal Protection Clause has been arrayed against a statute discriminating between the kinds of advertising which may be displayed on trucks in New York City, Railway Express Agency, Inc. v. New York, 336 U.S. 106 (1949), or an exemption in Ohio's ad valorem tax for merchandise owned by a nonresident in a storage warehouse, Allied Stores of Ohio, *9 Inc. v. Bowers, 358 U.S. 522 (1959).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In these cases, involving distinctions not drawn according to race, the Court has merely asked whether there is any rational foundation for the discriminations, and has deferred to the wisdom of the state legislatures.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In the case at bar, however, we deal with statutes containing racial classifications, and the fact of equal application does not immunize the statute from the very heavy burden of justification which the Fourteenth Amendment has traditionally required of state statutes drawn according to race.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The State argues that statements in the Thirty-ninth Congress about the time of the passage of the Fourteenth Amendment indicate that the Framers did not intend the Amendment to make unconstitutional state miscegenation laws.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Many of the statements alluded to by the State concern the debates over the Freedmen's Bureau Bill, which President Johnson vetoed, and the Civil Rights Act of 1866, 14 Stat.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 27, enacted over his veto.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: While these statements have some relevance to the intention of Congress in submitting the Fourteenth Amendment, it must be understood that they pertained to the passage of specific statutes and not to the broader, organic purpose of a constitutional amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: As for the various statements directly concerning the Fourteenth Amendment, we have said in connection with a related problem, that although these historical sources "cast some light" they are not sufficient to resolve the problem; "[a]t best, they are inconclusive.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The most avid proponents of the post-War Amendments undoubtedly intended them to remove all legal distinctions among `all persons born or naturalized in the United States.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Their opponents, just as certainly, were antagonistic to both the letter and the spirit of the Amendments and wished them to have the most limited effect."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Brown v. Board of Education, 347 U.S. 483, 489 (1954).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: See also Strauder *10 v. West Virginia, 100 U.S. 303, 310 (1880).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We have rejected the proposition that the debates in the Thirty-ninth Congress or in the state legislatures which ratified the Fourteenth Amendment supported the theory advanced by the State, that the requirement of equal protection of the laws is satisfied by penal laws defining offenses based on racial classifications so long as white and Negro participants in the offense were similarly punished.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: McLaughlin v. Florida, 379 U.S. 184 (1964).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The State finds support for its "equal application" theory in the decision of the Court in Pace v. Alabama, 106 U.S. 583 (1883).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In that case, the Court upheld a conviction under an Alabama statute forbidding adultery or fornication between a white person and a Negro which imposed a greater penalty than that of a statute proscribing similar conduct by members of the same race.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The Court reasoned that the statute could not be said to discriminate against Negroes because the punishment for each participant in the offense was the same.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: However, as recently as the 1964 Term, in rejecting the reasoning of that case, we stated "Pace represents a limited view of the Equal Protection Clause which has not withstood analysis in the subsequent decisions of this Court."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: McLaughlin v. Florida, supra, at 188.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: As we there demonstrated, the Equal Protection Clause requires the consideration of whether the classifications drawn by any statute constitute an arbitrary and invidious discrimination.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The clear and central purpose of the Fourteenth Amendment was to eliminate all official state sources of invidious racial discrimination in the States.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Slaughter-House Cases, 16 Wall.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 36, 71 (1873); Strauder v. West Virginia, 100 U.S. 303, 307-308 (1880); Ex parte Virginia, 100 U.S. 339, 344-345 (1880); Shelley v. Kraemer, 334 U.S. 1 (1948); Burton v. Wilmington Parking Authority, 365 U.S. 715 (1961).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: *11 There can be no question but that Virginia's miscegenation statutes rest solely upon distinctions drawn according to race.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The statutes proscribe generally accepted conduct if engaged in by members of different races.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Over the years, this Court has consistently repudiated "[d]istinctions between citizens solely because of their ancestry" as being "odious to a free people whose institutions are founded upon the doctrine of equality."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Hirabayashi v. United States, 320 U.S. 81, 100 (1943).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At the very least, the Equal Protection Clause demands that racial classifications, especially suspect in criminal statutes, be subjected to the "most rigid scrutiny," Korematsu v. United States, 323 U.S. 214, 216 (1944), and, if they are ever to be upheld, they must be shown to be necessary to the accomplishment of some permissible state objective, independent of the racial discrimination which it was the object of the Fourteenth Amendment to eliminate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Indeed, two members of this Court have already stated that they "cannot conceive of a valid legislative purpose .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: which makes the color of a person's skin the test of whether his conduct is a criminal offense."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: McLaughlin v. Florida, supra, at 198 (STEWART, J., joined by DOUGLAS, J., concurring).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: There is patently no legitimate overriding purpose independent of invidious racial discrimination which justifies this classification.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The fact that Virginia prohibits only interracial marriages involving white persons demonstrates that the racial classifications must stand on their own justification, as measures designed to maintain White Supremacy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [11] We have consistently denied *12 the constitutionality of measures which restrict the rights of citizens on account of race.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: There can be no doubt that restricting the freedom to marry solely because of racial classifications violates the central meaning of the Equal Protection Clause.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: These statutes also deprive the Lovings of liberty without due process of law in violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The freedom to marry has long been recognized as one of the vital personal rights essential to the orderly pursuit of happiness by free men.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Marriage is one of the "basic civil rights of man," fundamental to our very existence and survival.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Skinner v. Oklahoma, 316 U.S. 535, 541 (1942).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: See also Maynard v. Hill, 125 U.S. 190 (1888).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: To deny this fundamental freedom on so unsupportable a basis as the racial classifications embodied in these statutes, classifications so directly subversive of the principle of equality at the heart of the Fourteenth Amendment, is surely to deprive all the State's citizens of liberty without due process of law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The Fourteenth Amendment requires that the freedom of choice to marry not be restricted by invidious racial discriminations.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Under our Constitution, the freedom to marry, or not marry, a person of another race resides with the individual and cannot be infringed by the State.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: These convictions must be reversed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: I have previously expressed the belief that "it is simply not possible for a state law to be valid under our Constitution which makes the criminality of an act depend upon the race of the actor."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: McLaughlin v. Florida, 379 U.S. 184, 198 (concurring opinion).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: Because I adhere to that belief, I concur in the judgment of the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The cases before us raise questions which go to the roots of our concepts of American criminal jurisprudence: the restraints society must observe consistent with the Federal Constitution in prosecuting individuals for crime.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: More specifically, we deal with the admissibility of statements obtained from an individual who is subjected to custodial police interrogation and the necessity for procedures which assure that the individual is accorded his privilege under the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution not to be compelled to incriminate himself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: *440 We dealt with certain phases of this problem recently in Escobedo v. Illinois, 378 U.S. 478 (1964).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: There, as in the four cases before us, law enforcement officials took the defendant into custody and interrogated him in a police station for the purpose of obtaining a confession.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The police did not effectively advise him of his right to remain silent or of his right to consult with his attorney.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Rather, they confronted him with an alleged accomplice who accused him of having perpetrated a murder.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: When the defendant denied the accusation and said "I didn't shoot Manuel, you did it," they handcuffed him and took him to an interrogation room.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: There, while handcuffed and standing, he was questioned for four hours until he confessed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: During this interrogation, the police denied his request to speak to his attorney, and they prevented his retained attorney, who had come to the police station, from consulting with him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At his trial, the State, over his objection, introduced the confession against him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We held that the statements thus made were constitutionally inadmissible.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This case has been the subject of judicial interpretation and spirited legal debate since it was decided two years ago.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Both state and federal courts, in assessing its implications, have arrived at varying conclusions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [1] A wealth of scholarly material has been written tracing its ramifications and underpinnings.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [2] Police and prosecutor *441 have speculated on its range and desirability.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [3] We granted certiorari in these cases, 382 U.S. 924, 925, 937, in order further to explore some facets of the problems, thus exposed, of applying the privilege against self-incrimination to in-custody interrogation, and to give *442 concrete constitutional guidelines for law enforcement agencies and courts to follow.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We start here, as we did in Escobedo, with the premise that our holding is not an innovation in our jurisprudence, but is an application of principles long recognized and applied in other settings.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We have undertaken a thorough re-examination of the Escobedo decision and the principles it announced, and we reaffirm it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: That case was but an explication of basic rights that are enshrined in our Constitutionthat "No person .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself," and that "the accused shall .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: have the Assistance of Counsel"rights which were put in jeopardy in that case through official overbearing.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: These precious rights were fixed in our Constitution only after centuries of persecution and struggle.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: And in the words of Chief Justice Marshall, they were secured "for ages to come, and .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: designed to approach immortality as nearly as human institutions can approach it," Cohens v. Virginia, 6 Wheat.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
Over 70 years ago, our predecessors on this Court eloquently stated:
"The maxim nemo tenetur seipsum accusare had its origin in a protest against the inquisitorial and manifestly unjust methods of interrogating accused persons, which [have] long obtained in the continental system, and, until the expulsion of the Stuarts from the British throne in 1688, and the erection of additional barriers for the protection of the people against the exercise of arbitrary power, [were] not uncommon even in England.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: While the admissions or confessions of the prisoner, when voluntarily and freely made, have always ranked high in the scale of incriminating evidence, if an accused person be asked to explain his apparent connection with a crime under investigation, the ease with which the *443 questions put to him may assume an inquisitorial character, the temptation to press the witness unduly, to browbeat him if he be timid or reluctant, to push him into a corner, and to entrap him into fatal contradictions, which is so painfully evident in many of the earlier state trials, notably in those of Sir Nicholas Throckmorton, and Udal, the Puritan minister, made the system so odious as to give rise to a demand for its total abolition.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The change in the English criminal procedure in that particular seems to be founded upon no statute and no judicial opinion, but upon a general and silent acquiescence of the courts in a popular demand.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: But, however adopted, it has become firmly embedded in English, as well as in American jurisprudence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: So deeply did the iniquities of the ancient system impress themselves upon the minds of the American colonists that the States, with one accord, made a denial of the right to question an accused person a part of their fundamental law, so that a maxim, which in England was a mere rule of evidence, became clothed in this country with the impregnability of a constitutional enactment."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
In stating the obligation of the judiciary to apply these constitutional rights, this Court declared in Weems v. United States, 217 U.S. 349, 373 (1910):
".
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: our contemplation cannot be only of what has been but of what may be.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Under any other rule a constitution would indeed be as easy of application as it would be deficient in efficacy and power.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Its general principles would have little value and be converted by precedent into impotent and lifeless formulas.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Rights declared in words might be lost in reality.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: And this has been recognized.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The *444 meaning and vitality of the Constitution have developed against narrow and restrictive construction."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This was the spirit in which we delineated, in meaningful language, the manner in which the constitutional rights of the individual could be enforced against overzealous police practices.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It was necessary in Escobedo, as here, to insure that what was proclaimed in the Constitution had not become but a "form of words," Silverthorne Lumber Co. v. United States, 251 U.S. 385, 392 (1920), in the hands of government officials.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: And it is in this spirit, consistent with our role as judges, that we adhere to the principles of Escobedo today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Our holding will be spelled out with some specificity in the pages which follow but briefly stated it is this: the prosecution may not use statements, whether exculpatory or inculpatory, stemming from custodial interrogation of the defendant unless it demonstrates the use of procedural safeguards effective to secure the privilege against self-incrimination.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: By custodial interrogation, we mean questioning initiated by law enforcement officers after a person has been taken into custody or otherwise deprived of his freedom of action in any significant way.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [4] As for the procedural safeguards to be employed, unless other fully effective means are devised to inform accused persons of their right of silence and to assure a continuous opportunity to exercise it, the following measures are required.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Prior to any questioning, the person must be warned that he has a right to remain silent, that any statement he does make may be used as evidence against him, and that he has a right to the presence of an attorney, either retained or appointed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The defendant may waive effectuation of these rights, provided the waiver is made voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: If, however, he indicates in any manner and at any stage of the *445 process that he wishes to consult with an attorney before speaking there can be no questioning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Likewise, if the individual is alone and indicates in any manner that he does not wish to be interrogated, the police may not question him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The mere fact that he may have answered some questions or volunteered some statements on his own does not deprive him of the right to refrain from answering any further inquiries until he has consulted with an attorney and thereafter consents to be questioned.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The constitutional issue we decide in each of these cases is the admissibility of statements obtained from a defendant questioned while in custody or otherwise deprived of his freedom of action in any significant way.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In each, the defendant was questioned by police officers, detectives, or a prosecuting attorney in a room in which he was cut off from the outside world.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In none of these cases was the defendant given a full and effective warning of his rights at the outset of the interrogation process.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In all the cases, the questioning elicited oral admissions, and in three of them, signed statements as well which were admitted at their trials.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: They all thus share salient features incommunicado interrogation of individuals in a police-dominated atmosphere, resulting in self-incriminating statements without full warnings of constitutional rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: An understanding of the nature and setting of this in-custody interrogation is essential to our decisions today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The difficulty in depicting what transpires at such interrogations stems from the fact that in this country they have largely taken place incommunicado.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: From extensive factual studies undertaken in the early 1930's, including the famous Wickersham Report to Congress by a Presidential Commission, it is clear that police violence and the "third degree" flourished at that time.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [5]*446 In a series of cases decided by this Court long after these studies, the police resorted to physical brutalitybeating, hanging, whippingand to sustained and protracted questioning incommunicado in order to extort confessions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [6] The Commission on Civil Rights in 1961 found much evidence to indicate that "some policemen still resort to physical force to obtain confessions," 1961 Comm'n on Civil Rights Rep., Justice, pt.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The use of physical brutality and violence is not, unfortunately, relegated to the past or to any part of the country.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Only recently in Kings County, New York, the police brutally beat, kicked and placed lighted cigarette butts on the back of a potential witness under interrogation for the purpose of securing a statement incriminating a third party.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[7]
*447 The examples given above are undoubtedly the exception now, but they are sufficiently widespread to be the object of concern.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Unless a proper limitation upon custodial interrogation is achievedsuch as these decisions will advancethere can be no assurance that practices of this nature will be eradicated in the foreseeable future.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
The conclusion of the Wickersham Commission Report, made over 30 years ago, is still pertinent:
"To the contention that the third degree is necessary to get the facts, the reporters aptly reply in the language of the present Lord Chancellor of England (Lord Sankey): `It is not admissible to do a great right by doing a little wrong.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is not sufficient to do justice by obtaining a proper result by irregular or improper means.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Not only does the use of the third degree involve a flagrant violation of law by the officers of the law, but it involves also the dangers of false confessions, and it tends to make police and prosecutors less zealous in the search for objective evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: As the New York prosecutor quoted in the report said, `It is a short cut and makes the police lazy and unenterprising.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Or, as another official quoted remarked: `If you use your fists, you *448 are not so likely to use your wits.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We agree with the conclusion expressed in the report, that `The third degree brutalizes the police, hardens the prisoner against society, and lowers the esteem in which the administration of justice is held by the public.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: " IV National Commission on Law Observance and Enforcement, Report on Lawlessness in Law Enforcement 5 (1931).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Again we stress that the modern practice of in-custody interrogation is psychologically rather than physically oriented.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: As we have stated before, "Since Chambers v. Florida, 309 U.S. 227, this Court has recognized that coercion can be mental as well as physical, and that the blood of the accused is not the only hallmark of an unconstitutional inquisition."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Blackburn v. Alabama, 361 U.S. 199, 206 (1960).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Interrogation still takes place in privacy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Privacy results in secrecy and this in turn results in a gap in our knowledge as to what in fact goes on in the interrogation rooms.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: A valuable source of information about present police practices, however, may be found in various police manuals and texts which document procedures employed with success in the past, and which recommend various other effective tactics.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [8] These *449 texts are used by law enforcement agencies themselves as guides.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [9] It should be noted that these texts professedly present the most enlightened and effective means presently used to obtain statements through custodial interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The officers are told by the manuals that the "principal psychological factor contributing to a successful interrogation is privacybeing alone with the person under interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: By considering these texts and other data, it is possible to describe procedures observed and noted around the country.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[10] The efficacy of this tactic has been explained as follows:
"If at all practicable, the interrogation should take place in the investigator's office or at least in a room of his own choice.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The subject should be deprived of every psychological advantage.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In his own home he may be confident, indignant, or recalcitrant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He is more keenly aware of his rights and *450 more reluctant to tell of his indiscretions or criminal behavior within the walls of his home.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Moreover his family and other friends are nearby, their presence lending moral support.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In his own office, the investigator possesses all the advantages.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The atmosphere suggests the invincibility of the forces of the law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[11]
To highlight the isolation and unfamiliar surroundings, the manuals instruct the police to display an air of confidence in the suspect's guilt and from outward appearance to maintain only an interest in confirming certain details.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The guilt of the subject is to be posited as a fact.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The interrogator should direct his comments toward the reasons why the subject committed the act, rather than court failure by asking the subject whether he did it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Like other men, perhaps the subject has had a bad family life, had an unhappy childhood, had too much to drink, had an unrequited desire for women.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The officers are instructed to minimize the moral seriousness of the offense,[12] to cast blame on the victim or on society.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [13] These tactics are designed to put the subject in a psychological state where his story is but an elaboration of what the police purport to know already that he is guilty.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Explanations to the contrary are dismissed and discouraged.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The texts thus stress that the major qualities an interrogator should possess are patience and perseverance.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
*451 One writer describes the efficacy of these characteristics in this manner:
"In the preceding paragraphs emphasis has been placed on kindness and stratagems.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The investigator will, however, encounter many situations where the sheer weight of his personality will be the deciding factor.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Where emotional appeals and tricks are employed to no avail, he must rely on an oppressive atmosphere of dogged persistence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He must interrogate steadily and without relent, leaving the subject no prospect of surcease.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He must dominate his subject and overwhelm him with his inexorable will to obtain the truth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He should interrogate for a spell of several hours pausing only for the subject's necessities in acknowledgment of the need to avoid a charge of duress that can be technically substantiated.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In a serious case, the interrogation may continue for days, with the required intervals for food and sleep, but with no respite from the atmosphere of domination.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is possible in this way to induce the subject to talk without resorting to duress or coercion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The method should be used only when the guilt of the subject appears highly probable.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[14]
The manuals suggest that the suspect be offered legal excuses for his actions in order to obtain an initial admission of guilt.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
Where there is a suspected revenge-killing, for example, the interrogator may say:
"Joe, you probably didn't go out looking for this fellow with the purpose of shooting him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: My guess is, however, that you expected something from him and that's why you carried a gunfor your own protection.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: You knew him for what he was, no good.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Then when you met him he probably started using foul, abusive language and he gave some indication *452 that he was about to pull a gun on you, and that's when you had to act to save your own life.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: That's about it, isn't it, Joe?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[15]
Having then obtained the admission of shooting, the interrogator is advised to refer to circumstantial evidence which negates the self-defense explanation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This should enable him to secure the entire story.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: One text notes that "Even if he fails to do so, the inconsistency between the subject's original denial of the shooting and his present admission of at least doing the shooting will serve to deprive him of a self-defense `out' at the time of trial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[16]
When the techniques described above prove unavailing, the texts recommend they be alternated with a show of some hostility.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
One ploy often used has been termed the "friendly-unfriendly" or the "Mutt and Jeff" act:
".
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In this technique, two agents are employed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Mutt, the relentless investigator, who knows the subject is guilty and is not going to waste any time.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He's sent a dozen men away for this crime and he's going to send the subject away for the full term.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Jeff, on the other hand, is obviously a kindhearted man.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He has a family himself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He has a brother who was involved in a little scrape like this.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He disapproves of Mutt and his tactics and will arrange to get him off the case if the subject will cooperate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He can't hold Mutt off for very long.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The subject would be wise to make a quick decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The technique is applied by having both investigators present while Mutt acts out his role.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Jeff may stand by quietly and demur at some of Mutt's tactics.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: When Jeff makes his plea for cooperation, Mutt is not present in the room.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[17]
*453 The interrogators sometimes are instructed to induce a confession out of trickery.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The technique here is quite effective in crimes which require identification or which run in series.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In the identification situation, the interrogator may take a break in his questioning to place the subject among a group of men in a line-up.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: "The witness or complainant (previously coached, if necessary) studies the line-up and confidently points out the subject as the guilty party.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: "[18] Then the questioning resumes "as though there were now no doubt about the guilt of the subject."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
A variation on this technique is called the "reverse line-up":
"The accused is placed in a line-up, but this time he is identified by several fictitious witnesses or victims who associated him with different offenses.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is expected that the subject will become desperate and confess to the offense under investigation in order to escape from the false accusations.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[19]
The manuals also contain instructions for police on how to handle the individual who refuses to discuss the matter entirely, or who asks for an attorney or relatives.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The examiner is to concede him the right to remain silent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: "This usually has a very undermining effect.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: First of all, he is disappointed in his expectation of an unfavorable reaction on the part of the interrogator.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Secondly, a concession of this right to remain silent impresses *454 the subject with the apparent fairness of his interrogator.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[20] After this psychological conditioning, however, the officer is told to point out the incriminating significance of the suspect's refusal to talk:
"Joe, you have a right to remain silent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: That's your privilege and I'm the last person in the world who'll try to take it away from you.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: If that's the way you want to leave this, O. K. But let me ask you this.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Suppose you were in my shoes and I were in yours and you called me in to ask me about this and I told you, `I don't want to answer any of your questions.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: You'd think I had something to hide, and you'd probably be right in thinking that.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: That's exactly what I'll have to think about you, and so will everybody else.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: So let's sit here and talk this whole thing over.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[21]
Few will persist in their initial refusal to talk, it is said, if this monologue is employed correctly.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
In the event that the subject wishes to speak to a relative or an attorney, the following advice is tendered:
"[T]he interrogator should respond by suggesting that the subject first tell the truth to the interrogator himself rather than get anyone else involved in the matter.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: If the request is for an attorney, the interrogator may suggest that the subject save himself or his family the expense of any such professional service, particularly if he is innocent of the offense under investigation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The interrogator may also add, `Joe, I'm only looking for the truth, and if you're telling the truth, that's it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: You can handle this by yourself.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[22]
*455 From these representative samples of interrogation techniques, the setting prescribed by the manuals and observed in practice becomes clear.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In essence, it is this: To be alone with the subject is essential to prevent distraction and to deprive him of any outside support.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The aura of confidence in his guilt undermines his will to resist.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He merely confirms the preconceived story the police seek to have him describe.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Patience and persistence, at times relentless questioning, are employed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: To obtain a confession, the interrogator must "patiently maneuver himself or his quarry into a position from which the desired objective may be attained.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: "[23] When normal procedures fail to produce the needed result, the police may resort to deceptive stratagems such as giving false legal advice.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is important to keep the subject off balance, for example, by trading on his insecurity about himself or his surroundings.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The police then persuade, trick, or cajole him out of exercising his constitutional rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Even without employing brutality, the "third degree" or the specific stratagems described above, the very fact of custodial interrogation exacts a heavy toll on individual liberty and trades on the weakness of individuals.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [24]*456 This fact may be illustrated simply by referring to three confession cases decided by this Court in the Term immediately preceding our Escobedo decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In Townsend v. Sain, 372 U.S. 293 (1963), the defendant was a 19-year-old heroin addict, described as a "near mental defective," id., at 307-310.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The defendant in Lynumn v. Illinois, 372 U.S. 528 (1963), was a woman who confessed to the arresting officer after being importuned to "cooperate" in order to prevent her children from being taken by relief authorities.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This Court as in those cases reversed the conviction of a defendant in Haynes v. Washington, 373 U.S. 503 (1963), whose persistent request during his interrogation was to phone his wife or attorney.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [25] In other settings, these individuals might have exercised their constitutional rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In the incommunicado police-dominated atmosphere, they succumbed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In the cases before us today, given this background, we concern ourselves primarily with this interrogation atmosphere and the evils it can bring.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 759, Miranda v. Arizona, the police arrested the defendant and took him to a special interrogation room where they secured a confession.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 760, Vignera v. New York, the defendant made oral admissions to the police after interrogation in the afternoon, and then signed an inculpatory statement upon being questioned by an assistant district attorney later the same evening.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 761, Westover v. United States, the defendant was handed over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation by *457 local authorities after they had detained and interrogated him for a lengthy period, both at night and the following morning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: After some two hours of questioning, the federal officers had obtained signed statements from the defendant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Lastly, in No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 584, California v. Stewart, the local police held the defendant five days in the station and interrogated him on nine separate occasions before they secured his inculpatory statement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In these cases, we might not find the defendants' statements to have been involuntary in traditional terms.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Our concern for adequate safeguards to protect precious Fifth Amendment rights is, of course, not lessened in the slightest.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In each of the cases, the defendant was thrust into an unfamiliar atmosphere and run through menacing police interrogation procedures.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The potentiality for compulsion is forcefully apparent, for example, in Miranda, where the indigent Mexican defendant was a seriously disturbed individual with pronounced sexual fantasies, and in Stewart, in which the defendant was an indigent Los Angeles Negro who had dropped out of school in the sixth grade.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: To be sure, the records do not evince overt physical coercion or patent psychological ploys.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The fact remains that in none of these cases did the officers undertake to afford appropriate safeguards at the outset of the interrogation to insure that the statements were truly the product of free choice.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is obvious that such an interrogation environment is created for no purpose other than to subjugate the individual to the will of his examiner.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This atmosphere carries its own badge of intimidation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: To be sure, this is not physical intimidation, but it is equally destructive of human dignity.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [26] The current practice of incommunicado interrogation is at odds with one of our *458 Nation's most cherished principlesthat the individual may not be compelled to incriminate himself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Unless adequate protective devices are employed to dispel the compulsion inherent in custodial surroundings, no statement obtained from the defendant can truly be the product of his free choice.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: From the foregoing, we can readily perceive an intimate connection between the privilege against self-incrimination and police custodial questioning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is fitting to turn to history and precedent underlying the Self-Incrimination Clause to determine its applicability in this situation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We sometimes forget how long it has taken to establish the privilege against self-incrimination, the sources from which it came and the fervor with which it was defended.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Its roots go back into ancient times.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [27] Perhaps *459 the critical historical event shedding light on its origins and evolution was the trial of one John Lilburn, a vocal anti-Stuart Leveller, who was made to take the Star Chamber Oath in 1637.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The oath would have bound him to answer to all questions posed to him on any subject.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The Trial of John Lilburn and John Wharton, 3 How.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
He resisted the oath and declaimed the proceedings, stating:
