"Another fundamental right I then contended for, was, that no man's conscience ought to be racked by oaths imposed, to answer to questions concerning himself in matters criminal, or pretended to be so."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Haller & Davies, The Leveller Tracts 1647-1653, p. 454 (1944).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: On account of the Lilburn Trial, Parliament abolished the inquisitorial Court of Star Chamber and went further in giving him generous reparation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The lofty principles to which Lilburn had appealed during his trial gained popular acceptance in England.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [28] These sentiments worked their way over to the Colonies and were implanted after great struggle into the Bill of Rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [29] Those who framed our Constitution and the Bill of Rights were ever aware of subtle encroachments on individual liberty.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: They knew that "illegitimate and unconstitutional practices get their first footing .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: by silent approaches and slight deviations from legal modes of procedure."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Boyd v. United States, 116 U.S. 616, 635 (1886).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The privilege was elevated to constitutional status and has always been "as broad as the mischief *460 against which it seeks to guard."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Counselman v. Hitchcock, 142 U.S. 547, 562 (1892).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We cannot depart from this noble heritage.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Thus we may view the historical development of the privilege as one which groped for the proper scope of governmental power over the citizen.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: As a "noble principle often transcends its origins," the privilege has come rightfully to be recognized in part as an individual's substantive right, a "right to a private enclave where he may lead a private life.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: That right is the hallmark of our democracy."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: United States v. Grunewald, 233 F.2d 556, 579, 581-582 (Frank, J., dissenting), rev'd, 353 U.S. 391 (1957).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We have recently noted that the privilege against self-incriminationthe essential mainstay of our adversary systemis founded on a complex of values, Murphy v. Waterfront Comm'n, 378 U.S. 52, 55-57, n. 5 (1964); Tehan v. Shott, 382 U.S. 406, 414-415, n. 12 (1966).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: All these policies point to one overriding thought: the constitutional foundation underlying the privilege is the respect a governmentstate or federal must accord to the dignity and integrity of its citizens.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: To maintain a "fair state-individual balance," to require the government "to shoulder the entire load," 8 Wigmore, Evidence 317 (McNaughton rev.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 1961), to respect the inviolability of the human personality, our accusatory system of criminal justice demands that the government seeking to punish an individual produce the evidence against him by its own independent labors, rather than by the cruel, simple expedient of compelling it from his own mouth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Chambers v. Florida, 309 U.S. 227, 235-238 (1940).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In sum, the privilege is fulfilled only when the person is guaranteed the right "to remain silent unless he chooses to speak in the unfettered exercise of his own will."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U.S. 1, 8 (1964).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The question in these cases is whether the privilege is fully applicable during a period of custodial interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: *461 In this Court, the privilege has consistently been accorded a liberal construction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Albertson v. SACB, 382 U.S. 70, 81 (1965); Hoffman v. United States, 341 U.S. 479, 486 (1951); Arndstein v. McCarthy, 254 U.S. 71, 72-73 (1920); Counselman v. Hitchock, 142 U.S. 547, 562 (1892).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We are satisfied that all the principles embodied in the privilege apply to informal compulsion exerted by law-enforcement officers during in-custody questioning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: An individual swept from familiar surroundings into police custody, surrounded by antagonistic forces, and subjected to the techniques of persuasion described above cannot be otherwise than under compulsion to speak.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: As a practical matter, the compulsion to speak in the isolated setting of the police station may well be greater than in courts or other official investigations, where there are often impartial observers to guard against intimidation or trickery.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[30]
This question, in fact, could have been taken as settled in federal courts almost 70 years ago, when, in Bram v. United States, 168 U.S. 532, 542 (1897), this Court held:
"In criminal trials, in the courts of the United States, wherever a question arises whether a confession is incompetent because not voluntary, the issue is controlled by that portion of the Fifth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: commanding that no person `shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"
In Bram, the Court reviewed the British and American history and case law and set down the Fifth Amendment standard for compulsion which we implement today:
"Much of the confusion which has resulted from the effort to deduce from the adjudged cases what *462 would be a sufficient quantum of proof to show that a confession was or was not voluntary, has arisen from a misconception of the subject to which the proof must address itself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The rule is not that in order to render a statement admissible the proof must be adequate to establish that the particular communications contained in a statement were voluntarily made, but it must be sufficient to establish that the making of the statement was voluntary; that is to say, that from the causes, which the law treats as legally sufficient to engender in the mind of the accused hope or fear in respect to the crime charged, the accused was not involuntarily impelled to make a statement, when but for the improper influences he would have remained silent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: And see, id., at 542.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The Court has adhered to this reasoning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In 1924, Mr. Justice Brandeis wrote for a unanimous Court in reversing a conviction resting on a compelled confession, Wan v. United States, 266 U.S. 1.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
He stated:
"In the federal courts, the requisite of voluntariness is not satisfied by establishing merely that the confession was not induced by a promise or a threat.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: A confession is voluntary in law if, and only if, it was, in fact, voluntarily made.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: A confession may have been given voluntarily, although it was made to police officers, while in custody, and in answer to an examination conducted by them.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: But a confession obtained by compulsion must be excluded whatever may have been the character of the compulsion, and whether the compulsion was applied in a judicial proceeding or otherwise.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Bram v. United States, 168 U.S.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In addition to the expansive historical development of the privilege and the sound policies which have nurtured *463 its evolution, judicial precedent thus clearly establishes its application to incommunicado interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In fact, the Government concedes this point as well established in No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 761, Westover v. United States, stating: "We have no doubt .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: that it is possible for a suspect's Fifth Amendment right to be violated during in-custody questioning by a law-enforcement officer.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[31]
Because of the adoption by Congress of Rule 5 (a) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, and this Court's effectuation of that Rule in McNabb v. United States, 318 U.S. 332 (1943), and Mallory v. United States, 354 U.S. 449 (1957), we have had little occasion in the past quarter century to reach the constitutional issues in dealing with federal interrogations.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: These supervisory rules, requiring production of an arrested person before a commissioner "without unnecessary delay" and excluding evidence obtained in default of that statutory obligation, were nonetheless responsive to the same considerations of Fifth Amendment policy that unavoidably face us now as to the States.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In McNabb, 318 U. S., at 343-344, and in Mallory, 354 U. S., at 455-456, we recognized both the dangers of interrogation and the appropriateness of prophylaxis stemming from the very fact of interrogation itself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[32]
Our decision in Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U.S. 1 (1964), necessitates an examination of the scope of the privilege in state cases as well.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In Malloy, we squarely held the *464 privilege applicable to the States, and held that the substantive standards underlying the privilege applied with full force to state court proceedings.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: There, as in Murphy v. Waterfront Comm'n, 378 U.S. 52 (1964), and Griffin v. California, 380 U.S. 609 (1965), we applied the existing Fifth Amendment standards to the case before us.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Aside from the holding itself, the reasoning in Malloy made clear what had already become apparentthat the substantive and procedural safeguards surrounding admissibility of confessions in state cases had become exceedingly exacting, reflecting all the policies embedded in the privilege, 378 U.S., at 7-8.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [33] The voluntariness doctrine in the state cases, as Malloy indicates, encompasses all interrogation practices which are likely to exert such pressure upon an individual as to disable him from *465 making a free and rational choice.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [34] The implications of this proposition were elaborated in our decision in Escobedo v. Illinois, 378 U.S. 478, decided one week after Malloy applied the privilege to the States.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Our holding there stressed the fact that the police had not advised the defendant of his constitutional privilege to remain silent at the outset of the interrogation, and we drew attention to that fact at several points in the decision, 378 U.S., at 483, 485, 491.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This was no isolated factor, but an essential ingredient in our decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The entire thrust of police interrogation there, as in all the cases today, was to put the defendant in such an emotional state as to impair his capacity for rational judgment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The abdication of the constitutional privilege the choice on his part to speak to the policewas not made knowingly or competently because of the failure to apprise him of his rights; the compelling atmosphere of the in-custody interrogation, and not an independent decision on his part, caused the defendant to speak.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: A different phase of the Escobedo decision was significant in its attention to the absence of counsel during the questioning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: There, as in the cases today, we sought a protective device to dispel the compelling atmosphere of the interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In Escobedo, however, the police did not relieve the defendant of the anxieties which they had created in the interrogation rooms.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Rather, they denied his request for the assistance of counsel, 378 U.S., at 481, 488, 491.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [35] This heightened his dilemma, and *466 made his later statements the product of this compulsion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Haynes v. Washington, 373 U.S. 503, 514 (1963).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The denial of the defendant's request for his attorney thus undermined his ability to exercise the privilege to remain silent if he chose or to speak without any intimidation, blatant or subtle.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The presence of counsel, in all the cases before us today, would be the adequate protective device necessary to make the process of police interrogation conform to the dictates of the privilege.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: His presence would insure that statements made in the government-established atmosphere are not the product of compulsion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It was in this manner that Escobedo explicated another facet of the pre-trial privilege, noted in many of the Court's prior decisions: the protection of rights at trial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [36] That counsel is present when statements are taken from an individual during interrogation obviously enhances the integrity of the fact-finding processes in court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The presence of an attorney, and the warnings delivered to the individual, enable the defendant under otherwise compelling circumstances to tell his story without fear, effectively, and in a way that eliminates the evils in the interrogation process.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Without the protections flowing from adequate warnings and the rights of counsel, "all the careful safeguards erected around the giving of testimony, whether by an accused or any other witness, would become empty formalities in a procedure where the most compelling possible evidence of guilt, a confession, would have already been obtained at the unsupervised pleasure of the police."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U.S. 643, 685 (1961) (HARLAN, J., dissenting).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Pointer v. Texas, 380 U.S. 400 (1965).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Today, then, there can be no doubt that the Fifth Amendment privilege is available outside of criminal court proceedings and serves to protect persons in all settings in which their freedom of action is curtailed in any significant way from being compelled to incriminate themselves.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We have concluded that without proper safeguards the process of in-custody interrogation of persons suspected or accused of crime contains inherently compelling pressures which work to undermine the individual's will to resist and to compel him to speak where he would not otherwise do so freely.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In order to combat these pressures and to permit a full opportunity to exercise the privilege against self-incrimination, the accused must be adequately and effectively apprised of his rights and the exercise of those rights must be fully honored.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is impossible for us to foresee the potential alternatives for protecting the privilege which might be devised by Congress or the States in the exercise of their creative rule-making capacities.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Therefore we cannot say that the Constitution necessarily requires adherence to any particular solution for the inherent compulsions of the interrogation process as it is presently conducted.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Our decision in no way creates a constitutional straitjacket which will handicap sound efforts at reform, nor is it intended to have this effect.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We encourage Congress and the States to continue their laudable search for increasingly effective ways of protecting the rights of the individual while promoting efficient enforcement of our criminal laws.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: However, unless we are shown other procedures which are at least as effective in apprising accused persons of their right of silence and in assuring a continuous opportunity to exercise it, the following safeguards must be observed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At the outset, if a person in custody is to be subjected to interrogation, he must first be informed in clear and *468 unequivocal terms that he has the right to remain silent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: For those unaware of the privilege, the warning is needed simply to make them aware of itthe threshold requirement for an intelligent decision as to its exercise.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: More important, such a warning is an absolute prerequisite in overcoming the inherent pressures of the interrogation atmosphere.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is not just the subnormal or woefully ignorant who succumb to an interrogator's imprecations, whether implied or expressly stated, that the interrogation will continue until a confession is obtained or that silence in the face of accusation is itself damning and will bode ill when presented to a jury.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [37] Further, the warning will show the individual that his interrogators are prepared to recognize his privilege should he choose to exercise it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The Fifth Amendment privilege is so fundamental to our system of constitutional rule and the expedient of giving an adequate warning as to the availability of the privilege so simple, we will not pause to inquire in individual cases whether the defendant was aware of his rights without a warning being given.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Assessments of the knowledge the defendant possessed, based on information *469 as to his age, education, intelligence, or prior contact with authorities, can never be more than speculation;[38] a warning is a clearcut fact.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: More important, whatever the background of the person interrogated, a warning at the time of the interrogation is indispensable to overcome its pressures and to insure that the individual knows he is free to exercise the privilege at that point in time.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The warning of the right to remain silent must be accompanied by the explanation that anything said can and will be used against the individual in court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This warning is needed in order to make him aware not only of the privilege, but also of the consequences of forgoing it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is only through an awareness of these consequences that there can be any assurance of real understanding and intelligent exercise of the privilege.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Moreover, this warning may serve to make the individual more acutely aware that he is faced with a phase of the adversary systemthat he is not in the presence of persons acting solely in his interest.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The circumstances surrounding in-custody interrogation can operate very quickly to overbear the will of one merely made aware of his privilege by his interrogators.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Therefore, the right to have counsel present at the interrogation is indispensable to the protection of the Fifth Amendment privilege under the system we delineate today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Our aim is to assure that the individual's right to choose between silence and speech remains unfettered throughout the interrogation process.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: A once-stated warning, delivered by those who will conduct the interrogation, cannot itself suffice to that end among those who most require knowledge of their rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: A mere *470 warning given by the interrogators is not alone sufficient to accomplish that end.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Prosecutors themselves claim that the admonishment of the right to remain silent without more "will benefit only the recidivist and the professional."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Brief for the National District Attorneys Association as amicus curiae, p. 14.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Even preliminary advice given to the accused by his own attorney can be swiftly overcome by the secret interrogation process.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Escobedo v. Illinois, 378 U.S. 478, 485, n. 5.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Thus, the need for counsel to protect the Fifth Amendment privilege comprehends not merely a right to consult with counsel prior to questioning, but also to have counsel present during any questioning if the defendant so desires.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The presence of counsel at the interrogation may serve several significant subsidiary functions as well.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: If the accused decides to talk to his interrogators, the assistance of counsel can mitigate the dangers of untrustworthiness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: With a lawyer present the likelihood that the police will practice coercion is reduced, and if coercion is nevertheless exercised the lawyer can testify to it in court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The presence of a lawyer can also help to guarantee that the accused gives a fully accurate statement to the police and that the statement is rightly reported by the prosecution at trial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: See Crooker v. California, 357 U.S. 433, 443-448 (1958) (DOUGLAS, J., dissenting).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: An individual need not make a pre-interrogation request for a lawyer.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: While such request affirmatively secures his right to have one, his failure to ask for a lawyer does not constitute a waiver.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: No effective waiver of the right to counsel during interrogation can be recognized unless specifically made after the warnings we here delineate have been given.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The accused who does not know his rights and therefore does not make a request *471 may be the person who most needs counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
As the California Supreme Court has aptly put it:
"Finally, we must recognize that the imposition of the requirement for the request would discriminate against the defendant who does not know his rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The defendant who does not ask for counsel is the very defendant who most needs counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We cannot penalize a defendant who, not understanding his constitutional rights, does not make the formal request and by such failure demonstrates his helplessness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: To require the request would be to favor the defendant whose sophistication or status had fortuitously prompted him to make it."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: People v. Dorado, 62 Cal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In Carnley v. Cochran, 369 U.S. 506, 513 (1962), we stated: "[I]t is settled that where the assistance of counsel is a constitutional requisite, the right to be furnished counsel does not depend on a request."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This proposition applies with equal force in the context of providing counsel to protect an accused's Fifth Amendment privilege in the face of interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [39] Although the role of counsel at trial differs from the role during interrogation, the differences are not relevant to the question whether a request is a prerequisite.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Accordingly we hold that an individual held for interrogation must be clearly informed that he has the right to consult with a lawyer and to have the lawyer with him during interrogation under the system for protecting the privilege we delineate today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: As with the warnings of the right to remain silent and that anything stated can be used in evidence against him, this warning is an absolute prerequisite to interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: No amount of *472 circumstantial evidence that the person may have been aware of this right will suffice to stand in its stead: Only through such a warning is there ascertainable assurance that the accused was aware of this right.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: If an individual indicates that he wishes the assistance of counsel before any interrogation occurs, the authorities cannot rationally ignore or deny his request on the basis that the individual does not have or cannot afford a retained attorney.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The financial ability of the individual has no relationship to the scope of the rights involved here.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The privilege against self-incrimination secured by the Constitution applies to all individuals.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The need for counsel in order to protect the privilege exists for the indigent as well as the affluent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In fact, were we to limit these constitutional rights to those who can retain an attorney, our decisions today would be of little significance.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The cases before us as well as the vast majority of confession cases with which we have dealt in the past involve those unable to retain counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [40] While authorities are not required to relieve the accused of his poverty, they have the obligation not to take advantage of indigence in the administration of justice.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [41] Denial *473 of counsel to the indigent at the time of interrogation while allowing an attorney to those who can afford one would be no more supportable by reason or logic than the similar situation at trial and on appeal struck down in Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U.S. 335 (1963), and Douglas v. California, 372 U.S. 353 (1963).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In order fully to apprise a person interrogated of the extent of his rights under this system then, it is necessary to warn him not only that he has the right to consult with an attorney, but also that if he is indigent a lawyer will be appointed to represent him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Without this additional warning, the admonition of the right to consult with counsel would often be understood as meaning only that he can consult with a lawyer if he has one or has the funds to obtain one.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The warning of a right to counsel would be hollow if not couched in terms that would convey to the indigentthe person most often subjected to interrogationthe knowledge that he too has a right to have counsel present.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [42] As with the warnings of the right to remain silent and of the general right to counsel, only by effective and express explanation to the indigent of this right can there be assurance that he was truly in a position to exercise it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[43]
Once warnings have been given, the subsequent procedure is clear.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: If the individual indicates in any manner, *474 at any time prior to or during questioning, that he wishes to remain silent, the interrogation must cease.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [44] At this point he has shown that he intends to exercise his Fifth Amendment privilege; any statement taken after the person invokes his privilege cannot be other than the product of compulsion, subtle or otherwise.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Without the right to cut off questioning, the setting of in-custody interrogation operates on the individual to overcome free choice in producing a statement after the privilege has been once invoked.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: If the individual states that he wants an attorney, the interrogation must cease until an attorney is present.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At that time, the individual must have an opportunity to confer with the attorney and to have him present during any subsequent questioning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: If the individual cannot obtain an attorney and he indicates that he wants one before speaking to police, they must respect his decision to remain silent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This does not mean, as some have suggested, that each police station must have a "station house lawyer" present at all times to advise prisoners.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It does mean, however, that if police propose to interrogate a person they must make known to him that he is entitled to a lawyer and that if he cannot afford one, a lawyer will be provided for him prior to any interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: If authorities conclude that they will not provide counsel during a reasonable period of time in which investigation in the field is carried out, they may refrain from doing so without violating the person's Fifth Amendment privilege so long as they do not question him during that time.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: *475 If the interrogation continues without the presence of an attorney and a statement is taken, a heavy burden rests on the government to demonstrate that the defendant knowingly and intelligently waived his privilege against self-incrimination and his right to retained or appointed counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Escobedo v. Illinois, 378 U.S. 478, 490, n. 14.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This Court has always set high standards of proof for the waiver of constitutional rights, Johnson v. Zerbst, 304 U.S. 458 (1938), and we re-assert these standards as applied to in-custody interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Since the State is responsible for establishing the isolated circumstances under which the interrogation takes place and has the only means of making available corroborated evidence of warnings given during incommunicado interrogation, the burden is rightly on its shoulders.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: An express statement that the individual is willing to make a statement and does not want an attorney followed closely by a statement could constitute a waiver.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: But a valid waiver will not be presumed simply from the silence of the accused after warnings are given or simply from the fact that a confession was in fact eventually obtained.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
A statement we made in Carnley v. Cochran, 369 U.S. 506, 516 (1962), is applicable here:
"Presuming waiver from a silent record is impermissible.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The record must show, or there must be an allegation and evidence which show, that an accused was offered counsel but intelligently and understandingly rejected the offer.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Anything less is not waiver."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: See also Glasser v. United States, 315 U.S. 60 (1942).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Moreover, where in-custody interrogation is involved, there is no room for the contention that the privilege is waived if the individual answers some questions or gives *476 some information on his own prior to invoking his right to remain silent when interrogated.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[45]
Whatever the testimony of the authorities as to waiver of rights by an accused, the fact of lengthy interrogation or incommunicado incarceration before a statement is made is strong evidence that the accused did not validly waive his rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In these circumstances the fact that the individual eventually made a statement is consistent with the conclusion that the compelling influence of the interrogation finally forced him to do so.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is inconsistent with any notion of a voluntary relinquishment of the privilege.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Moreover, any evidence that the accused was threatened, tricked, or cajoled into a waiver will, of course, show that the defendant did not voluntarily waive his privilege.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The requirement of warnings and waiver of rights is a fundamental with respect to the Fifth Amendment privilege and not simply a preliminary ritual to existing methods of interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The warnings required and the waiver necessary in accordance with our opinion today are, in the absence of a fully effective equivalent, prerequisites to the admissibility of any statement made by a defendant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: No distinction can be drawn between statements which are direct confessions and statements which amount to "admissions" of part or all of an offense.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The privilege against self-incrimination protects the individual from being compelled to incriminate himself in any manner; it does not distinguish degrees of incrimination.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Similarly, *477 for precisely the same reason, no distinction may be drawn between inculpatory statements and statements alleged to be merely "exculpatory."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: If a statement made were in fact truly exculpatory it would, of course, never be used by the prosecution.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In fact, statements merely intended to be exculpatory by the defendant are often used to impeach his testimony at trial or to demonstrate untruths in the statement given under interrogation and thus to prove guilt by implication.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: These statements are incriminating in any meaningful sense of the word and may not be used without the full warnings and effective waiver required for any other statement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In Escobedo itself, the defendant fully intended his accusation of another as the slayer to be exculpatory as to himself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The principles announced today deal with the protection which must be given to the privilege against self-incrimination when the individual is first subjected to police interrogation while in custody at the station or otherwise deprived of his freedom of action in any significant way.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is at this point that our adversary system of criminal proceedings commences, distinguishing itself at the outset from the inquisitorial system recognized in some countries.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Under the system of warnings we delineate today or under any other system which may be devised and found effective, the safeguards to be erected about the privilege must come into play at this point.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Our decision is not intended to hamper the traditional function of police officers in investigating crime.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: See Escobedo v. Illinois, 378 U.S. 478, 492.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: When an individual is in custody on probable cause, the police may, of course, seek out evidence in the field to be used at trial against him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Such investigation may include inquiry of persons not under restraint.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: General on-the-scene questioning as to facts surrounding a crime or other general questioning of citizens in the fact-finding process is not affected by our holding.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is an act of *478 responsible citizenship for individuals to give whatever information they may have to aid in law enforcement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In such situations the compelling atmosphere inherent in the process of in-custody interrogation is not necessarily present.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[46]
In dealing with statements obtained through interrogation, we do not purport to find all confessions inadmissible.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Confessions remain a proper element in law enforcement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Any statement given freely and voluntarily without any compelling influences is, of course, admissible in evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The fundamental import of the privilege while an individual is in custody is not whether he is allowed to talk to the police without the benefit of warnings and counsel, but whether he can be interrogated.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: There is no requirement that police stop a person who enters a police station and states that he wishes to confess to a crime,[47] or a person who calls the police to offer a confession or any other statement he desires to make.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Volunteered statements of any kind are not barred by the Fifth Amendment and their admissibility is not affected by our holding today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: To summarize, we hold that when an individual is taken into custody or otherwise deprived of his freedom by the authorities in any significant way and is subjected to questioning, the privilege against self-incrimination is jeopardized.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Procedural safeguards must be employed to *479 protect the privilege, and unless other fully effective means are adopted to notify the person of his right of silence and to assure that the exercise of the right will be scrupulously honored, the following measures are required.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He must be warned prior to any questioning that he has the right to remain silent, that anything he says can be used against him in a court of law, that he has the right to the presence of an attorney, and that if he cannot afford an attorney one will be appointed for him prior to any questioning if he so desires.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Opportunity to exercise these rights must be afforded to him throughout the interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: After such warnings have been given, and such opportunity afforded him, the individual may knowingly and intelligently waive these rights and agree to answer questions or make a statement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: But unless and until such warnings and waiver are demonstrated by the prosecution at trial, no evidence obtained as a result of interrogation can be used against him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: A recurrent argument made in these cases is that society's need for interrogation outweighs the privilege.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This argument is not unfamiliar to this Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: See, e. g., Chambers v. Florida, 309 U.S. 227, 240-241 (1940).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The whole thrust of our foregoing discussion demonstrates that the Constitution has prescribed the rights of the individual when confronted with the power of government when it provided in the Fifth Amendment that an individual cannot be compelled to be a witness against himself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: That right cannot be abridged.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
As Mr. Justice Brandeis once observed:
"Decency, security and liberty alike demand that government officials shall be subjected to the same *480 rules of conduct that are commands to the citizen.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In a government of laws, existence of the government will be imperilled if it fails to observe the law scrupulously.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Our Government is the potent, the omnipresent teacher.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: For good or for ill, it teaches the whole people by its example.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Crime is contagious.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: If the Government becomes a lawbreaker, it breeds contempt for law; it invites every man to become a law unto himself; it invites anarchy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: To declare that in the administration of the criminal law the end justifies the means .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: would bring terrible retribution.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Against that pernicious doctrine this Court should resolutely set its face."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Olmstead v. United States, 277 U.S. 438, 485 (1928) (dissenting opinion).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[49]
In this connection, one of our country's distinguished jurists has pointed out: "The quality of a nation's civilization can be largely measured by the methods it uses in the enforcement of its criminal law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[50]
If the individual desires to exercise his privilege, he has the right to do so.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This is not for the authorities to decide.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: An attorney may advise his client not to talk to police until he has had an opportunity to investigate the case, or he may wish to be present with his client during any police questioning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In doing so an attorney is merely exercising the good professional judgment he has been taught.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This is not cause for considering the attorney a menace to law enforcement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He is merely carrying out what he is sworn to do under his oath to protect to the extent of his ability the rights of his *481 client.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In fulfilling this responsibility the attorney plays a vital role in the administration of criminal justice under our Constitution.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In announcing these principles, we are not unmindful of the burdens which law enforcement officials must bear, often under trying circumstances.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We also fully recognize the obligation of all citizens to aid in enforcing the criminal laws.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This Court, while protecting individual rights, has always given ample latitude to law enforcement agencies in the legitimate exercise of their duties.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The limits we have placed on the interrogation process should not constitute an undue interference with a proper system of law enforcement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: As we have noted, our decision does not in any way preclude police from carrying out their traditional investigatory functions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Although confessions may play an important role in some convictions, the cases before us present graphic examples of the overstatement of the "need" for confessions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In each case authorities conducted interrogations ranging up to five days in duration despite the presence, through standard investigating practices, of considerable evidence against each defendant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [51] Further examples are chronicled in our prior cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: See, e. g., Haynes v. Washington, 373 U.S. 503, 518-519 (1963); Rogers v. Richmond, 365 U.S. 534, 541 (1961); Malinski v. New York, 324 U.S. 401, 402 (1945).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[52]
*482 It is also urged that an unfettered right to detention for interrogation should be allowed because it will often redound to the benefit of the person questioned.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: When police inquiry determines that there is no reason to believe that the person has committed any crime, it is said, he will be released without need for further formal procedures.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The person who has committed no offense, however, will be better able to clear himself after warnings with counsel present than without.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It can be assumed that in such circumstances a lawyer would advise his client to talk freely to police in order to clear himself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Custodial interrogation, by contrast, does not necessarily afford the innocent an opportunity to clear themselves.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: A serious consequence of the present practice of the interrogation alleged to be beneficial for the innocent is that many arrests "for investigation" subject large numbers of innocent persons to detention and interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In one of the cases before us, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 584, California v. Stewart, police held four persons, who were in the defendant's house at the time of the arrest, in jail for five days until defendant confessed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At that time they were finally released.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Police stated that there was "no evidence to connect them with any crime."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Available statistics on the extent of this practice where it is condoned indicate that these four are far from alone in being subjected to arrest, prolonged detention, and interrogation without the requisite probable cause.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[53]
*483 Over the years the Federal Bureau of Investigation has compiled an exemplary record of effective law enforcement while advising any suspect or arrested person, at the outset of an interview, that he is not required to make a statement, that any statement may be used against him in court, that the individual may obtain the services of an attorney of his own choice and, more recently, that he has a right to free counsel if he is unable to pay.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [54] A letter received from the Solicitor General in response to a question from the Bench makes it clear that the present pattern of warnings and respect for the *484 rights of the individual followed as a practice by the FBI is consistent with the procedure which we delineate today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
It states:
"At the oral argument of the above cause, Mr. Justice Fortas asked whether I could provide certain information as to the practices followed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
I have directed these questions to the attention of the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and am submitting herewith a statement of the questions and of the answers which we have received.
"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
`(1) When an individual is interviewed by agents of the Bureau, what warning is given to him?
"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: `The standard warning long given by Special Agents of the FBI to both suspects and persons under arrest is that the person has a right to say nothing and a right to counsel, and that any statement he does make may be used against him in court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Examples of this warning are to be found in the Westover case at 342 F.2d 684 (1965), and Jackson v. U. S., 337 F.2d 136 (1964), cert.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: `After passage of the Criminal Justice Act of 1964, which provides free counsel for Federal defendants unable to pay, we added to our instructions to Special Agents the requirement that any person who is under arrest for an offense under FBI jurisdiction, or whose arrest is contemplated following the interview, must also be advised of his right to free counsel if he is unable to pay, and the fact that such counsel will be assigned by the Judge.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
At the same time, we broadened the right to counsel warning *485 to read counsel of his own choice, or anyone else with whom he might wish to speak.
"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
`(2) When is the warning given?
"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: `The FBI warning is given to a suspect at the very outset of the interview, as shown in the Westover case, cited above.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The warning may be given to a person arrested as soon as practicable after the arrest, as shown in the Jackson case, also cited above, and in U. S. v. Konigsberg, 336 F.2d 844 (1964), cert.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
379 U.S. 933, but in any event it must precede the interview with the person for a confession or admission of his own guilt.
"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
`(3) What is the Bureau's practice in the event that (a) the individual requests counsel and (b) counsel appears?
"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: `When the person who has been warned of his right to counsel decides that he wishes to consult with counsel before making a statement, the interview is terminated at that point, Shultz v. U. S., 351 F.2d 287 (1965).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It may be continued, however, as to all matters other than the person's own guilt or innocence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: If he is indecisive in his request for counsel, there may be some question on whether he did or did not waive counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Situations of this kind must necessarily be left to the judgment of the interviewing Agent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
For example, in Hiram v. U. S., 354 F.2d 4 (1965), the Agent's conclusion that the person arrested had waived his right to counsel was upheld by the courts.
"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: `A person being interviewed and desiring to consult counsel by telephone must be permitted to do so, as shown in Caldwell v. U. S., 351 F.2d 459 (1965).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: When counsel appears in person, he is permitted to confer with his client in private.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
*486 " `(4) What is the Bureau's practice if the individual requests counsel, but cannot afford to retain an attorney?
"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: `If any person being interviewed after warning of counsel decides that he wishes to consult with counsel before proceeding further the interview is terminated, as shown above.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: FBI Agents do not pass judgment on the ability of the person to pay for counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: They do, however, advise those who have been arrested for an offense under FBI jurisdiction, or whose arrest is contemplated following the interview, of a right to free counsel if they are unable to pay, and the availability of such counsel from the Judge.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[55]
The practice of the FBI can readily be emulated by state and local enforcement agencies.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The argument that the FBI deals with different crimes than are dealt with by state authorities does not mitigate the significance of the FBI experience.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[56]
The experience in some other countries also suggests that the danger to law enforcement in curbs on interrogation is overplayed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The English procedure since 1912 under the Judges' Rules is significant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: As recently *487 strengthened, the Rules require that a cautionary warning be given an accused by a police officer as soon as he has evidence that affords reasonable grounds for suspicion; they also require that any statement made be given by the accused without questioning by police.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [57]*488 The right of the individual to consult with an attorney during this period is expressly recognized.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[58]
The safeguards present under Scottish law may be even greater than in England.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Scottish judicial decisions bar use in evidence of most confessions obtained through police interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [59] In India, confessions made to police not in the presence of a magistrate have been excluded *489 by rule of evidence since 1872, at a time when it operated under British law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [60] Identical provisions appear in the Evidence Ordinance of Ceylon, enacted in 1895.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [61] Similarly, in our country the Uniform Code of Military Justice has long provided that no suspect may be interrogated without first being warned of his right not to make a statement and that any statement he makes may be used against him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [62] Denial of the right to consult counsel during interrogation has also been proscribed by military tribunals.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [63] There appears to have been no marked detrimental effect on criminal law enforcement in these jurisdictions as a result of these rules.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Conditions of law enforcement in our country are sufficiently similar to permit reference to this experience as assurance that lawlessness will not result from warning an individual of his rights or allowing him to exercise them.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Moreover, it is consistent with our legal system that we give at least as much protection to these rights as is given in the jurisdictions described.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We deal in our country with rights grounded in a specific requirement of the Fifth Amendment of the Constitution, *490 whereas other jurisdictions arrived at their conclusions on the basis of principles of justice not so specifically defined.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[64]
It is also urged upon us that we withhold decision on this issue until state legislative bodies and advisory groups have had an opportunity to deal with these problems by rule making.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [65] We have already pointed out that the Constitution does not require any specific code of procedures for protecting the privilege against self-incrimination during custodial interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Congress and the States are free to develop their own safeguards for the privilege, so long as they are fully as effective as those described above in informing accused persons of their right of silence and in affording a continuous opportunity to exercise it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In any event, however, the issues presented are of constitutional dimensions and must be determined by the courts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The admissibility of a statement in the face of a claim that it was obtained in violation of the defendant's constitutional rights is an issue the resolution of which has long since been undertaken by this Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: See Hopt v. Utah, 110 U.S. 574 (1884).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Judicial solutions to problems of constitutional dimension have evolved decade by decade.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: As courts have been presented with the need to enforce constitutional rights, they have found means of doing so.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: That was our responsibility when Escobedo was before us and it is our *491 responsibility today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Where rights secured by the Constitution are involved, there can be no rule making or legislation which would abrogate them.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
V.
Because of the nature of the problem and because of its recurrent significance in numerous cases, we have to this point discussed the relationship of the Fifth Amendment privilege to police interrogation without specific concentration on the facts of the cases before us.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We turn now to these facts to consider the application to these cases of the constitutional principles discussed above.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In each instance, we have concluded that statements were obtained from the defendant under circumstances that did not meet constitutional standards for protection of the privilege.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Miranda v. Arizona.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: On March 13, 1963, petitioner, Ernesto Miranda, was arrested at his home and taken in custody to a Phoenix police station.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He was there identified by the complaining witness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The police then took him to "Interrogation Room No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 2" of the detective bureau.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: There he was questioned by two police officers.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The officers admitted at trial that Miranda was not advised that he had a right to have an attorney present.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [66] Two hours later, the *492 officers emerged from the interrogation room with a written confession signed by Miranda.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At the top of the statement was a typed paragraph stating that the confession was made voluntarily, without threats or promises of immunity and "with full knowledge of my legal rights, understanding any statement I make may be used against me.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
"[67]
At his trial before a jury, the written confession was admitted into evidence over the objection of defense counsel, and the officers testified to the prior oral confession made by Miranda during the interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Miranda was found guilty of kidnapping and rape.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He was sentenced to 20 to 30 years' imprisonment on each count, the sentences to run concurrently.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: On appeal, the Supreme Court of Arizona held that Miranda's constitutional rights were not violated in obtaining the confession and affirmed the conviction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In reaching its decision, the court emphasized heavily the fact that Miranda did not specifically request counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We reverse.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: From the testimony of the officers and by the admission of respondent, it is clear that Miranda was not in any way apprised of his right to consult with an attorney and to have one present during the interrogation, nor was his right not to be compelled to incriminate himself effectively protected in any other manner.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Without these warnings the statements were inadmissible.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The mere fact that he signed a statement which contained a typed-in clause stating that he had "full knowledge" of his "legal rights" does not approach the knowing and intelligent waiver required to relinquish constitutional rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Haynes v. Washington, 373 U. S. *493 503, 512-513 (1963); Haley v. Ohio, 332 U.S. 596, 601 (1948) (opinion of MR. JUSTICE DOUGLAS).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Vignera v. New York.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Petitioner, Michael Vignera, was picked up by New York police on October 14, 1960, in connection with the robbery three days earlier of a Brooklyn dress shop.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: They took him to the 17th Detective Squad headquarters in Manhattan.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Sometime thereafter he was taken to the 66th Detective Squad.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: There a detective questioned Vignera with respect to the robbery.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Vignera orally admitted the robbery to the detective.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The detective was asked on cross-examination at trial by defense counsel whether Vignera was warned of his right to counsel before being interrogated.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The prosecution objected to the question and the trial judge sustained the objection.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Thus, the defense was precluded from making any showing that warnings had not been given.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: While at the 66th Detective Squad, Vignera was identified by the store owner and a saleslady as the man who robbed the dress shop.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At about 3 p. m. he was formally arrested.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The police then transported him to still another station, the 70th Precinct in Brooklyn, "for detention."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At 11 p. m. Vignera was questioned by an assistant district attorney in the presence of a hearing reporter who transcribed the questions and Vignera's answers.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: This verbatim account of these proceedings contains no statement of any warnings given by the assistant district attorney.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At Vignera's trial on a charge of first degree robbery, the detective testified as to the oral confession.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The transcription of the statement taken was also introduced in evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
At the conclusion of the testimony, the trial judge charged the jury in part as follows:
"The law doesn't say that the confession is void or invalidated because the police officer didn't advise the defendant as to his rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Did you hear what *494 I said?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: I am telling you what the law of the State of New York is."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Vignera was found guilty of first degree robbery.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He was subsequently adjudged a third-felony offender and sentenced to 30 to 60 years' imprisonment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [68] The conviction was affirmed without opinion by the Appellate Division, Second Department, 21 A.D. 2d 752, 252 N. Y. S. 2d 19, and by the Court of Appeals, also without opinion, 15 N.Y. 2d 970, 207 N.E.2d 527, 259 N. Y. S. 2d 857, remittitur amended, 16 N.Y. 2d 614, 209 N.E.2d 110, 261 N. Y. S. 2d 65.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In argument to the Court of Appeals, the State contended that Vignera had no constitutional right to be advised of his right to counsel or his privilege against self-incrimination.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The foregoing indicates that Vignera was not warned of any of his rights before the questioning by the detective and by the assistant district attorney.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: No other steps were taken to protect these rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Thus he was not effectively apprised of his Fifth Amendment privilege or of his right to have counsel present and his statements are inadmissible.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Westover v. United States.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At approximately 9:45 p. m. on March 20, 1963, petitioner, Carl Calvin Westover, was arrested by local police in Kansas City as a suspect in two Kansas City robberies.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: A report was also received from the FBI that he was wanted on a felony charge in California.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The local authorities took him to a police station and placed him in a line-up on the local charges, and at about 11:45 p. m. he was booked.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Kansas City police interrogated Westover *495 on the night of his arrest.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He denied any knowledge of criminal activities.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The next day local officers interrogated him again throughout the morning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Shortly before noon they informed the FBI that they were through interrogating Westover and that the FBI could proceed to interrogate him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: There is nothing in the record to indicate that Westover was ever given any warning as to his rights by local police.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At noon, three special agents of the FBI continued the interrogation in a private interview room of the Kansas City Police Department, this time with respect to the robbery of a savings and loan association and a bank in Sacramento, California.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: After two or two and one-half hours, Westover signed separate confessions to each of these two robberies which had been prepared by one of the agents during the interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At trial one of the agents testified, and a paragraph on each of the statements states, that the agents advised Westover that he did not have to make a statement, that any statement he made could be used against him, and that he had the right to see an attorney.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Westover was tried by a jury in federal court and convicted of the California robberies.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: His statements were introduced at trial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: He was sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment on each count, the sentences to run consecutively.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: On appeal, the conviction was affirmed by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: On the facts of this case we cannot find that Westover knowingly and intelligently waived his right to remain silent and his right to consult with counsel prior to the time he made the statement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [69] At the *496 time the FBI agents began questioning Westover, he had been in custody for over 14 hours and had been interrogated at length during that period.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The FBI interrogation began immediately upon the conclusion of the interrogation by Kansas City police and was conducted in local police headquarters.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Although the two law enforcement authorities are legally distinct and the crimes for which they interrogated Westover were different, the impact on him was that of a continuous period of questioning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: There is no evidence of any warning given prior to the FBI interrogation nor is there any evidence of an articulated waiver of rights after the FBI commenced its interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The record simply shows that the defendant did in fact confess a short time after being turned over to the FBI following interrogation by local police.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Despite the fact that the FBI agents gave warnings at the outset of their interview, from Westover's point of view the warnings came at the end of the interrogation process.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In these circumstances an intelligent waiver of constitutional rights cannot be assumed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We do not suggest that law enforcement authorities are precluded from questioning any individual who has been held for a period of time by other authorities and interrogated by them without appropriate warnings.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: A different case would be presented if an accused were taken into custody by the second authority, removed both in time and place from his original surroundings, and then adequately advised of his rights and given an opportunity to exercise them.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: But here the FBI interrogation was conducted immediately following the state interrogation in the same police stationin the same compelling surroundings.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Thus, in obtaining a confession from Westover *497 the federal authorities were the beneficiaries of the pressure applied by the local in-custody interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In these circumstances the giving of warnings alone was not sufficient to protect the privilege.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: California v. Stewart.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In the course of investigating a series of purse-snatch robberies in which one of the victims had died of injuries inflicted by her assailant, respondent, Roy Allen Stewart, was pointed out to Los Angeles police as the endorser of dividend checks taken in one of the robberies.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At about 7:15 p. m., January 31, 1963, police officers went to Stewart's house and arrested him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: One of the officers asked Stewart if they could search the house, to which he replied, "Go ahead."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The search turned up various items taken from the five robbery victims.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At the time of Stewart's arrest, police also arrested Stewart's wife and three other persons who were visiting him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: These four were jailed along with Stewart and were interrogated.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Stewart was taken to the University Station of the Los Angeles Police Department where he was placed in a cell.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: During the next five days, police interrogated Stewart on nine different occasions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Except during the first interrogation session, when he was confronted with an accusing witness, Stewart was isolated with his interrogators.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: During the ninth interrogation session, Stewart admitted that he had robbed the deceased and stated that he had not meant to hurt her.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Police then brought Stewart before a magistrate for the first time.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Since there was no evidence to connect them with any crime, the police then released the other four persons arrested with him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Nothing in the record specifically indicates whether Stewart was or was not advised of his right to remain silent or his right to counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In a number of instances, *498 however, the interrogating officers were asked to recount everything that was said during the interrogations.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: None indicated that Stewart was ever advised of his rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Stewart was charged with kidnapping to commit robbery, rape, and murder.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: At his trial, transcripts of the first interrogation and the confession at the last interrogation were introduced in evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The jury found Stewart guilty of robbery and first degree murder and fixed the penalty as death.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: On appeal, the Supreme Court of California reversed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It held that under this Court's decision in Escobedo, Stewart should have been advised of his right to remain silent and of his right to counsel and that it would not presume in the face of a silent record that the police advised Stewart of his rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
[70]
We affirm.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [71] In dealing with custodial interrogation, we will not presume that a defendant has been effectively apprised of his rights and that his privilege against self-incrimination has been adequately safeguarded on a record that does not show that any warnings have been given or that any effective alternative has been employed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Nor can a knowing and intelligent waiver of *499 these rights be assumed on a silent record.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Furthermore, Stewart's steadfast denial of the alleged offenses through eight of the nine interrogations over a period of five days is subject to no other construction than that he was compelled by persistent interrogation to forgo his Fifth Amendment privilege.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Therefore, in accordance with the foregoing, the judgments of the Supreme Court of Arizona in No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 759, of the New York Court of Appeals in No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 760, and of the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 761 are reversed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The judgment of the Supreme Court of California in No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 584 is affirmed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: MR. JUSTICE CLARK, dissenting in Nos.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 759, 760, and 761, and concurring in the result in No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It is with regret that I find it necessary to write in these cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: However, I am unable to join the majority because its opinion goes too far on too little, while my dissenting brethren do not go quite far enough.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Nor can I join in the Court's criticism of the present practices of police and investigatory agencies as to custodial interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The materials it refers to as "police manuals"[1] are, as I read them, merely writings in this field by professors and some police officers.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Not one is shown by the record here to be the official manual of any police department, much less in universal use in crime detection.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Moreover, the examples of police brutality mentioned by the Court[2] are rare exceptions to the thousands of cases *500 that appear every year in the law reports.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The police agenciesall the way from municipal and state forces to the federal bureausare responsible for law enforcement and public safety in this country.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: I am proud of their efforts, which in my view are not fairly characterized by the Court's opinion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The ipse dixit of the majority has no support in our cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Indeed, the Court admits that "we might not find the defendants' statements [here] to have been involuntary in traditional terms."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Ante, p. 457.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In short, the Court has added more to the requirements that the accused is entitled to consult with his lawyer and that he must be given the traditional warning that he may remain silent and that anything that he says may be used against him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Escobedo v. Illinois, 378 U.S. 478, 490-491 (1964).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Now, the Court fashions a constitutional rule that the police may engage in no custodial interrogation without additionally advising the accused that he has a right under the Fifth Amendment to the presence of counsel during interrogation and that, if he is without funds, counsel will be furnished him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: When at any point during an interrogation the accused seeks affirmatively or impliedly to invoke his rights to silence or counsel, interrogation must be forgone or postponed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The Court further holds that failure to follow the new procedures requires inexorably the exclusion of any statement by the accused, as well as the fruits thereof.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Such a strict constitutional specific inserted at the nerve center of crime detection may well kill the patient.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: [3]*501 Since there is at this time a paucity of information and an almost total lack of empirical knowledge on the practical operation of requirements truly comparable to those announced by the majority, I would be more restrained lest we go too far too fast.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
