text: Custodial interrogation has long been recognized as "undoubtedly an essential tool in effective law enforcement."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Haynes v. Washington, 373 U.S. 503, 515 (1963).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Recognition of this fact should put us on guard against the promulgation of doctrinaire rules.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Especially is this true where the Court finds that "the Constitution has prescribed" its holding and where the light of our past cases, from Hopt v. Utah, 110 U.S. 574, (1884), down to Haynes v. Washington, supra, is to *502 the contrary.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Indeed, even in Escobedo the Court never hinted that an affirmative "waiver" was a prerequisite to questioning; that the burden of proof as to waiver was on the prosecution; that the presence of counsel absent a waiverduring interrogation was required; that a waiver can be withdrawn at the will of the accused; that counsel must be furnished during an accusatory stage to those unable to pay; nor that admissions and exculpatory statements are "confessions."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: To require all those things at one gulp should cause the Court to choke over more cases than Crooker v. California, 357 U.S. 433 (1958), and Cicenia v. Lagay, 357 U.S. 504 (1958), which it expressly overrules today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The rule prior to todayas Mr. Justice Goldberg, the author of the Court's opinion in Escobedo, stated it in Haynes v. Washingtondepended upon "a totality of circumstances evidencing an involuntary .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: admission of guilt."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text:
And he concluded:
"Of course, detection and solution of crime is, at best, a difficult and arduous task requiring determination and persistence on the part of all responsible officers charged with the duty of law enforcement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: And, certainly, we do not mean to suggest that all interrogation of witnesses and suspects is impermissible.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Such questioning is undoubtedly an essential tool in effective law enforcement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: The line between proper and permissible police conduct and techniques and methods offensive to due process is, at best, a difficult one to draw, particularly in cases such as this where it is necessary to make fine judgments as to the effect of psychologically coercive pressures and inducements on the mind and will of an accused.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: We are here impelled to the conclusion, from all of the facts presented, that the bounds of due process have been exceeded."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: I would continue to follow that rule.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Under the "totality of circumstances" rule of which my Brother Goldberg spoke in Haynes, I would consider in each case whether the police officer prior to custodial interrogation added the warning that the suspect might have counsel present at the interrogation and, further, that a court would appoint one at his request if he was too poor to employ counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In the absence of warnings, the burden would be on the State to prove that counsel was knowingly and intelligently waived or that in the totality of the circumstances, including the failure to give the necessary warnings, the confession was clearly voluntary.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Rather than employing the arbitrary Fifth Amendment rule[4] which the Court lays down I would follow the more pliable dictates of the Due Process Clauses of the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments which we are accustomed to administering and which we know from our cases are effective instruments in protecting persons in police custody.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In this way we would not be acting in the dark nor in one full sweep changing the traditional rules of custodial interrogation which this Court has for so long recognized as a justifiable and proper tool in balancing individual rights against the rights of society.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: It will be soon enough to go further when we are able to appraise with somewhat better accuracy the effect of such a holding.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: I would affirm the convictions in Miranda v. Arizona, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 759; Vignera v. New York, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 760; and Westover v. United States, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In each of those cases I find from the circumstances no warrant for reversal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: In *504 California v. Stewart, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: 584, I would dismiss the writ of certiorari for want of a final judgment, 28 U.S. C. § 1257 (3) (1964 ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: ); but if the merits are to be reached I would affirm on the ground that the State failed to fulfill its burden, in the absence of a showing that appropriate warnings were given, of proving a waiver or a totality of circumstances showing voluntariness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: Should there be a retrial, I would leave the State free to attempt to prove these elements.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Warren
text: MR. JUSTICE HARLAN, whom MR. JUSTICE STEWART and MR.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: I believe the decision of the Court represents poor constitutional law and entails harmful consequences for the country at large.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: How serious these consequences may prove to be only time can tell.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: But the basic flaws in the Court's justification seem to me readily apparent now once all sides of the problem are considered.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: INTRODUCTION.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: At the outset, it is well to note exactly what is required by the Court's new constitutional code of rules for confessions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The foremost requirement, upon which later admissibility of a confession depends, is that a fourfold warning be given to a person in custody before he is questioned, namely, that he has a right to remain silent, that anything he says may be used against him, that he has a right to have present an attorney during the questioning, and that if indigent he has a right to a lawyer without charge.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: To forgo these rights, some affirmative statement of rejection is seemingly required, and threats, tricks, or cajolings to obtain this waiver are forbidden.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: If before or during questioning the suspect seeks to invoke his right to remain silent, interrogation must be forgone or cease; a request for counsel *505 brings about the same result until a lawyer is procured.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Finally, there are a miscellany of minor directives, for example, the burden of proof of waiver is on the State, admissions and exculpatory statements are treated just like confessions, withdrawal of a waiver is always permitted, and so forth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text:
[1]
While the fine points of this scheme are far less clear than the Court admits, the tenor is quite apparent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The new rules are not designed to guard against police brutality or other unmistakably banned forms of coercion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Those who use third-degree tactics and deny them in court are equally able and destined to lie as skillfully about warnings and waivers.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Rather, the thrust of the new rules is to negate all pressures, to reinforce the nervous or ignorant suspect, and ultimately to discourage any confession at all.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The aim in short is toward "voluntariness" in a utopian sense, or to view it from a different angle, voluntariness with a vengeance.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: To incorporate this notion into the Constitution requires a strained reading of history and precedent and a disregard of the very pragmatic concerns that alone may on occasion justify such strains.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: I believe that reasoned examination will show that the Due Process Clauses provide an adequate tool for coping with confessions and that, even if the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination be invoked, its precedents taken as a whole do not sustain the present rules.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Viewed as a choice based on pure policy, these new rules prove to be a highly debatable, if not one-sided, appraisal of the competing interests, imposed over widespread objection, at the very time when judicial restraint is most called for by the circumstances.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: CONSTITUTIONAL PREMISES.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: It is most fitting to begin an inquiry into the constitutional precedents by surveying the limits on confessions the Court has evolved under the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: This is so because these cases show that there exists a workable and effective means of dealing with confessions in a judicial manner; because the cases are the baseline from which the Court now departs and so serve to measure the actual as opposed to the professed distance it travels; and because examination of them helps reveal how the Court has coasted into its present position.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The earliest confession cases in this Court emerged from federal prosecutions and were settled on a nonconstitutional basis, the Court adopting the common-law rule that the absence of inducements, promises, and threats made a confession voluntary and admissible.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Hopt v. Utah, 110 U.S. 574; Pierce v. United States, 160 U.S. 355.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: While a later case said the Fifth Amendment privilege controlled admissibility, this proposition was not itself developed in subsequent decisions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: [2] The Court did, however, heighten the test of admissibility in federal trials to one of voluntariness "in fact," Wan v. *507 United States, 266 U.S. 1, 14 (quoted, ante, p. 462), and then by and large left federal judges to apply the same standards the Court began to derive in a string of state court cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: This new line of decisions, testing admissibility by the Due Process Clause, began in 1936 with Brown v. Mississippi, 297 U.S. 278, and must now embrace somewhat more than 30 full opinions of the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: [3] While the voluntariness rubric was repeated in many instances, e. g., Lyons v. Oklahoma, 322 U.S. 596, the Court never pinned it down to a single meaning but on the contrary infused it with a number of different values.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: To travel quickly over the main themes, there was an initial emphasis on reliability, e. g., Ward v. Texas, 316 U.S. 547, supplemented by concern over the legality and fairness of the police practices, e. g., Ashcraft v. Tennessee, 322 U.S. 143, in an "accusatorial" system of law enforcement, Watts v. Indiana, 338 U.S. 49, 54, and eventually by close attention to the individual's state of mind and capacity for effective choice, e. g., Gallegos v. Colorado, 370 U.S. 49.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The outcome was a continuing re-evaluation on the facts of each case of how much pressure on the suspect was permissible.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text:
[4]
*508 Among the criteria often taken into account were threats or imminent danger, e. g., Payne v. Arkansas, 356 U.S. 560, physical deprivations such as lack of sleep or food, e. g., Reck v. Pate, 367 U.S. 433, repeated or extended interrogation, e. g., Chambers v. Florida, 309 U.S. 227, limits on access to counsel or friends, Crooker v. California, 357 U.S. 433; Cicenia v. Lagay, 357 U.S. 504, length and illegality of detention under state law, e. g., Haynes v. Washington, 373 U.S. 503, and individual weakness or incapacities, Lynumn v. Illinois, 372 U.S. 528.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Apart from direct physical coercion, however, no single default or fixed combination of defaults guaranteed exclusion, and synopses of the cases would serve little use because the overall gauge has been steadily changing, usually in the direction of restricting admissibility.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: But to mark just what point had been reached before the Court jumped the rails in Escobedo v. Illinois, 378 U.S. 478, it is worth capsulizing the then-recent case of Haynes v. Washington, 373 U.S. 503.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: There, Haynes had been held some 16 or more hours in violation of state law before signing the disputed confession, had received no warnings of any kind, and despite requests had been refused access to his wife or to counsel, the police indicating that access would be allowed after a confession.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Emphasizing especially this last inducement and rejecting some contrary indicia of voluntariness, the Court in a 5-to-4 decision held the confession inadmissible.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: There are several relevant lessons to be drawn from this constitutional history.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The first is that with over 25 years of precedent the Court has developed an elaborate, sophisticated, and sensitive approach to admissibility of confessions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: It is "judicial" in its treatment of one case at a time, see Culombe v. Connecticut, 367 U.S. 568, 635 (concurring opinion of THE CHIEF JUSTICE), flexible in its ability to respond to the endless mutations of fact presented, and ever more familiar to the lower courts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: *509 Of course, strict certainty is not obtained in this developing process, but this is often so with constitutional principles, and disagreement is usually confined to that borderland of close cases where it matters least.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The second point is that in practice and from time to time in principle, the Court has given ample recognition to society's interest in suspect questioning as an instrument of law enforcement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Cases countenancing quite significant pressures can be cited without difficulty,[5] and the lower courts may often have been yet more tolerant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Of course the limitations imposed today were rejected by necessary implication in case after case, the right to warnings having been explicitly rebuffed in this Court many years ago.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Powers v. United States, 223 U.S. 303; Wilson v. United States, 162 U.S. 613.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: As recently as Haynes v. Washington, 373 U.S. 503, 515, the Court openly acknowledged that questioning of witnesses and suspects "is undoubtedly an essential tool in effective law enforcement."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Accord, Crooker v. California, 357 U.S. 433, 441.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Finally, the cases disclose that the language in many of the opinions overstates the actual course of decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: It has been said, for example, that an admissible confession must be made by the suspect "in the unfettered exercise of his own will," Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U.S. 1, 8, and that "a prisoner is not `to be made the deluded instrument of his own conviction,' " Culombe v. Connecticut, 367 U.S. 568, 581 (Frankfurter, J., announcing the Court's judgment and an opinion).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Though often repeated, such principles are rarely observed in full measure.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Even the word "voluntary" may be deemed somewhat *510 misleading, especially when one considers many of the confessions that have been brought under its umbrella.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: See, e. g., supra, n. 5.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The tendency to overstate may be laid in part to the flagrant facts often before the Court; but in any event one must recognize how it has tempered attitudes and lent some color of authority to the approach now taken by the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: I turn now to the Court's asserted reliance on the Fifth Amendment, an approach which I frankly regard as a trompe l'oeil.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The Court's opinion in my view reveals no adequate basis for extending the Fifth Amendment's privilege against self-incrimination to the police station.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Far more important, it fails to show that the Court's new rules are well supported, let alone compelled, by Fifth Amendment precedents.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Instead, the new rules actually derive from quotation and analogy drawn from precedents under the Sixth Amendment, which should properly have no bearing on police interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The Court's opening contention, that the Fifth Amendment governs police station confessions, is perhaps not an impermissible extension of the law but it has little to commend itself in the present circumstances.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Historically, the privilege against self-incrimination did not bear at all on the use of extra-legal confessions, for which distinct standards evolved; indeed, "the history of the two principles is wide apart, differing by one hundred years in origin, and derived through separate lines of precedents .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: 8 Wigmore, Evidence § 2266, at 401 (McNaughton rev.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Practice under the two doctrines has also differed in a number of important respects.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: [6]*511 Even those who would readily enlarge the privilege must concede some linguistic difficulties since the Fifth Amendment in terms proscribes only compelling any person "in any criminal case to be a witness against himself."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Kamisar, Equal Justice in the Gatehouses and Mansions of American Criminal Procedure, in Criminal Justice in Our Time 1, 25-26 (1965).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Though weighty, I do not say these points and similar ones are conclusive, for, as the Court reiterates, the privilege embodies basic principles always capable of expansion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: [7] Certainly the privilege does represent a protective concern for the accused and an emphasis upon accusatorial rather than inquisitorial values in law enforcement, although this is similarly true of other limitations such as the grand jury requirement and the reasonable doubt standard.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Accusatorial values, however, have openly been absorbed into the due process standard governing confessions; this indeed is why at present "the kinship of the two rules [governing confessions and self-incrimination] is too apparent for denial."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: McCormick, Evidence 155 (1954).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Since extension of the general principle has already occurred, to insist that the privilege applies as such serves only to carry over inapposite historical details and engaging rhetoric and to obscure the policy choices to be made in regulating confessions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Having decided that the Fifth Amendment privilege does apply in the police station, the Court reveals that the privilege imposes more exacting restrictions than does the Fourteenth Amendment's voluntariness test.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: [8]*512 It then emerges from a discussion of Escobedo that the Fifth Amendment requires for an admissible confession that it be given by one distinctly aware of his right not to speak and shielded from "the compelling atmosphere" of interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: See ante, pp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: From these key premises, the Court finally develops the safeguards of warning, counsel, and so forth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: I do not believe these premises are sustained by precedents under the Fifth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text:
[9]
The more important premise is that pressure on the suspect must be eliminated though it be only the subtle influence of the atmosphere and surroundings.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The Fifth Amendment, however, has never been thought to forbid all pressure to incriminate one's self in the situations covered by it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: On the contrary, it has been held that failure to incriminate one's self can result in denial of removal of one's case from state to federal court, Maryland v. Soper, 270 U.S. 9; in refusal of a military commission, Orloff v. Willoughby, 345 U.S. 83; in denial of a discharge in bankruptcy, Kaufman v. Hurwitz, 176 F.2d 210; and in numerous other adverse consequences.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: See 8 Wigmore, Evidence § 2272, at 441-444, n. 18 (McNaughton rev.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: 1961); Maguire, Evidence of Guilt § 2.062 (1959).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: This is not to say that short of jail or torture any sanction is permissible in any case; policy and history alike may impose sharp limits.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: See, e. g., *513 Griffin v. California, 380 U.S. 609.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: However, the Court's unspoken assumption that any pressure violates the privilege is not supported by the precedents and it has failed to show why the Fifth Amendment prohibits that relatively mild pressure the Due Process Clause permits.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The Court appears similarly wrong in thinking that precise knowledge of one's rights is a settled prerequisite under the Fifth Amendment to the loss of its protections.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: A number of lower federal court cases have held that grand jury witnesses need not always be warned of their privilege, e. g., United States v. Scully, 225 F.2d 113, 116, and Wigmore states this to be the better rule for trial witnesses.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: See 8 Wigmore, Evidence § 2269 (McNaughton rev.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Henry v. Mississippi, 379 U.S. 443, 451-452 (waiver of constitutional rights by counsel despite defendant's ignorance held allowable).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: No Fifth Amendment precedent is cited for the Court's contrary view.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: There might of course be reasons apart from Fifth Amendment precedent for requiring warning or any other safeguard on questioning but that is a different matter entirely.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: See infra, pp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: A closing word must be said about the Assistance of Counsel Clause of the Sixth Amendment, which is never expressly relied on by the Court but whose judicial precedents turn out to be linchpins of the confession rules announced today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: To support its requirement of a knowing and intelligent waiver, the Court cites Johnson v. Zerbst, 304 U.S. 458, ante, p. 475; appointment of counsel for the indigent suspect is tied to Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U.S. 335, and Douglas v. California, 372 U.S. 353, ante, p. 473; the silent-record doctrine is borrowed from Carnley v. Cochran, 369 U.S. 506, ante, p. 475, as is the right to an express offer of counsel, ante, p. 471.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: All these cases imparting glosses to the Sixth Amendment concerned counsel at trial or on appeal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: While the Court finds no pertinent difference between judicial proceedings and police interrogation, I believe *514 the differences are so vast as to disqualify wholly the Sixth Amendment precedents as suitable analogies in the present cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text:
[10]
The only attempt in this Court to carry the right to counsel into the station house occurred in Escobedo, the Court repeating several times that that stage was no less "critical" than trial itself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: This is hardly persuasive when we consider that a grand jury inquiry, the filing of a certiorari petition, and certainly the purchase of narcotics by an undercover agent from a prospective defendant may all be equally "critical" yet provision of counsel and advice on that score have never been thought compelled by the Constitution in such cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The sound reason why this right is so freely extended for a criminal trial is the severe injustice risked by confronting an untrained defendant with a range of technical points of law, evidence, and tactics familiar to the prosecutor but not to himself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: This danger shrinks markedly in the police station where indeed the lawyer in fulfilling his professional responsibilities of necessity may become an obstacle to truthfinding.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: See infra, n. 12.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The Court's summary citation of the Sixth Amendment cases here seems to me best described as "the domino method of constitutional adjudication .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: wherein every explanatory statement in a previous opinion is made the basis for extension to a wholly different situation."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Friendly, supra, n. 10, at 950.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: POLICY CONSIDERATIONS.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Examined as an expression of public policy, the Court's new regime proves so dubious that there can be no due *515 compensation for its weakness in constitutional law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The foregoing discussion has shown, I think, how mistaken is the Court in implying that the Constitution has struck the balance in favor of the approach the Court takes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Ante, p. 479.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Rather, precedent reveals that the Fourteenth Amendment in practice has been construed to strike a different balance, that the Fifth Amendment gives the Court little solid support in this context, and that the Sixth Amendment should have no bearing at all.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Legal history has been stretched before to satisfy deep needs of society.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: In this instance, however, the Court has not and cannot make the powerful showing that its new rules are plainly desirable in the context of our society, something which is surely demanded before those rules are engrafted onto the Constitution and imposed on every State and county in the land.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Without at all subscribing to the generally black picture of police conduct painted by the Court, I think it must be frankly recognized at the outset that police questioning allowable under due process precedents may inherently entail some pressure on the suspect and may seek advantage in his ignorance or weaknesses.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The atmosphere and questioning techniques, proper and fair though they be, can in themselves exert a tug on the suspect to confess, and in this light "[t]o speak of any confessions of crime made after arrest as being `voluntary' or `uncoerced' is somewhat inaccurate, although traditional.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: A confession is wholly and incontestably voluntary only if a guilty person gives himself up to the law and becomes his own accuser."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Ashcraft v. Tennessee, 322 U.S. 143, 161 (Jackson, J., dissenting).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Until today, the role of the Constitution has been only to sift out undue pressure, not to assure spontaneous confessions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text:
[11]
*516 The Court's new rules aim to offset these minor pressures and disadvantages intrinsic to any kind of police interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The rules do not serve due process interests in preventing blatant coercion since, as I noted earlier, they do nothing to contain the policeman who is prepared to lie from the start.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The rules work for reliability in confessions almost only in the Pickwickian sense that they can prevent some from being given at all.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: [12] In short, the benefit of this new regime is simply to lessen or wipe out the inherent compulsion and inequalities to which the Court devotes some nine pages of description.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: What the Court largely ignores is that its rules impair, if they will not eventually serve wholly to frustrate, an instrument of law enforcement that has long and quite reasonably been thought worth the price paid for it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: [13] There can be little doubt that the Court's new code would markedly decrease the number of confessions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: To warn the suspect that he may remain silent and remind him that his confession may be used in court are minor obstructions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: To require also an express waiver by the suspect and an end to questioning whenever he demurs *517 must heavily handicap questioning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: And to suggest or provide counsel for the suspect simply invites the end of the interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: See, supra, n. 12.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: How much harm this decision will inflict on law enforcement cannot fairly be predicted with accuracy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Evidence on the role of confessions is notoriously incomplete, see Developments, supra, n. 2, at 941-944, and little is added by the Court's reference to the FBI experience and the resources believed wasted in interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: See infra, n. 19, and text.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: We do know that some crimes cannot be solved without confessions, that ample expert testimony attests to their importance in crime control,[14] and that the Court is taking a real risk with society's welfare in imposing its new regime on the country.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The social costs of crime are too great to call the new rules anything but a hazardous experimentation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: While passing over the costs and risks of its experiment, the Court portrays the evils of normal police questioning in terms which I think are exaggerated.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Albeit stringently confined by the due process standards interrogation is no doubt often inconvenient and unpleasant for the suspect.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: However, it is no less so for a man to be arrested and jailed, to have his house searched, or to stand trial in court, yet all this may properly happen to the most innocent given probable cause, a warrant, or an indictment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Society has always paid a stiff price for law and order, and peaceful interrogation is not one of the dark moments of the law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: This brief statement of the competing considerations seems to me ample proof that the Court's preference is highly debatable at best and therefore not to be read into *518 the Constitution.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: However, it may make the analysis more graphic to consider the actual facts of one of the four cases reversed by the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Miranda v. Arizona serves best, being neither the hardest nor easiest of the four under the Court's standards.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text:
[15]
On March 3, 1963, an 18-year-old girl was kidnapped and forcibly raped near Phoenix, Arizona.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Ten days later, on the morning of March 13, petitioner Miranda was arrested and taken to the police station.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: At this time Miranda was 23 years old, indigent, and educated to the extent of completing half the ninth grade.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: He had "an emotional illness" of the schizophrenic type, according to the doctor who eventually examined him; the doctor's report also stated that Miranda was "alert and oriented as to time, place, and person," intelligent within normal limits, competent to stand trial, and sane within the legal definition.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: At the police station, the victim picked Miranda out of a lineup, and two officers then took him into a separate room to interrogate him, starting about 11:30 a. m. Though at first denying his guilt, within a short time Miranda gave a detailed oral confession and then wrote out in his own hand and signed a brief statement admitting and describing the crime.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: All this was accomplished in two hours or less without any force, threats or promises andI will assume this though the record is uncertain, ante, 491-492 and nn.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: 66-67without any effective warnings at all.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Miranda's oral and written confessions are now held inadmissible under the Court's new rules.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: One is entitled to feel astonished that the Constitution can be read to produce this result.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: These confessions were obtained *519 during brief, daytime questioning conducted by two officers and unmarked by any of the traditional indicia of coercion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: They assured a conviction for a brutal and unsettling crime, for which the police had and quite possibly could obtain little evidence other than the victim's identifications, evidence which is frequently unreliable.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: There was, in sum, a legitimate purpose, no perceptible unfairness, and certainly little risk of injustice in the interrogation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Yet the resulting confessions, and the responsible course of police practice they represent, are to be sacrificed to the Court's own finespun conception of fairness which I seriously doubt is shared by many thinking citizens in this country.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text:
[16]
The tenor of judicial opinion also falls well short of supporting the Court's new approach.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Although Escobedo has widely been interpreted as an open invitation to lower courts to rewrite the law of confessions, a significant heavy majority of the state and federal decisions in point have sought quite narrow interpretations.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: [17] Of *520 the courts that have accepted the invitation, it is hard to know how many have felt compelled by their best guess as to this Court's likely construction; but none of the state decisions saw fit to rely on the state privilege against self-incrimination, and no decision at all has gone as far as this Court goes today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text:
[18]
It is also instructive to compare the attitude in this case of those responsible for law enforcement with the official views that existed when the Court undertook three major revisions of prosecutorial practice prior to this case, Johnson v. Zerbst, 304 U.S. 458, Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U.S. 643, and Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U.S. 335.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: In Johnson, which established that appointed counsel must be offered the indigent in federal criminal trials, the Federal Government all but conceded the basic issue, which had in fact been recently fixed as Department of Justice policy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: See Beaney, Right to Counsel 29-30, 36-42 (1955).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: In Mapp, which imposed the exclusionary rule on the States for Fourth Amendment violations, more than half of the States had themselves already adopted some such rule.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: See 367 U.S., at 651.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: In Gideon, which extended Johnson v. Zerbst to the States, an amicus brief was filed by 22 States and Commonwealths urging that course; only two States besides that of the respondent came forward to protest.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: See 372 U.S., at 345.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: By contrast, in this case new restrictions on police *521 questioning have been opposed by the United States and in an amicus brief signed by 27 States and Commonwealths, not including the three other States which are parties.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: No State in the country has urged this Court to impose the newly announced rules, nor has any State chosen to go nearly so far on its own.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The Court in closing its general discussion invokes the practice in federal and foreign jurisdictions as lending weight to its new curbs on confessions for all the States.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: A brief resume will suffice to show that none of these jurisdictions has struck so one-sided a balance as the Court does today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Heaviest reliance is placed on the FBI practice.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Differing circumstances may make this comparison quite untrustworthy,[19] but in any event the FBI falls sensibly short of the Court's formalistic rules.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: For example, there is no indication that FBI agents must obtain an affirmative "waiver" before they pursue their questioning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Nor is it clear that one invoking his right to silence may not be prevailed upon to change his mind.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: And the warning as to appointed counsel apparently indicates only that one will be assigned by the judge when the suspect appears before him; the thrust of the Court's rules is to induce the suspect to obtain appointed counsel before continuing the interview.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Apparently American military practice, briefly mentioned by the Court, has these same limits and is still less favorable to the suspect than the FBI warning, making no mention of appointed counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Developments, supra, n. 2, at 1084-1089.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The law of the foreign countries described by the Court also reflects a more moderate conception of the rights of *522 the accused as against those of society when other data are considered.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Concededly, the English experience is most relevant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: In that country, a caution as to silence but not counsel has long been mandated by the "Judges' Rules," which also place other somewhat imprecise limits on police cross-examination of suspects.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: However, in the court's discretion confessions can be and apparently quite frequently are admitted in evidence despite disregard of the Judges' Rules, so long as they are found voluntary under the common-law test.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Moreover, the check that exists on the use of pretrial statements is counterbalanced by the evident admissibility of fruits of an illegal confession and by the judge's often-used authority to comment adversely on the defendant's failure to testify.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text:
[20]
India, Ceylon and Scotland are the other examples chosen by the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: In India and Ceylon the general ban on police-adduced confessions cited by the Court is subject to a major exception: if evidence is uncovered by police questioning, it is fully admissible at trial along with the confession itself, so far as it relates to the evidence and is not blatantly coerced.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: See Developments, supra, n. 2, at 1106-1110; Reg.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: v. Ramasamy [1965] A. C. 1 (P. C.).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Scotland's limits on interrogation do measure up to the Court's; however, restrained comment at trial on the defendant's failure to take the stand is allowed the judge, and in many other respects Scotch law redresses the prosecutor's disadvantage in ways not permitted in this country.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: [21] The Court ends its survey by imputing *523 added strength to our privilege against self-incrimination since, by contrast to other countries, it is embodied in a written Constitution.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Considering the liberties the Court has today taken with constitutional history and precedent, few will find this emphasis persuasive.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: In closing this necessarily truncated discussion of policy considerations attending the new confession rules, some reference must be made to their ironic untimeliness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: There is now in progress in this country a massive re-examination of criminal law enforcement procedures on a scale never before witnessed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Participants in this undertaking include a Special Committee of the American Bar Association, under the chairmanship of Chief Judge Lumbard of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit; a distinguished study group of the American Law Institute, headed by Professors Vorenberg and Bator of the Harvard Law School; and the President's Commission on Law Enforcement and Administration of Justice, under the leadership of the Attorney General of the United States.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: [22] Studies are also being conducted by the District of Columbia Crime Commission, the Georgetown Law Center, and by others equipped to do practical research.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: [23] There are also signs that legislatures in some of the States may be preparing to re-examine the problem before us.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text:
[24]
*524 It is no secret that concern has been expressed lest long-range and lasting reforms be frustrated by this Court's too rapid departure from existing constitutional standards.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Despite the Court's disclaimer, the practical effect of the decision made today must inevitably be to handicap seriously sound efforts at reform, not least by removing options necessary to a just compromise of competing interests.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: Of course legislative reform is rarely speedy or unanimous, though this Court has been more patient in the past.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: [25] But the legislative reforms when they come would have the vast advantage of empirical data and comprehensive study, they would allow experimentation and use of solutions not open to the courts, and they would restore the initiative in criminal law reform to those forums where it truly belongs.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: CONCLUSIONS.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: All four of the cases involved here present express claims that confessions were inadmissible, not because of coercion in the traditional due process sense, but solely because of lack of counsel or lack of warnings concerning counsel and silence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: For the reasons stated in this opinion, I would adhere to the due process test and reject the new requirements inaugurated by the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: On this premise my disposition of each of these cases can be stated briefly.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: In two of the three cases coming from state courts, Miranda v. Arizona (No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: 759) and Vignera v. New York (No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: 760), the confessions were held admissible and no other errors worth comment are alleged by petitioners.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: *525 I would affirm in these two cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The other state case is California v. Stewart (No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: 584), where the state supreme court held the confession inadmissible and reversed the conviction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: In that case I would dismiss the writ of certiorari on the ground that no final judgment is before us, 28 U.S. C. § 1257 (1964 ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: ); putting aside the new trial open to the State in any event, the confession itself has not even been finally excluded since the California Supreme Court left the State free to show proof of a waiver.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: If the merits of the decision in Stewart be reached, then I believe it should be reversed and the case remanded so the state supreme court may pass on the other claims available to respondent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: In the federal case, Westover v. United States (No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: 761), a number of issues are raised by petitioner apart from the one already dealt with in this dissent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: None of these other claims appears to me tenable, nor in this context to warrant extended discussion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: It is urged that the confession was also inadmissible because not voluntary even measured by due process standards and because federal-state cooperation brought the McNabb-Mallory rule into play under Anderson v. United States, 318 U.S. 350.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: However, the facts alleged fall well short of coercion in my view, and I believe the involvement of federal agents in petitioner's arrest and detention by the State too slight to invoke Anderson.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: I agree with the Government that the admission of the evidence now protested by petitioner was at most harmless error, and two final contentionsone involving weight of the evidence and another improper prosecutor commentseem to me without merit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: I would therefore affirm Westover's conviction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: In conclusion: Nothing in the letter or the spirit of the Constitution or in the precedents squares with the heavy-handed and one-sided action that is so precipitously *526 taken by the Court in the name of fulfilling its constitutional responsibilities.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: The foray which the Court makes today brings to mind the wise and farsighted words of Mr. Justice Jackson in Douglas v. Jeannette, 319 U.S. 157, 181 (separate opinion): "This Court is forever adding new stories to the temples of constitutional law, and the temples have a way of collapsing when one story too many is added."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Harlan
text: MR. JUSTICE WHITE, with whom MR. JUSTICE HARLAN and MR.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The proposition that the privilege against self-incrimination forbids in-custody interrogation without the warnings specified in the majority opinion and without a clear waiver of counsel has no significant support in the history of the privilege or in the language of the Fifth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: As for the English authorities and the common-law history, the privilege, firmly established in the second half of the seventeenth century, was never applied except to prohibit compelled judicial interrogations.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The rule excluding coerced confessions matured about 100 years later, "[b]ut there is nothing in the reports to suggest that the theory has its roots in the privilege against self-incrimination.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: And so far as the cases reveal, the privilege, as such, seems to have been given effect only in judicial proceedings, including the preliminary examinations by authorized magistrates."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Morgan, The Privilege Against Self-Incrimination, 34 Minn. L. Rev.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Our own constitutional provision provides that no person "shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: These words, when "[c]onsidered in the light to be shed by grammar and the dictionary.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: appear to signify simply that nobody shall be *527 compelled to give oral testimony against himself in a criminal proceeding under way in which he is defendant."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Corwin, The Supreme Court's Construction of the Self-Incrimination Clause, 29 Mich. L. Rev.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: And there is very little in the surrounding circumstances of the adoption of the Fifth Amendment or in the provisions of the then existing state constitutions or in state practice which would give the constitutional provision any broader meaning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Mayers, The Federal Witness' Privilege Against Self-Incrimination: Constitutional or Common-Law?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: 4 American Journal of Legal History 107 (1960).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Such a construction, however, was considerably narrower than the privilege at common law, and when eventually faced with the issues, the Court extended the constitutional privilege to the compulsory production of books and papers, to the ordinary witness before the grand jury and to witnesses generally.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Boyd v. United States, 116 U.S. 616, and Counselman v. Hitchcock, 142 U.S. 547.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Both rules had solid support in common-law history, if not in the history of our own constitutional provision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: A few years later the Fifth Amendment privilege was similarly extended to encompass the then well-established rule against coerced confessions: "In criminal trials, in the courts of the United States, wherever a question arises whether a confession is incompetent because not voluntary, the issue is controlled by that portion of the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States, commanding that no person `shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: " Bram v. United States, 168 U.S. 532, 542.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Although this view has found approval in other cases, Burdeau v. McDowell, 256 U.S. 465, 475; Powers v. United States, 223 U.S. 303, 313; Shotwell v. United States, 371 U.S. 341, 347, it has also been questioned, see Brown v. Mississippi, 297 U.S. 278, 285; United States v. Carignan, *528 342 U.S. 36, 41; Stein v. New York, 346 U.S. 156, 191, n. 35, and finds scant support in either the English or American authorities, see generally Regina v. Scott, Dears.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: & Bell 47; 3 Wigmore, Evidence § 823 (3d ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: 1940), at 249 ("a confession is not rejected because of any connection with the privilege against self-crimination"), and 250, n. 5 (particularly criticizing Bram); 8 Wigmore, Evidence § 2266, at 400-401 (McNaughton rev.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Whatever the source of the rule excluding coerced confessions, it is clear that prior to the application of the privilege itself to state courts, Malloy v. Hogan, 378 U.S. 1, the admissibility of a confession in a state criminal prosecution was tested by the same standards as were applied in federal prosecutions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Bram, however, itself rejected the proposition which the Court now espouses.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The question in Bram was whether a confession, obtained during custodial interrogation, had been compelled, and if such interrogation was to be deemed inherently vulnerable the Court's inquiry could have ended there.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text:
After examining the English and American authorities, however, the Court declared that:
"In this court also it has been settled that the mere fact that the confession is made to a police officer, while the accused was under arrest in or out of prison, or was drawn out by his questions, does not necessarily render the confession involuntary, but, as one of the circumstances, such imprisonment or interrogation may be taken into account in determining whether or not the statements of the prisoner were voluntary."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: In this respect the Court was wholly consistent with prior and subsequent pronouncements in this Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Thus prior to Bram the Court, in Hopt v. Utah, 110 U.S. 574, 583-587, had upheld the admissibility of a *529 confession made to police officers following arrest, the record being silent concerning what conversation had occurred between the officers and the defendant in the short period preceding the confession.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text:
Relying on Hopt, the Court ruled squarely on the issue in Sparf and Hansen v. United States, 156 U.S. 51, 55:
"Counsel for the accused insist that there cannot be a voluntary statement, a free open confession, while a defendant is confined and in irons under an accusation of having committed a capital offence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: We have not been referred to any authority in support of that position.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: It is true that the fact of a prisoner being in custody at the time he makes a confession is a circumstance not to be overlooked, because it bears upon the inquiry whether the confession was voluntarily made or was extorted by threats or violence or made under the influence of fear.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: But confinement or imprisonment is not in itself sufficient to justify the exclusion of a confession, if it appears to have been voluntary, and was not obtained by putting the prisoner in fear or by promises.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Wharton's Cr.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: §§ 661, 663, and authorities cited."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Accord, Pierce v. United States, 160 U.S. 355, 357.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: And in Wilson v. United States, 162 U.S. 613, 623, the Court had considered the significance of custodial interrogation without any antecedent warnings regarding the right to remain silent or the right to counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: There the defendant had answered questions posed by a Commissioner, who had failed to advise him of his rights, and his answers were held admissible over his claim of involuntariness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: "The fact that [a defendant] is in custody and manacled does not necessarily render his statement involuntary, nor is that necessarily the effect of popular excitement shortly preceding.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: And it is laid down *530 that it is not essential to the admissibility of a confession that it should appear that the person was warned that what he said would be used against him, but on the contrary, if the confession was voluntary, it is sufficient though it appear that he was not so warned."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Since Bram, the admissibility of statements made during custodial interrogation has been frequently reiterated.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Powers v. United States, 223 U.S. 303, cited Wilson approvingly and held admissible as voluntary statements the accused's testimony at a preliminary hearing even though he was not warned that what he said might be used against him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Without any discussion of the presence or absence of warnings, presumably because such discussion was deemed unnecessary, numerous other cases have declared that "[t]he mere fact that a confession was made while in the custody of the police does not render it inadmissible," McNabb v. United States, 318 U.S. 332, 346; accord, United States v. Mitchell, 322 U.S. 65, despite its having been elicited by police examination, Wan v. United States, 266 U.S. 1, 14; United States v. Carignan, 342 U.S. 36, 39.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Likewise, in Crooker v. California, 357 U.S. 433, 437, the Court said that "the bare fact of police `detention and police examination in private of one in official state custody' does not render involuntary a confession by the one so detained."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: And finally, in Cicenia v. Lagay, 357 U.S. 504, a confession obtained by police interrogation after arrest was held voluntary even though the authorities refused to permit the defendant to consult with his attorney.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: See generally Culombe v. Connecticut, 367 U.S. 568, 587-602 (opinion of Frankfurter, J.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: ); 3 Wigmore, Evidence § 851, at 313 (3d ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: 1940); see also Joy, Admissibility of Confessions 38, 46 (1842).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Only a tiny minority of our judges who have dealt with the question, including today's majority, have considered in-custody interrogation, without more, to be a violation of the Fifth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: And this Court, as *531 every member knows, has left standing literally thousands of criminal convictions that rested at least in part on confessions taken in the course of interrogation by the police after arrest.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: That the Court's holding today is neither compelled nor even strongly suggested by the language of the Fifth Amendment, is at odds with American and English legal history, and involves a departure from a long line of precedent does not prove either that the Court has exceeded its powers or that the Court is wrong or unwise in its present reinterpretation of the Fifth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: It does, however, underscore the obvious that the Court has not discovered or found the law in making today's decision, nor has it derived it from some irrefutable sources; what it has done is to make new law and new public policy in much the same way that it has in the course of interpreting other great clauses of the Constitution.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: [1] This is what the Court historically has done.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Indeed, it is what it must do and will continue to do until and unless there is some fundamental change in the constitutional distribution of governmental powers.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: But if the Court is here and now to announce new and fundamental policy to govern certain aspects of our affairs, it is wholly legitimate to examine the mode of this or any other constitutional decision in this Court and to inquire into the advisability of its end product in terms of the long-range interest of the country.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: At the very least the Court's text and reasoning should withstand analysis and be a fair exposition of the constitutional provision which its opinion interprets.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Decisions *532 like these cannot rest alone on syllogism, metaphysics or some ill-defined notions of natural justice, although each will perhaps play its part.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: In proceeding to such constructions as it now announces, the Court should also duly consider all the factors and interests bearing upon the cases, at least insofar as the relevant materials are available; and if the necessary considerations are not treated in the record or obtainable from some other reliable source, the Court should not proceed to formulate fundamental policies based on speculation alone.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: First, we may inquire what are the textual and factual bases of this new fundamental rule.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: To reach the result announced on the grounds it does, the Court must stay within the confines of the Fifth Amendment, which forbids self-incrimination only if compelled.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Hence the core of the Court's opinion is that because of the "compulsion inherent in custodial surroundings, no statement obtained from [a] defendant [in custody] can truly be the product of his free choice," ante, at 458, absent the use of adequate protective devices as described by the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: However, the Court does not point to any sudden inrush of new knowledge requiring the rejection of 70 years' experience.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Nor does it assert that its novel conclusion reflects a changing consensus among state courts, see Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U.S. 643, or that a succession of cases had steadily eroded the old rule and proved it unworkable, see Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U.S. 335.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Rather than asserting new knowledge, the Court concedes that it cannot truly know what occurs during custodial questioning, because of the innate secrecy of such proceedings.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: It extrapolates a picture of what it conceives to be the norm from police investigatorial manuals, published in 1959 and 1962 or earlier, without any attempt to allow for adjustments in police practices that may *533 have occurred in the wake of more recent decisions of state appellate tribunals or this Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: But even if the relentless application of the described procedures could lead to involuntary confessions, it most assuredly does not follow that each and every case will disclose this kind of interrogation or this kind of consequence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: [2] Insofar as appears from the Court's opinion, it has not examined a single transcript of any police interrogation, let alone the interrogation that took place in any one of these cases which it decides today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Judged by any of the standards for empirical investigation utilized in the social sciences the factual basis for the Court's premise is patently inadequate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Although in the Court's view in-custody interrogation is inherently coercive, the Court says that the spontaneous product of the coercion of arrest and detention is still to be deemed voluntary.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: An accused, arrested on probable cause, may blurt out a confession which will be admissible despite the fact that he is alone and in custody, without any showing that he had any notion of his right to remain silent or of the consequences of his admission.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Yet, under the Court's rule, if the police ask him a single question such as "Do you have anything to say?"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: or "Did you kill your wife?"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: his response, if there is one, has somehow been compelled, even if the accused has *534 been clearly warned of his right to remain silent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Common sense informs us to the contrary.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: While one may say that the response was "involuntary" in the sense the question provoked or was the occasion for the response and thus the defendant was induced to speak out when he might have remained silent if not arrested and not questioned, it is patently unsound to say the response is compelled.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Today's result would not follow even if it were agreed that to some extent custodial interrogation is inherently coercive.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: See Ashcraft v. Tennessee, 322 U.S. 143, 161 (Jackson, J., dissenting).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The test has been whether the totality of circumstances deprived the defendant of a "free choice to admit, to deny, or to refuse to answer," Lisenba v. California, 314 U.S. 219, 241, and whether physical or psychological coercion was of such a degree that "the defendant's will was overborne at the time he confessed," Haynes v. Washington, 373 U.S. 503, 513; Lynumn v. Illinois, 372 U.S. 528, 534.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The duration and nature of incommunicado custody, the presence or absence of advice concerning the defendant's constitutional rights, and the granting or refusal of requests to communicate with lawyers, relatives or friends have all been rightly regarded as important data bearing on the basic inquiry.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: See, e. g., Ashcraft v. Tennessee, 322 U.S. 143; Haynes v. Washington, 373 U.S.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: [3]*535 But it has never been suggested, until today, that such questioning was so coercive and accused persons so lacking in hardihood that the very first response to the very first question following the commencement of custody must be conclusively presumed to be the product of an overborne will.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: If the rule announced today were truly based on a conclusion that all confessions resulting from custodial interrogation are coerced, then it would simply have no rational foundation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Compare Tot v. United States, 319 U.S. 463, 466; United States v. Romano, 382 U.S. 136.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: A fortiori that would be true of the extension of the rule to exculpatory statements, which the Court effects after a brief discussion of why, in the Court's view, they must be deemed incriminatory but without any discussion of why they must be deemed coerced.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: See Wilson v. United States, 162 U.S. 613, 624.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Even if one were to postulate that the Court's concern is not that all confessions induced by police interrogation are coerced but rather that some such confessions are coerced and present judicial procedures are believed to be inadequate to identify the confessions that are coerced and those that are not, it would still not be essential to impose the rule that the Court has now fashioned.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Transcripts or observers could be required, specific time limits, tailored to fit the cause, could be imposed, or other devices could be utilized to reduce the chances that otherwise indiscernible coercion will produce an inadmissible confession.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: On the other hand, even if one assumed that there was an adequate factual basis for the conclusion that all confessions obtained during in-custody interrogation are the product of compulsion, the rule propounded by *536 the Court would still be irrational, for, apparently, it is only if the accused is also warned of his right to counsel and waives both that right and the right against self-incrimination that the inherent compulsiveness of interrogation disappears.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: But if the defendant may not answer without a warning a question such as "Where were you last night?"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: without having his answer be a compelled one, how can the Court ever accept his negative answer to the question of whether he wants to consult his retained counsel or counsel whom the court will appoint?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: And why if counsel is present and the accused nevertheless confesses, or counsel tells the accused to tell the truth, and that is what the accused does, is the situation any less coercive insofar as the accused is concerned?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The Court apparently realizes its dilemma of foreclosing questioning without the necessary warnings but at the same time permitting the accused, sitting in the same chair in front of the same policemen, to waive his right to consult an attorney.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: It expects, however, that the accused will not often waive the right; and if it is claimed that he has, the State faces a severe, if not impossible burden of proof.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: All of this makes very little sense in terms of the compulsion which the Fifth Amendment proscribes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: That amendment deals with compelling the accused himself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: It is his free will that is involved.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Confessions and incriminating admissions, as such, are not forbidden evidence; only those which are compelled are banned.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: I doubt that the Court observes these distinctions today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: By considering any answers to any interrogation to be compelled regardless of the content and course of examination and by escalating the requirements to prove waiver, the Court not only prevents the use of compelled confessions but for all practical purposes forbids interrogation except in the presence of counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: That is, instead of confining itself to protection of the right against compelled *537 self-incrimination the Court has created a limited Fifth Amendment right to counselor, as the Court expresses it, a "need for counsel to protect the Fifth Amendment privilege .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Ante, at 470.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The focus then is not on the will of the accused but on the will of counsel and how much influence he can have on the accused.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Obviously there is no warrant in the Fifth Amendment for thus installing counsel as the arbiter of the privilege.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: In sum, for all the Court's expounding on the menacing atmosphere of police interrogation procedures, it has failed to supply any foundation for the conclusions it draws or the measures it adopts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Criticism of the Court's opinion, however, cannot stop with a demonstration that the factual and textual bases for the rule it propounds are, at best, less than compelling.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Equally relevant is an assessment of the rule's consequences measured against community values.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The Court's duty to assess the consequences of its action is not satisfied by the utterance of the truth that a value of our system of criminal justice is "to respect the inviolability of the human personality" and to require government to produce the evidence against the accused by its own independent labors.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Ante, at 460.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: More than the human dignity of the accused is involved; the human personality of others in the society must also be preserved.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Thus the values reflected by the privilege are not the sole desideratum; society's interest in the general security is of equal weight.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The obvious underpinning of the Court's decision is a deep-seated distrust of all confessions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: As the Court declares that the accused may not be interrogated without counsel present, absent a waiver of the right to counsel, and as the Court all but admonishes the lawyer to *538 advise the accused to remain silent, the result adds up to a judicial judgment that evidence from the accused should not be used against him in any way, whether compelled or not.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: This is the not so subtle overtone of the opinionthat it is inherently wrong for the police to gather evidence from the accused himself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: And this is precisely the nub of this dissent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: I see nothing wrong or immoral, and certainly nothing unconstitutional, in the police's asking a suspect whom they have reasonable cause to arrest whether or not he killed his wife or in confronting him with the evidence on which the arrest was based, at least where he has been plainly advised that he may remain completely silent, see Escobedo v. Illinois, 378 U.S. 478, 499 (dissenting opinion).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Until today, "the admissions or confessions of the prisoner, when voluntarily and freely made, have always ranked high in the scale of incriminating evidence."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Brown v. Walker, 161 U.S. 591, 596; see also Hopt v. Utah, 110 U.S. 574, 584-585.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Particularly when corroborated, as where the police have confirmed the accused's disclosure of the hiding place of implements or fruits of the crime, such confessions have the highest reliability and significantly contribute to the certitude with which we may believe the accused is guilty.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Moreover, it is by no means certain that the process of confessing is injurious to the accused.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: To the contrary it may provide psychological relief and enhance the prospects for rehabilitation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: This is not to say that the value of respect for the inviolability of the accused's individual personality should be accorded no weight or that all confessions should be indiscriminately admitted.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: This Court has long read the Constitution to proscribe compelled confessions, a salutary rule from which there should be no retreat.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: But I see no sound basis, factual or otherwise, and the Court gives none, for concluding that the present rule against the receipt of coerced confessions is inadequate for the *539 task of sorting out inadmissible evidence and must be replaced by the per se rule which is now imposed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Even if the new concept can be said to have advantages of some sort over the present law, they are far outweighed by its likely undesirable impact on other very relevant and important interests.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The most basic function of any government is to provide for the security of the individual and of his property.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Lanzetta v. New Jersey, 306 U.S. 451, 455.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: These ends of society are served by the criminal laws which for the most part are aimed at the prevention of crime.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Without the reasonably effective performance of the task of preventing private violence and retaliation, it is idle to talk about human dignity and civilized values.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The modes by which the criminal laws serve the interest in general security are many.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: First the murderer who has taken the life of another is removed from the streets, deprived of his liberty and thereby prevented from repeating his offense.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: In view of the statistics on recidivism in this country[4] and of the number of instances *540 in which apprehension occurs only after repeated offenses, no one can sensibly claim that this aspect of the criminal law does not prevent crime or contribute significantly to the personal security of the ordinary citizen.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Secondly, the swift and sure apprehension of those who refuse to respect the personal security and dignity of their neighbor unquestionably has its impact on others who might be similarly tempted.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: That the criminal law is wholly or partly ineffective with a segment of the population or with many of those who have been apprehended and convicted is a very faulty basis for concluding that it is not effective with respect to the great bulk of our citizens or for thinking that without the criminal laws, *541 or in the absence of their enforcement, there would be no increase in crime.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Arguments of this nature are not borne out by any kind of reliable evidence that I have seen to this date.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Thirdly, the law concerns itself with those whom it has confined.
label: RHETORIC
