author: Justice White
text: The hope and aim of modern penology, fortunately, is as soon as possible to return the convict to society a better and more law-abiding man than when he left.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Sometimes there is success, sometimes failure.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: But at least the effort is made, and it should be made to the very maximum extent of our present and future capabilities.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The rule announced today will measurably weaken the ability of the criminal law to perform these tasks.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: It is a deliberate calculus to prevent interrogations, to reduce the incidence of confessions and pleas of guilty and to increase the number of trials.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: [5] Criminal trials, no *542 matter how efficient the police are, are not sure bets for the prosecution, nor should they be if the evidence is not forthcoming.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Under the present law, the prosecution fails to prove its case in about 30% of the criminal cases actually tried in the federal courts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: See Federal Offenders: 1964, supra, note 4, at 6 (Table 4), 59 (Table 1); Federal Offenders: 1963, supra, note 4, at 5 (Table 3); District of Columbia Offenders: 1963, supra, note 4, at 2 (Table 1).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: But it is something else again to remove from the ordinary criminal case all those confessions which heretofore have been held to be free and voluntary acts of the accused and to thus establish a new constitutional barrier to the ascertainment of truth by the judicial process.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: There is, in my view, every reason to believe that a good many criminal defendants who otherwise would have been convicted on what this Court has previously thought to be the most satisfactory kind of evidence will now, under this new version of the Fifth Amendment, either not be tried at all or will be acquitted if the State's evidence, minus the confession, is put to the test of litigation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: I have no desire whatsoever to share the responsibility for any such impact on the present criminal process.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: In some unknown number of cases the Court's rule will return a killer, a rapist or other criminal to the streets and to the environment which produced him, to repeat his crime whenever it pleases him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: As a consequence, there will not be a gain, but a loss, in human dignity.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The real concern is not the unfortunate consequences of this new decision on the criminal law as an abstract, disembodied series of authoritative proscriptions, but the impact on those who rely on the public authority for protection and who without it can only engage in violent self-help with guns, knives and the help of their neighbors similarly inclined.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: There is, of *543 course, a saving factor: the next victims are uncertain, unnamed and unrepresented in this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Nor can this decision do other than have a corrosive effect on the criminal law as an effective device to prevent crime.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: A major component in its effectiveness in this regard is its swift and sure enforcement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The easier it is to get away with rape and murder, the less the deterrent effect on those who are inclined to attempt it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: This is still good common sense.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: If it were not, we should posthaste liquidate the whole law enforcement establishment as a useless, misguided effort to control human conduct.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: And what about the accused who has confessed or would confess in response to simple, noncoercive questioning and whose guilt could not otherwise be proved?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Is it so clear that release is the best thing for him in every case?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Has it so unquestionably been resolved that in each and every case it would be better for him not to confess and to return to his environment with no attempt whatsoever to help him?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: I think not.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: It may well be that in many cases it will be no less than a callous disregard for his own welfare as well as for the interests of his next victim.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: There is another aspect to the effect of the Court's rule on the person whom the police have arrested on probable cause.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: The fact is that he may not be guilty at all and may be able to extricate himself quickly and simply if he were told the circumstances of his arrest and were asked to explain.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: This effort, and his release, must now await the hiring of a lawyer or his appointment by the court, consultation with counsel and then a session with the police or the prosecutor.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Similarly, where probable cause exists to arrest several suspects, as where the body of the victim is discovered in a house having several residents, compare Johnson v. State, 238 Md.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: denied, 382 U.S. 1013, it will often *544 be true that a suspect may be cleared only through the results of interrogation of other suspects.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Here too the release of the innocent may be delayed by the Court's rule.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Much of the trouble with the Court's new rule is that it will operate indiscriminately in all criminal cases, regardless of the severity of the crime or the circumstances involved.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: It applies to every defendant, whether the professional criminal or one committing a crime of momentary passion who is not part and parcel of organized crime.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: It will slow down the investigation and the apprehension of confederates in those cases where time is of the essence, such as kidnapping, see Brinegar v. United States, 338 U.S. 160, 183 (Jackson, J., dissenting); People v. Modesto, 62 Cal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: 2d 436, 446, 398 P.2d 753, 759 (1965), those involving the national security, see United States v. Drummond, 354 F.2d 132, 147 (C. A.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: 1965) (en banc) (espionage case), pet.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: pending, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Gessner v. United States, 354 F.2d 726, 730, n. 10 (C. A.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: 1965) (upholding, in espionage case, trial ruling that Government need not submit classified portions of interrogation transcript), and some of those involving organized crime.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: In the latter context the lawyer who arrives may also be the lawyer for the defendant's colleagues and can be relied upon to insure that no breach of the organization's security takes place even though the accused may feel that the best thing he can do is to cooperate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: At the same time, the Court's per se approach may not be justified on the ground that it provides a "bright line" permitting the authorities to judge in advance whether interrogation may safely be pursued without jeopardizing the admissibility of any information obtained as a consequence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Nor can it be claimed that judicial time and effort, assuming that is a relevant consideration, *545 will be conserved because of the ease of application of the new rule.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Today's decision leaves open such questions as whether the accused was in custody, whether his statements were spontaneous or the product of interrogation, whether the accused has effectively waived his rights, and whether nontestimonial evidence introduced at trial is the fruit of statements made during a prohibited interrogation, all of which are certain to prove productive of uncertainty during investigation and litigation during prosecution.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: For all these reasons, if further restrictions on police interrogation are desirable at this time, a more flexible approach makes much more sense than the Court's constitutional straitjacket which forecloses more discriminating treatment by legislative or rule-making pronouncements.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: Applying the traditional standards to the cases before the Court, I would hold these confessions voluntary.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: I would therefore affirm in Nos.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice White
text: 759, 760, and 761, and reverse in No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This Texas federal appeal and its Georgia companion, Doe v. Bolton, post, p. 179, present constitutional challenges to state criminal abortion legislation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Texas statutes under attack here are typical of those that have been in effect in many States for approximately a century.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Georgia statutes, in contrast, have a modern cast and are a legislative product that, to an extent at least, obviously reflects the influences of recent attitudinal change, of advancing medical knowledge and techniques, and of new thinking about an old issue.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We forthwith acknowledge our awareness of the sensitive and emotional nature of the abortion controversy, of the vigorous opposing views, even among physicians, and of the deep and seemingly absolute convictions that the subject inspires.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: One's philosophy, one's experiences, one's exposure to the raw edges of human existence, one's religious training, one's attitudes toward life and family and their values, and the moral standards one establishes and seeks to observe, are all likely to influence and to color one's thinking and conclusions about abortion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In addition, population growth, pollution, poverty, and racial overtones tend to complicate and not to simplify the problem.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Our task, of course, is to resolve the issue by constitutional measurement, free of emotion and of predilection.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We seek earnestly to do this, and, because we do, we *117 have inquired into, and in this opinion place some emphasis upon, medical and medical-legal history and what that history reveals about man's attitudes toward the abortion procedure over the centuries.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
We bear in mind, too, Mr. Justice Holmes' admonition in his nowvindicated dissent in Lochner v. New York, 198 U.S. 45, 76 (1905):
"[The Constitution] is made for people of fundamentally differing views, and the accident of our finding certain opinions natural and familiar or novel and even shocking ought not to conclude our judgment upon the question whether statutes embodying them conflict with the Constitution of the United States."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
I
The Texas statutes that concern us here are Arts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 1191-1194 and 1196 of the State's Penal Code.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [1] These make it a crime to "procure an abortion," as therein *118 defined, or to attempt one, except with respect to "an abortion procured or attempted by medical advice for the purpose of saving the life of the mother."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Similar statutes are in existence in a majority of the States.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
[2]
*119 Texas first enacted a criminal abortion statute in 1854.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Texas Laws 1854, c. 49, § 1, set forth in 3 H. Gammel, Laws of Texas 1502 (1898).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This was soon modified into language that has remained substantially unchanged to the present time.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: See Texas Penal Code of 1857, c. 7, Arts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 531-536; G. Paschal, Laws of Texas, Arts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Stat., c. 8, Arts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Stat., Arts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The final article in each of these compilations provided the same exception, as does the present Article 1196, for an abortion by "medical advice for the purpose of saving the life of the mother.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
"[3]


*120 II
Jane Roe,[4] a single woman who was residing in Dallas County, Texas, instituted this federal action in March 1970 against the District Attorney of the county.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: She sought a declaratory judgment that the Texas criminal abortion statutes were unconstitutional on their face, and an injunction restraining the defendant from enforcing the statutes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Roe alleged that she was unmarried and pregnant; that she wished to terminate her pregnancy by an abortion "performed by a competent, licensed physician, under safe, clinical conditions"; that she was unable to get a "legal" abortion in Texas because her life did not appear to be threatened by the continuation of her pregnancy; and that she could not afford to travel to another jurisdiction in order to secure a legal abortion under safe conditions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: She claimed that the Texas statutes were unconstitutionally vague and that they abridged her right of personal privacy, protected by the First, Fourth, Fifth, Ninth, and Fourteenth Amendments.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: By an amendment to her complaint Roe purported to sue "on behalf of herself and all other women" similarly situated.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: James Hubert Hallford, a licensed physician, sought and was granted leave to intervene in Roe's action.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In his complaint he alleged that he had been arrested previously for violations of the Texas abortion statutes and *121 that two such prosecutions were pending against him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: He described conditions of patients who came to him seeking abortions, and he claimed that for many cases he, as a physician, was unable to determine whether they fell within or outside the exception recognized by Article 1196.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: He alleged that, as a consequence, the statutes were vague and uncertain, in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment, and that they violated his own and his patients' rights to privacy in the doctor-patient relationship and his own right to practice medicine, rights he claimed were guaranteed by the First, Fourth, Fifth, Ninth, and Fourteenth Amendments.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: John and Mary Doe,[5] a married couple, filed a companion complaint to that of Roe.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: They also named the District Attorney as defendant, claimed like constitutional deprivations, and sought declaratory and injunctive relief.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Does alleged that they were a childless couple; that Mrs. Doe was suffering from a "neural-chemical" disorder; that her physician had "advised her to avoid pregnancy until such time as her condition has materially improved" (although a pregnancy at the present time would not present "a serious risk" to her life); that, pursuant to medical advice, she had discontinued use of birth control pills; and that if she should become pregnant, she would want to terminate the pregnancy by an abortion performed by a competent, licensed physician under safe, clinical conditions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: By an amendment to their complaint, the Does purported to sue "on behalf of themselves and all couples similarly situated."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The two actions were consolidated and heard together by a duly convened three-judge district court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The suits thus presented the situations of the pregnant single woman, the childless couple, with the wife not pregnant, *122 and the licensed practicing physician, all joining in the attack on the Texas criminal abortion statutes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Upon the filing of affidavits, motions were made for dismissal and for summary judgment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The court held that Roe and members of her class, and Dr. Hallford, had standing to sue and presented justiciable controversies, but that the Does had failed to allege facts sufficient to state a present controversy and did not have standing.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It concluded that, with respect to the requests for a declaratory judgment, abstention was not warranted.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: On the merits, the District Court held that the "fundamental right of single women and married persons to choose whether to have children is protected by the Ninth Amendment, through the Fourteenth Amendment," and that the Texas criminal abortion statutes were void on their face because they were both unconstitutionally vague and constituted an overbroad infringement of the plaintiffs' Ninth Amendment rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The court then held that abstention was warranted with respect to the requests for an injunction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It therefore dismissed the Does' complaint, declared the abortion statutes void, and dismissed the application for injunctive relief.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 314 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The plaintiffs Roe and Doe and the intervenor Hallford, pursuant to 28 U.S. C. § 1253, have appealed to this Court from that part of the District Court's judgment denying the injunction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The defendant District Attorney has purported to cross-appeal, pursuant to the same statute, from the court's grant of declaratory relief to Roe and Hallford.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Both sides also have taken protective appeals to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: That court ordered the appeals held in abeyance pending decision here.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We postponed decision on jurisdiction to the hearing on the merits.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
*123 III
It might have been preferable if the defendant, pursuant to our Rule 20, had presented to us a petition for certiorari before judgment in the Court of Appeals with respect to the granting of the plaintiffs' prayer for declaratory relief.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Our decisions in Mitchell v. Donovan, 398 U.S. 427 (1970), and Gunn v. University Committee, 399 U.S. 383 (1970), are to the effect that § 1253 does not authorize an appeal to this Court from the grant or denial of declaratory relief alone.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We conclude, nevertheless, that those decisions do not foreclose our review of both the injunctive and the declaratory aspects of a case of this kind when it is properly here, as this one is, on appeal under § 1253 from specific denial of injunctive relief, and the arguments as to both aspects are necessarily identical.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: See Carter v. Jury Comm'n, 396 U.S. 320 (1970); Florida Lime Growers v. Jacobsen, 362 U.S. 73, 80-81 (1960).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It would be destructive of time and energy for all concerned were we to rule otherwise.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Doe v. Bolton, post, p. 179.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
IV
We are next confronted with issues of justiciability, standing, and abstention.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Have Roe and the Does established that "personal stake in the outcome of the controversy," Baker v. Carr, 369 U.S. 186, 204 (1962), that insures that "the dispute sought to be adjudicated will be presented in an adversary context and in a form historically viewed as capable of judicial resolution," Flast v. Cohen, 392 U.S. 83, 101 (1968), and Sierra Club v. Morton, 405 U.S. 727, 732 (1972)?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: And what effect did the pendency of criminal abortion charges against Dr. Hallford in state court have upon the propriety of the federal court's granting relief to him as a plaintiff-intervenor?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: *124 A. Jane Roe.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Despite the use of the pseudonym, no suggestion is made that Roe is a fictitious person.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: For purposes of her case, we accept as true, and as established, her existence; her pregnant state, as of the inception of her suit in March 1970 and as late as May 21 of that year when she filed an alias affidavit with the District Court; and her inability to obtain a legal abortion in Texas.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Viewing Roe's case as of the time of its filing and thereafter until as late as May, there can be little dispute that it then presented a case or controversy and that, wholly apart from the class aspects, she, as a pregnant single woman thwarted by the Texas criminal abortion laws, had standing to challenge those statutes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Abele v. Markle, 452 F.2d 1121, 1125 (CA2 1971); Crossen v. Breckenridge, 446 F.2d 833, 838-839 (CA6 1971); Poe v. Menghini, 339 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: See Truax v. Raich, 239 U.S. 33 (1915).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Indeed, we do not read the appellee's brief as really asserting anything to the contrary.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The "logical nexus between the status asserted and the claim sought to be adjudicated," Flast v. Cohen, 392 U. S., at 102, and the necessary degree of contentiousness, Golden v. Zwickler, 394 U.S. 103 (1969), are both present.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The appellee notes, however, that the record does not disclose that Roe was pregnant at the time of the District Court hearing on May 22, 1970,[6] or on the following June 17 when the court's opinion and judgment were filed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: And he suggests that Roe's case must now be moot because she and all other members of her class are no longer subject to any 1970 pregnancy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: *125 The usual rule in federal cases is that an actual controversy must exist at stages of appellate or certiorari review, and not simply at the date the action is initiated.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: United States v. Munsingwear, Inc., 340 U.S. 36 (1950); Golden v. Zwickler, supra; SEC v. Medical Committee for Human Rights, 404 U.S. 403 (1972).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: But when, as here, pregnancy is a significant fact in the litigation, the normal 266-day human gestation period is so short that the pregnancy will come to term before the usual appellate process is complete.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: If that termination makes a case moot, pregnancy litigation seldom will survive much beyond the trial stage, and appellate review will be effectively denied.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Our law should not be that rigid.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Pregnancy often comes more than once to the same woman, and in the general population, if man is to survive, it will always be with us.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Pregnancy provides a classic justification for a conclusion of nonmootness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It truly could be "capable of repetition, yet evading review."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Southern Pacific Terminal Co. v. ICC, 219 U.S. 498, 515 (1911).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: See Moore v. Ogilvie, 394 U.S. 814, 816 (1969); Carroll v. Princess Anne, 393 U.S. 175, 178-179 (1968); United States v. W. T. Grant Co., 345 U.S. 629, 632-633 (1953).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We, therefore, agree with the District Court that Jane Roe had standing to undertake this litigation, that she presented a justiciable controversy, and that the termination of her 1970 pregnancy has not rendered her case moot.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: B. Dr. Hallford.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The doctor's position is different.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
He entered Roe's litigation as a plaintiff-intervenor, alleging in his complaint that he:
"[I]n the past has been arrested for violating the Texas Abortion Laws and at the present time stands charged by indictment with violating said laws in the Criminal District Court of Dallas County, Texas to-wit: (1) The State of Texas vs. *126 James H. Hallford, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: C-69-5307-IH, and (2) The State of Texas vs. James H. Hallford, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In both cases the defendant is charged with abortion .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In his application for leave to intervene, the doctor made like representations as to the abortion charges pending in the state court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: These representations were also repeated in the affidavit he executed and filed in support of his motion for summary judgment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Dr. Hallford is, therefore, in the position of seeking, in a federal court, declaratory and injunctive relief with respect to the same statutes under which he stands charged in criminal prosecutions simultaneously pending in state court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Although he stated that he has been arrested in the past for violating the State's abortion laws, he makes no allegation of any substantial and immediate threat to any federally protected right that cannot be asserted in his defense against the state prosecutions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Neither is there any allegation of harassment or bad-faith prosecution.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In order to escape the rule articulated in the cases cited in the next paragraph of this opinion that, absent harassment and bad faith, a defendant in a pending state criminal case cannot affirmatively challenge in federal court the statutes under which the State is prosecuting him, Dr. Hallford seeks to distinguish his status as a present state defendant from his status as a "potential future defendant" and to assert only the latter for standing purposes here.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We see no merit in that distinction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Our decision in Samuels v. Mackell, 401 U.S. 66 (1971), compels the conclusion that the District Court erred when it granted declaratory relief to Dr. Hallford instead of refraining from so doing.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The court, of course, was correct in refusing to grant injunctive relief to the doctor.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The reasons supportive of that action, however, are those expressed in Samuels v. Mackell, supra, and in Younger v. *127 Harris, 401 U.S. 37 (1971); Boyle v. Landry, 401 U.S. 77 (1971); Perez v. Ledesma, 401 U.S. 82 (1971); and Byrne v. Karalexis, 401 U.S. 216 (1971).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: See also Dombrowski v. Pfister, 380 U.S. 479 (1965).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We note, in passing, that Younger and its companion cases were decided after the three-judge District Court decision in this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Dr. Hallford's complaint in intervention, therefore, is to be dismissed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [7] He is remitted to his defenses in the state criminal proceedings against him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We reverse the judgment of the District Court insofar as it granted Dr. Hallford relief and failed to dismiss his complaint in intervention.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: C. The Does.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In view of our ruling as to Roe's standing in her case, the issue of the Does' standing in their case has little significance.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The claims they assert are essentially the same as those of Roe, and they attack the same statutes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Nevertheless, we briefly note the Does' posture.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Their pleadings present them as a childless married couple, the woman not being pregnant, who have no desire to have children at this time because of their having received medical advice that Mrs. Doe should avoid pregnancy, and for "other highly personal reasons."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: But they "fear .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: they may face the prospect of becoming *128 parents."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: And if pregnancy ensues, they "would want to terminate" it by an abortion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: They assert an inability to obtain an abortion legally in Texas and, consequently, the prospect of obtaining an illegal abortion there or of going outside Texas to some place where the procedure could be obtained legally and competently.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We thus have as plaintiffs a married couple who have, as their asserted immediate and present injury, only an alleged "detrimental effect upon [their] marital happiness" because they are forced to "the choice of refraining from normal sexual relations or of endangering Mary Doe's health through a possible pregnancy."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Their claim is that sometime in the future Mrs. Doe might become pregnant because of possible failure of contraceptive measures, and at that time in the future she might want an abortion that might then be illegal under the Texas statutes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This very phrasing of the Does' position reveals its speculative character.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Their alleged injury rests on possible future contraceptive failure, possible future pregnancy, possible future unpreparedness for parenthood, and possible future impairment of health.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Any one or more of these several possibilities may not take place and all may not combine.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In the Does' estimation, these possibilities might have some real or imagined impact upon their marital happiness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: But we are not prepared to say that the bare allegation of so indirect an injury is sufficient to present an actual case or controversy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Younger v. Harris, 401 U. S., at 41-42; Golden v. Zwickler, 394 U. S., at 109-110; Abele v. Markle, 452 F. 2d, at 1124-1125; Crossen v. Breckenridge, 446 F. 2d, at 839.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Does' claim falls far short of those resolved otherwise in the cases that the Does urge upon us, namely, Investment Co. Institute v. Camp, 401 U.S. 617 (1971); Data Processing Service v. Camp, 397 U.S. 150 (1970); *129 and Epperson v. Arkansas, 393 U.S. 97 (1968).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: See also Truax v. Raich, 239 U.S. 33 (1915).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Does therefore are not appropriate plaintiffs in this litigation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Their complaint was properly dismissed by the District Court, and we affirm that dismissal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
V
The principal thrust of appellant's attack on the Texas statutes is that they improperly invade a right, said to be possessed by the pregnant woman, to choose to terminate her pregnancy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Appellant would discover this right in the concept of personal "liberty" embodied in the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause; or in personal, marital, familial, and sexual privacy said to be protected by the Bill of Rights or its penumbras, see Griswold v. Connecticut, 381 U.S. 479 (1965); Eisenstadt v. Baird, 405 U.S. 438 (1972); id., at 460 (WHITE, J., concurring in result); or among those rights reserved to the people by the Ninth Amendment, Griswold v. Connecticut, 381 U. S., at 486 (Goldberg, J., concurring).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Before addressing this claim, we feel it desirable briefly to survey, in several aspects, the history of abortion, for such insight as that history may afford us, and then to examine the state purposes and interests behind the criminal abortion laws.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
VI
It perhaps is not generally appreciated that the restrictive criminal abortion laws in effect in a majority of States today are of relatively recent vintage.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Those laws, generally proscribing abortion or its attempt at any time during pregnancy except when necessary to preserve the pregnant woman's life, are not of ancient or even of common-law origin.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Instead, they derive from statutory changes effected, for the most part, in the latter half of the 19th century.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Ancient attitudes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: These are not capable of precise determination.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We are told that at the time of the Persian Empire abortifacients were known and that criminal abortions were severely punished.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [8] We are also told, however, that abortion was practiced in Greek times as well as in the Roman Era,[9] and that "it was resorted to without scruple.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: "[10] The Ephesian, Soranos, often described as the greatest of the ancient gynecologists, appears to have been generally opposed to Rome's prevailing free-abortion practices.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: He found it necessary to think first of the life of the mother, and he resorted to abortion when, upon this standard, he felt the procedure advisable.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [11] Greek and Roman law afforded little protection to the unborn.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: If abortion was prosecuted in some places, it seems to have been based on a concept of a violation of the father's right to his offspring.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Ancient religion did not bar abortion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Hippocratic Oath.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: What then of the famous Oath that has stood so long as the ethical guide of the medical profession and that bears the name of the great Greek (460(?)-377(?)
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: B. C.), who has been described *131 as the Father of Medicine, the "wisest and the greatest practitioner of his art," and the "most important and most complete medical personality of antiquity," who dominated the medical schools of his time, and who typified the sum of the medical knowledge of the past?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [13] The Oath varies somewhat according to the particular translation, but in any translation the content is clear: "I will give no deadly medicine to anyone if asked, nor suggest any such counsel; and in like manner I will not give to a woman a pessary to produce abortion,"[14] or "I will neither give a deadly drug to anybody if asked for it, nor will I make a suggestion to this effect.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Similarly, I will not give to a woman an abortive remedy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
"[15]
Although the Oath is not mentioned in any of the principal briefs in this case or in Doe v. Bolton, post, p. 179, it represents the apex of the development of strict ethical concepts in medicine, and its influence endures to this day.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Why did not the authority of Hippocrates dissuade abortion practice in his time and that of Rome?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The late Dr. Edelstein provides us with a theory:[16] The Oath was not uncontested even in Hippocrates' day; only the Pythagorean school of philosophers frowned upon the related act of suicide.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Most Greek thinkers, on the other hand, commended abortion, at least prior to viability.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: See Plato, Republic, V, 461; Aristotle, Politics, VII, 1335b 25.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: For the Pythagoreans, however, it was a matter of dogma.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: For them the embryo was animate from the moment of conception, and abortion meant destruction of a living being.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The abortion clause of the Oath, therefore, "echoes Pythagorean doctrines," *132 and "[i]n no other stratum of Greek opinion were such views held or proposed in the same spirit of uncompromising austerity.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
"[17]
Dr. Edelstein then concludes that the Oath originated in a group representing only a small segment of Greek opinion and that it certainly was not accepted by all ancient physicians.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: He points out that medical writings down to Galen (A. D. 130-200) "give evidence of the violation of almost every one of its injunctions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: "[18] But with the end of antiquity a decided change took place.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Resistance against suicide and against abortion became common.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Oath came to be popular.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The emerging teachings of Christianity were in agreement with the Pythagorean ethic.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Oath "became the nucleus of all medical ethics" and "was applauded as the embodiment of truth."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Thus, suggests Dr. Edelstein, it is "a Pythagorean manifesto and not the expression of an absolute standard of medical conduct.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
"[19]
This, it seems to us, is a satisfactory and acceptable explanation of the Hippocratic Oath's apparent rigidity.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It enables us to understand, in historical context, a long-accepted and revered statement of medical ethics.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The common law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It is undisputed that at common law, abortion performed before "quickening" the first recognizable movement of the fetus in utero, appearing usually from the 16th to the 18th week of pregnancy[20]was not an indictable offense.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [21] The absence *133 of a common-law crime for pre-quickening abortion appears to have developed from a confluence of earlier philosophical, theological, and civil and canon law concepts of when life begins.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: These disciplines variously approached the question in terms of the point at which the embryo or fetus became "formed" or recognizably human, or in terms of when a "person" came into being, that is, infused with a "soul" or "animated."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: A loose consensus evolved in early English law that these events occurred at some point between conception and live birth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [22] This was "mediate animation."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Although *134 Christian theology and the canon law came to fix the point of animation at 40 days for a male and 80 days for a female, a view that persisted until the 19th century, there was otherwise little agreement about the precise time of formation or animation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: There was agreement, however, that prior to this point the fetus was to be regarded as part of the mother, and its destruction, therefore, was not homicide.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Due to continued uncertainty about the precise time when animation occurred, to the lack of any empirical basis for the 40-80-day view, and perhaps to Aquinas' definition of movement as one of the two first principles of life, Bracton focused upon quickening as the critical point.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The significance of quickening was echoed by later common-law scholars and found its way into the received common law in this country.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Whether abortion of a quick fetus was a felony at common law, or even a lesser crime, is still disputed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Bracton, writing early in the 13th century, thought it homicide.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [23] But the later and predominant view, following the great common-law scholars, has been that it was, at most, a lesser offense.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In a frequently cited *135 passage, Coke took the position that abortion of a woman "quick with childe" is "a great misprision, and no murder.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: "[24] Blackstone followed, saying that while abortion after quickening had once been considered manslaughter (though not murder), "modern law" took a less severe view.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [25] A recent review of the common-law precedents argues, however, that those precedents contradict Coke and that even post-quickening abortion was never established as a common-law crime.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [26] This is of some importance because while most American courts ruled, in holding or dictum, that abortion of an unquickened fetus was not criminal under their received common law,[27] others followed Coke in stating that abortion *136 of a quick fetus was a "misprision," a term they translated to mean "misdemeanor.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: "[28] That their reliance on Coke on this aspect of the law was uncritical and, apparently in all the reported cases, dictum (due probably to the paucity of common-law prosecutions for post-quickening abortion), makes it now appear doubtful that abortion was ever firmly established as a common-law crime even with respect to the destruction of a quick fetus.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The English statutory law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: England's first criminal abortion statute, Lord Ellenborough's Act, 43 Geo.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It made abortion of a quick fetus, § 1, a capital crime, but in § 2 it provided lesser penalties for the felony of abortion before quickening, and thus preserved the "quickening" distinction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This contrast was continued in the general revision of 1828, 9 Geo.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It disappeared, however, together with the death penalty, in 1837, 7 Will.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: § 6, and did not reappear in the Offenses Against the Person Act of 1861, 24 & 25 Vict., c. 100, § 59, that formed the core of English anti-abortion law until the liberalizing reforms of 1967.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In 1929, the Infant Life (Preservation) Act, 19 & 20 Geo.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 5, c. 34, came into being.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Its emphasis was upon the destruction of "the life of a child capable of being born alive."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It made a willful act performed with the necessary intent a felony.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It contained a proviso that one was not to be *137 found guilty of the offense "unless it is proved that the act which caused the death of the child was not done in good faith for the purpose only of preserving the life of the mother."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: A seemingly notable development in the English law was the case of Rex v. Bourne, [1939] 1 K. B.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This case apparently answered in the affirmative the question whether an abortion necessary to preserve the life of the pregnant woman was excepted from the criminal penalties of the 1861 Act.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In his instructions to the jury, Judge Macnaghten referred to the 1929 Act, and observed that that Act related to "the case where a child is killed by a wilful act at the time when it is being delivered in the ordinary course of nature."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Id., at 691.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: He concluded that the 1861 Act's use of the word "unlawfully," imported the same meaning expressed by the specific proviso in the 1929 Act, even though there was no mention of preserving the mother's life in the 1861 Act.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: He then construed the phrase "preserving the life of the mother" broadly, that is, "in a reasonable sense," to include a serious and permanent threat to the mother's health, and instructed the jury to acquit Dr. Bourne if it found he had acted in a good-faith belief that the abortion was necessary for this purpose.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The jury did acquit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Recently, Parliament enacted a new abortion law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This is the Abortion Act of 1967, 15 & 16 Eliz.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Act permits a licensed physician to perform an abortion where two other licensed physicians agree (a) "that the continuance of the pregnancy would involve risk to the life of the pregnant woman, or of injury to the physical or mental health of the pregnant woman or any existing children of her family, greater than if the pregnancy were terminated," or (b) "that there is a substantial risk that if the child were born it would suffer from such physical or mental abnormalities as *138 to be seriously handicapped."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Act also provides that, in making this determination, "account may be taken of the pregnant woman's actual or reasonably foreseeable environment."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It also permits a physician, without the concurrence of others, to terminate a pregnancy where he is of the good-faith opinion that the abortion "is immediately necessary to save the life or to prevent grave permanent injury to the physical or mental health of the pregnant woman."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The American law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In this country, the law in effect in all but a few States until mid-19th century was the pre-existing English common law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Connecticut, the first State to enact abortion legislation, adopted in 1821 that part of Lord Ellenborough's Act that related to a woman "quick with child.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: "[29] The death penalty was not imposed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Abortion before quickening was made a crime in that State only in 1860.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [30] In 1828, New York enacted legislation[31] that, in two respects, was to serve as a model for early anti-abortion statutes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: First, while barring destruction of an unquickened fetus as well as a quick fetus, it made the former only a misdemeanor, but the latter second-degree manslaughter.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Second, it incorporated a concept of therapeutic abortion by providing that an abortion was excused if it "shall have been necessary to preserve the life of such mother, or shall have been advised by two physicians to be necessary for such purpose."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: By 1840, when Texas had received the common law,[32] only eight American States *139 had statutes dealing with abortion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [33] It was not until after the War Between the States that legislation began generally to replace the common law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Most of these initial statutes dealt severely with abortion after quickening but were lenient with it before quickening.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Most punished attempts equally with completed abortions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: While many statutes included the exception for an abortion thought by one or more physicians to be necessary to save the mother's life, that provision soon disappeared and the typical law required that the procedure actually be necessary for that purpose.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Gradually, in the middle and late 19th century the quickening distinction disappeared from the statutory law of most States and the degree of the offense and the penalties were increased.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: By the end of the 1950's, a large majority of the jurisdictions banned abortion, however and whenever performed, unless done to save or preserve the life of the mother.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [34] The exceptions, Alabama and the District of Columbia, permitted abortion to preserve the mother's health.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [35] Three States permitted abortions that were not "unlawfully" performed or that were not "without lawful justification," leaving interpretation of those standards to the courts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [36] In *140 the past several years, however, a trend toward liberalization of abortion statutes has resulted in adoption, by about one-third of the States, of less stringent laws, most of them patterned after the ALI Model Penal Code, § 230.3,[37] set forth as Appendix B to the opinion in Doe v. Bolton, post, p. 205.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It is thus apparent that at common law, at the time of the adoption of our Constitution, and throughout the major portion of the 19th century, abortion was viewed with less disfavor than under most American statutes currently in effect.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Phrasing it another way, a woman enjoyed a substantially broader right to terminate a pregnancy than she does in most States today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: At least with respect to the early stage of pregnancy, and very possibly without such a limitation, the opportunity *141 to make this choice was present in this country well into the 19th century.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Even later, the law continued for some time to treat less punitively an abortion procured in early pregnancy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The position of the American Medical Association.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The anti-abortion mood prevalent in this country in the late 19th century was shared by the medical profession.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Indeed, the attitude of the profession may have played a significant role in the enactment of stringent criminal abortion legislation during that period.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: An AMA Committee on Criminal Abortion was appointed in May 1857.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It presented its report, 12 Trans.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 73-78 (1859), to the Twelfth Annual Meeting.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: That report observed that the Committee had been appointed to investigate criminal abortion "with a view to its general suppression."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
It deplored abortion and its frequency and it listed three causes of "this general demoralization":
"The first of these causes is a wide-spread popular ignorance of the true character of the crime a belief, even among mothers themselves, that the foetus is not alive till after the period of quickening.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: "The second of the agents alluded to is the fact that the profession themselves are frequently supposed careless of foetal life .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: "The third reason of the frightful extent of this crime is found in the grave defects of our laws, both common and statute, as regards the independent and actual existence of the child before birth, as a living being.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: These errors, which are sufficient in most instances to prevent conviction, are based, and only based, upon mistaken and exploded medical dogmas.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: With strange inconsistency, the law fully acknowledges the foetus in utero and its inherent rights, for civil purposes; while personally and as criminally affected, it fails to recognize it, *142 and to its life as yet denies all protection."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Committee then offered, and the Association adopted, resolutions protesting "against such unwarrantable destruction of human life," calling upon state legislatures to revise their abortion laws, and requesting the cooperation of state medical societies "in pressing the subject."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In 1871 a long and vivid report was submitted by the Committee on Criminal Abortion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It ended with the observation, "We had to deal with human life.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In a matter of less importance we could entertain no compromise.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: An honest judge on the bench would call things by their proper names.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We could do no less."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It proffered resolutions, adopted by the Association, id., at 38-39, recommending, among other things, that it "be unlawful and unprofessional for any physician to induce abortion or premature labor, without the concurrent opinion of at least one respectable consulting physician, and then always with a view to the safety of the child if that be possible," and calling "the attention of the clergy of all denominations to the perverted views of morality entertained by a large class of femalesaye, and men also, on this important question."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Except for periodic condemnation of the criminal abortionist, no further formal AMA action took place until 1967.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In that year, the Committee on Human Reproduction urged the adoption of a stated policy of opposition to induced abortion, except when there is "documented medical evidence" of a threat to the health or life of the mother, or that the child "may be born with incapacitating physical deformity or mental deficiency," or that a pregnancy "resulting from legally established statutory or forcible rape or incest may constitute a threat to the mental or physical health of the *143 patient," two other physicians "chosen because of their recognized professional competence have examined the patient and have concurred in writing," and the procedure "is performed in a hospital accredited by the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Hospitals."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The providing of medical information by physicians to state legislatures in their consideration of legislation regarding therapeutic abortion was "to be considered consistent with the principles of ethics of the American Medical Association."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This recommendation was adopted by the House of Delegates.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Proceedings of the AMA House of Delegates 40-51 (June 1967).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In 1970, after the introduction of a variety of proposed resolutions, and of a report from its Board of Trustees, a reference committee noted "polarization of the medical profession on this controversial issue"; division among those who had testified; a difference of opinion among AMA councils and committees; "the remarkable shift in testimony" in six months, felt to be influenced "by the rapid changes in state laws and by the judicial decisions which tend to make abortion more freely available;" and a feeling "that this trend will continue."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: On June 25, 1970, the House of Delegates adopted preambles and most of the resolutions proposed by the reference committee.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The preambles emphasized "the best interests of the patient," "sound clinical judgment," and "informed patient consent," in contrast to "mere acquiescence to the patient's demand."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The resolutions asserted that abortion is a medical procedure that should be performed by a licensed physician in an accredited hospital only after consultation with two other physicians and in conformity with state law, and that no party to the procedure should be required to violate personally held moral principles.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [38] Proceedings *144 of the AMA House of Delegates 220 (June 1970).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The AMA Judicial Council rendered a complementary opinion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The position of the American Public Health Association.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In October 1970, the Executive Board of the APHA adopted Standards for Abortion Services.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
These were five in number:
"a.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Rapid and simple abortion referral must be readily available through state and local public *145 health departments, medical societies, or other nonprofit organizations.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: An important function of counselling should be to simplify and expedite the provision of abortion services; it should not delay the obtaining of these services.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: "c. Psychiatric consultation should not be mandatory.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: As in the case of other specialized medical services, psychiatric consultation should be sought for definite indications and not on a routine basis.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: "d. A wide range of individuals from appropriately trained, sympathetic volunteers to highly skilled physicians may qualify as abortion counselors.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: "e. Contraception and/or sterilization should be discussed with each abortion patient."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Recommended Standards for Abortion Services, 61 Am.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
Among factors pertinent to life and health risks associated with abortion were three that "are recognized as important":
"a. the skill of the physician,
"b. the environment in which the abortion is performed, and above all
"c. the duration of pregnancy, as determined by uterine size and confirmed by menstrual history."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Id., at 397.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It was said that "a well-equipped hospital" offers more protection "to cope with unforeseen difficulties than an office or clinic without such resources.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The factor of gestational age is of overriding importance."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Thus, it was recommended that abortions in the second trimester and early abortions in the presence of existing medical complications be performed in hospitals as inpatient procedures.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: For pregnancies in the first trimester, *146 abortion in the hospital with or without overnight stay "is probably the safest practice."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: An abortion in an extramural facility, however, is an acceptable alternative "provided arrangements exist in advance to admit patients promptly if unforeseen complications develop."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Standards for an abortion facility were listed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It was said that at present abortions should be performed by physicians or osteopaths who are licensed to practice and who have "adequate training."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Id., at 398.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The position of the American Bar Association.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: At its meeting in February 1972 the ABA House of Delegates approved, with 17 opposing votes, the Uniform Abortion Act that had been drafted and approved the preceding August by the Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We set forth the Act in full in the margin.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [40] The *147 Conference has appended an enlightening Prefatory Note.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
[41]

VII
Three reasons have been advanced to explain historically the enactment of criminal abortion laws in the 19th century and to justify their continued existence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: *148 It has been argued occasionally that these laws were the product of a Victorian social concern to discourage illicit sexual conduct.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Texas, however, does not advance this justification in the present case, and it appears that no court or commentator has taken the argument seriously.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [42] The appellants and amici contend, moreover, that this is not a proper state purpose at all and suggest that, if it were, the Texas statutes are overbroad in protecting it since the law fails to distinguish between married and unwed mothers.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: A second reason is concerned with abortion as a medical procedure.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: When most criminal abortion laws were first enacted, the procedure was a hazardous one for the woman.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [43] This was particularly true prior to the *149 development of antisepsis.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Antiseptic techniques, of course, were based on discoveries by Lister, Pasteur, and others first announced in 1867, but were not generally accepted and employed until about the turn of the century.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Abortion mortality was high.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Even after 1900, and perhaps until as late as the development of antibiotics in the 1940's, standard modern techniques such as dilation and curettage were not nearly so safe as they are today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Thus, it has been argued that a State's real concern in enacting a criminal abortion law was to protect the pregnant woman, that is, to restrain her from submitting to a procedure that placed her life in serious jeopardy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Modern medical techniques have altered this situation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Appellants and various amici refer to medical data indicating that abortion in early pregnancy, that is, prior to the end of the first trimester, although not without its risk, is now relatively safe.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Mortality rates for women undergoing early abortions, where the procedure is legal, appear to be as low as or lower than the rates for normal childbirth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [44] Consequently, any interest of the State in protecting the woman from an inherently hazardous procedure, except when it would be equally dangerous for her to forgo it, has largely disappeared.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Of course, important state interests in the areas of health and medical standards do remain.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: *150 The State has a legitimate interest in seeing to it that abortion, like any other medical procedure, is performed under circumstances that insure maximum safety for the patient.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This interest obviously extends at least to the performing physician and his staff, to the facilities involved, to the availability of after-care, and to adequate provision for any complication or emergency that might arise.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The prevalence of high mortality rates at illegal "abortion mills" strengthens, rather than weakens, the State's interest in regulating the conditions under which abortions are performed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Moreover, the risk to the woman increases as her pregnancy continues.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Thus, the State retains a definite interest in protecting the woman's own health and safety when an abortion is proposed at a late stage of pregnancy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The third reason is the State's interestsome phrase it in terms of dutyin protecting prenatal life.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Some of the argument for this justification rests on the theory that a new human life is present from the moment of conception.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [45] The State's interest and general obligation to protect life then extends, it is argued, to prenatal life.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Only when the life of the pregnant mother herself is at stake, balanced against the life she carries within her, should the interest of the embryo or fetus not prevail.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Logically, of course, a legitimate state interest in this area need not stand or fall on acceptance of the belief that life begins at conception or at some other point prior to live birth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In assessing the State's interest, recognition may be given to the less rigid claim that as long as at least potential life is involved, the State may assert interests beyond the protection of the pregnant woman alone.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: *151 Parties challenging state abortion laws have sharply disputed in some courts the contention that a purpose of these laws, when enacted, was to protect prenatal life.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [46] Pointing to the absence of legislative history to support the contention, they claim that most state laws were designed solely to protect the woman.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Because medical advances have lessened this concern, at least with respect to abortion in early pregnancy, they argue that with respect to such abortions the laws can no longer be justified by any state interest.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: There is some scholarly support for this view of original purpose.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [47] The few state courts called upon to interpret their laws in the late 19th and early 20th centuries did focus on the State's interest in protecting the woman's health rather than in preserving the embryo and fetus.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [48] Proponents of this view point out that in many States, including Texas,[49] by statute or judicial interpretation, the pregnant woman herself could not be prosecuted for self-abortion or for cooperating in an abortion performed upon her by another.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [50] They claim that adoption of the "quickening" distinction through received common *152 law and state statutes tacitly recognizes the greater health hazards inherent in late abortion and impliedly repudiates the theory that life begins at conception.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It is with these interests, and the weight to be attached to them, that this case is concerned.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
VIII
The Constitution does not explicitly mention any right of privacy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In a line of decisions, however, going back perhaps as far as Union Pacific R. Co. v. Botsford, 141 U.S. 250, 251 (1891), the Court has recognized that a right of personal privacy, or a guarantee of certain areas or zones of privacy, does exist under the Constitution.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In varying contexts, the Court or individual Justices have, indeed, found at least the roots of that right in the First Amendment, Stanley v. Georgia, 394 U.S. 557, 564 (1969); in the Fourth and Fifth Amendments, Terry v. Ohio, 392 U.S. 1, 8-9 (1968), Katz v. United States, 389 U.S. 347, 350 (1967), Boyd v. United States, 116 U.S. 616 (1886), see Olmstead v. United States, 277 U.S. 438, 478 (1928) (Brandeis, J., dissenting); in the penumbras of the Bill of Rights, Griswold v. Connecticut, 381 U. S., at 484-485; in the Ninth Amendment, id., at 486 (Goldberg, J., concurring); or in the concept of liberty guaranteed by the first section of the Fourteenth Amendment, see Meyer v. Nebraska, 262 U.S. 390, 399 (1923).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: These decisions make it clear that only personal rights that can be deemed "fundamental" or "implicit in the concept of ordered liberty," Palko v. Connecticut, 302 U.S. 319, 325 (1937), are included in this guarantee of personal privacy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: They also make it clear that the right has some extension to activities relating to marriage, Loving v. Virginia, 388 U.S. 1, 12 (1967); procreation, Skinner v. Oklahoma, 316 U.S. 535, 541-542 (1942); contraception, Eisenstadt v. Baird, 405 U. S., at 453-454; id., at 460, 463-465 *153 (WHITE, J., concurring in result); family relationships, Prince v. Massachusetts, 321 U.S. 158, 166 (1944); and child rearing and education, Pierce v. Society of Sisters, 268 U.S. 510, 535 (1925), Meyer v. Nebraska, supra.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This right of privacy, whether it be founded in the Fourteenth Amendment's concept of personal liberty and restrictions upon state action, as we feel it is, or, as the District Court determined, in the Ninth Amendment's reservation of rights to the people, is broad enough to encompass a woman's decision whether or not to terminate her pregnancy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The detriment that the State would impose upon the pregnant woman by denying this choice altogether is apparent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Specific and direct harm medically diagnosable even in early pregnancy may be involved.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Maternity, or additional offspring, may force upon the woman a distressful life and future.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Psychological harm may be imminent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Mental and physical health may be taxed by child care.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: There is also the distress, for all concerned, associated with the unwanted child, and there is the problem of bringing a child into a family already unable, psychologically and otherwise, to care for it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In other cases, as in this one, the additional difficulties and continuing stigma of unwed motherhood may be involved.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: All these are factors the woman and her responsible physician necessarily will consider in consultation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: On the basis of elements such as these, appellant and some amici argue that the woman's right is absolute and that she is entitled to terminate her pregnancy at whatever time, in whatever way, and for whatever reason she alone chooses.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: With this we do not agree.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Appellant's arguments that Texas either has no valid interest at all in regulating the abortion decision, or no interest strong enough to support any limitation upon the woman's sole determination, are unpersuasive.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The *154 Court's decisions recognizing a right of privacy also acknowledge that some state regulation in areas protected by that right is appropriate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: As noted above, a State may properly assert important interests in safeguarding health, in maintaining medical standards, and in protecting potential life.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: At some point in pregnancy, these respective interests become sufficiently compelling to sustain regulation of the factors that govern the abortion decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The privacy right involved, therefore, cannot be said to be absolute.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In fact, it is not clear to us that the claim asserted by some amici that one has an unlimited right to do with one's body as one pleases bears a close relationship to the right of privacy previously articulated in the Court's decisions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Court has refused to recognize an unlimited right of this kind in the past.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Jacobson v. Massachusetts, 197 U.S. 11 (1905) (vaccination); Buck v. Bell, 274 U.S. 200 (1927) (sterilization).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We, therefore, conclude that the right of personal privacy includes the abortion decision, but that this right is not unqualified and must be considered against important state interests in regulation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We note that those federal and state courts that have recently considered abortion law challenges have reached the same conclusion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: A majority, in addition to the District Court in the present case, have held state laws unconstitutional, at least in part, because of vagueness or because of overbreadth and abridgment of rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Abele v. Markle, 342 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 800 (Conn. 1972), appeal docketed, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 72-56; Abele v. Markle, 351 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 224 (Conn. 1972), appeal docketed, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 72-730; Doe v. Bolton, 319 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 1048 (ND Ga. 1970), appeal decided today, post, p. 179; Doe v. Scott, 321 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 1385 (ND Ill. 1971), appeal docketed, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 70-105; Poe v. Menghini, 339 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 986 (Kan. 1972); YWCA v. Kugler, 342 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 1048 (NJ 1972); Babbitz v. McCann, *155 310 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 293 (ED Wis. 1970), appeal dismissed, 400 U.S. 1 (1970); People v. Belous, 71 Cal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: denied, 397 U.S. 915 (1970); State v. Barquet, 262 So.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Others have sustained state statutes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Crossen v. Attorney General, 344 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 587 (ED Ky. 1972), appeal docketed, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 72-256; Rosen v. Louisiana State Board of Medical Examiners, 318 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 1217 (ED La.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 1970), appeal docketed, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 70-42; Corkey v. Edwards, 322 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 1248 (WDNC 1971), appeal docketed, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 71-92; Steinberg v. Brown, 321 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 741 (ND Ohio 1970); Doe v. Rampton (Utah 1971), appeal docketed, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 71-5666; Cheaney v. State, ___ Ind.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 2d 876 (Miss.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 1972); State v. Munson, 86 S. D. 663, 201 N.W.2d 123 (1972), appeal docketed, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Although the results are divided, most of these courts have agreed that the right of privacy, however based, is broad enough to cover the abortion decision; that the right, nonetheless, is not absolute and is subject to some limitations; and that at some point the state interests as to protection of health, medical standards, and prenatal life, become dominant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
