text: We agree with this approach.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Where certain "fundamental rights" are involved, the Court has held that regulation limiting these rights may be justified only by a "compelling state interest," Kramer v. Union Free School District, 395 U.S. 621, 627 (1969); Shapiro v. Thompson, 394 U.S. 618, 634 (1969), Sherbert v. Verner, 374 U.S. 398, 406 (1963), and that legislative enactments must be narrowly drawn to express only the legitimate state interests at stake.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Griswold v. Connecticut, 381 U. S., at 485; Aptheker v. Secretary of State, 378 U.S. 500, 508 (1964); Cantwell v. Connecticut, 310 U.S. 296, 307-308 (1940); see *156 Eisenstadt v. Baird, 405 U. S., at 460, 463-464 (WHITE, J., concurring in result).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In the recent abortion cases, cited above, courts have recognized these principles.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Those striking down state laws have generally scrutinized the State's interests in protecting health and potential life, and have concluded that neither interest justified broad limitations on the reasons for which a physician and his pregnant patient might decide that she should have an abortion in the early stages of pregnancy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Courts sustaining state laws have held that the State's determinations to protect health or prenatal life are dominant and constitutionally justifiable.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
IX
The District Court held that the appellee failed to meet his burden of demonstrating that the Texas statute's infringement upon Roe's rights was necessary to support a compelling state interest, and that, although the appellee presented "several compelling justifications for state presence in the area of abortions," the statutes outstripped these justifications and swept "far beyond any areas of compelling state interest."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Appellant and appellee both contest that holding.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Appellant, as has been indicated, claims an absolute right that bars any state imposition of criminal penalties in the area.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Appellee argues that the State's determination to recognize and protect prenatal life from and after conception constitutes a compelling state interest.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: As noted above, we do not agree fully with either formulation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The appellee and certain amici argue that the fetus is a "person" within the language and meaning of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In support of this, they outline at length and in detail the well-known facts of fetal development.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: If this suggestion of personhood is established, the appellant's case, of course, collapses, *157 for the fetus' right to life would then be guaranteed specifically by the Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The appellant conceded as much on reargument.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [51] On the other hand, the appellee conceded on reargument[52] that no case could be cited that holds that a fetus is a person within the meaning of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Constitution does not define "person" in so many words.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Section 1 of the Fourteenth Amendment contains three references to "person."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The first, in defining "citizens," speaks of "persons born or naturalized in the United States."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The word also appears both in the Due Process Clause and in the Equal Protection Clause.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: "Person" is used in other places in the Constitution: in the listing of qualifications for Representatives and Senators, Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 2, and § 3, cl.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 3; in the Apportionment Clause, Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 3;[53] in the Migration and Importation provision, Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 1; in the Emolument Clause, Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 8; in the Electors provisions, Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: II, § 1, cl.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 2, and the superseded cl.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 3; in the provision outlining qualifications for the office of President, Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 5; in the Extradition provisions, Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: IV, § 2, cl.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 2, and the superseded Fugitive Slave Clause 3; and in the Fifth, Twelfth, and Twenty-second Amendments, as well as in §§ 2 and 3 of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: But in nearly all these instances, the use of the word is such that it has application only postnatally.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: None indicates, with any assurance, that it has any possible pre-natal application.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
[54]
*158 All this, together with our observation, supra, that throughout the major portion of the 19th century prevailing legal abortion practices were far freer than they are today, persuades us that the word "person," as used in the Fourteenth Amendment, does not include the unborn.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [55] This is in accord with the results reached in those few cases where the issue has been squarely presented.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: McGarvey v. Magee-Womens Hospital, 340 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 751 (WD Pa. 1972); Byrn v. New York City Health & Hospitals Corp., 31 N.Y. 2d 194, 286 N.E.2d 887 (1972), appeal docketed, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 72-434; Abele v. Markle, 351 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Cheaney v. State, ___ Ind., at ___, 285 N. E. 2d, at 270; Montana v. Rogers, 278 F.2d 68, 72 (CA7 1960), aff'd sub nom.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Montana v. Kennedy, 366 U.S. 308 (1961); Keeler v. Superior Court, 2 Cal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Indeed, our decision in United States v. Vuitch, 402 U.S. 62 (1971), inferentially is to the same effect, for we there would not have indulged in statutory interpretation favorable to abortion in specified circumstances if the necessary consequence was the termination of life entitled to Fourteenth Amendment protection.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This conclusion, however, does not of itself fully answer the contentions raised by Texas, and we pass on to other considerations.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The pregnant woman cannot be isolated in her privacy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: She carries an embryo and, later, a fetus, if one accepts the medical definitions of the developing young in the human uterus.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: See Dorland's Illustrated Medical Dictionary 478-479, 547 (24th ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The situation therefore is inherently different from marital intimacy, or bedroom possession of obscene material, or marriage, or procreation, or education, with which Eisenstadt and Griswold, Stanley, Loving, Skinner, and Pierce and Meyer were respectively concerned.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: As we have intimated above, it is reasonable and appropriate for a State to decide that at some point in time another interest, that of health of the mother or that of potential human life, becomes significantly involved.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The woman's privacy is no longer sole and any right of privacy she possesses must be measured accordingly.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Texas urges that, apart from the Fourteenth Amendment, life begins at conception and is present throughout pregnancy, and that, therefore, the State has a compelling interest in protecting that life from and after conception.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We need not resolve the difficult question of when life begins.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: When those trained in the respective disciplines of medicine, philosophy, and theology are unable to arrive at any consensus, the judiciary, at this point in the development of man's knowledge, is not in a position to speculate as to the answer.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: *160 It should be sufficient to note briefly the wide divergence of thinking on this most sensitive and difficult question.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: There has always been strong support for the view that life does not begin until live birth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This was the belief of the Stoics.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [56] It appears to be the predominant, though not the unanimous, attitude of the Jewish faith.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [57] It may be taken to represent also the position of a large segment of the Protestant community, insofar as that can be ascertained; organized groups that have taken a formal position on the abortion issue have generally regarded abortion as a matter for the conscience of the individual and her family.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [58] As we have noted, the common law found greater significance in quickening.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Physicians and their scientific colleagues have regarded that event with less interest and have tended to focus either upon conception, upon live birth, or upon the interim point at which the fetus becomes "viable," that is, potentially able to live outside the mother's womb, albeit with artificial aid.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [59] Viability is usually placed at about seven months (28 weeks) but may occur earlier, even at 24 weeks.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [60] The Aristotelian theory of "mediate animation," that held sway throughout the Middle Ages and the Renaissance in Europe, continued to be official Roman Catholic dogma until the 19th century, despite opposition to this "ensoulment" theory from those in the Church who would recognize the existence of life from *161 the moment of conception.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [61] The latter is now, of course, the official belief of the Catholic Church.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: As one brief amicus discloses, this is a view strongly held by many non-Catholics as well, and by many physicians.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Substantial problems for precise definition of this view are posed, however, by new embryological data that purport to indicate that conception is a "process" over time, rather than an event, and by new medical techniques such as menstrual extraction, the "morning-after" pill, implantation of embryos, artificial insemination, and even artificial wombs.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
[62]
In areas other than criminal abortion, the law has been reluctant to endorse any theory that life, as we recognize it, begins before live birth or to accord legal rights to the unborn except in narrowly defined situations and except when the rights are contingent upon live birth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: For example, the traditional rule of tort law denied recovery for prenatal injuries even though the child was born alive.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [63] That rule has been changed in almost every jurisdiction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In most States, recovery is said to be permitted only if the fetus was viable, or at least quick, when the injuries were sustained, though few *162 courts have squarely so held.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [64] In a recent development, generally opposed by the commentators, some States permit the parents of a stillborn child to maintain an action for wrongful death because of prenatal injuries.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [65] Such an action, however, would appear to be one to vindicate the parents' interest and is thus consistent with the view that the fetus, at most, represents only the potentiality of life.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Similarly, unborn children have been recognized as acquiring rights or interests by way of inheritance or other devolution of property, and have been represented by guardians ad litem.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [66] Perfection of the interests involved, again, has generally been contingent upon live birth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In short, the unborn have never been recognized in the law as persons in the whole sense.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
X
In view of all this, we do not agree that, by adopting one theory of life, Texas may override the rights of the pregnant woman that are at stake.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We repeat, however, that the State does have an important and legitimate interest in preserving and protecting the health of the pregnant woman, whether she be a resident of the State or a nonresident who seeks medical consultation and treatment there, and that it has still another important and legitimate interest in protecting the potentiality of human life.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: These interests are separate and distinct.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Each grows in substantiality as the woman approaches *163 term and, at a point during pregnancy, each becomes "compelling."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: With respect to the State's important and legitimate interest in the health of the mother, the "compelling" point, in the light of present medical knowledge, is at approximately the end of the first trimester.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This is so because of the now-established medical fact, referred to above at 149, that until the end of the first trimester mortality in abortion may be less than mortality in normal childbirth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: It follows that, from and after this point, a State may regulate the abortion procedure to the extent that the regulation reasonably relates to the preservation and protection of maternal health.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Examples of permissible state regulation in this area are requirements as to the qualifications of the person who is to perform the abortion; as to the licensure of that person; as to the facility in which the procedure is to be performed, that is, whether it must be a hospital or may be a clinic or some other place of less-than-hospital status; as to the licensing of the facility; and the like.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This means, on the other hand, that, for the period of pregnancy prior to this "compelling" point, the attending physician, in consultation with his patient, is free to determine, without regulation by the State, that, in his medical judgment, the patient's pregnancy should be terminated.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: If that decision is reached, the judgment may be effectuated by an abortion free of interference by the State.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: With respect to the State's important and legitimate interest in potential life, the "compelling" point is at viability.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This is so because the fetus then presumably has the capability of meaningful life outside the mother's womb.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: State regulation protective of fetal life after viability thus has both logical and biological justifications.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: If the State is interested in protecting fetal life after viability, it may go so far as to proscribe abortion *164 during that period, except when it is necessary to preserve the life or health of the mother.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Measured against these standards, Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 1196 of the Texas Penal Code, in restricting legal abortions to those "procured or attempted by medical advice for the purpose of saving the life of the mother," sweeps too broadly.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The statute makes no distinction between abortions performed early in pregnancy and those performed later, and it limits to a single reason, "saving" the mother's life, the legal justification for the procedure.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The statute, therefore, cannot survive the constitutional attack made upon it here.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: This conclusion makes it unnecessary for us to consider the additional challenge to the Texas statute asserted on grounds of vagueness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: See United States v. Vuitch, 402 U. S., at 67-72.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
XI
To summarize and to repeat:
1.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: A state criminal abortion statute of the current Texas type, that excepts from criminality only a life-saving procedure on behalf of the mother, without regard to pregnancy stage and without recognition of the other interests involved, is violative of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: (a) For the stage prior to approximately the end of the first trimester, the abortion decision and its effectuation must be left to the medical judgment of the pregnant woman's attending physician.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: (b) For the stage subsequent to approximately the end of the first trimester, the State, in promoting its interest in the health of the mother, may, if it chooses, regulate the abortion procedure in ways that are reasonably related to maternal health.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: (c) For the stage subsequent to viability, the State in promoting its interest in the potentiality of human life *165 may, if it chooses, regulate, and even proscribe, abortion except where it is necessary, in appropriate medical judgment, for the preservation of the life or health of the mother.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The State may define the term "physician," as it has been employed in the preceding paragraphs of this Part XI of this opinion, to mean only a physician currently licensed by the State, and may proscribe any abortion by a person who is not a physician as so defined.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In Doe v. Bolton, post, p. 179, procedural requirements contained in one of the modern abortion statutes are considered.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: That opinion and this one, of course, are to be read together.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
[67]
This holding, we feel, is consistent with the relative weights of the respective interests involved, with the lessons and examples of medical and legal history, with the lenity of the common law, and with the demands of the profound problems of the present day.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The decision leaves the State free to place increasing restrictions on abortion as the period of pregnancy lengthens, so long as those restrictions are tailored to the recognized state interests.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The decision vindicates the right of the physician to administer medical treatment according to his professional judgment up to the points where important *166 state interests provide compelling justifications for intervention.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Up to those points, the abortion decision in all its aspects is inherently, and primarily, a medical decision, and basic responsibility for it must rest with the physician.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: If an individual practitioner abuses the privilege of exercising proper medical judgment, the usual remedies, judicial and intra-professional, are available.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text:
XII
Our conclusion that Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 1196 is unconstitutional means, of course, that the Texas abortion statutes, as a unit, must fall.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The exception of Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: 1196 cannot be struck down separately, for then the State would be left with a statute proscribing all abortion procedures no matter how medically urgent the case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Although the District Court granted appellant Roe declaratory relief, it stopped short of issuing an injunction against enforcement of the Texas statutes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Court has recognized that different considerations enter into a federal court's decision as to declaratory relief, on the one hand, and injunctive relief, on the other.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Zwickler v. Koota, 389 U.S. 241, 252-255 (1967); Dombrowski v. Pfister, 380 U.S. 479 (1965).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We are not dealing with a statute that, on its face, appears to abridge free expression, an area of particular concern under Dombrowski and refined in Younger v. Harris, 401 U. S., at 50.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: We find it unnecessary to decide whether the District Court erred in withholding injunctive relief, for we assume the Texas prosecutorial authorities will give full credence to this decision that the present criminal abortion statutes of that State are unconstitutional.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The judgment of the District Court as to intervenor Hallford is reversed, and Dr. Hallford's complaint in intervention is dismissed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: In all other respects, the judgment *167 of the District Court is affirmed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Costs are allowed to the appellee.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [For concurring opinion of MR. CHIEF JUSTICE BURGER, see post, p.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [For concurring opinion of MR. JUSTICE DOUGLAS, see post, p.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: [For dissenting opinion of MR. JUSTICE WHITE, see post, p.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: In 1963, this Court, in Ferguson v. Skrupa, 372 U.S. 726, purported to sound the death knell for the doctrine of substantive due process, a doctrine under which many state laws had in the past been held to violate the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: As Mr. Justice Black's opinion for the Court in Skrupa put it: "We have returned to the original constitutional proposition that courts do not substitute their social and economic beliefs for the judgment of legislative bodies, who are elected to pass laws."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: Id., at 730.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text:
[1]
Barely two years later, in Griswold v. Connecticut, 381 U.S. 479, the Court held a Connecticut birth control law unconstitutional.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: In view of what had been so recently said in Skrupa, the Court's opinion in Griswold understandably did its best to avoid reliance on the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment as the ground for decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: Yet, the Connecticut law did not violate any provision of the Bill of Rights, nor any other specific provision of the Constitution.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: [2] So it was clear *168 to me then, and it is equally clear to me now, that the Griswold decision can be rationally understood only as a holding that the Connecticut statute substantively invaded the "liberty" that is protected by the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: [3] As so understood, Griswold stands as one in a long line of pre-Skrupa cases decided under the doctrine of substantive due process, and I now accept it as such.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: "In a Constitution for a free people, there can be no doubt that the meaning of `liberty' must be broad indeed."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: Board of Regents v. Roth, 408 U.S. 564, 572.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: The Constitution nowhere mentions a specific right of personal choice in matters of marriage and family life, but the "liberty" protected by the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment covers more than those freedoms explicitly named in the Bill of Rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: See Schware v. Board of Bar Examiners, 353 U.S. 232, 238-239; Pierce v. Society of Sisters, 268 U.S. 510, 534-535; Meyer v. Nebraska, 262 U.S. 390, 399-400.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: Shapiro v. Thompson, 394 U.S. 618, 629-630; United States v. Guest, 383 U.S. 745, 757-758; Carrington v. Rash, 380 U.S. 89, 96; Aptheker v. Secretary of State, 378 U.S. 500, 505; Kent v. Dulles, 357 U.S. 116, 127; Bolling v. Sharpe, 347 U.S. 497, 499-500; Truax v. Raich, 239 U.S. 33, 41.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: *169 As Mr. Justice Harlan once wrote: "[T]he full scope of the liberty guaranteed by the Due Process Clause cannot be found in or limited by the precise terms of the specific guarantees elsewhere provided in the Constitution.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: This `liberty' is not a series of isolated points pricked out in terms of the taking of property; the freedom of speech, press, and religion; the right to keep and bear arms; the freedom from unreasonable searches and seizures; and so on.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: It is a rational continuum which, broadly speaking, includes a freedom from all substantial arbitrary impositions and purposeless restraints.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: and which also recognizes, what a reasonable and sensitive judgment must, that certain interests require particularly careful scrutiny of the state needs asserted to justify their abridgment."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: Poe v. Ullman, 367 U.S. 497, 543 (opinion dissenting from dismissal of appeal) (citations omitted).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: In the words of Mr. Justice Frankfurter, "Great concepts like .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: `liberty' .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: were purposely left to gather meaning from experience.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: For they relate to the whole domain of social and economic fact, and the statesmen who founded this Nation knew too well that only a stagnant society remains unchanged."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: National Mutual Ins.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: Co. v. Tidewater Transfer Co., 337 U.S. 582, 646 (dissenting opinion).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: Several decisions of this Court make clear that freedom of personal choice in matters of marriage and family life is one of the liberties protected by the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: Loving v. Virginia, 388 U.S. 1, 12; Griswold v. Connecticut, supra; Pierce v. Society of Sisters, supra; Meyer v. Nebraska, supra.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: See also Prince v. Massachusetts, 321 U.S. 158, 166; Skinner v. Oklahoma, 316 U.S. 535, 541.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: As recently as last Term, in Eisenstadt v. Baird, 405 U.S. 438, 453, we recognized "the right of the individual, married or single, to be free from unwarranted governmental intrusion into matters so fundamentally affecting a person *170 as the decision whether to bear or beget a child."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: That right necessarily includes the right of a woman to decide whether or not to terminate her pregnancy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: "Certainly the interests of a woman in giving of her physical and emotional self during pregnancy and the interests that will be affected throughout her life by the birth and raising of a child are of a far greater degree of significance and personal intimacy than the right to send a child to private school protected in Pierce v. Society of Sisters, 268 U.S. 510 (1925), or the right to teach a foreign language protected in Meyer v. Nebraska, 262 U.S. 390 (1923)."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: Abele v. Markle, 351 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: Clearly, therefore, the Court today is correct in holding that the right asserted by Jane Roe is embraced within the personal liberty protected by the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: It is evident that the Texas abortion statute infringes that right directly.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: Indeed, it is difficult to imagine a more complete abridgment of a constitutional freedom than that worked by the inflexible criminal statute now in force in Texas.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: The question then becomes whether the state interests advanced to justify this abridgment can survive the "particularly careful scrutiny" that the Fourteenth Amendment here requires.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: The asserted state interests are protection of the health and safety of the pregnant woman, and protection of the potential future human life within her.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: These are legitimate objectives, amply sufficient to permit a State to regulate abortions as it does other surgical procedures, and perhaps sufficient to permit a State to regulate abortions more stringently or even to prohibit them in the late stages of pregnancy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: But such legislation is not before us, and I think the Court today has thoroughly demonstrated that these state interests cannot constitutionally support the broad abridgment of personal *171 liberty worked by the existing Texas law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stewart
text: Accordingly, I join the Court's opinion holding that that law is invalid under the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The Court's opinion brings to the decision of this troubling question both extensive historical fact and a wealth of legal scholarship.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: While the opinion thus commands my respect, I find myself nonetheless in fundamental disagreement with those parts of it that invalidate the Texas statute in question, and therefore dissent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text:
I
The Court's opinion decides that a State may impose virtually no restriction on the performance of abortions during the first trimester of pregnancy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Our previous decisions indicate that a necessary predicate for such an opinion is a plaintiff who was in her first trimester of pregnancy at some time during the pendency of her law-suit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: While a party may vindicate his own constitutional rights, he may not seek vindication for the rights of others.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Moose Lodge v. Irvis, 407 U.S. 163 (1972); Sierra Club v. Morton, 405 U.S. 727 (1972).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The Court's statement of facts in this case makes clear, however, that the record in no way indicates the presence of such a plaintiff.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: We know only that plaintiff Roe at the time of filing her complaint was a pregnant woman; for aught that appears in this record, she may have been in her last trimester of pregnancy as of the date the complaint was filed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Nothing in the Court's opinion indicates that Texas might not constitutionally apply its proscription of abortion as written to a woman in that stage of pregnancy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Nonetheless, the Court uses her complaint against the Texas statute as a fulcrum for deciding that States may *172 impose virtually no restrictions on medical abortions performed during the first trimester of pregnancy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: In deciding such a hypothetical lawsuit, the Court departs from the longstanding admonition that it should never "formulate a rule of constitutional law broader than is required by the precise facts to which it is to be applied."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist

author: Justice Rehnquist

II
Even if there were a plaintiff in this case capable of litigating the issue which the Court decides, I would reach a conclusion opposite to that reached by the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: I have difficulty in concluding, as the Court does, that the right of "privacy" is involved in this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Texas, by the statute here challenged, bars the performance of a medical abortion by a licensed physician on a plaintiff such as Roe.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: A transaction resulting in an operation such as this is not "private" in the ordinary usage of that word.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Nor is the "privacy" that the Court finds here even a distant relative of the freedom from searches and seizures protected by the Fourth Amendment to the Constitution, which the Court has referred to as embodying a right to privacy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Katz v. United States, 389 U.S. 347 (1967).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: If the Court means by the term "privacy" no more than that the claim of a person to be free from unwanted state regulation of consensual transactions may be a form of "liberty" protected by the Fourteenth Amendment, there is no doubt that similar claims have been upheld in our earlier decisions on the basis of that liberty.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: I agree with the statement of MR. JUSTICE STEWART in his concurring opinion that the "liberty," against deprivation of which without due process the Fourteenth *173 Amendment protects, embraces more than the rights found in the Bill of Rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: But that liberty is not guaranteed absolutely against deprivation, only against deprivation without due process of law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The test traditionally applied in the area of social and economic legislation is whether or not a law such as that challenged has a rational relation to a valid state objective.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Williamson v. Lee Optical Co., 348 U.S. 483, 491 (1955).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment undoubtedly does place a limit, albeit a broad one, on legislative power to enact laws such as this.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: If the Texas statute were to prohibit an abortion even where the mother's life is in jeopardy, I have little doubt that such a statute would lack a rational relation to a valid state objective under the test stated in Williamson, supra.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: But the Court's sweeping invalidation of any restrictions on abortion during the first trimester is impossible to justify under that standard, and the conscious weighing of competing factors that the Court's opinion apparently substitutes for the established test is far more appropriate to a legislative judgment than to a judicial one.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The Court eschews the history of the Fourteenth Amendment in its reliance on the "compelling state interest" test.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: See Weber v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Co., 406 U.S. 164, 179 (1972) (dissenting opinion).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: But the Court adds a new wrinkle to this test by transposing it from the legal considerations associated with the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to this case arising under the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Unless I misapprehend the consequences of this transplanting of the "compelling state interest test," the Court's opinion will accomplish the seemingly impossible feat of leaving this area of the law more confused than it found it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: *174 While the Court's opinion quotes from the dissent of Mr. Justice Holmes in Lochner v. New York, 198 U.S. 45, 74 (1905), the result it reaches is more closely attuned to the majority opinion of Mr. Justice Peckham in that case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: As in Lochner and similar cases applying substantive due process standards to economic and social welfare legislation, the adoption of the compelling state interest standard will inevitably require this Court to examine the legislative policies and pass on the wisdom of these policies in the very process of deciding whether a particular state interest put forward may or may not be "compelling."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The decision here to break pregnancy into three distinct terms and to outline the permissible restrictions the State may impose in each one, for example, partakes more of judicial legislation than it does of a determination of the intent of the drafters of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The fact that a majority of the States reflecting, after all, the majority sentiment in those States, have had restrictions on abortions for at least a century is a strong indication, it seems to me, that the asserted right to an abortion is not "so rooted in the traditions and conscience of our people as to be ranked as fundamental," Snyder v. Massachusetts, 291 U.S. 97, 105 (1934).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Even today, when society's views on abortion are changing, the very existence of the debate is evidence that the "right" to an abortion is not so universally accepted as the appellant would have us believe.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: To reach its result, the Court necessarily has had to find within the scope of the Fourteenth Amendment a right that was apparently completely unknown to the drafters of the Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: As early as 1821, the first state law dealing directly with abortion was enacted by the Connecticut Legislature.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Stat., Tit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: By the time of the adoption of the Fourteenth *175 Amendment in 1868, there were at least 36 laws enacted by state or territorial legislatures limiting abortion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: [1] While many States have amended or updated *176 their laws, 21 of the laws on the books in 1868 remain in effect today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: [2] Indeed, the Texas statute struck down today was, as the majority notes, first enacted in 1857 *177 and "has remained substantially unchanged to the present time."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Ante, at 119.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: There apparently was no question concerning the validity of this provision or of any of the other state statutes when the Fourteenth Amendment was adopted.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The only conclusion possible from this history is that the drafters did not intend to have the Fourteenth Amendment withdraw from the States the power to legislate with respect to this matter.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text:
III
Even if one were to agree that the case that the Court decides were here, and that the enunciation of the substantive constitutional law in the Court's opinion were proper, the actual disposition of the case by the Court is still difficult to justify.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The Texas statute is struck down in toto, even though the Court apparently concedes that at later periods of pregnancy Texas might impose these selfsame statutory limitations on abortion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: My understanding of past practice is that a statute found *178 to be invalid as applied to a particular plaintiff, but not unconstitutional as a whole, is not simply "struck down" but is, instead, declared unconstitutional as applied to the fact situation before the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Yick Wo v. Hopkins, 118 U.S. 356 (1886); Street v. New York, 394 U.S. 576 (1969).

author: Justice Rehnquist

Before the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act of 2002 (BCRA), federal law prohibitedand still does prohibit corporations and unions from using general treasury funds to make direct contributions to candidates or independent expenditures that expressly advocate the election or defeat of a candidate, through any form of media, in connection with certain qualified federal elections.

PACs must file detailed monthly reports with the FEC, which are due at different times depending on the type of election that is about to occur:
"`These reports must contain information regarding the amount of cash on hand; the total amount of receipts, detailed by 10 different categories; the identification of each political committee and candidate's authorized or affiliated committee making contributions, and any persons making loans, providing rebates, refunds, dividends, or interest or any other offset to operating expenditures in an aggregate amount over $200; the total amount of all disbursements, detailed by 12 different categories; the names of all authorized or affiliated committees to whom expenditures aggregating over $200 have been made; persons to whom loan repayments or refunds have been made; the total sum of all contributions, operating expenses, outstanding debts and obligations, and the settlement terms of the retirement of any debt or obligation.'"
