case: Citizens United v. Federal Election Com'n
text: Doing so would undermine the rule-of-law values that justify stare decisis in the first place.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Roberts
case: Citizens United v. Federal Election Com'n
text: It would effectively license the Court to invent and adopt new principles of constitutional law solely for the purpose of rationalizing its past errors, without a proper analysis of whether those principles have merit on their own.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Roberts
case: Citizens United v. Federal Election Com'n
text: This approach would allow the Court's past missteps to spawn future mistakes, undercutting the very rule-of-law values that stare decisis is designed to protect.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Roberts
case: Citizens United v. Federal Election Com'n
text: None of this is to say that the Government is barred from making new arguments to support the outcome in Austin.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Roberts
case: Citizens United v. Federal Election Com'n
text: On the contrary, it is free to do so.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Roberts
case: Citizens United v. Federal Election Com'n
text: And of course the Court is free to accept them.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Roberts
case: Citizens United v. Federal Election Com'n
text: But the Government's new arguments must stand or fall on their own; they are not entitled to receive the special deference we accord to precedent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Roberts
case: Citizens United v. Federal Election Com'n
text: They are, as grounds to support Austin, literally unprecedented.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Roberts
case: Citizens United v. Federal Election Com'n
text: Moreover, to the extent the Government relies on new arguments and declines to defend Austin on its own termswe may reasonably infer that it lacks confidence in that decision's original justification.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Roberts
case: Citizens United v. Federal Election Com'n
text: Because continued adherence to Austin threatens to subvert the "principled and intelligible" development of our First Amendment jurisprudence, Vasquez, 474 U.S., at 265, 106 S. Ct. 617, I support the Court's determination to overrule that decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Roberts
case: Citizens United v. Federal Election Com'n
text:
* * *
We have had two rounds of briefing in this case, two oral arguments, and 54 amicus *925 briefs to help us carry out our obligation to decide the necessary constitutional questions according to law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Roberts
case: Citizens United v. Federal Election Com'n
text: We have also had the benefit of a comprehensive dissent that has helped ensure that the Court has considered all the relevant issues.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Roberts
case: Citizens United v. Federal Election Com'n
text: This careful consideration convinces me that Congress violates the First Amendment when it decrees that some speakers may not engage in political speech at election time, when it matters most.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: On December 8, 2000, the Supreme Court of Florida ordered that the Circuit Court of Leon County tabulate by hand 9,000 ballots in Miami-Dade County.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: It also ordered the inclusion in the certified vote totals of 215 votes identified in Palm Beach County and 168 votes identified in Miami-Dade County for Vice President Albert Gore, Jr., and Senator Joseph Lieberman, Democratic candidates for President and Vice President.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The State Supreme Court noted that petitioner George W. Bush asserted that the net gain for Vice President Gore in Palm Beach County was 176 votes, and directed the Circuit Court to resolve that dispute on remand.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Gore v. Harris, 772 So.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The court further held that relief would require manual recounts in all Florida counties where so-called "undervotes" had not been subject to manual tabulation.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The court ordered all manual recounts to begin at once.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Governor Bush and Richard Cheney, Republican candidates for President and Vice President, filed an emergency application for a stay of this mandate.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: On December 9, we granted the application, treated the application as a petition for a writ of certiorari, and granted certiorari.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Post, p. 1046.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The proceedings leading to the present controversy are discussed in some detail in our opinion in Bush v. Palm Beach County Canvassing Bd., ante, p. 70 (per curiam) (Bush I).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: On November 8, 2000, the day following the Presidential election, the Florida Division of Elections reported that petitioner Bush had received 2,909,135 votes, and respondent Gore had received 2,907,351 votes, a margin of *101 1,784 for Governor Bush.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Because Governor Bush's margin of victory was less than "one-half of a percent .
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: of the votes cast," an automatic machine recount was conducted under § 102.141(4) of the Florida Election Code, the results of which showed Governor Bush still winning the race but by a diminished margin.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Vice President Gore then sought manual recounts in Volusia, Palm Beach, Broward, and Miami-Dade Counties, pursuant to Florida's election protest provisions.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: A dispute arose concerning the deadline for local county canvassing boards to submit their returns to the Secretary of State (Secretary).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Secretary declined to waive the November 14 deadline imposed by statute.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Florida Supreme Court, however, set the deadline at November 26.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: We granted certiorari and vacated the Florida Supreme Court's decision, finding considerable uncertainty as to the grounds on which it was based.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Bush I, ante, at 78.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: On December 11, the Florida Supreme Court issued a decision on remand reinstating that date.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Palm Beach County Canvassing Bd.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: v. Harris, 772 So.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: On November 26, the Florida Elections Canvassing Commission certified the results of the election and declared Governor Bush the winner of Florida's 25 electoral votes.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: On November 27, Vice President Gore, pursuant to Florida's contest provisions, filed a complaint in Leon County Circuit Court contesting the certification.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: He sought relief pursuant to § 102.168(3)(c), which provides that "[r]eceipt of a number of illegal votes or rejection of a number of legal votes sufficient to change or place in doubt the result of the election" shall be grounds for a contest.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Circuit Court denied relief, stating that Vice President Gore failed to meet his burden of proof.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: He appealed to the First District Court of Appeal, which certified the matter to the Florida Supreme Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Accepting jurisdiction, the Florida Supreme Court affirmed in part and reversed in part.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Gore v. Harris, 772 *102 So.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The court held that the Circuit Court had been correct to reject Vice President Gore's challenge to the results certified in Nassau County and his challenge to the Palm Beach County Canvassing Board's determination that 3,300 ballots cast in that county were not, in the statutory phrase, "legal votes."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Supreme Court held that Vice President Gore had satisfied his burden of proof under § 102.168(3)(c) with respect to his challenge to Miami-Dade County's failure to tabulate, by manual count, 9,000 ballots on which the machines had failed to detect a vote for President ("undervotes").
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Noting the closeness of the election, the court explained that "[o]n this record, there can be no question that there are legal votes within the 9,000 uncounted votes sufficient to place the results of this election in doubt."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: A "legal vote," as determined by the Supreme Court, is "one in which there is a `clear indication of the intent of the voter.'
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The court therefore ordered a hand recount of the 9,000 ballots in Miami-Dade County.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Observing that the contest provisions vest broad discretion in the circuit judge to "provide any relief appropriate under such circumstances," § 102.168(8), the Supreme Court further held that the Circuit Court could order "the Supervisor of Elections and the Canvassing Boards, as well as the necessary public officials, in all counties that have not conducted a manual recount or tabulation of the undervotes .
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: to do so forthwith, said tabulation to take place in the individual counties where the ballots are located."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Supreme Court also determined that Palm Beach County and Miami-Dade County, in their earlier manual recounts, had identified a net gain of 215 and 168 legal votes, respectively, for Vice President Gore.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Rejecting the Circuit Court's conclusion that Palm Beach County lacked the authority to include the 215 net votes submitted *103 past the November 26 deadline, the Supreme Court explained that the deadline was not intended to exclude votes identified after that date through ongoing manual recounts.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: As to Miami-Dade County, the court concluded that although the 168 votes identified were the result of a partial recount, they were "legal votes [that] could change the outcome of the election."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Supreme Court therefore directed the Circuit Court to include those totals in the certified results, subject to resolution of the actual vote total from the Miami-Dade partial recount.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The petition presents the following questions: whether the Florida Supreme Court established new standards for resolving Presidential election contests, thereby violating Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: 2, of the United States Constitution and failing to comply with 3 U.S. C. § 5, and whether the use of standardless manual recounts violates the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: With respect to the equal protection question, we find a violation of the Equal Protection Clause.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text:
II

A
The closeness of this election, and the multitude of legal challenges which have followed in its wake, have brought into sharp focus a common, if heretofore unnoticed, phenomenon.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Nationwide statistics reveal that an estimated 2% of ballots cast do not register a vote for President for whatever reason, including deliberately choosing no candidate at all or some voter error, such as voting for two candidates or insufficiently marking a ballot.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: See Ho, More Than 2M Ballots Uncounted, AP Online (Nov. 28, 2000); Kelley, Balloting Problems Not Rare But Only in a Very Close Election Do Mistakes and Mismarking Make a Difference, Omaha World-Herald (Nov. 15, 2000).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: In certifying election results, the votes eligible for inclusion in the certification are the votes meeting the properly established legal requirements.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: *104 This case has shown that punchcard balloting machines can produce an unfortunate number of ballots which are not punched in a clean, complete way by the voter.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: After the current counting, it is likely legislative bodies nationwide will examine ways to improve the mechanisms and machinery for voting.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text:
B
The individual citizen has no federal constitutional right to vote for electors for the President of the United States unless and until the state legislature chooses a statewide election as the means to implement its power to appoint members of the electoral college.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Const., Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: This is the source for the statement in McPherson v. Blacker, 146 U.S. 1, 35 (1892), that the state legislature's power to select the manner for appointing electors is plenary; it may, if it so chooses, select the electors itself, which indeed was the manner used by state legislatures in several States for many years after the framing of our Constitution.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: History has now favored the voter, and in each of the several States the citizens themselves vote for Presidential electors.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: When the state legislature vests the right to vote for President in its people, the right to vote as the legislature has prescribed is fundamental; and one source of its fundamental nature lies in the equal weight accorded to each vote and the equal dignity owed to each voter.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The State, of course, after granting the franchise in the special context of Article II, can take back the power to appoint electors.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: See id., at 35 ("`[T]here is no doubt of the right of the legislature to resume the power at any time, for it can neither be taken away nor abdicated' ") (quoting S. Rep. No.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The right to vote is protected in more than the initial allocation of the franchise.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Equal protection applies as well to the manner of its exercise.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Having once granted the right to vote on equal terms, the State may not, by later arbitrary and disparate treatment, value one person's vote over that *105 of another.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: See, e. g., Harper v. Virginia Bd.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: of Elections,  383 U.S. 663, 665 (1966) ("[O]nce the franchise is granted to the electorate, lines may not be drawn which are inconsistent with the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment").
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: It must be remembered that "the right of suffrage can be denied by a debasement or dilution of the weight of a citizen's vote just as effectively as by wholly prohibiting the free exercise of the franchise."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U.S. 533, 555 (1964).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: There is no difference between the two sides of the present controversy on these basic propositions.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Respondents say that the very purpose of vindicating the right to vote justifies the recount procedures now at issue.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The question before us, however, is whether the recount procedures the Florida Supreme Court has adopted are consistent with its obligation to avoid arbitrary and disparate treatment of the members of its electorate.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Much of the controversy seems to revolve around ballot cards designed to be perforated by a stylus but which, either through error or deliberate omission, have not been perforated with sufficient precision for a machine to register the perforations.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: In some cases a piece of the carda chadis hanging, say, by two corners.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: In other cases there is no separation at all, just an indentation.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Florida Supreme Court has ordered that the intent of the voter be discerned from such ballots.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: For purposes of resolving the equal protection challenge, it is not necessary to decide whether the Florida Supreme Court had the authority under the legislative scheme for resolving election disputes to define what a legal vote is and to mandate a manual recount implementing that definition.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The recount mechanisms implemented in response to the decisions of the Florida Supreme Court do not satisfy the minimum requirement for nonarbitrary treatment of voters necessary to secure the fundamental right.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Florida's basic command for the count of legally cast votes is to consider the "intent of *106 the voter."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: This is unobjectionable as an abstract proposition and a starting principle.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The problem inheres in the absence of specific standards to ensure its equal application.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The formulation of uniform rules to determine intent based on these recurring circumstances is practicable and, we conclude, necessary.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The law does not refrain from searching for the intent of the actor in a multitude of circumstances; and in some cases the general command to ascertain intent is not susceptible to much further refinement.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: In this instance, however, the question is not whether to believe a witness but how to interpret the marks or holes or scratches on an inanimate object, a piece of cardboard or paper which, it is said, might not have registered as a vote during the machine count.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The factfinder confronts a thing, not a person.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The search for intent can be confined by specific rules designed to ensure uniform treatment.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The want of those rules here has led to unequal evaluation of ballots in various respects.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: See id., at 1267 (Wells, C. J., dissenting) ("Should a county canvassing board count or not count a `dimpled chad' where the voter is able to successfully dislodge the chad in every other contest on that ballot?
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Here, the county canvassing boards disagree").
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: As seems to have been acknowledged at oral argument, the standards for accepting or rejecting contested ballots might vary not only from county to county but indeed within a single county from one recount team to another.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The record provides some examples.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: A monitor in Miami-Dade County testified at trial that he observed that three members of the county canvassing board applied different standards in defining a legal vote.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: And testimony at trial also revealed that at least one county changed its evaluative standards during the counting process.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Palm Beach County, for example, began the process with a 1990 guideline which precluded counting completely attached chads, switched to a rule that considered *107 a vote to be legal if any light could be seen through a chad, changed back to the 1990 rule, and then abandoned any pretense of a per se rule, only to have a court order that the county consider dimpled chads legal.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: This is not a process with sufficient guarantees of equal treatment.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: An early case in our one-person, one-vote jurisprudence arose when a State accorded arbitrary and disparate treatment to voters in its different counties.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Gray v. Sanders,  372 U.S. 368 (1963).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Court found a constitutional violation.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: We relied on these principles in the context of the Presidential selection process in Moore v. Ogilvie, 394 U.S. 814 (1969), where we invalidated a county-based procedure that diluted the influence of citizens in larger counties in the nominating process.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: There we observed that "[t]he idea that one group can be granted greater voting strength than another is hostile to the one man, one vote basis of our representative government."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Id., at 819.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The State Supreme Court ratified this uneven treatment.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: It mandated that the recount totals from two counties, Miami-Dade and Palm Beach, be included in the certified total.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The court also appeared to hold sub silentio that the recount totals from Broward County, which were not completed until after the original November 14 certification by the Secretary, were to be considered part of the new certified vote totals even though the county certification was not contested by Vice President Gore.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Yet each of the counties used varying standards to determine what was a legal vote.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Broward County used a more forgiving standard than Palm Beach County, and uncovered almost three times as many new votes, a result markedly disproportionate to the difference in population between the counties.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: In addition, the recounts in these three counties were not limited to so-called undervotes but extended to all of the ballots.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The distinction has real consequences.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: A manual recount of all ballots identifies not only those ballots which show no vote but also those which contain more than one, *108 the so-called overvotes.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Neither category will be counted by the machine.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: This is not a trivial concern.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: At oral argument, respondents estimated there are as many as 110,000 overvotes statewide.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: As a result, the citizen whose ballot was not read by a machine because he failed to vote for a candidate in a way readable by a machine may still have his vote counted in a manual recount; on the other hand, the citizen who marks two candidates in a way discernible by the machine will not have the same opportunity to have his vote count, even if a manual examination of the ballot would reveal the requisite indicia of intent.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Furthermore, the citizen who marks two candidates, only one of which is discernible by the machine, will have his vote counted even though it should have been read as an invalid ballot.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The State Supreme Court's inclusion of vote counts based on these variant standards exemplifies concerns with the remedial processes that were under way.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: That brings the analysis to yet a further equal protection problem.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The votes certified by the court included a partial total from one county, Miami-Dade.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Florida Supreme Court's decision thus gives no assurance that the recounts included in a final certification must be complete.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Indeed, it is respondents' submission that it would be consistent with the rules of the recount procedures to include whatever partial counts are done by the time of final certification, and we interpret the Florida Supreme Court's decision to permit this.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: See 772 So.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: 2d, at 1261-1262, n. 21 (noting "practical difficulties" may control outcome of election, but certifying partial Miami-Dade total nonetheless).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: This accommodation no doubt results from the truncated contest period established by the Florida Supreme Court in Palm Beach County Canvassing Bd.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: v. Harris, at respondents' own urging.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The press of time does not diminish the constitutional concern.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: A desire for speed is not a general excuse for ignoring equal protection guarantees.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: *109 In addition to these difficulties the actual process by which the votes were to be counted under the Florida Supreme Court's decision raises further concerns.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: That order did not specify who would recount the ballots.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The county canvassing boards were forced to pull together ad hoc teams of judges from various Circuits who had no previous training in handling and interpreting ballots.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Furthermore, while others were permitted to observe, they were prohibited from objecting during the recount.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The recount process, in its features here described, is inconsistent with the minimum procedures necessary to protect the fundamental right of each voter in the special instance of a statewide recount under the authority of a single state judicial officer.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Our consideration is limited to the present circumstances, for the problem of equal protection in election processes generally presents many complexities.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The question before the Court is not whether local entities, in the exercise of their expertise, may develop different systems for implementing elections.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Instead, we are presented with a situation where a state court with the power to assure uniformity has ordered a statewide recount with minimal procedural safeguards.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: When a court orders a statewide remedy, there must be at least some assurance that the rudimentary requirements of equal treatment and fundamental fairness are satisfied.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Given the Court's assessment that the recount process underway was probably being conducted in an unconstitutional manner, the Court stayed the order directing the recount so it could hear this case and render an expedited decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The contest provision, as it was mandated by the State Supreme Court, is not well calculated to sustain the confidence that all citizens must have in the outcome of elections.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The State has not shown that its procedures include the necessary safeguards.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The problem, for instance, of the estimated 110,000 overvotes has not been *110 addressed, although Chief Justice Wells called attention to the concern in his dissenting opinion.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Upon due consideration of the difficulties identified to this point, it is obvious that the recount cannot be conducted in compliance with the requirements of equal protection and due process without substantial additional work.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: It would require not only the adoption (after opportunity for argument) of adequate statewide standards for determining what is a legal vote, and practicable procedures to implement them, but also orderly judicial review of any disputed matters that might arise.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: In addition, the Secretary has advised that the recount of only a portion of the ballots requires that the vote tabulation equipment be used to screen out undervotes, a function for which the machines were not designed.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: If a recount of overvotes were also required, perhaps even a second screening would be necessary.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Use of the equipment for this purpose, and any new software developed for it,would have to be evaluated for accuracy by the Secretary, as required by Fla. Stat.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Supreme Court of Florida has said that the legislature intended the State's electors to "participat[e] fully in the federal electoral process," as provided in 3 U.S. C. § 5.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: 2d, at 1289; see also Palm Beach County Canvassing Bd.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: That statute, in turn, requires that any controversy or contest that is designed to lead to a conclusive selection of electors be completed by December 12.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: That date is upon us, and there is no recount procedure in place under the State Supreme Court's order that comports with minimal constitutional standards.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Because it is evident that any recount seeking to meet the December 12 date will be unconstitutional for the reasons we have discussed, we reverse the judgment of the Supreme Court of Florida ordering a recount to proceed.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: *111 Seven Justices of the Court agree that there are constitutional problems with the recount ordered by the Florida Supreme Court that demand a remedy.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: See post, at 134 (Souter, J., dissenting); post, at 145-146 (Breyer, J., dissenting).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The only disagreement is as to the remedy.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Because the Florida Supreme Court has said that the Florida Legislature intended to obtain the safe-harbor benefits of 3 U.S. C. § 5, Justice Breyer's proposed remedyremanding to the Florida Supreme Court for its ordering of a constitutionally proper contest until December 18contemplates action in violation of the Florida Election Code, and hence could not be part of an "appropriate" order authorized by Fla. Stat.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text:
* * *
None are more conscious of the vital limits on judicial authority than are the Members of this Court, and none stand more in admiration of the Constitution's design to leave the selection of the President to the people, through their legislatures, and to the political sphere.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: When contending parties invoke the process of the courts, however, it becomes our unsought responsibility to resolve the federal and constitutional issues the judicial system has been forced to confront.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The judgment of the Supreme Court of Florida is reversed, and the case is remanded for further proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Pursuant to this Court's Rule 45.2, the Clerk is directed to issue the mandate in this case forthwith.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: We join the per curiam opinion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: We write separately because we believe there are additional grounds that require us to reverse the Florida Supreme Court's decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text:
*112 I
We deal here not with an ordinary election, but with an election for the President of the United States.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text:
In Burroughs v. United States, 290 U.S. 534, 545 (1934), we said:
"While presidential electors are not officers or agents of the federal government (In re Green, 134 U.S. 377, 379 [(1890)]), they exercise federal functions under, and discharge duties in virtue of authority conferred by, the Constitution of the United States.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The President is vested with the executive power of the nation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The importance of his election and the vital character of its relationship to and effect upon the welfare and safety of the whole people cannot be too strongly stated."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Likewise, in Anderson v. Celebrezze, 460 U.S. 780, 794 795 (1983) (footnote omitted), we said: "[I]n the context of a Presidential election, state-imposed restrictions implicate a uniquely important national interest.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: For the President and the Vice President of the United States are the only elected officials who represent all the voters in the Nation."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: In most cases, comity and respect for federalism compel us to defer to the decisions of state courts on issues of state law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: That practice reflects our understanding that the decisions of state courts are definitive pronouncements of the will of the States as sovereigns.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Erie R. Co. v. Tompkins, 304 U.S. 64 (1938).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Of course, in ordinary cases, the distribution of powers among the branches of a State's government raises no questions of federal constitutional law, subject to the requirement that the government be republican in character.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: But there are a few exceptional cases in which the Constitution imposes a duty or confers a power on a particular branch of a State's government.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: This is one of them.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Article II, § 1, cl.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2, provides that "[e]ach State shall appoint, in such Manner as the Legislature thereof may direct," electors for President and Vice President.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: (Emphasis added.)
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Thus, *113 the text of the election law itself, and not just its interpretation by the courts of the States, takes on independent significance.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: In McPherson v. Blacker, 146 U.S. 1 (1892), we explained that Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2, "convey[s] the broadest power of determination" and "leaves it to the legislature exclusively to define the method" of appointment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: A significant departure from the legislative scheme for appointing Presidential electors presents a federal constitutional question.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Title 3 U.S. C. § 5 informs our application of Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2, to the Florida statutory scheme, which, as the Florida Supreme Court acknowledged, took that statute into account.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Section 5 provides that the State's selection of electors "shall be conclusive, and shall govern in the counting of the electoral votes" if the electors are chosen under laws enacted prior to election day, and if the selection process is completed six days prior to the meeting of the electoral college.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text:
As we noted in Bush v. Palm Beach County Canvassing Bd., ante, at 78:
"Since § 5 contains a principle of federal law that would assure finality of the State's determination if made pursuant to a state law in effect before the election, a legislative wish to take advantage of the `safe harbor' would counsel against any construction of the Election Code that Congress might deem to be a change in the law."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: If we are to respect the legislature's Article II powers, therefore, we must ensure that post election state-court actions do not frustrate the legislative desire to attain the "safe harbor" provided by § 5.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: In Florida, the legislature has chosen to hold statewide elections to appoint the State's 25 electors.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Importantly, the legislature has delegated the authority to run the elections and to oversee election disputes to the Secretary of *114 State (Secretary), Fla. Stat.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2001), and to state circuit courts, §§ 102.168(1), 102.168(8).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Isolated sections of the code may well admit of more than one interpretation, but the general coherence of the legislative scheme may not be altered by judicial interpretation so as to wholly change the statutorily provided apportionment of responsibility among these various bodies.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: In any election but a Presidential election, the Florida Supreme Court can give as little or as much deference to Florida's executives as it chooses, so far as Article II is concerned, and this Court will have no cause to question the court's actions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: But, with respect to a Presidential election, the court must be both mindful of the legislature's role under Article II in choosing the manner of appointing electors and deferential to those bodies expressly empowered by the legislature to carry out its constitutional mandate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: In order to determine whether a state court has infringed upon the legislature's authority, we necessarily must examine the law of the State as it existed prior to the action of the court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Though we generally defer to state courts on the interpretation of state lawsee, e. g., Mullaney v. Wilbur,  421 U.S. 684 (1975)there are of course areas in which the Constitution requires this Court to undertake an independent, if still deferential, analysis of state law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: For example, in NAACP v. Alabama ex rel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Patterson,  357 U.S. 449 (1958), it was argued that we were without jurisdiction because the petitioner had not pursued the correct appellate remedy in Alabama's state courts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Petitioner had sought a state-law writ of certiorari in the Alabama Supreme Court when a writ of mandamus, according to that court, was proper.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: We found this state-law ground inadequate to defeat our jurisdiction because we were "unable to reconcile the procedural holding of the Alabama Supreme Court" with prior Alabama precedent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Id., at 456.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The purported state-law ground was so novel, in our independent *115 estimation, that "petitioner could not fairly be deemed to have been apprised of its existence."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Id., at 457.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Six years later we decided Bouie v. City of Columbia, 378 U.S. 347 (1964), in which the state court had held, contrary to precedent, that the state trespass law applied to black sit-in demonstrators who had consent to enter private property but were then asked to leave.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Relying upon NAACP,  we concluded that the South Carolina Supreme Court's interpretation of a state penal statute had impermissibly broadened the scope of that statute beyond what a fair reading provided, in violation of due process.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: What we would do in the present case is precisely parallel: hold that the Florida Supreme Court's interpretation of the Florida election laws impermissibly distorted them beyond what a fair reading required, in violation of Article II.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text:
[1]
This inquiry does not imply a disrespect for state courts  but rather a respect for the constitutionally prescribed role of state legislatures.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: To attach definitive weight to the pronouncement of a state court, when the very question at issue is whether the court has actually departed from the statutory meaning, would be to abdicate our responsibility to enforce the explicit requirements of Article II.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text:
*116 II
Acting pursuant to its constitutional grant of authority, the Florida Legislature has created a detailed, if not perfectly crafted, statutory scheme that provides for appointment of Presidential electors by direct election.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Under the statute, "[v]otes cast for the actual candidates for President and Vice President shall be counted as votes cast for the presidential electors supporting such candidates."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The legislature has designated the Secretary as the "chief election officer," with the responsibility to "[o]btain and maintain uniformity in the application, operation, and interpretation of the election laws."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The state legislature has delegated to county canvassing boards the duties of administering elections.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Those boards are responsible for providing results to the state Elections Canvassing Commission, comprising the Governor, the Secretary of State, and the Director of the Division of Elections.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Boardman v. Esteva, 323 So.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2d 259, 268, n. 5 (1975) ("The election process .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: is committed to the executive branch of government through duly designated officials all charged with specific duties .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: [The] judgments [of these officials] are entitled to be regarded by the courts as presumptively correct .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: After the election has taken place, the canvassing boards receive returns from precincts, count the votes, and in the event that a candidate was defeated by 0.5% or less, conduct a mandatory recount.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The county canvassing boards must file certified election returns with the Department of State by 5 p.m. on the seventh day following the election.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The Elections Canvassing Commission must then certify the results of the election.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The state legislature has also provided mechanisms both for protesting election returns and for contesting certified *117 election results.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Section 102.166 governs protests.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Any protest must be filed prior to the certification of election results by the county canvassing board.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Once a protest has been filed, "[t]he county canvassing board may authorize a manual recount."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: If a sample recount conducted pursuant to § 102.166(5) "indicates an error in the vote tabulation which could affect the outcome of the election," the county canvassing board is instructed to: "(a) Correct the error and recount the remaining precincts with the vote tabulation system; (b) Request the Department of State to verify the tabulation software; or (c) Manually recount all ballots," § 102.166(5).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: In the event a canvassing board chooses to conduct a manual recount of all ballots, § 102.166(7) prescribes procedures for such a recount.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Contests to the certification of an election, on the other hand, are controlled by § 102.168.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The grounds for contesting an election include "[r]eceipt of a number of illegal votes or rejection of a number of legal votes sufficient to change or place in doubt the result of the election."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Any contest must be filed in the appropriate Florida circuit court, § 102.168(1), and the canvassing board or election board is the proper party defendant, § 102.168(4).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Section 102.168(8) provides that "[t]he circuit judge to whom the contest is presented may fashion such orders as he or she deems necessary to ensure that each allegation in the complaint is investigated, examined, or checked, to prevent or correct any alleged wrong, and to provide any relief appropriate under such circumstances."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: In Presidential elections, the contest period necessarily terminates on the date set by 3 U.S. C. § 5 for concluding the State's "final determination" of election controversies.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: In its first decision, Palm Beach Canvassing Bd.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: v. Harris,  772 So.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2d 1220 (2000) (Harris I), the Florida Supreme Court extended the 7-day statutory certification deadline established *118 by the legislature.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: [2] This modification of the code, by lengthening the protest period, necessarily shortened the contest period for Presidential elections.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Underlying the extension of the certification deadline and the shortchanging of the contest period was, presumably, the clear implication that certification was a matter of significance: The certified winner would enjoy presumptive validity, making a contest proceeding by the losing candidate an uphill battle.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: In its latest opinion, however, the court empties certification of virtually all legal consequence during the contest, and in doing so departs from the provisions enacted by the Florida Legislature.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The court determined that canvassing boards' decisions regarding whether to recount ballots past the certification deadline (even the certification deadline established by Harris I ) are to be reviewed de novo, although the Election Code clearly vests discretion whether to recount in the boards, and sets strict deadlines subject to the Secretary's rejection of late tallies and monetary fines for tardiness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: See Fla. Stat.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Moreover, the Florida court held that all late vote tallies arriving during the contest period should be automatically included in the certification regardless of the certification deadline (even the certification deadline established by Harris I ), thus virtually eliminating both the deadline and the Secretary's discretion to disregard recounts that violate it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text:
[3]
Moreover, the court's interpretation of "legal vote," and hence its decision to order a contest-period recount, plainly departed from the legislative scheme.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Florida statutory law cannot reasonably be thought to require the counting of improperly *119 marked ballots.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Each Florida precinct before election day provides instructions on how properly to cast a vote, Fla. Stat.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: § 101.46 (1992); each polling place on election day contains a working model of the voting machine it uses, Fla. Stat.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2001); and each voting booth contains a sample ballot, § 101.46.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text:
In precincts using punch card ballots, voters are instructed to punch out the ballot cleanly:
"AFTER VOTING, CHECK YOUR BALLOT CARD TO BE SURE YOUR VOTING SELECTIONS ARE CLEARLY AND CLEANLY PUNCHED AND THERE ARE NO CHIPS LEFT HANGING ON THE BACK OF THE CARD."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Instructions to Voters, quoted in Brief for Respondent Harris et al.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: No reasonable person would call it "an error in the vote tabulation," Fla. Stat.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2001), or a "rejection of .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: legal votes," § 102.168(3)(c),[4] when electronic or electro mechanical equipment performs precisely in the manner designed, and fails to count those ballots that are not marked in the manner that these voting instructions explicitly and prominently specify.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The scheme that the Florida Supreme Court's opinion attributes to the legislature is one in which machines are required to be "capable of correctly counting votes," § 101.5606(4), but which nonetheless regularly produces elections in which legal votes are predictably not tabulated, so that in close elections manual recounts are regularly required.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: This is of course absurd.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The Secretary, who is authorized by law to issue binding interpretations of the Election Code, §§ 97.012, 106.23, rejected this peculiar reading of the statutes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: See DE 00-13 (opinion of the Division of Elections).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The Florida Supreme Court, *120 although it must defer to the Secretary's interpretations, see Krivanek v. Take Back Tampa Political Committee, 625 So.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2d 840, 844 (Fla. 1993), rejected her reasonable interpretation and embraced the peculiar one.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: See Palm Beach County Canvassing Bd.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2d 1273 (2000) (Harris III).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: But as we indicated in our remand of the earlier case, in a Presidential election the clearly expressed intent of the legislature must prevail.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: And there is no basis for reading the Florida statutes as requiring the counting of improperly marked ballots, as an examination of the Florida Supreme Court's textual analysis shows.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: We will not parse that analysis here, except to note that the principal provision of the Election Code on which it relied, § 101.5614(5), was, as Chief Justice Wells pointed out in his dissent in Gore v. Harris,  772 So.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2d 1243, 1267 (2000) (Harris II), entirely irrelevant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The State's Attorney General (who was supporting the Gore challenge) confirmed in oral argument here that never before the present election had a manual recount been conducted on the basis of the contention that "undervotes" should have been examined to determine voter intent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: in Bush v. Palm Beach County Canvassing Bd., O. T. 2000, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Broward County Canvassing Board v. Hogan, 607 So.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2d 508, 509 (Fla. Ct. App.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 1992) (denial of recount for failure to count ballots with "hanging paper chads").
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: For the court to step away from this established practice, prescribed by the Secretary, the state official charged by the legislature with "responsibility to .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: [o]btain and maintain uniformity in the application, operation, and interpretation of the election laws," § 97.012(1), was to depart from the legislative scheme.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text:
III
The scope and nature of the remedy ordered by the Florida Supreme Court jeopardizes the "legislative wish" to take *121 advantage of the safe harbor provided by 3 U.S. C. § 5.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Bush v. Palm Beach County Canvassing Bd., ante, at 78 (per curiam) .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: December 12, 2000, is the last date for a final determination of the Florida electors that will satisfy § 5.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Yet in the late afternoon of December 8thfour days before this deadlinethe Supreme Court of Florida ordered recounts of tens of thousands of so-called "undervotes" spread through 64 of the State's 67 counties.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: This was done in a search for elusiveperhaps delusivecertainty as to the exact count of 6 million votes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: But no one claims that these ballots have not previously been tabulated; they were initially read by voting machines at the time of the election, and thereafter reread by virtue of Florida's automatic recount provision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: No one claims there was any fraud in the election.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The Supreme Court of Florida ordered this additional recount under the provision of the Election Code giving the circuit judge the authority to provide relief that is "appropriate under such circumstances."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Surely when the Florida Legislature empowered the courts of the State to grant "appropriate" relief, it must have meant relief that would have become final by the cutoff date of 3 U.S. C. § 5.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: In light of the inevitable legal challenges and ensuing appeals to the Supreme Court of Florida and petitions for certiorari to this Court, the entire recounting process could not possibly be completed by that date.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Whereas the majority in the Supreme Court of Florida stated its confidence that "the remaining undervotes in these counties can be [counted] within the required time frame," 772 So.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2d, at 1262, n. 22, it made no assertion that the seemingly inevitable appeals could be disposed of in that time.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Although the Florida Supreme Court has on occasion taken over a year to resolve disputes over local elections, see, e. g., Beckstrom v. Volusia County Canvassing Bd., 707 So.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2d 720 (1998) (resolving contest of sheriff's race 16 months after the *122 election), it has heard and decided the appeals in the present case with great promptness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: But the federal deadlines for the Presidential election simply do not permit even such a shortened process.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text:
As the dissent noted:
"In [the four days remaining], all questionable ballots must be reviewed by the judicial officer appointed to discern the intent of the voter in a process open to the public.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Fairness dictates that a provision be made for either party to object to how a particular ballot is counted.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Additionally, this short time period must allow for judicial review.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: I respectfully submit this cannot be completed without taking Florida's presidential electors outside the safe harbor provision, creating the very real possibility of disenfranchising those nearly six million voters who are able to correctly cast their ballots on election day."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: 2d, at 1269 (opinion of Wells, C.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: (footnote omitted).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The other dissenters echoed this concern: "[T]he majority is departing from the essential requirements of the law by providing a remedy which is impossible to achieve and which will ultimately lead to chaos."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Id., at 1273 (Harding, J., dissenting, joined by Shaw, J.).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Given all these factors, and in light of the legislative intent identified by the Florida Supreme Court to bring Florida within the "safe harbor" provision of 3 U.S. C. § 5, the remedy prescribed by the Supreme Court of Florida cannot be deemed an "appropriate" one as of December 8.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: It significantly departed from the statutory framework in place on November 7, and authorized open-ended further proceedings which could not be completed by December 12, thereby preventing a final determination by that date.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: For these reasons, in addition to those given in the per curiam opinion, we would reverse.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The Constitution assigns to the States the primary responsibility for determining the manner of selecting the Presidential electors.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: When questions arise about the meaning of state laws, including election laws, it is our settled practice to accept the opinions of the highest courts of the States as providing the final answers.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: On rare occasions, however, either federal statutes or the Federal Constitution may require federal judicial intervention in state elections.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: This is not such an occasion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The federal questions that ultimately emerged in this case are not substantial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Article II provides that "[e]ach State  shall appoint, in such Manner as the Legislature thereof may direct, a Number of Electors."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: (emphasis added).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: It does not create state legislatures out of whole cloth, but rather takes them as they comeas creatures born of, and constrained by, their state constitutions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Lest there be any doubt, we stated over 100 years ago in McPherson v. Blacker, 146 U.S. 1, 25 (1892), that "[w]hat is forbidden or required to be done by a State" in the Article II context "is forbidden or required of the legislative power under state constitutions as they exist."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In the same vein, we also observed that "[t]he [State's] legislative power is the supreme authority except as limited by the constitution of the State."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [1] The legislative power in Florida is subject to judicial review pursuant *124 to Article V of the Florida Constitution, and nothing in Article II of the Federal Constitution frees the state legislature from the constraints in the State Constitution that created it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Moreover, the Florida Legislature's own decision to employ a unitary code for all elections indicates that it intended the Florida Supreme Court to play the same role in Presidential elections that it has historically played in resolving electoral disputes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The Florida Supreme Court's exercise of appellate jurisdiction therefore was wholly consistent with, and indeed contemplated by, the grant of authority in Article II.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: It hardly needs stating that Congress, pursuant to 3 U.S. C. § 5, did not impose any affirmative duties upon the States that their governmental branches could "violate."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Rather, § 5 provides a safe harbor for States to select electors in contested elections "by judicial or other methods" established by laws prior to the election day.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Section 5, like Article II, assumes the involvement of the state judiciary in interpreting state election laws and resolving election disputes under those laws.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Neither § 5 nor Article II grants federal judges any special authority to substitute their views for those of the state judiciary on matters of state law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Nor are petitioners correct in asserting that the failure of the Florida Supreme Court to specify in detail the precise manner in which the "intent of the voter," Fla. Stat.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 2001), is to be determined rises to the level of a constitutional violation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [2] We found such a violation *125 when individual votes within the same State were weighted unequally, see, e. g., Reynolds v. Sims, 377 U.S. 533, 568 (1964), but we have never before called into question the substantive standard by which a State determines that a vote has been legally cast.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: And there is no reason to think that the guidance provided to the fact finders, specifically the various canvassing boards, by the "intent of the voter" standard is any less sufficientor will lead to results any less uniformthan, for example, the "beyond a reasonable doubt" standard employed every day by ordinary citizens in courtrooms across this country.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[3]
*126 Admittedly, the use of differing substandards for determining voter intent in different counties employing similar voting systems may raise serious concerns.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Those concerns are alleviatedif not eliminatedby the fact that a single impartial magistrate will ultimately adjudicate all objections arising from the recount process.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Of course, as a general matter, "[t]he interpretation of constitutional principles must not be too literal.

author: Justice Souter
text: There are three issues: whether the State Supreme Court's interpretation of the statute providing for a contest of the state election results somehow violates 3 U.S. C. § 5; whether that court's construction of the state statutory provisions governing contests impermissibly changes a state law from what the State's legislature has provided, in violation of Article II, § 1, cl.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: 2, of the National Constitution; and whether the manner of interpreting markings on disputed ballots failing to cause machines to register votes for President (the undervote ballots) violates the equal protection or *130 due process guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: None of these issues is difficult to describe or to resolve.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text:
I
The 3 U.S. C. § 5 issue is not serious.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: That provision sets certain conditions for treating a State's certification of Presidential electors as conclusive in the event that a dispute over recognizing those electors must be resolved in the Congress under 3 U.S. C. § 15.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: Conclusiveness requires selection under a legal scheme in place before the election, with results determined at least six days before the date set for casting electoral votes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: But no State is required to conform to § 5 if it cannot do that (for whatever reason); the sanction for failing to satisfy the conditions of § 5 is simply loss of what has been called its "safe harbor."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: And even that determination is to be made, if made anywhere, in the Congress.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text:
II
The second matter here goes to the State Supreme Court's interpretation of certain terms in the state statute governing election "contests," Fla. Stat.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: 2001); there is no question here about the state court's interpretation of the related provisions dealing with the antecedent process of "protesting" particular vote counts, § 102.166, which was involved in the previous case, Bush v. Palm Beach County Canvassing Bd.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: The issue is whether the judgment of the State Supreme Court has displaced the state legislature's provisions for election contests: is the law as declared by the court different from the provisions made by the legislature, to which the National Constitution commits responsibility for determining how each State's Presidential electors are chosen?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: Bush does not, of course, claim that any judicial act interpreting a statute of uncertain meaning is enough to displace the legislative provision and violate Article II; statutes require interpretation, which does not without more affect the legislative character *131 of a statute within the meaning of the Constitution.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: Brief for Petitioner in Bush v. Palm Beach County Canvassing Bd., O. T. 2000, No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: What Bush does argue, as I understand the contention, is that the interpretation of § 102.168 was so unreasonable as to transcend the accepted bounds of statutory interpretation, to the point of being a nonjudicial act and producing new law untethered to the legislative Act in question.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: The starting point for evaluating the claim that the Florida Supreme Court's interpretation effectively rewrote § 102.168 must be the language of the provision on which Gore relies to show his right to raise this contest: that the previously certified result in Bush's favor was produced by "rejection of a number of legal votes sufficient to change or place in doubt the result of the election."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: None of the state court's interpretations is unreasonable to the point of displacing the legislative enactment quoted.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: As I will note below, other interpretations were of course possible, and some might have been better than those adopted by the Florida court's majority; the two dissents from the majority opinion of that court and various briefs submitted to us set out alternatives.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: But the majority view is in each instance within the bounds of reasonable interpretation, and the law as declared is consistent with Article II.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: The statute does not define a "legal vote," the rejection of which may affect the election.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: The State Supreme Court was therefore required to define it, and in doing that the court looked to another election statute, § 101.5614(5), dealing with damaged or defective ballots, which contains a provision that no vote shall be disregarded "if there is a clear indication of the intent of the voter as determined by the canvassing board."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: The court read that objective of looking to the voter's intent as indicating that the legislature probably meant "legal vote" to mean a vote recorded on a ballot indicating what the voter intended.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: Gore v. Harris, 772 *132 So.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: 10 (defining "legal votes" as "votes properly executed in accordance with the instructions provided to all registered voters in advance of the election and in the polling places").
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: But even so, there is no constitutional violation in following the majority view; Article II is unconcerned with mere disagreements about interpretive merits.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: The Florida court next interpreted "rejection" to determine what act in the counting process may be attacked in a contest.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: Again, the statute does not define the term.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: The court majority read the word to mean simply a failure to count.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: That reading is certainly within the bounds of common sense, given the objective to give effect to a voter's intent if that can be determined.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: A different reading, of course, is possible.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter

label: RHETORIC

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: The court held that if the uncounted ballots were so numerous that it was reasonably possible that they contained enough "legal" votes to swing the election, this contest would be authorized by the statute.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: In sum, the interpretations by the Florida court raise no substantial question under Article II.

author: Justice Souter

III
It is only on the third issue before us that there is a meritorious argument for relief, as this Court's per curiam opinion recognizes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: It is an issue that might well have been dealt with adequately by the Florida courts if the state proceedings had not been interrupted, and if not disposed of at the state level it could have been considered by the Congress in any electoral vote dispute.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: But because the course of *134 state proceedings has been interrupted, time is short, and the issue is before us, I think it sensible for the Court to address it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: Petitioners have raised an equal protection claim (or, alternatively, a due process claim, see generally Logan v. Zimmerman Brush Co., 455 U.S. 422 (1982)), in the charge that unjustifiably disparate standards are applied in different electoral jurisdictions to otherwise identical facts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: It is true that the Equal Protection Clause does not forbid the use of a variety of voting mechanisms within a jurisdiction, even though different mechanisms will have different levels of effectiveness in recording voters' intentions; local variety can be justified by concerns about cost, the potential value of innovation, and so on.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter
text: But evidence in the record here suggests that a different order of disparity obtains under rules for determining a voter's intent that have been applied (and could continue to be applied) to identical types of ballots used in identical brands of machines and exhibiting identical physical characteristics (such as "hanging" or "dimpled" chads).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Souter

The Chief Justice acknowledges that provisions of Florida's Election Code "may well admit of more than one interpretation."

author: Justice Souter

label: RHETORIC

[1]
In deferring to state courts on matters of state law, we appropriately recognize that this Court acts as an "`outside[r]' lacking the common exposure to local law which comes from sitting in the jurisdiction."

label: RHETORIC
