text: This device has two characteristics which distinguish it from other nuclear reactors.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: First, the neutrons which fly about inside the reactor (to use crude but graphic layman's terminology) and split atoms of fissionable Uranium-235 thus releasing new neutrons and energy in the form of heatare "fast" neutrons.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: That is, they travel at a velocity of about 10,000 miles per second, much faster than neutrons in ordinary reactors.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Second, this reactor is a "breeder": it has the property of being able to produce about 1.2 times as much fissionable material as it consumes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: This result comes about through a sort of modern alchemy; when the neutrons fly outside the inner core of the reactor, which is composed of fissionable U-235, they enter a blanket of nonfissionable U-238.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Atoms in this blanket are changed, when struck by a neutron, into Plutonium, itself a fissionable fuel which can be removed from the reactor and be put to possible use in other installations.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Thus, the reactor "breeds" Plutonium faster than it uses up U-235.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: It not only generates energy to produce electric power, it also creates new reactor fuel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: This "breeder" effect is attainable because of the use of fast neutrons.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Two boron control rods inserted into the reactor are a means designed to reduce its power level at any time.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: And in addition to these rods, eight more boron rods are suspended by an electromagnet over the reactor; in case the reactivity rises to a dangerously *400 high level, these safety rods are intended to drop into the reactor automatically and shut it down immediately.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The whole machine is housed in a series of thick concrete, graphite, and steel layers, all underground.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Over this entire complex is placed a footballshaped building, enclosed in a two-inch steel shield capable of containing an explosion equal in force to 1,000 pounds of TNT, which is greater than any explosion which any of the experts who testified in this case believes is at all likely to result from an accident in the operation of the reactor.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The application, after describing the reactor in much greater detail than this rudimentary summary, went on to provide that the reactor would be located at Lagoona Beach, Mich., on the shores of Lake Erie, about 35 miles from the center of Detroit, Mich., and about 30 miles from the center of Toledo, Ohio.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The Commission took the case under advisement and, on August 4, 1956, despite a report of its Advisory Committee on Reactor Safeguards which was at best noncommittal about the probable safety of the proposed reactor in operation, issued a provisional construction permit without having held public hearings, as the law at that time permitted it to do.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text:
This permit was subject to the following condition:
"The conversion of this permit to a license is subject to submittal by PRDC to the Commission (by amendment of the application) of the complete, final Hazards Summary Report (portions of which may be submitted and evaluated from time to time).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The final Hazards Summary Report must show that the final design provides reasonable assurance .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: that the health and safety of the public will not be endangered by operation of the reactor .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: On August 31, 1956, in accordance with the Commission's then existing rules of practice, the respondents in *401 this Court, International Union of Electrical, Radio, and Machine Workers, United Automobile, Aircraft, and Agricultural Implement Workers of America, and United Papermakers and Paperworkers, petitioned the Commission for permission to intervene and oppose continuation in effect of PRDC's provisional construction permit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The AEC granted permission to intervene on October 8, 1956, and set the case down for a hearing before one of its hearing examiners.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Extensive hearings were held between January 8, 1957, and August 7, 1957, and on November 22, 1957, in accordance with the AEC's order setting the case for hearing before him, the examiner, instead of issuing an initial decision and opinion of his own, transferred and certified the record of the hearings to the full Commission for its consideration.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Oral argument was had before the Commission on May 29, 1958.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: On December 10, 1958, the Commission rendered its "Opinion and Initial Decision" continuing PRDC's permit in effect, subject to the same condition recited above.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: To its opinion were appended extensive findings of fact, including Finding 22, which is of central importance to the decision of this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text:
That finding reads as follows:
"22.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The Commission finds reasonable assurance in the record that a utilization facility of the general type proposed in the PRDC application and amendments thereto can be constructed and will be able to be operated at the location proposed without undue risk to the health and safety of the public."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Commissioners Vance and Floberg joined in the opinion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Commissioner Graham filed a short concurring opinion agreeing with the Commission's basic safety findings, just quoted, but doing so in much shorter compass than the majority.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Commissioners Libby and McCone (the chairman) took no part in the decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The result of this initial opinion was an order continuing PRDC's provisional *402 construction permit in effect, but containing the same condition which the original permit, issued on August 4, 1956, had contained.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The intervening unions, as was their right, filed detailed exceptions to this initial decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The Commission fully reconsidered all the contentions and reviewed the evidence presented at the lengthy hearings, with particular attention to the testimony of the scientific experts, several of them members of the Advisory Committee on Reactor Safeguards, who had testified.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: On May 26, 1959, the Commission issued its "Opinion and Final Decision," dealing with all questions presented in even greater detail and reaffirming its initial decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The Commission emphasized that "public safety is the first, last, and a permanent consideration in any decision on the issuance of a construction permit or a license to operate a nuclear facility."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Even after operation of the reactor is licensedif it ever isthe Commission, it said, will retain jurisdiction over PRDC's activities to ensure that the highest safety standards are maintained.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The opinion went on to examine the suitability of the proposed site, noted that it was near a great population center, and nevertheless concluded that at the present stage there was reasonable assurance that the general type of reactor proposed by PRDC would be safe enough at that location.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The Commission pointed out, however, that its action in allowing PRDC to proceed with construction was by its nature tentative and preliminary, and that it was by no means committed to the issuance of an operating license.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: "PRDC has been on notice since before the first shovel of dirt was moved," it said, "that its construction permit is provisional upon further demonstration of many technological and financial facts, including the complete safety of the reactor."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: A more severe safety test would have to be passed when the reactor was completed, the opinion said, since "[t]he degree of `reasonable assurance' .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: *403 that satisfies us .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: for purposes of the provisional construction permit would not be the same as we would require in considering the issuance of the operating license."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text:
The Commission then made new findings of fact, including the following counterpart of its initial Finding 22:
"22.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The Commission finds reasonable assurance in the record, for the purposes of this provisional construction permit, that a utilization facility of the general type proposed in the PRDC Application and amendments thereto can be constructed and operated at the location without undue risk to the health and safety of the public."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: All three of the Commissioners who took part in the case joined in this final decision, and the Commission entered its final order continuing in effect the PRDC provisional construction permit, but again subject to the condition that a more extensive safety investigation, and a definitive safety finding, would have to be made before operation was permitted.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The intervening unions, respondents in this Court, then petitioned the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit to review and set aside this order of the Commission.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Only the final order continuing the permit in effect was drawn in question.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: No complaint was made of the original ex parte grant of the permit in 1956.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: PRDC intervened in the Court of Appeals in support of the AEC.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: On June 10, 1960, by a divided vote, a three-judge panel of the Court of Appeals set aside the AEC's order and remanded the case to the Commission.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: A petition for rehearing en banc was denied, two judges dissenting, and we brought the case here.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: We turn now to an examination of the statutes and regulations pursuant to which the Commission purported to continue in effect PRDC's construction permit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The *404 basic provision is § 104b of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, 42 U.S. C. § 2134 (b), which authorizes the AEC to "issue licenses to persons applying therefor for utilization and production facilities involved in the conduct of research and development activities .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: In issuing licenses under this subsection, the Commission shall impose the minimum amount of such regulations and terms of license as will permit the Commission to fulfill its obligations under this chapter to promote the common defense and security and to protect the health and safety of the public .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Two things about this section should be emphasized.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: First, there is no doubt that the term "licenses" as used therein includes the provisional construction permit which PRDC has received.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The last sentence of § 185, 42 U.S. C. § 2235, expressly so provides, as we shall soon see.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: And second, there is also no doubt that construction permits, like all other licenses, can be issued only consistently with the health and safety of the public.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: But the responsibility for safeguarding that health and safety belongs under the statute to the Commission.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: And § 104b, especially when read in connection with the general rule-making power conferred by § 161i (3), 42 U.S. C. § 2201 (i) (3), clearly contemplates that the Commission shall by regulation set forth what the public safety requires as a prerequisite to the issuance of any license or permit under the Act.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The issuance of construction permits is subject to § 185, 42 U.S. C. § 2235.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text:
That section provides that
"All applicants for licenses to construct or modify production or utilization facilities shall, if the application is otherwise acceptable to the Commission, be initially granted a construction permit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The construction permit shall state the earliest and latest dates for the completion of the construction or modification.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Unless the construction or modification of the facility is completed by the completion date, the *405 construction permit shall expire, and all rights there-under be forfeited, unless upon good cause shown, the Commission extends the completion date.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Upon the completion of the construction or modification of the facility, upon the filing of any additional information needed to bring the original application up to date, and upon finding that the facility authorized has been constructed and will operate in conformity with the application as amended and in conformity with the provisions of this chapter and of the rules and regulations of the Commission, and in the absence of any good cause being shown to the Commission why the granting of a license would not be in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, the Commission shall thereupon issue a license to the applicant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: For all other purpose of this chapter, a construction permit is deemed to be a `license.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text:
"
It is clear from the face of this statuteand all parties agreethat Congress contemplated a step-by-step procedure.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: First an applicant would have to get a construction permit, then he would have to construct his facility, and then he would have to ask the Commission to grant him a license to operate the facility.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: This procedure is described in its general outlines in Marks and Trowbridge, Framework for Atomic Industry, 76-77 (1955).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: See also Green, The Law of Reactor Safety, 12 Vand.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The second step of the procedure, the application for and granting of an operating license, is governed by § 182a, 42 U.S. C. § 2232 (a).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text:
That provision reads, in pertinent part:
"In connection with applications for licenses to operate production or utilization facilities, the applicant shall state such technical specifications .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: and such other information as the Commission may, by rule or regulation, deem necessary in order to enable it to find that the utilization or production of special *406 nuclear material will be in accord with the common defense and security and will provide adequate protection to the health and safety of the public."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: It is clear from this provision that before licensing the operation of PRDC's reactor, the AEC will have to make a positive finding that operation of the facility will "provide adequate protection to the health and safety of the public."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: What is not clear, and what is at the center of the controversy in this case, is whether the Commission must also have made such a finding when it issued PRDC's construction permit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: There is nothing on the face of either § 182 or § 185 which tells us what safety findings must be made before this preliminary step is taken.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: We know, however, from § 104b that some such finding must be made.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: For enlightenment on the nature of this finding, both parties urge us to examine the Commission's regulations, and accordingly we proceed to do so.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text:
The crucial regulation for our purposes is the Commission's regulation 50.35, 10 CFR § 50.35:
"§ 50.35.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Extended time for providing technical information.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Where, because of the nature of a proposed project, an applicant is not in a position to supply initially all of the technical information otherwise required to complete the application, he shall indicate the reason, the items or kinds of information omitted, and the approximate times when such data will be produced.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: If the Commission is satisfied that it has information sufficient to provide reasonable assurance that a facility of the general type proposed can be constructed and operated at the proposed location without undue risk to the health and safety of the public and that the omitted information will be supplied, it may process the application and issue a construction permit on a provisional basis without the omitted information subject *407 to its later production and an evaluation by the Commission that the final design provides reasonable assurance that the health and safety of the public will not be endangered."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: This regulation, obviously, elaborates upon and describes in fuller detail the step-by-step licensing procedure contemplated by §§ 182 and 185.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: It states, pursuant to the authority conferred by §§ 104b and 161i (3), what safety findings shall be required at each stage of the proceeding.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: There is general agreement that the second safety finding referred to, "that the final design provides reasonable assurance that the health and safety of the public will not be endangered," comports with the requirements of § 182 concerning the issuance of a license to operate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: There is also agreement that the regulation's first required safety finding, "that [the AEC] has information sufficient to provide reasonable assurance that a facility of the general type proposed can be constructed and operated at the proposed location without undue risk to the health and safety of the public," is a valid exercise of the rule-making power conferred upon the AEC by statute, and requires that some finding as to safety of operation be made even before a provisional construction permit is granted.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The question is whether that first finding must be backed up with as much conviction as to the safety of the final design of the specific reactor in operation as the second, final finding must be.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: We think the great weight of the argument supports the position taken by PRDC and by the Commission, that Reg.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: 50.35 permits the Commission to defer a definitive safety finding until operation is actually licensed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The words of the regulation themselves certainly lean strongly in that direction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The first finding is to be made, by definition, on the basis of incomplete information, and concerns only the "general type" of reactor proposed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: *408 The second finding is phrased unequivocally in terms of "reasonable assurance," while the first speaks more tentatively of "information sufficient to provide reasonable assurance."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The Commission, furthermore, had good reason to make this distinction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: For nuclear reactors are fast-developing and fast-changing.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: What is up to date now may not, probably will not, be as acceptable tomorrow.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Problems which seem insuperable now may be solved tomorrow, perhaps in the very process of construction itself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: We see no reason why we should not accord to the Commission's interpretation of its own regulation and governing statute that respect which is customarily given to a practical administrative construction of a disputed provision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Particularly is this respect due when the administrative practice at stake "involves a contemporaneous construction of a statute by the men charged with the responsibility of setting its machinery in motion, of making the parts work efficiently and smoothly while they are yet untried and new."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Norwegian Nitrogen Products Co. v. United States, 288 U.S. 294, 315 (1933).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: And finally, and perhaps demanding particular weight, this construction has time and again been brought to the attention of the Joint Committee of Congress on Atomic Energy, which under § 202 of the Act, 42 U.S. C. § 2252, has a special duty during each session of Congress to "conduct hearings in either open or executive session for the purpose of receiving information concerning the development, growth, and state of the atomic energy industry," and to oversee the operations of the AEC.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: See, e. g., Hearings on Development, Growth, and State of the Atomic Energy Industry, 84th Cong., 2d Sess., p. 106 (1956); Hearings on Development, etc., 85th Cong., 2d Sess., pp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: 119-121 (1958); Hearings on Development, etc., 86th Cong., 2d Sess., pp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: 103-109, 677-678 (1960); Hearings on Development, etc., 87th Cong., 1st Sess., pp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: 29-32 (1961); Hearings on *409 Governmental Indemnity for Private Licensees and AEC Contractors Against Reactor Hazards, 84th Cong., 2d Sess., pp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: 62-65 (1956); A Study of AEC Procedures and Organization in the Licensing of Reactor Facilities, 85th Cong., 1st Sess., pp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Print 1957).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: No change in this procedure has ever been suggested by the Committee, although it has on occasion been critical of other aspects of the PRDC proceedings not before us.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: It may often be shaky business to attribute significance to the inaction of Congress, but under these circumstances, and considering especially the peculiar responsibility and place of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy in the statutory scheme, we think it fair to read this history as a de facto acquiescence in and ratification of the Commission's licensing procedure by Congress.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Cf., e. g., Ivanhoe Irrig.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: This same procedure has been used in each of the nine instances in which the Commission has granted a provisional construction permit for a developmental nuclear power reactor, e. g., Yankee Atomic Elec.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Co., CPPR-5 (AEC 1957), and we hold that it was properly used in this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: It is plain that the statute and regulations, as so construed and applied, were complied with fully.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The Commission did not, as respondents' argument seems at times to suggest, find merely that the construction of the reactor would present no safety problem.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The Commission's opinion and findings clearly were deeply concerned about the prospective safety of operation of the proposed reactor.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Admitting that on the basis of the facts before it it was unable to make a definitive finding of safety, the Commission nevertheless foundand respondents do not deny that the finding was supported by substantial evidencethat it had information sufficient to provide *410 reasonable assurance that the general type of reactor proposed could be operated without undue risk to the health and safety of the public.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Its Finding 22, which we have quoted, was in the very words of Reg.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: 50.35, except for the insertion of the phrase, "for the purposes of this provisional construction permit."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: This phrase was merely declaratory of the nature of the proceeding before the Commission, and in no way denigrated the finding as to safety of operation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Respondents contend nevertheless that their construction of the statute is compelled by the legislative history.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Since the Court of Appeals relied heavily on this history, we have studied it carefully.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Two incidents are cited in particular.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: First, the Joint Committee stated in its report on the bill which became the Atomic Energy Act of 1954, and which when reported contained §§ 182 and 185 in substantially their present shape, that "[s]ection 185 .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: requires the issuance of a license if the construction is carried out in accordance with the terms of the construction permit."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: S. Rep. No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: 1699, 83d Cong., 2d Sess., p. 28 (1954); H. R. Rep. No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The best we can say about this statement, with all deference, is that it must have been inadvertent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Witnesses who appeared before the Joint Committee at the hearings on the bill had made the very complaint that under the words of the bill as proposed a company might invest large sums in construction of a reactor, and then be denied the right to operate it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: This situation, they claimed, was unfair, and would substantially discourage the private investment in the field of atomic power which it was one of the bill's major purposes to stimulate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: See Hearings before the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy on the Bill to Amend the Atomic Energy Act of 1946, 83d Cong., 2d Sess., Pt.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: 113, 119 (statement of Paul W. McQuillen, representing *411 the Dow Chemical-Detroit Edison and Associates atomic power development project, predecessors of PRDC); pp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: 226-227 (statement of E. H. Dixon, chairman of the Committee on Atomic Power of the Edison Electric Institute and president of Middle-South Utilities, Inc.); p. 417 (statement of the Special Committee on Atomic Energy of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: In spite of these pleas, however, the bill was unchanged.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Industry spokesmen renewed the argument the next year when they sought unsuccessfully to have § 185 amended.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Hearings on Development, etc., 84th Cong., 1st Sess., pp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Even a glance at § 185 suffices to show that issuance of a construction permit does not make automatic the later issuance of a license to operate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: For that section sets forth three conditions, in addition to the completion of the construction, which must be met before an operating license is granted: (1) filing of any additional information necessary to bring the application up to dateinformation which will necessarily in this case include detailed safety data concerning the final design of petitioner's reactor; (2) a finding that the reactor will operate in accordance with the act and regulations i.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: e., that the safety and health of the public will be adequately protectedand with the construction permit itself, which is expressly conditioned upon a full investigation and finding of safety before operation is permitted; and (3) the absence of any good cause why the granting of a license to operate would not be in accordance with the Acte.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: g., a showing by respondent unions, who will have full rights to appear and contest the issuance of an operating license, that the reactor may not be reasonably safe.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Respondents rely more heavily on another event during the debates on this bill on the floor of the Senate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Senator Humphrey, an opponent of the bill, expressed a *412 desire that it be made clear that "the construction permit is equivalent to a license," and that "the revised section 182 on license application .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: appl[ies] directly to construction permits."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Senator Hickenlooper, floor manager of the bill and the ranking Senate member of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, indicated that he agreed with this construction of §§ 182 and 185.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Senator Humphrey wanted these matters made clear because he feared that otherwise a construction permit could be easily obtained and substantial investment made in construction, and then the Commission would feel obliged, perhaps under pressure, to issue an operating license in order that this investment should not go to waste.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The language used in the exchange between Senators Humphrey and Hickenlooper is susceptible, if read broadly and out of context, of the construction which respondents attribute to it, namely, that no § 185 construction permit may be issued unless the Commission has made the same safety-of-operation finding which it must make under § 182a before allowing actual operation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: But the context of the exchange makes it clear that no such implication was intended by the participants.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Senator Humphrey's statements were made during the consideration of an amendment which he had himself proposed on July 16.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text:
This amendment would have added the following clause to the end of § 185:
"and no construction permit shall be issued by the Commission until after the completion of the procedures established by section 182 for the consideration of applications for licenses under this act."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Upon being assured by Senator Hickenlooper that an earlier amendment which Senator Hickenlooper himself had offered to § 189 took care of the problem, Senator Humphrey withdrew his proposal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: This amendment to *413 § 189, which was adopted, was concerned solely with hearings and judicial review.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Plainly Senator Humphrey's concern was not with the substantive safety findings necessary to the issuance of a construction permit, but rather with the procedural safeguards with which that issuance should, in his opinion, be surrounded.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The reference to the application of § 182 to construction permits was made not with § 182a in mindthat subsection sets out the substantive safety standard for the issuance of an operating licensebut rather with a view to the application of § 182b, about which Senator Humphrey particularly asked Senator Hickenlooper during the exchange on the floor referred to, and which merely provides that notice of a license application must be published and given to any appropriate regulatory agencies, a procedural requirement which was fully satisfied in this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: This interpretation of the meaning of Senator Humphrey's remarks is borne out by a statement of Representative Holifield, who, together with Representative Price, had dissented from the favorable report of the Joint Committee, precisely because, inter alia, under the bill as reported a construction permit did not have to be preceded by the same procedures as an operating license.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: See S. Rep. No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: 1699, 83d Cong., 2d Sess., p. 123 (1954); H. R. Rep. No.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Representative Price wanted the same amendment added to § 185 which Senator Humphrey proposed, and he characterized this amendment as necessary to ensure "that the same procedural safeguards in the case of licenses be applied to construction permits."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: We think, therefore, that Senator Humphrey's statement referred only to procedural prerequisites of construction permits, and had nothing to do with the substantive safety considerations which this case involves.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: If there were any doubt about this matter, the *414 consistent administrative practice, made known to Congress many times and never disturbed by it, would dictate this conclusion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The Court of Appeals put forward as an alternative basis for its decision the holding that under the law the Commission may not authorize the construction of a reactor near a large population center without "compelling reasons" for doing so, 108 U. S. App.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: D. C., at 103-104, 280 F.2d, at 651-652, and that no such reasons had been found by the AEC in this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: It is not clear whether respondents have abandoned that contention in this Court, and it is likewise uncertain whether they ever presented it to the Commission, a step which would ordinarily be a prerequisite to its consideration by the Court of Appeals.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: In any event, the position is without merit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The statute and regulations say nothing about "compelling reasons."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Of course Congress (and the Commission, too, for that matter) had the problem of safety uppermost in mind, and of course that problem is most acute when a reactor, potentially dangerous, is located near a large city.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: But the Commission found reasonable assurance, for present purposes, that the reactor could be safely operated at the proposed location, and that is enough to satisfy the requirements of law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The Commission recognized that the site and all its properties are among the most important ingredients of a finding of safety vel non.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: It considered the site along with all the other relevant data.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: There is no warrant in the statute for setting aside the Commission's conclusion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: We hold, therefore, that the Court of Appeals erred in setting aside the order of the AEC continuing PRDC's provisional construction permit in effect.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: We deem it appropriate to add a few words concerning the fears of nuclear disaster which respondents so urgently place before us.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The respondents' argument is tantamount to *415 an insistence that the Commission cannot be counted on, when the time comes to make a definitive safety finding, wholly to exclude the consideration that PRDC will have made an enormous investment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The petitioners concede that the Commission is absolutely denied any authority to consider this investment when acting upon an application for a license for operation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: PRDC has been on notice long since that it proceeds with construction at its own risk, and that all its funds may go for naught.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: With its eyes open, PRDC has willingly accepted that risk, however great.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: No license to operate may be issued to PRDC until a full hazards report has been filed, until the AEC's Advisory Committee on Reactor Safeguards makes a full investigation and public report on safety to the Commission, until the Commission itself, after notice and hearings at which respondents, if they desire, may be heard, has made the safety-of-operation finding required by § 182a and Reg.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: 50.35, and until the other requirements of § 185 have been met.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: It may be that an operating license will never be issued.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: If one is, that will not be the end of the matter.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: The respondents may have judicial review.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Moreover, the Commission's responsibility for supervision of PRDC continues.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: For, under Reg.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: 50.57, 10 CFR § 50.57, operation at full power (100,000 electric kilowatts) will not be permitted until several steps of gradually increasing operation have been successfully mastered, with a full public hearing at each step, and no further advance permitted without the AEC's being fully satisfied that a step-up will meet the high safety standards imposed by law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: This is the multi-step scheme which Congress and the Commission have devised to protect the public health and safety.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: We hold that the actions of the Commission up to now have been within the Congressional authorization.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: We cannot assume that the Commission will exceed its powers, or that these *416 many safeguards to protect the public interest will not be fully effective.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Accordingly, the judgment is reversed and the causes are remanded to the Court of Appeals for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: Reversed and remanded.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
text: MR. JUSTICE DOUGLAS, with whom MR.

author: Justice O'Connor

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice O'Connor

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice O'Connor

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice O'Connor

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice O'Connor
text: The Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment "is essentially a direction that all persons similarly situated should be treated alike."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice O'Connor

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice O'Connor
text: Under our rational basis standard of review, "legislation is presumed to be valid and will be sustained if the classification drawn by the statute is rationally related to a legitimate state interest."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice O'Connor
text: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, supra, at 440; see also Department of Agriculture v. Moreno, 413 U.S. 528, 534 (1973); Romer v. Evans, 517 U.S. 620, 632-633 (1996); Nordlinger v. Hahn, 505 U.S. 1, 11-12 (1992).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The Court holds that a state court lacks the power to enjoin persons subject to its jurisdiction from initiating duplicative and vexatious litigation in the federal courts, litigation which had not been commenced at the time of the state-court injunction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: While this conclusion is arguably supported by a portion of the holding of Donovan v. Dallas, 377 U.S. 408 (1964), it is in many ways contrary to the reasoning of that decision, and undermines the historic power of courts of equity to guard against abuse of judicial proceedings.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Because Donovan involves a procedural rule which has application in myriad situations, I believe that its holding should be in part re-examined.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text:
In Swift & Co. v. Wickham, 382 U.S. 111, 116 (1965), the Court said:
"Unless inexorably commanded by statute, a procedural principle of this importance should not be kept on the books in the name of stare decisis once it is proved to be unworkable in practice; the mischievous consequences to litigants and courts alike from the perpetuation of an unworkable rule are too great."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The author of Donovan was particularly cognizant of the sensitive relationship between state and federal courts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: See *20 Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37 (1971); Atlantic Coast Line R. Co. v. Locomotive Engineers, 398 U.S. 281, 287 (1970).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Because the rule in Donovan implicates that relationship, I would not extend its holding as the Court now does.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The Court in Donovan based its decision on the "general rule" that "state and federal courts would not interfere with or try to restrain each other's proceedings."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Such a general rule of parity implies that, where a federal district court has power to enjoin the institution of proceedings in state court, a state court must have a similar power to forbid the initiation of vexatious litigation in federal court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Congress, in enacting the Anti-Injunction Act limiting the authority of United States courts to stay proceedings in any court of a State, 28 U.S. C. § 2283, excepted from the limitation an injunction "where necessary in aid of its jurisdiction, or to protect or effectuate its judgments."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: See Mitchum v. Foster, 407 U.S. 225, 231-236 (1972); Atlantic Coast Line, supra, at 294-296.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Kline v. Burke Constr.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: If Congress saw fit to create such an exception to the "[l]egislative policy [which] is here expressed in a clear-cut prohibition," Clothing Workers v. Richman Bros. Co., 348 U.S. 511, 516 (1955), it could not have intended to deny the same limited injunctive authority to state courts of general jurisdiction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Neither the Supremacy Clause of Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: VI of the Constitution or the congressional grants of jurisdiction to federal courts in any way militate against the conclusion that both state and federal courts possess the authority to protect jurisdiction which they have acquired from being undercut or nullified by suits later instituted in the courts of the other jurisdiction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Unlike the Texas Court of Civil Appeals in Donovan, the New Mexico District Court in this case enjoined only the initiation of new proceedings, specifically excepting two federal-court actions already begun by petitioner and its constituent partners.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: Any ambiguity inherent in the wording of the *21 District Court's injunction with regard to other proceedings has been authoritatively resolved by the Supreme Court of New Mexico, which held: "The injunction is directed only towards the institution of future litigation wherein no federal or state court has yet to acquire jurisdiction."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The existence of power in the state courts to guard against the abuse of the federal courts for purposes of harassment is not foreclosed by Donovan, even though this Court, in vacating the contempt citation of those parties who initiated a federal action subsequent to the state order, necessarily held that the Texas court lacked such power in that instance.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: There, in the subsequent action, the federal plaintiffs sought to enjoin the Supreme Court of Texas from interfering with a pending action which this Court held they had a right to maintain.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The conclusion that the New Mexico court has the power to forbid petitioner from involving respondent in a multitude of separate actions with different parties does not undercut the holding of Donovan that a federal plaintiff may seek to protect his right to proceed with a pending suit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
text: The Supreme Court of New Mexico has acted consistently with both the holding and the reasoning of Donovan, and I would therefore affirm its judgment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
In Exxon Shipping Co. v. Baker, 554 U.S. 471 (2008),
the Court recognized that punitive damages normally are
available in maritime cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Relying on Miles v. Apex Marine Corp., 498 U.S. 19
(1990), the Court today holds that unseaworthiness claims
are an exception to that general rule.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Respondent Chris-
topher Batterton, defending the Ninth Circuit’s decision in
his favor, relies on the Court’s more recent decision in
Atlantic Sounding Co. v. Townsend, 557 U.S. 404 (2009).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
In my view, the Ninth Circuit correctly determined that
Atlantic Sounding is the controlling precedent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
I would there-
fore affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals, cogently
explained in Senior Circuit Judge Kleinfeld’s opinion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
I
  Batterton was employed as a deckhand for petitioner
The Dutra Group, a dredging and marine construction
company.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
As Batterton worked on a Dutra vessel, fellow
crewmembers pumped pressurized air into a below-decks
compartment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
The build up of pressurized air blew open a
hatch cover that crushed Batterton’s hand, permanently
disabling him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
The accident could have been prevented,
2                  DUTRA GROUP v. BATTERTON

                        GINSBURG, J., dissenting

Batterton alleges, by a valve to vent excess air from the
compartment, something to hold the hatch cover open, or
simply better warnings or supervision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Batterton filed a civil action asserting one claim of
negligence under the Jones Act1 and two claims under
general maritime law: one for breach of the duty to pro-
vide a seaworthy vessel and one for breach of the duty to
provide maintenance and cure.2 As to his unseaworthi-
ness claim, Batterton sought punitive damages, alleging
that Dutra’s breach was wanton and willful.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Dutra moved to strike or dismiss Batterton’s punitive
damages request.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
The District Court denied the motion,
2014 WL 12538172, *2 (CD Cal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Dec. 15, 2014), and the
Ninth Circuit, accepting an interlocutory appeal, affirmed,
880 F.3d 1089.

text:
Longstanding Ninth Circuit precedent,
the court observed, recognized the availability of punitive
damages in seamen’s actions for unseaworthiness.

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Id., at
1091 (citing Evich v. Morris, 819 F.2d 256, 258 (1987)).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Miles, 498 U.S., at 29–33, which held that loss-of-society
damages are not available in survivors’ actions for unsea-
worthiness resulting in a seaman’s wrongful death, the
court observed, did not undermine that precedent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
“Whatever room might [have] be[en]
left to support broadening Miles to cover punitive damages”
sought by a seaman, the Ninth Circuit said, “was cut off by

ment or, if the seaman dies from the injury, the personal representative

Laws of the United States
regulating recovery for personal injury to, or death of, a railway em-

2 “Maintenance and cure” is the right of “the seaman, ill or injured in

(5th ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:

                       GINSBURG, J., dissenting

[this] Court’s decision in Atlantic Sounding,” in which this
Court, recognizing that “historically, punitive damages
have been available and awarded in general maritime
actions,” held that such damages are available in seamen’s

author: Justice Ginsburg

(quoting
Atlantic Sounding, 557 U.S., at 407; alteration omitted).

author: Justice Ginsburg

Punitive damages, the Ninth Circuit concluded, are simi-
larly available when a seaman sues for unseaworthiness
under general maritime law.

author: Justice Ginsburg

II
  I turn now to an examination of Miles and Atlantic
Sounding closer than the attention accorded those deci-
sions by the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Miles, decided in 1990, addressed this question: In a
wrongful-death action premised on unseaworthiness, may
a deceased seaman’s parent recover damages for loss of
society?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
As the Court explained in Miles,
historically, general maritime law did not recognize a
cause of action for wrongful death.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Id., at 23 (citing The
Harrisburg, 119 U.S. 199 (1886)).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
But since the late 19th
century, every State had adopted a statutory wrongful-
death cause of action.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text: Miles, 498 U.S., at 23.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
And in two
statutes, Congress had provided for wrongful-death recov-
eries in maritime cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
First, the Jones Act, 46
U.S. C. §30104, provided a right of action for the survivor
of a seaman killed in the course of his employment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Sec-
ond, the Death on the High Seas Act (DOHSA), 46 U.S. C.
§30301 et seq., provided a right of action for the survivor of
anyone killed “by wrongful act, neglect, or default .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
on
the high seas.” §30302; Miles, 498 U.S., at 24.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
But the
Jones Act and DOHSA left some wrongful deaths at sea
without a remedy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
See Miles, 498 U.S., at 25–26.3 To fill
——————
  3 These were the unprovided-for cases: “First, in territorial waters,

general maritime law allowed a remedy for unseaworthiness resulting
in injury, but not for death.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Second, DOHSA allowed a remedy for
4                  DUTRA GROUP v. BATTERTON

                        GINSBURG, J., dissenting

gaps in this statutory regime, and in light of legislative
abrogation of the common-law disallowance of wrongful-
death claims, the Court in Moragne v. States Marine
Lines, Inc., 398 U.S. 375, 409 (1970), recognized a general
maritime cause of action for the wrongful death of a long-
shoreman.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
See also Miles, 498 U.S., at 26–30 (claim for
wrongful death is also available to seamen’s survivors).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
After recounting this history, the Miles Court addressed
the damages relief available for maritime wrongful death.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Because “Congress and the States ha[d] legislated exten-
sively in” the field of maritime law, the Court stated,
“admiralty court[s] should look primarily to these legisla-
tive enactments for policy guidance.” Id., at 27.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Congress
had expressly limited damages recoverable under DOHSA
to “pecuniary loss” sustained by the decedent’s survivor.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text: Id., at 31 (citing 46 U.S. C. App.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
§762, recodified at
§30303).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
And the Jones Act adopted the substantive
provisions of the Federal Employers Liability Act, 45
U.S. C. §51 et seq., which the Court construed to confine
wrongful-death damages to “pecuniary loss.” Miles, 498
U.S., at 32.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
The Miles Court reasoned that loss-of-society
damages were nonpecuniary, that such damages could not
be recovered under DOHSA or the Jones Act, and that it
would “be inconsistent with [the Court’s] place in the
constitutional scheme .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
to sanction more expansive
remedies” under general maritime law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Miles, 498 U. S.,

——————
death resulting from unseaworthiness on the high seas, but general
maritime law did not allow such recovery for a similar death in territo-
rial waters.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
in those States whose statutes allowed a claim
for wrongful death resulting from unseaworthiness, recovery was
available for the death of a longshoreman due to unseaworthiness, but
not for the death of a Jones Act seaman.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
This was because wrongful
death actions under the Jones Act are limited to negligence, and the
Jones Act pre-empts state law remedies for the death or injury of a
seaman.” Miles v. Apex Marine Corp., 498 U.S. 19, 26 (1990) (citation
omitted).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Cite as: 588 U. S. ____ (2019)                   5

                       GINSBURG, J., dissenting

at 31–33.4
   Some 19 years after Miles, in Atlantic Sounding, this
Court held that punitive damages are available in actions
for maintenance and cure under general maritime law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Atlantic Sounding’s reasoning had four
components.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
First, the Court observed, punitive damages
had a long common-law pedigree.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Sec-
ond, the “general rule that punitive damages were avail-
able at common law extended to claims arising under fed-
eral maritime law.” Id., at 411; see id., at 411–412.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Third,
“[n]othing in maritime law undermine[d] the applicability
of this general rule in the maintenance and cure context,”
notwithstanding slim evidence that punitive damages
were historically awarded in maintenance and cure ac-
tions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text: Id., at 412; see id., at 412–415, and n. 4.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Finally,
neither the Jones Act nor any other statute indicated that
Congress sought to displace the presumption that reme-
dies generally available under the common law are avail-
able for maritime claims.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
While the Jones Act armed sea-
men with a statutory action for negligence attributable to
a vessel operator, that remedy, Atlantic Sounding noted,
did not curtail pre-existing maritime causes of action and
remedies.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
The Atlantic Sounding Court
rejected as “far too broad” the argument that the remedies
available under general maritime law were confined to
those available under the Jones Act or DOHSA.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
——————
   4 The Miles Court relied on comparable reasoning in denying the

Under “the tradi-
tional maritime rule,” “there [wa]s no survival of unseaworthiness
claims.” Id., at 34.

The Court declined to decide whether to recognize a
general maritime survival right, however, because, even if such a right
were recognized, it would not support recovery of lost future income.

This damages limitation followed from the Jones Act, DOHSA,
and most States’ laws, which did not permit recovery of such damages.

   The Atlantic Sounding inquiries control this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
As in
Atlantic Sounding, “both the general maritime cause of
action”—here, unseaworthiness—“and the remedy (puni-
tive damages) were well established before the passage of
the Jones Act.” 557 U.S., at 420; Mitchell v. Trawler
Racer, Inc., 362 U.S. 539, 544 (1960); The Osceola, 189
U.S. 158, 175 (1903).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
And, unlike the maritime wrongful-
death action at issue in Miles, Batterton’s claim of unsea-
worthiness resulting in personal injury was not created to
fill gaps in a statutory scheme.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
See Atlantic Sounding,
557 U.S., at 420; Miles, 498 U.S., at 27, 36.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
The damages
available for Batterton’s unseaworthiness claim, Atlantic
Sounding therefore signals, need not track those available
under the Jones Act.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
III
   Applying Atlantic Sounding’s test, see supra, at 5, puni-
tive damages are not categorically barred in unseaworthi-
ness actions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Atlantic Sounding itself answers the first
two inquiries.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text: See supra, at 5.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
“Punitive damages have
long been an available remedy at common law for wanton,
willful, or outrageous conduct.” 557 U.S., at 409; see id.,
at 409–410.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
And “[t]he general rule that punitive damages
[are] available at common law extended to claims arising
under federal maritime law.” Id., at 411; see id., at 411–
412.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
As next explained, the third and fourth components
of Atlantic Sounding’s test are also satisfied.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
A
  Atlantic Sounding asks, third, whether anything in
maritime law “undermines the applicability [to the mari-
time action at issue] of th[e] general rule” that punitive
damages are available under general maritime law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Id.,
at 412.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
True, there is no evidence that courts awarded
punitive damages for unseaworthiness before the mid-
20th century.

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg

But neither is there

                      GINSBURG, J., dissenting

evidence that punitive damages were unavailable in un-
