author: Justice Ginsburg
text: of Oral Arg.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Contrary to the Court’s assertion, evidence of the avail-
ability of punitive damages for maintenance and cure was
not “central to our decision in Atlantic Sounding.” Ante, at
14–15.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text: Far from it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
“[A] search for cases in which puni-
tive damages were awarded for the willful denial of
maintenance and cure .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
yields very little.” Atlantic
Sounding, 557 U.S., at 430 (ALITO, J., dissenting).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
The
Court in Atlantic Sounding invoked historical evidence
about punitive damages in maintenance and cure actions,
“strikingly slim” though it was, id., at 431, only to under-
score this point: Without a showing that punitive damages
were unavailable, the generally applicable common-law
rule allowing punitive damages should not be displaced.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text: See id., at 412–415 (majority opinion).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Here, too, the
absence of evidence that punitive damages were unavail-
able in unseaworthiness cases supports adherence to the
general common-law rule permitting punitive damages.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
B
   Atlantic Sounding asks fourth: Has Congress “enacted
legislation departing from th[e] common-law understand-
ing” that punitive damages are generally available?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
See
id., at 415.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Dutra contends that unseaworthiness claims
and claims under the Jones Act are “simply two paths to
compensation for the same injury.” Brief for Petitioner
19–20 (emphasis deleted).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Positing that punitive damages
are unavailable under the Jones Act,5 Dutra concludes
they are likewise unavailable in unseaworthiness suits.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text: Id., at 17.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text: See also ante, at 13–15.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Dutra’s argument is
unavailing, for the Jones Act does not preclude the award
of punitive damages in unseaworthiness cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
——————
  5 This Court has not decided whether punitive damages are available

under the Jones Act.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
See Atlantic Sounding Co. v. Townsend, 557 U.S.
404, 424, n. 12 (2009) (reserving the question).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
8                  DUTRA GROUP v. BATTERTON

                        GINSBURG, J., dissenting

   As noted, the Jones Act provides a cause of action for a
seaman injured by his or her employer’s negligence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Congress passed the Act “primarily to
overrule The Osceola, [189 U.S. 158,] in which this Court
prohibited a seaman or his family from recovering for
injuries or death suffered due to his employers’ negli-
gence.” Atlantic Sounding, 557 U.S., at 415.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
The Jones
Act was intended to “enlarge th[e] protection” afforded to
seamen, “not to narrow it.” The Arizona v. Anelich, 298
U.S. 110, 123 (1936).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Accordingly, the Jones Act did not
provide an “exclusive remedy” for seamen’s injuries; in-
stead, it “preserve[d]” and supplemented “common-law
causes of action.” Atlantic Sounding, 557 U.S., at 416–
417.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
As Miles itself recognized, the Jones Act “d[id] not
disturb seamen’s general maritime claims for injuries
resulting from unseaworthiness.” 498 U.S., at 29.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
When the Jones Act was enacted, unseaworthiness and
negligence were “discrete concepts”: Unseaworthiness
related “to the structure of the ship and the adequacy of
[its] equipment and furnishings,” while negligence con-
cerned “the direction and control of operations aboard
ship.” G. Gilmore & C. Black, Law of Admiralty §6–3,
p. 277 (2d ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Because these actions were distinct,
it is improbable that, by enacting the Jones Act, Congress
meant to limit the remedies available in unseaworthiness
cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Though unseaworthiness and Jones Act negligence
now “significant[ly] overlap,” ante, at 8, that overlap re-
sulted primarily from mid-20th-century judicial decisions
expanding the scope of unseaworthiness liability.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
See
Mitchell, 362 U.S., at 547–550.6 Those decisions do not so
——————
  6 In particular, this Court held that a shipowner’s duty to provide a

seaworthy vessel was “absolute,” thereby rendering unseaworthiness a
strict-liability tort.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Seas Shipping Co. v. Sieracki, 328 U.S. 85, 94–95
(1946); Mahnich v. Southern S. S. Co., 321 U.S. 96, 100–101 (1944); see
1B Benedict on Admiralty §23, pp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
In
addition, courts broadened the range of conditions that could render a
                      Cite as: 588 U. S. ____ (2019)                      9

                         GINSBURG, J., dissenting

much as hint that Congress, in enacting the Jones Act,
intended to cabin the relief available for unseaworthiness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Even today, unseaworthiness and Jones Act negligence
are “not identical.” 2 R. Force & M. Norris, The Law of
Seamen §27:25, p. 27–61 (5th ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
2003).7 The persistent
differences between unseaworthiness and Jones Act
claims weigh against inserting into general maritime law
damages limitations that may be applicable to Jones Act
suits.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
See supra, at 7, n. 5.8
  The Court observes that a plaintiff may not recover
twice for the same injury under the Jones Act and unsea-
worthiness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text: Ante, at 9.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text: True enough.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
But the Court does
not explain why a bar to double recovery of compensatory
damages should affect the availability of a single award of
punitive damages.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Notably, punitive damages are not
awarded to compensate the plaintiff; their office is to
punish the defendant and deter misconduct.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
See Exxon,
——————
vessel unseaworthy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
7 Unseaworthiness is a strict-liability tort, ante, at 7–8; the Jones Act

requires proof of negligence, Lewis v. Lewis & Clark Marine, Inc., 531
U.S. 438, 441 (2001).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Unseaworthiness claims run against the vessel’s
owner, Mahnich, 321 U.S., at 100; Jones Act claims are brought
against the seaman’s “employer,” §30104.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Injury caused by the negli-
gent act or omission of a fit fellow crewmember may be actionable
under the Jones Act but is not ground for an unseaworthiness suit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
1B
Benedict on Admiralty §23, at 3–34 to 3–38; see Usner v. Luckenbach
Overseas Corp., 400 U.S. 494 (1971).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
And a vessel owner is liable for
unseaworthiness only when the unseaworthy condition proximately
caused the plaintiff ’s injury; under the Jones Act, a plaintiff can prevail
upon showing the “slight[est]” causal connection between the defend-
ant’s conduct and the plaintiff ’s injury.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
2 Force & Norris, The Law of
Seamen §27:25, at 27–62 to 27–63.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
See also id., §27:2, at 27–7, and n. 6
(the duty to provide a seaworthy vessel may run to “seamen” who do
not qualify as such under the Jones Act).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
8 The Court recognizes “that the general maritime law need not be

static,” but would confine changes in that law to those needed to align it
with statutory law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text: Ante, at 16, n. 9.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
As just stated, however, supra, at
8–9, the Jones Act was intended to augment, not to cabin, relief avail-
able to seamen.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
10              DUTRA GROUP v. BATTERTON

                    GINSBURG, J., dissenting

554 U.S., at 492; W. Keeton, D. Dobbs, R. Keeton, & D.
Owen, Prosser and Keeton on Law of Torts §2, p. 9 (5th ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
There is thus no tension between preventing dou-
ble recovery of compensatory damages and allowing the
recovery, once, of punitive damages.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
IV
    Finally, the Court takes up policy arguments against
the availability of punitive damages in unseaworthiness
actions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text: Ante, at 15–18.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
The Court, however, has long
recognized the general availability of punitive damages
under maritime law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
E.g., Atlantic Sounding, 557 U.S., at
411–412; Exxon, 554 U.S., at 489–490; The Amiable Nancy,
3 Wheat.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Punitive damages serve to deter and punish “lawless
misconduct.” Ibid.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
The imperative of countering a
“heightened threat of harm,” Exxon, 554 U.S., at 490, is
especially pressing with regard to sailors, who face unique
“hazards in the ship’s service,” Harden v. Gordon, 11 F.
Cas.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
These
dangers, more than paternalistic 19th-century attitudes
towards sailors, see ante, at 18, account for the Court’s
“ ‘special solicitude’ ” for “those who undertake to ‘venture
upon hazardous and unpredictable sea voyages.’ ” Air &
Liquid Systems Corp. v. DeVries, 586 U. S. ___, ___ (2019)
(slip op., at 9) (quoting American Export Lines, Inc. v.
Alvez, 446 U.S. 274, 285 (1980)).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Dutra and the Court warn that allowing punitive dam-
ages in unseaworthiness actions could impair maritime
commerce.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text: Brief for Petitioner 33–34; ante, at 17–18.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
But
punitive damages have been available in maintenance and
cure cases in all Circuits for the last decade, Atlantic
Sounding, 557 U.S. 404, and in unseaworthiness cases in
some Circuits for longer, see Self v. Great Lakes Dredge &
Dock Co., 832 F.2d 1540, 1550 (CA11 1987); Evich, 819
F.2d, at 258.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
No tidal wave has overwhelmed commerce
                 Cite as: 588 U. S. ____ (2019)          11

                   GINSBURG, J., dissenting

in those Circuits.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Permitting punitive damages for unseaworthiness, the
Court further urges, would create “bizarre disparities.”
Ante, at 17.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
I see no “bizarre disparit[y]” in allowing an
injured sailor to seek remedies unavailable to survivors of
deceased seamen.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
See Keeton, supra, §127, at 949, 951
(state wrongful-death statutes frequently limit survivors’
recoveries to pecuniary damages).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Nor is it “bizarre” to
permit recovery of punitive damages against a shipowner
“for injuries due to unseaworthiness of the vessel.” The
Arizona, 298 U.S., at 120.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
Exposure to such damages
helps to deter wrongdoing, particularly when malfeasance
is “hard to detect.” Exxon, 554 U.S., at 494.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
If there is
any “bizarre disparit[y],” it is the one the Court today
creates: Punitive damages are available for willful and
wanton breach of the duty to provide maintenance and
cure, but not for similarly culpable breaches of the duty to
provide a seaworthy vessel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Ginsburg
text:
*    *    *
 For the reasons stated, I would affirm the Court of
Appeals’ judgment
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Petitioners, husband and wife, stand convicted under § 145 of the Internal Revenue Code[1] of an attempt to evade and defeat their income taxes for the year 1948.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The prosecution was based on the net worth method of proof, also in issue in three companion cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: [2] and a number of other decisions here from the Courts of Appeals of nine circuits.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: During the past two decades this Court has been asked to review an increasing number of criminal cases in which proof of tax evasion rested on this theory.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: We have denied certiorari because the cases involved only questions of evidence and, in isolation, presented no important questions of law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In 1943 the Court did have occasion to pass upon an application of the net worth theory where the taxpayer had no records.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: United States v. Johnson, 319 U.S. 503.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In recent years, however, tax-evasion convictions obtained under the net worth theory have come here with increasing frequency and left impressions beyond those of the previously unrelated petitions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: We concluded that the method involved something more than the ordinary use of circumstantial evidence in the usual criminal case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Its bearing, therefore, on the safeguards traditionally *125 provided in the administration of criminal justice called for a consideration of the entire theory.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: At our last Term a number of cases arising from the Courts of Appeals brought to our attention the serious doubts of those courts regarding the implications of the net worth method.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Accordingly, we granted certiorari in these four cases and have held others to await their decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In a typical net worth prosecution, the Government having concluded that the taxpayer's records are inadequate as a basis for determining income tax liability, attempts to establish an "opening net worth" or total net value of the taxpayer's assets at the beginning of a given year.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: It then proves increases in the taxpayer's net worth for each succeeding year during the period under examination and calculates the difference between the adjusted net values of the taxpayer's assets at the beginning and end of each of the years involved.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The taxpayer's nondeductible expenditures, including living expenses, are added to these increases, and if the resulting figure for any year is substantially greater than the taxable income reported by the taxpayer for that year, the Government claims the excess represents unreported taxable income.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In addition, it asks the jury to infer willfulness from this understatement, when taken in connection with direct evidence of "conduct, the likely effect of which would be to mislead or to conceal."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Spies v. United States, 317 U.S. 492, 499.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Before proceeding with a discussion of these cases, we believe it important to outline the general problems implicit in this type of litigation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In this consideration we assume, as we must in view of its widespread use, that the Government deems the net worth method useful in the enforcement of the criminal sanctions of our income tax laws.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Nevertheless, careful study indicates that it is so fraught with danger for the innocent that the courts must closely scrutinize its use.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: *126 One basic assumption in establishing guilt by this method is that most assets derive from a taxable source, and that when this is not true the taxpayer is in a position to explain the discrepancy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The application of such an assumption raises serious legal problems in the administration of the criminal law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Unlike civil actions for the recovery of deficiencies, where the determinations of the Commissioner have prima facie validity, the prosecution must always prove the criminal charge beyond a reasonable doubt.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: This has led many of our courts to be disturbed by the use of the net worth method, particularly in its scope and the latitude which it allows prosecutors.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: E. g., Demetree v. United States, 207 F.2d 892, 894 (1953); United States v. Caserta, 199 F.2d 905, 907 (1952); United States v. Fenwick, 177 F.2d 488.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: But the net worth method has not grown up overnight.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: It was first utilized in such cases as Capone v. United States, 51 F.2d 609 (1931) and Guzik v. United States, 54 F.2d 618 (1931), to corroborate direct proof of specific unreported income.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In United States v. Johnson, supra, this Court approved of its use to support the inference that the taxpayer, owner of a vast and elaborately concealed network of gambling houses upon which he declared no income, had indeed received unreported income in a "substantial amount."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: It was a potent weapon in establishing taxable income from undisclosed sources when all other efforts failed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Since the Johnson case, however, its horizons have been widened until now it is used in run-of-the-mine cases, regardless of the amount of tax deficiency involved.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In each of the four cases decided today the allegedly unreported income comes from the same disclosed sources as produced the taxpayer's reported income and in none is the tax deficiency anything like the deficiencies in Johnson, Capone or Guzik.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The net worth method, it seems, has evolved from the final volley to the first shot in the Government's *127 battle for revenue, and its use in the ordinary income-bracket cases greatly increases the chances for error.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: This leads us to point out the dangers that must be consciously kept in mind in order to assure adequate appraisal of the specific facts in individual cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Among the defenses often asserted is the taxpayer's claim that the net worth increase shown by the Government's statement is in reality not an increase at all because of the existence of substantial cash on hand at the starting point.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: This favorite defense asserts that the cache is made up of many year's savings which for various reasons were hidden and not expended until the prosecution period.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Obviously, the Government has great difficulty in refuting such a contention.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: However, taxpayers too encounter many obstacles in convincing the jury of the existence of such hoards.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: This is particularly so when the emergence of the hidden savings also uncovers a fraud on the taxpayer's creditors.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In this connection, the taxpayer frequently gives "leads" to the Government agents indicating the specific sources from which his cash on hand has come, such as prior earnings, stock transactions, real estate profits inheritances, gifts, etc.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Sometimes these "leads" point back to old transactions far removed from the prosecution period.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Were the Government required to run down all such leads it would face grave investigative difficulties; still its failure to do so might jeopardize the position of the taxpayer.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: As we have said, the method requires assumptions, among which is the equation of unexplained increases in net worth with unreported taxable income.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Obviously such an assumption has many weaknesses.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: It may be that gifts, inheritances, loans and the like account for the newly acquired wealth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: There is great danger that the jury may assume that once the Government has established the figures in its worth computations, *128 the crime of tax evasion automatically follows.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The possibility of this increases where the jury, without guarding instructions, is allowed to take into the jury room the various charts summarizing the computations; bare figures have a way of acquiring an existence of their own, independent of the evidence which gave rise to them.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Although it may sound fair to say that the taxpayer can explain the "bulge" in his net worth, he may be entirely honest and yet unable to recount his financial history.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In addition, such a rule would tend to shift the burden of proof.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Were the taxpayer compelled to come forward with evidence, he might risk lending support to the Government's case by showing loose business methods or losing the jury through his apparent evasiveness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Of course, in other criminal prosecutions juries may disbelieve and convict the innocent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: But the courts must minimize this danger.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: When there are no books and records, willfulness may be inferred by the jury from that fact coupled with proof of an understatement of income.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: But when the Government uses the net worth method, and the books and records of the taxpayer appear correct on their face, an inference of willfulness from net worth increases alone might be unjustified, especially where the circumstances surrounding the deficiency are as consistent with innocent mistake as with willful violation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: On the other hand, the very failure of the books to disclose a proved deficiency might indicate deliberate falsification.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In many cases of this type, the prosecution relies on the taxpayer's statements, made to revenue agents in the course of their investigation, to establish vital links in the Government's proof.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: But when a revenue agent confronts the taxpayer with an apparent deficiency, the latter may be more concerned with a quick settlement than an honest search for the truth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Moreover, the prosecution may pick and choose from the taxpayer's statement, *129 relying on the favorable portion and throwing aside that which does not bolster its position.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The problem of corroboration, dealt with in the companion cases of Smith v. United States, post, p. 147, and United States v. Calderon, post, p. 160, therefore becomes crucial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The statute defines the offense here involved by individual years.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: While the Government may be able to prove with reasonable accuracy an increase in net worth over a period of years, it often has great difficulty in relating that income sufficiently to any specific prosecution year.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: While a steadily increasing net worth may justify an inference of additional earnings, unless that increase can be reasonably allocated to the appropriate tax year the taxpayer may be convicted on counts of which he is innocent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: While we cannot say that these pitfalls inherent in the net worth method foreclose its use, they do require the exercise of great care and restraint.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The complexity of the problem is such that it cannot be met merely by the application of general rules.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Universal Camera Corp. v. Labor Board, 340 U.S. 474, 489.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Trial courts should approach these cases in the full realization that the taxpayer may be ensnared in a system which, though difficult for the prosecution to utilize, is equally hard for the defendant to refute.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Charges should be especially clear, including, in addition to the formal instructions, a summary of the nature of the net worth method, the assumptions on which it rests, and the inferences available both for and against the accused.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Appellate courts should review the cases, bearing constantly in mind the difficulties that arise when circumstantial evidence as to guilt is the chief weapon of a method that is itself only an approximation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: With these considerations as a guide, we turn to the facts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: *130 The indictment returned against the Hollands embraced three counts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The first two charged Marion L. Holland, the husband, with attempted evasion of his income tax for the years 1946 and 1947.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: He was found not guilty by the jury on both of these counts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The third count charged Holland and his wife with attempted evasion in 1948 of the tax on $19,736.74 not reported by them in their joint return.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The jury found both of them guilty.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Mrs. Holland was fined $5,000, while her husband was sentenced to two years' imprisonment and fined $10,000.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The Government's opening net worth computation shows defendants with a net worth of $19,152.59 at the beginning of the indictment period.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Shortly thereafter, defendants purchased a hotel, bar and restaurant, and began operating them as the Holland House.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Within three years, during which they reported $31,265.92 in taxable income, their apparent net worth increased by $113,185.32.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: [3] The Government's evidence indicated that, during 1948, the year for which defendants were convicted, their net worth increased by some $32,000, while the amount of taxable income reported by them totaled less than one-third that sum.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Use of Net Worth Method Where Books Are Apparently Adequate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: As we have previously noted, this is not the first net worth case to reach this Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In United States v. Johnson, supra, the Court affirmed a tax-evasion conviction on evidence showing that the taxpayer's expenditures had exceeded his "available declared resources."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Since Johnson and his concealed establishments had destroyed *131 the few records they had, the Government was forced to resort to the net worth method of proof.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: This Court approved on the ground that "to require more .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: would be tantamount to holding that skilful concealment is an invincible barrier to proof," 319 U.S., at 517-518.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Petitioners ask that we restrict the Johnson case to situations where the taxpayer has kept no books.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: They claim that § 41 of the Internal Revenue Code,[4] expressly limiting the authority of the Government to deviate from the taxpayer's method of accounting, confines the net worth method to situations where the taxpayer has no books or where his books are inadequate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Despite some support for this view among the lower courts (see United States v. Riganto, 121 F. Supp.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: 158, 161, 162; United States v. Williams, 208 F.2d 437, 437-438; Remmer v. United States, 205 F.2d 277, 286, judgment vacated on other grounds, 347 U.S. 227), we conclude that this argument must fail.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The provision that the "net income shall be computed .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: in accordance with the method of accounting regularly employed in keeping the books of such taxpayer," refers to methods such as the cash receipts or the accrual method, which allocate income and expenses between years.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: United States v. American Can Co., 280 U.S. 412, 419.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The net worth technique as used in this case, is not a method of accounting different from the one employed by defendants.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: It is not a method of accounting at all, except insofar as it calls upon taxpayers to account for their unexplained income.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Petitioners' accounting system was appropriate *132 for their business purposes; and, admittedly, the Government did not detect any specific false entries therein.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Nevertheless, if we believe the Government's evidence, as the jury did, we must conclude that the defendants' books were more consistent than truthful, and that many items of income had disappeared before they had even reached the recording stage.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Certainly Congress never intended to make § 41 a set of blinders which prevents the Government from looking beyond the self-serving declarations in a taxpayer's books.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: "The United States has relied for the collection of its income tax largely upon the taxpayer's own disclosures .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: This system can function successfully only if those within and near taxable income keep and render true accounts."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Spies v. United States, 317 U. S., at 495.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: To protect the revenue from those who do not "render true accounts," the Government must be free to use all legal evidence available to it in determining whether the story told by the taxpayer's books accurately reflects his financial history.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Establishing a Definite Opening Net Worth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: We agree with petitioners that an essential condition in cases of this type is the establishment, with reasonable certainty, of an opening net worth, to serve as a starting point from which to calculate future increases in the taxpayer's assets.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The importance of accuracy in this figure is immediately apparent, as the correctness of the result depends entirely upon the inclusion in this sum of all assets on hand at the outset.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The Government's net worth statement included as assets at the starting point stock costing $29,650 and $2,153.09 in cash.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: [5] The Hollands claim that the Government failed to include in its opening net worth figure an accumulation of $113,000 *133 in currency and "hundreds and possibly thousands of shares of stock" which they owned at the beginning of the prosecution period.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: They asserted that the cash had been accumulated prior to the opening date, $104,000 of it before 1933, and the balance between 1933 and 1945.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: They had kept the money, they claimed, mostly in $100 bills and at various times in a canvas bag, a suitcase, and a metal box.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: They had never dipped into it until 1946, when it became the source of the apparent increase in wealth which the Government later found in the form of a home, a ranch, a hotel and other properties.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: This was the main issue presented to the jury.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The Government did not introduce any direct evidence to dispute this claim.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Rather it relied on the inference that anyone who had had $104,000 in cash would not have undergone the hardship and privation endured by the Hollands all during the late 20's and throughout the 30's.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: During this period they lost their cafe business; accumulated $35,000 in debts which were never paid; lost their household furniture because of an unpaid balance of $92.20; suffered a default judgment for $506.66; and were forced to separate for some eight years because it was to their "economical advantage."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: During the latter part of this period, Mrs. Holland was obliged to support herself and their son by working at a motion picture house in Denver while her husband was in Wyoming.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The evidence further indicated that improvements to the hotel, and other assets acquired during the prosecution years, were bought in installments and with bills of small denominations, as if out of earnings rather than from an accumulation of $100 bills.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The Government also negatived the possibility of petitioners' accumulating such a sum by checking Mr. Holland's income tax returns as far back as 1913, showing that the income declared in previous years was insufficient to enable defendants to save any appreciable *134 amount of money.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The jury resolved this question of the existence of a cache of cash against the Hollands, and we believe the verdict was fully supported.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: As to the stock, Mr. Holland began dabbling in the stock market in a small way in 1937 and 1938.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: His purchases appear to have been negligible and on borrowed money.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: His only reported income from stocks was in his tax returns for 1944 and 1945 when he disclosed dividends of $1,600 and $1,850 respectively.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: While the record is unclear on this point, it appears that during the period from 1942 to 1945 he pledged considerable stock as collateral for loans.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: There is no evidence, however, showing what portions of this stock Mr. Holland actually owned at any one time, since he was trading in shares from day to day.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: And, even if we assume that he owned all the stock, some 4,550 shares, there is evidence that Mr. Holland's stock transactions were usually in "stock selling for only a few dollars per share."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In this light, the Government's figure of approximately $30,000 is not out of line.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In 1946 Holland reported the sale of about $50,000 in stock, but no receipt of dividends; nor were dividends reported in subsequent years.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: It is reasonable to assume that he sold all of his stock in 1946.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In fact, Holland stated to the revenue agents that he had not "fooled with the stock market" since the beginning of 1946; that he had not owned any stocks for two or three years prior to 1949; that he had saved about $50,000 from 1933 to 1946, and that in 1946 he had $9,000 in cash with the balance of his savings in stocks.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: [6] The Government's evidence, bolstered by the admissions of petitioners, provided *135 convincing proof that they had no stock other than the amount included in the opening net worth statement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: By the same token, the petitioners' argument that the Government failed to account for the proceeds of stock sold by them before the starting date must also fail.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The Government's evidence fully justified the jury's conclusion that there were no proceeds over and above the amount credited to petitioners.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The Government's Investigation of Leads.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: So overwhelming, indeed, was the Government's proof on the issue of cash on hand that the Government agents did not bother to check petitioners' story that some of the cash represented proceeds from the sales of two cafes in the 20's; and that in 1933 an additional portion of this $113,000 in currency was obtained by exchanging some $12,000 in gold at a named bank.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: While sound administration of the criminal law requires that the net worth approacha powerful method of proving otherwise undetectable offensesshould not be denied the Government, its failure to investigate leads furnished by the taxpayer might result in serious injustice.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: It is, of course, not for us to prescribe investigative procedures,[7] but it is within the province of the courts to pass upon the sufficiency of the evidence to convict.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: When the Government rests its case solely on the approximations and circumstantial inferences of a net worth computation, the cogency of its proof depends upon its effective negation of reasonable explanations by the taxpayer inconsistent with guilt.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Such refutation might fail when the Government does not track down relevant leads furnished by the *136 taxpayerleads reasonably susceptible of being checked, which, if true, would establish the taxpayer's innocence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: When the Government fails to show an investigation into the validity of such leads, the trial judge may consider them as true and the Government's case insufficient to go to the jury.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: This should aid in forestalling unjust prosecutions, and have the practical advantage of eliminating the dilemma, especially serious in this type of case, of the accused's being forced by the risk of an adverse verdict to come forward to substantiate leads which he had previously furnished the Government.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: It is a procedure entirely consistent with the position long espoused by the Government, that its duty is not to convict but to see that justice is done.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In this case, the Government's detailed investigation was a complete answer to the petitioners' explanations.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Admitting that in cases of this kind it "would be desirable to track to its conclusion every conceivable line of inquiry," the Government centered its inquiry on the explanations of the Hollands and entered upon a detailed investigation of their lives covering several states and over a score of years.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The jury could have believed that Mr. Holland had received moneys from the sale of cafes in the twenties and that he had turned in gold in 1933 and still it could reasonably have concluded that the Hollands lacked the claimed cache of currency in 1946, the crucial year.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Even if these leads were assumed to be true, the Government's evidence was sufficient to convict.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The distant incidents relied on by petitioners were so remote in time and in their connection with subsequent events proved by the Government that, whatever petitioners' net worth in 1933, it appears by convincing evidence that on January 1, 1946, they had only such assets as the Government credited to them in its opening net worth statement.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: *137 Net Worth Increases Must be Attributable to Taxable Income.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Also requisite to the use of the net worth method is evidence supporting the inference that the defendant's net worth increases are attributable to currently taxable income.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The Government introduced evidence tending to show that although the business of the hotel apparently increased during the years in question, the reported profits fell to approximately one-quarter of the amount declared by the previous management in a comparable period;[8] that the cash register tapes, on which the books were based, were destroyed by the petitioners; and that the books did not reflect the receipt of money later withdrawn from the hotel's cash register for the personal living expenses of the petitioners and for payments made for restaurant supplies.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The unrecorded items in this latter category totaled over $12,500 for 1948.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Thus there was ample evidence that not all the income from the hotel had been included in its books and records.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In fact, the net worth increase claimed by the Government for 1948 could have come entirely from the unreported income of the hotel and still the hotel's total earnings for the year would have been only 73% of the sum reported by the previous owner for the comparable period in 1945.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: But petitioners claim the Government failed to adduce adequate proof because it did not negative all the possible nontaxable sources of the alleged net worth increasesgifts, loans, inheritances, etc.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: We cannot agree.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The Government's proof, in our view, carried with it the negations the petitioners urge.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Increases in net *138 worth, standing alone, cannot be assumed to be attributable to currently taxable income.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: But proof of a likely source, from which the jury could reasonably find that the net worth increases sprang, is sufficient.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In the Johnson case, where there was no direct evidence of the source of the taxpayer's income, this Court's conclusion that the taxpayer "had large, unreported income was reinforced by proof .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: that [for certain years his] private expenditures .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: exceeded his available declared resources."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: This was sufficient to support "the finding that he had some unreported income which was properly attributable to his earnings .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: United States v. Johnson, 319 U. S., at 517.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: There the taxpayer was the owner of an undisclosed business capable of producing taxable income; here the disclosed business of the petitioners was proven to be capable of producing much more income than was reported and in a quantity sufficient to account for the net worth increases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Any other rule would burden the Government with investigating the many possible nontaxable sources of income, each of which is as unlikely as it is difficult to disprove.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: This is not to say that the Government may disregard explanations of the defendant reasonably susceptible of being checked.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: But where relevant leads are not forthcoming, the Government is not required to negate every possible source of nontaxable income, a matter peculiarly within the knowledge of the defendant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: See Rossi v. United States, 289 U.S. 89, 91-92.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The Burden of Proof Remains on the Government.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Nor does this rule shift the burden of proof.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The Government must still prove every element of the offense beyond a reasonable doubt though not to a mathematical certainty.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The settled standards of the criminal law are applicable to net worth cases just as to prosecutions for other crimes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Once the Government has established its *139 case, the defendant remains quiet at his peril.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Yee Hem v. United States, 268 U.S. 178, 185.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The practical disadvantages to the taxpayer are lessened by the pressures on the Government to check and negate relevant leads.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Willfulness Must be Present.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: A final element necessary for conviction is willfulness.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The petitioners contend that willfulness "involves a specific intent which must be proven by independent evidence and which cannot be inferred from the mere understatement of income."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: This is a fair statement of the rule.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Here, however, there was evidence of a consistent pattern of underreporting large amounts of income, and of the failure on petitioners' part to include all of their income in their books and records.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Since, on proper submission, the jury could have found that these acts supported an inference of willfulness, their verdict must stand.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Spies v. United States, supra, at 499-500.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The Charge to the Jury.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Petitioners press upon us, finally, the contention that the instructions of the trial court were so erroneous and misleading as to constitute grounds for reversal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: We have carefully reviewed the instructions and cannot agree.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: But some require comment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The petitioners assail the refusal of the trial judge to instruct that where the Government's evidence is circumstantial it must be such as to exclude every reasonable hypothesis other than that of guilt.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: There is some support for this type of instruction in the lower court decisions, Garst v. United States, 180 F. 339, 343; Anderson v. United States, 30 F.2d 485-487; Stutz v. United States, 47 F.2d 1029, 1030; Hanson v. United States, 208 F.2d 914, 916, but the better rule is that where the jury is properly instructed on the standards for reasonable doubt, such an additional instruction *140 on circumstantial evidence is confusing and incorrect, United States v. Austin-Bagley Corp., 31 F.2d 229, 234, cert.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: denied, 279 U.S. 863; United States v. Becker, 62 F.2d 1007, 1010; 1 Wigmore, Evidence (3d ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Circumstantial evidence in this respect is intrinsically no different from testimonial evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Admittedly, circumstantial evidence may in some cases point to a wholly incorrect result.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Yet this is equally true of testimonial evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In both instances, a jury is asked to weigh the chances that the evidence correctly points to guilt against the possibility of inaccuracy or ambiguous inference.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: In both, the jury must use its experience with people and events in weighing the probabilities.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: If the jury is convinced beyond a reasonable doubt, we can require no more.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: Even more insistent is the petitioners' attack, not made below, on the charge of the trial judge as to reasonable doubt.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: He defined it as "the kind of doubt .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: which you folks in the more serious and important affairs of your own lives might be willing to act upon."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: We think this section of the charge should have been in terms of the kind of doubt that would make a person hesitate to act, see Bishop v. United States, 71 Ohio App.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: D. C. 132, 137-138, 107 F.2d 297, 303, rather than the kind on which he would be willing to act.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: But we believe that the instruction as given was not of the type that could mislead the jury into finding no reasonable doubt when in fact there was some.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: A definition of a doubt as something the jury would act upon would seem to create confusion rather than misapprehension.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: "Attempts to explain the term `reasonable doubt' do not usually result in making it any clearer to the minds of the jury," Miles v. United States, 103 U.S. 304, 312, and we feel that, taken as a whole, the instructions correctly conveyed the concept of reasonable doubt to the jury.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: *141 Petitioners also assign as error the refusal of the trial judge to give instructions on the wording of the criminal statute under which they were indicted, even though the judge fully and correctly instructed the jury on every element of the crime.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The impossibility of pointing to any way in which defendants' rights were prejudiced by this, assuming it was error, is enough to indicate that the trial judge was correct, see United States v. Center Veal & Beef Co., 162 F.2d 766, 771.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: There is here no question of the jury's duty to apply the law to the facts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: That operation implies the application of a general standard to the specific physical facts as found by the jury.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text: The meanings of standards such as willfulness were properly explained by the trial judge in no greater particularity than necessary, and thus the jury's function was not invaded.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Clark
text:
In the light of these considerations the judgment is
Affirmed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Today the Court holds that New Hampshire cannot decide that a New Hampshire lawyer should live in New Hampshire.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: This may not be surprising to those who view law as just another form of business frequently practiced across state lines by interchangeable actors; the Privileges and Immunities Clause of Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: IV, § 2, has long been held to apply to States' attempts to discriminate against nonresidents who seek to ply their trade interstate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The decision will be surprising to many, however, because it so clearly disregards the fact that the practice of law is  almost by definition  fundamentally different from those other occupations that are practiced across state lines without significant deviation from State to State.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The fact that each State is free, in a large number of areas, to establish independently of the other States its own laws for the governance of its citizens, is *290 a fundamental precept of our Constitution that, I submit, is of equal stature with the need for the States to form a cohesive union.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: What is at issue here is New Hampshire's right to decide that those people who in many ways will intimately deal with New Hampshire's self-governance should reside within that State.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The Court's opinion states that the Privileges and Immunities Clause of Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: IV, § 2, "was intended to `fuse into one Nation a collection of independent, sovereign States.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: " Ante, at 279 (quoting Toomer v. Witsell, 334 U.S. 385, 395 (1948)).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: To this end, we are told, the Clause has been construed to protect the fundamental "privilege" of citizens of one State to do business in another State on terms substantially equal with that State's citizens.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: This privilege must be protected to effectuate the Clause's purpose to "create a national economic union."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Ante, at 280.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: And for the Court, the practice of law is no different from those occupations considered in earlier Privileges and Immunities Clause cases, because "the practice of law is important to the national economy."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Ante, at 281.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: After concluding that the Clause applies to lawyers, the Court goes on to reject the many reasons the Supreme Court of New Hampshire advances for limiting the State's lawyers to those who reside in state.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The Court either labels these reasons insubstantial, or it advances, with the assurance of an inveterate second-guesser, a "less restrictive means" for the State to attack the perceived problem.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The Framers of our Constitution undoubtedly wished to ensure that the newly created Union did not revert to its component parts because of interstate jealousies and insular tendencies, and it seems clear that the Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: IV Privileges and Immunities Clause was one result of these concerns.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: But the Framers also created a system of federalism that deliberately allowed for the independent operation of many sovereign States, each with their own laws created by their own legislators and judges.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The assumption from the beginning was that the various States' laws need not, and would not, *291 be the same; the lawmakers of each State might endorse different philosophies and would have to respond to differing interests of their constituents, based on various factors that were of inherently local character.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Any student of our Nation's history is well aware of the differing interests of the various States that were represented at Philadelphia; despite the tremendous improvements in transportation and communication that have served to create a more homogeneous country the differences among the various States have hardly disappeared.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: It is but a small step from these facts to the recognition that a State has a very strong interest in seeing that its legislators and its judges come from among the constituency of state residents, so that they better understand the local interests to which they will have to respond.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The Court does not contest this point; it recognizes that a State may require its lawmakers to be residents without running afoul of the Privileges and Immunities Clause of Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: See ante, at 282, n. 13.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Unlike the Court, I would take the next step, and recognize that the State also has a very "substantial" interest in seeing that its lawyers also are members of that constituency.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: I begin with two important principles that the Court seems to have forgotten: first, that in reviewing state statutes under this Clause "States should have considerable leeway in analyzing local evils and prescribing appropriate cures," United Building & Construction Trades Council v. Mayor & Council of Camden, 465 U.S. 208, 223 (1984) (citing Toomer, supra, at 396), and second, that regulation of the practice of law generally has been "left exclusively to the States .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Leis v. Flynt, 439 U.S. 438, 442 (1979) (per curiam).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: My belief that the practice of law differs from other trades and businesses for Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: IV, § 2, purposes is not based on some notion that law is for some reason a superior profession.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The reason that the practice of law should be treated differently is that law is one occupation that does not *292 readily translate across state lines.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: [1] Certain aspects of legal practice are distinctly and intentionally nonnational; in this regard one might view this country's legal system as the antithesis of the norms embodied in the Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: IV Privileges and Immunities Clause.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Put simply, the State has a substantial interest in creating its own set of laws responsive to its own local interests, and it is reasonable for a State to decide that those people who have been trained to analyze law and policy are better equipped to write those state laws and adjudicate cases arising under them.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The State therefore may decide that it has an interest in maximizing the number of resident lawyers, so as to increase the quality of the pool from which its lawmakers can be drawn.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: [2] A residency law such as the one at issue is the obvious way to accomplish these goals.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Since at any given time within a State there is only enough legal work to support a certain number of lawyers, each out-of-state *293 lawyer who is allowed to practice necessarily takes legal work that could support an in-state lawyer, who would otherwise be available to perform various functions that a State has an interest in promoting.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text:
[3]
Nor does the State's interest end with enlarging the pool of qualified lawmakers.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: A State similarly might determine that because lawyers play an important role in the formulation of state policy through their adversary representation, they should be intimately conversant with the local concerns that should inform such policies.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: And the State likewise might conclude that those citizens trained in the law are likely to bring their useful expertise to other important functions that benefit from such expertise and are of interest to state governments  such as trusteeships, or directorships of corporations or charitable organizations, or school board positions, or merely the role of the interested citizen at a town meeting.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Thus, although the Court suggests that state bars can require out-of-state members to "represent indigents and perhaps to participate in formal legal-aid work," ante, at 287, the Court ignores a host of other important functions that a State could find would likely be performed only by in-state bar members.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: States may find a substantial interest in members of their bar being residents, and this insular interest  as with the opposing interest in interstate harmony represented by Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: IV, § 2  itself has its genesis in the language and structure of the Constitution.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text:
[4]
*294 It is no answer to these arguments that many lawyers simply will not perform these functions, or that out-of-state lawyers can perform them equally well, or that the State can devise less restrictive alternatives for accomplishing these goals.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Conclusory second-guessing of difficult legislative decisions, such as the Court resorts to today, is not an attractive way for federal courts to engage in judicial review.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Thus, whatever the reality of how much New Hampshire can expect to gain from having the members of its bar reside within that State, the point is that New Hampshire is entitled to believe and hope that its lawyers will provide the various unique services mentioned above, just as it is entitled to believe that the residency requirement is the appropriate way to that end.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: As noted, some of these services can only be provided by lawyers who also are residents.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: With respect to the other services, the State can reasonably find that lawyers who reside in state are more likely to undertake them.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: In addition, I find the Court's "less restrictive means" analysis both ill-advised and potentially unmanageable.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Initially I would note, as I and other Members of this Court have before, see Central Hudson Gas & Elec.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Corp. v. Public Service Comm'n of New York, 447 U.S. 557, 599-600 (1980) (REHNQUIST, J., dissenting) (citing Illinois Elections Bd.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: v. Socialist Workers Party, 440 U.S. 173, 188-189 (1979) (BLACKMUN, J., concurring)); cf.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Florida v. Royer, 460 U.S. 491, 528-529 (1983) (REHNQUIST, J., dissenting), that such an analysis, when carried too far, will ultimately lead to striking *295 down almost any statute on the ground that the Court could think of another "less restrictive" way to write it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: This approach to judicial review, far more than the usual application of a standard of review, tends to place courts in the position of second-guessing legislators on legislative matters.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Surely this is not a consequence to be desired.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: In any event, I find the less-restrictive-means analysis, which is borrowed from our First Amendment jurisprudence, to be out of place in the context of the Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Toomer v. Witsell, 334 U. S., at 396, and Hicklin v. Orbeck, 437 U.S. 518, 529-530 (1978), indicate that the means employed by the State should bear a "substantial" or "close relation" to the State's objectives, and they speak in terms of whether the State's approach is "tailored" to its stated goal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: This approach perhaps has a place: to the extent that an obvious way to accomplish the State's proffered goal is apparent, the fact that the State did not follow that path may indicate that the State had another, less legitimate goal in mind.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: But I believe the challenge of a "less restrictive means" should be overcome if merely a legitimate reason exists for not pursuing that path.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: And in any event courts should not play the game that the Court has played here  independently scrutinizing each asserted state interest to see if it could devise a better way than the State to accomplish that goal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Here the appellee primarily argues that if the State really was concerned about out-of-state lawyers it would not allow those who leave the State after joining the bar to remain members.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The answer to this argument was well stated by the dissenting judges in the Court of Appeals for the First Circuit: "[T]he Supreme Court of New Hampshire might have concluded that not many New Hampshire lawyers will both pull up stakes and continue to practice in the state.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: And it might further believe that the bureaucracy required to keep track of such comings and goings would not be worth the trouble .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: 723 F.2d 110, 122, n. 4 (1983) (opinion of Campbell, C. J., and Breyer, J.).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: *296 There is yet another interest asserted by the State that I believe would justify a decision to limit membership in the state bar to state residents.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The State argues that out-of-state bar members pose a problem in situations where counsel must be available on short notice to represent clients on unscheduled matters.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The Court brushes this argument aside, speculating that "a high percentage of nonresident lawyers willing to take the state bar examination and pay the annual dues will reside in places reasonably convenient to New Hampshire," and suggesting that in any event the trial court could alleviate this problem by requiring the lawyer to retain local counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Ante, at 286-287.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Assuming that the latter suggestion does not itself constitute unlawful discrimination under the Court's test, there nevertheless may be good reasons why a State or a trial court would rather not get into structuring attorney-client relationships by requiring the retention of local counsel for emergency matters.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The situation would have to be explained to the client, and the allocation of responsibility between resident and nonresident counsel could cause as many problems as the Court's suggestion might cure.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Nor do I believe that the problem can be confined to emergency matters.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: The Court admits that even in the ordinary course of litigation a trial judge will want trial lawyers to be available on short notice; the uncertainties of managing a trial docket are such that lawyers rarely are given a single date on which a trial will begin; they may be required to "stand by"  or whatever the local terminology is  for days at a time, and then be expected to be ready in a matter of hours, with witnesses, when the case in front of them suddenly settles.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: A State reasonably can decide that a trial court should not have added to its present scheduling difficulties the uncertainties and added delays fostered by counsel who might reside 1,000 miles from New Hampshire.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: If there is any single problem with state legal systems that this Court might consider "substantial," it is the problem of delay *297 in litigation  a subject that has been profusely explored in the literature over the past several years.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: See, e. g., Attacking Litigation Costs and Delay, Final Report of the Action Commission to Reduce Court Costs and Delay (American Bar Association 1984); S. Wasby, T. Marvell, & A. Aikman, Volume and Delay in State Appellate Courts: Problems and Responses (1979).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Surely the State has a substantial interest in taking steps to minimize this problem.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: Thus, I think that New Hampshire had more than enough "substantial reasons" to conclude that its lawyers should also be its residents.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Rehnquist
case: Supreme Court of NH v. Piper
text: I would hold that the Rule of the New Hampshire Supreme Court does not violate the Privileges and Immunities Clause of Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
I remain of the view that the Federal Arbitration Act
(FAA), 9 U.S. C. §1 et seq., does not apply to proceedings
in state courts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
See Allied-Bruce Terminix Cos. v. Dobson,
513 U.S. 265, 285–297 (1995) (dissenting opinion); see
also Preston v. Ferrer, 552 U.S. 346, 363 (2008) (same);
Buckeye Check Cashing, Inc. v. Cardegna, 546 U.S. 440,
449 (2006) (same); Green Tree Financial Corp. v. Bazzle,
539 U.S. 444, 460 (2003) (same); Doctor’s Associates, Inc.
v. Casarotto, 517 U.S. 681, 689 (1996) (same).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
Thus, the
FAA does not require state courts to order arbitration.

Accordingly, I would affirm the judgment of the California
Court of Appeal.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

author: Justice Thomas

14–462
