         DIRECTV, INC., PETITIONER v. AMY 

                 IMBURGIA, ET AL.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: This case raises the single question whether a warrantless search that provides probable cause for an arrest can nonetheless be justified as an incident of that arrest.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: A divided Ohio Supreme Court answered that question in the affirmative, reasoning that the search was neither remote in time nor place from the arrest.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: We disagree.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: On a June evening, as petitioner and a companion exited a private residence and entered the parking lot of a YMCA, they were approached by two plainclothes officers of the Ashland, Ohio, Police Department.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The officers were driving in an unmarked police vehicle.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Petitioner was carrying a *542 brown paper grocery bag with the words "Kash 'n Karry" and "Loaded with Low Prices" printed on the outside in a manner that the officers later described as "gingerly."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Neither officer knew petitioner or his companion.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: One of the two officers, Officer Thomas, exited the vehicle and, without identifying himself, asked petitioner to " `come here a minute.'
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Petitioner did not respond and kept walking.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: When Officer Thomas identified himself as a police officer, petitioner "threw the sack he was carrying onto the hood of [his] car and turned to face Thomas who was approaching."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Officer Thomas asked petitioner what the bag contained; petitioner did not respond; Officer Thomas then rebuffed petitioner's attempt to protect the bag, pushed petitioner's hand away, and opened the bag.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The drug paraphernalia discovered within provided probable cause for the arrest and evidence sufficient to support petitioner's conviction for drug abuse.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: No contention has been raised in this case that the officer's reaching for the bag involved a self-protective action necessary for the officer's safety.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: See Terry v. Ohio, 392 U.S. 1 (1968).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Although the Fourth Amendment may permit a brief detention of property on the basis of only "reasonable, articulable suspicion" that it contains contraband or evidence of criminal activity, United States v. Place, 462 U.S. 696, 702 (1983), it proscribes  except in certain well-defined circumstances  the search of that property unless accomplished pursuant to judicial warrant issued upon probable cause.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: See, e. g., Skinner v. Railway Labor Executives' Assn., 489 U.S. 602, 619 (1989); Mincey v. Arizona, 437 U.S. 385, 390 (1978); Katz v. United States, 389 U.S. 347, 357 (1967).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: That guarantee protects alike the "traveler who carries a toothbrush and a few articles of clothing in a paper bag" and "the sophisticated executive with the locked attache case."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: United States v. Ross, 456 U.S. 798, 822 (1982).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Ohio Supreme Court upheld the warrantless search of petitioner's *543 bag under the exception for searches incident to arrest.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: See United States v. Chadwick, 433 U.S. 1, 14-15 (1977); Chimel v. California, 395 U.S. 752, 763 (1969).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The court stated that petitioner was not arrested until after the contraband was discovered in the search of the bag.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: It nonetheless held that the search was constitutional because its fruits justified the arrest that followed.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: That reasoning, however, "justify[ing] the arrest by the search and at the same time .
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: the search by the arrest," just "will not do."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Johnson v. United States, 333 U.S. 10, 16-17 (1948).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: As we have had occasion in the past to observe, "[i]t is axiomatic that an incident search may not precede an arrest and serve as part of its justification."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Sibron v. New York, 392 U.S. 40, 63 (1968); see also Henry v. United States, 361 U.S. 98, 102 (1959); Rawlings v. Kentucky, 448 U.S. 98, 111, n. 6 (1980).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The exception for searches incident to arrest permits the police to search a lawfully arrested person and areas within his immediate control.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Contrary to the Ohio Supreme Court's reasoning, it does not permit the police to search any citizen without a warrant or probable cause so long as an arrest immediately follows.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The State does not defend the reasoning of the Ohio Supreme Court, but rather contends that petitioner abandoned the bag when he threw it on his car and turned to face Officer Thomas.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: See Abel v. United States, 362 U.S. 217, 241 (1960); Hester v. United States, 265 U.S. 57, 58 (1924).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: That argument was unanimously rejected by the Ohio Supreme Court, 45 Ohio St. 3d, at 263, n. 6, 544 N.E.2d, at 246, n. 6; id., at 266, 544 N.E.2d, at 249 (Sweeney, J., dissenting); id., at 273-274, 544 N.E.2d, at 255, n. 10 (Wright, J., dissenting), and we have no reason to disturb its conclusion.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: As the state court properly recognized, a citizen who attempts to protect his private property from inspection, after throwing it on a car to respond to a police officer's inquiry, *544 clearly has not abandoned that property.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Rios v. United States, 364 U.S. 253, 262, n. 6 (1960).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text:
The motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and the petition for writ of certiorari are granted, and the judgment of the Supreme Court of Ohio is
Reversed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
I agree with THE CHIEF JUSTICE that the former Creek
Nation Reservation was disestablished at statehood and
Oklahoma therefore has jurisdiction to prosecute petitioner
for sexually assaulting his wife’s granddaughter.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
Ante, at
1–2 (dissenting opinion).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
I write separately to note an ad-
ditional defect in the Court’s decision: It reverses a state-
court judgment that it has no jurisdiction to review.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
“[W]e
have long recognized that ‘where the judgment of a state
court rests upon two grounds, one of which is federal and
the other non-federal in character, our jurisdiction fails if
the non-federal ground is independent of the federal ground
and adequate to support the judgment.’ ” Michigan v. Long,
463 U.S. 1032, 1038, n. 4 (1983) (quoting Fox Film Corp. v.
Muller, 296 U.S. 207, 210 (1935)).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
Under this well-settled
rule, we lack jurisdiction to review the Oklahoma Court of
Criminal Appeals’ decision, because it rests on an adequate
and independent state ground.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
In his application for state postconviction relief, peti-
tioner claimed that Oklahoma lacked jurisdiction to prose-
cute him because his crime was committed on Creek Nation
land and thus was subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of
the Federal Government under the Major Crimes Act, 18
U.S. C. §1153.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
In support of his argument, petitioner cited
the Tenth’s Circuit’s decision in Murphy v. Royal, 875 F.3d
896 (2017).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
2                   MCGIRT v. OKLAHOMA

                     THOMAS, J., dissenting

   The Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals concluded that
petitioner’s claim was procedurally barred under state law
because it was “not raised previously on direct appeal” and
thus was “waived for further review.” 2018 OK CR 1057 ¶2,
___ P. 3d ___, ___ (citing Okla.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text: Stat., Tit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
The court found no grounds for excusing this default, ex-
plaining that “[p]etitioner [had] not established any suffi-
cient reason why his current grounds for relief were not pre-
viously raised.” ___ P. 3d, at ___.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
This state procedural bar
was applied independent of any federal law, and it is ade-
quate to support the decision below.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
We therefore lack ju-
risdiction to disturb the state court’s judgment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
There are two possible arguments in favor of jurisdiction,
neither of which hold water.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
First, one might claim that the
state procedural bar is not an “adequate” ground for deci-
sion in this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
In Murphy, the Tenth Circuit suggested
that Oklahoma law permits jurisdictional challenges to be
raised for the first time on collateral review.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
875 F.3d, at
907, n. 5 (citing Wallace v. State, 1997 OK CR 18, 935 P.2d
366).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
But the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals did not
even hint at such grounds for excusing petitioner’s default
here.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
More importantly, however, we may not go beyond
“the four corners of the opinion” and delve into background
principles of Oklahoma law to determine the adequacy of
the independent state ground.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text: Long, 463 U.S., at 1040.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
This Court put an end to that approach in Long, noting that
“[t]he process of examining state law is unsatisfactory be-
cause it requires us to interpret state laws with which we
are generally unfamiliar, and which often, as in this case,
have not been discussed at length by the parties.” Id., at
1039.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
Moreover, such second-guessing disrespects “the in-
dependence of state courts,” id., at 1040, and the State it-
self, Coleman v. Thompson, 501 U.S. 722, 738–739 (1991).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
Second, one might argue, as the Court does, that we have
jurisdiction because the decision below rests on federal, not
state, grounds.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text: See ante, at 38, n. 15.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
It is true that the
                  Cite as: 591 U. S. ____ (2020)             3

                     THOMAS, J., dissenting

Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals briefly recited the
procedural history of Murphy and recognized that the
Tenth Circuit’s decision—which we granted certiorari to re-
view—is not yet final.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
But contrary to the Court’s assertion
that brief discussion of federal case law did not come close
to “address[ing] the merits of [petitioner’s] federal [Major
Crimes Act] claim.” Ante, at 38, n. 15.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
The state court did
not analyze the relevant statutory text or this Court’s deci-
sions in Solem v. Bartlett, 465 U.S. 463 (1984), and Ne-
braska v. Parker, 577 U.S. 481 (2016).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
It reads far too
much into the opinion to claim that the court’s brief refer-
ence to the Tenth Circuit’s decision in Murphy transformed
the state court’s decision into one that “fairly appear[s] to
rest primarily on federal law or to be interwoven with fed-
eral law,” Long, supra, at 1040–1041; see also ante, at 38,
n. 15.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
Nothing in the court’s opinion suggests that its judg-
ment was at all based on federal law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
Thus, even if we were
to set aside the fact that the state court “clearly and ex-
pressly state[d] that [its decision] was based on state proce-
dural grounds,” we could not presume jurisdiction here.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
Coleman, supra, at 735–736 (internal quotation marks
omitted).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
The Court might think that, in the grand scheme of
things, this jurisdictional defect is fairly insignificant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
Af-
ter all, we were bound to resolve this federal question
sooner or later.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text: See Royal v. Murphy, 584 U. S. ___ (2018).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
But our desire to decisively “settle [important disputes] for
the sake of convenience and efficiency” must yield to the
“overriding and time-honored concern about keeping the
Judiciary’s power within its proper constitutional sphere.”
Hollingsworth v. Perry, 570 U.S. 693, 704–705 (2013) (in-
ternal quotation marks omitted).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
Because the Oklahoma
court’s “judgment does not depend upon the decision of any
federal question[,] we have no power to disturb it.” Enter-
prise Irrigation Dist.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text: v. Farmers Mut.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
4                  MCGIRT v. OKLAHOMA

                    THOMAS, J., dissenting

  I agree with THE CHIEF JUSTICE that the Court misap-
plies our precedents in granting petitioner relief.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
Ante, at
6–38 (dissenting opinion).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
But in doing so, the Court also
overrides Oklahoma’s statutory procedural bar, upsetting a
violent sex offender’s conviction without the power to do so.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
The State of Oklahoma deserves more respect under our
Constitution’s federal system.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Thomas
text:
Therefore, I respectfully dis-
sent.

JUSTICE BLACKMUN that "[n]o differences between commercial speech and other protected speech justify suppression of commercial speech in order to influence public conduct through manipulation of the availability of information."

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Post, at 578.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Accordingly, with the qualifications implicit in the preceding *573 paragraph, I join the opinions of MR. JUSTICE BLACKMUN and MR. JUSTICE STEVENS concurring in the judgment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: MR. JUSTICE BLACKMUN, with whom MR. JUSTICE BRENNAN joins, concurring in the judgment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: I agree with the Court that the Public Service Commission's ban on promotional advertising of electricity by public utilities is inconsistent with the First and Fourteenth Amendments.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: I concur only in the Court's judgment, however, because I believe the test now evolved and applied by the Court is not consistent with our prior cases and does not provide adequate protection for truthful, nonmisleading, noncoercive commercial speech.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: The Court asserts, ante, at 566, that "a four-part analysis has developed" from our decisions concerning commercial speech.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Under this four-part test a restraint on commercial "communication [that] is neither misleading nor related to unlawful activity" is subject to an intermediate level of scrutiny, and suppression is permitted whenever it "directly advances" a "substantial" governmental interest and is "not more extensive than is necessary to serve that interest."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Ante, at 564 and 566.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: I agree with the Court that this level of intermediate scrutiny is appropriate for a restraint on commercial speech designed to protect consumers from misleading or coercive speech, or a regulation related to the time, place, or manner of commercial speech.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: I do not agree, however, that the Court's four-part test is the proper one to be applied when a State seeks to suppress information about a product in order to manipulate a private economic decision that the State cannot or has not regulated or outlawed directly.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Since the Court, without citing empirical data or other authority, finds a "direct link" between advertising and energy consumption, it leaves open the possibility that the State may suppress advertising of electricity in order to lessen demand for electricity.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: I, of course, agree with the Court that, *574 in today's world, energy conservation is a goal of paramount national and local importance.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: I disagree with the Court, however, when it says that suppression of speech may be a permissible means to achieve that goal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: MR. JUSTICE STEVENS appropriately notes: "The justification for the regulation is nothing more than the expressed fear that the audience may find the utility's message persuasive.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Without the aid of any coercion, deception, or misinformation, truthful communication may persuade some citizens to consume more electricity than they otherwise would."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Post, at 581.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: The Court recognizes that we have never held that commercial speech may be suppressed in order to further the State's interest in discouraging purchases of the underlying product that is advertised.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Ante, at 566, n. 9.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Permissible restraints on commercial speech have been limited to measures designed to protect consumers from fraudulent, misleading, or coercive sales techniques.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: [1] Those designed to deprive consumers of information about products or services that are legally offered for sale consistently have been invalidated.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text:
[2]
I seriously doubt whether suppression of information concerning the availability and price of a legally offered product is ever a permissible way for the State to "dampen" demand for or use of the product.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Even though "commercial" speech is involved, such a regulatory measure strikes at the heart of the First Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: This is because it is a covert attempt *575 by the State to manipulate the choices of its citizens, not by persuasion or direct regulation, but by depriving the public of the information needed to make a free choice.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: As the Court recognizes, the State's policy choices are insulated from the visibility and scrutiny that direct regulation would entail and the conduct of citizens is molded by the information that government chooses to give them.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Ante, at 566, n. 9 ("We review with special care regulations that entirely suppress commercial speech in order to pursue a nonspeech-related policy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: In those circumstances, a ban on speech could screen from public view the underlying governmental policy").
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: See Rotunda, The Commercial Speech Doctrine in the Supreme Court, 1976 U. Ill. Law Forum 1080, 1080-1083.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: If the First Amendment guarantee means anything, it means that, absent clear and present danger, government has no power to restrict expression because of the effect its message is likely to have on the public.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: See generally Comment, First Amendment Protection for Commercial Advertising: The New Constitutional Doctrine, 44 U. Chi.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Our cases indicate that this guarantee applies even to commercial speech.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: In Virginia Pharmacy Board v. Virginia Consumer Council, 425 U.S. 748 (1976), we held that Virginia could not pursue its goal of encouraging the public to patronize the "professional pharmacist" (one who provided individual attention and a stable pharmacist-customer relationship) by "keeping the public in ignorance of the entirely lawful terms that competing pharmacists are offering."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Id., at 770.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: We noted that our decision left the State free to pursue its goal of maintaining high standards among its pharmacists by "requir[ing] whatever professional standards it wishes of its pharmacists."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: We went on in Virginia Pharmacy Board to discuss the types of regulation of commercial speech that, due to the "commonsense differences" between this form of speech and other forms, are or may be constitutionally permissible.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: We indicated that government may impose reasonable "time, *576 place, and manner" restrictions, and that it can deal with false, deceptive, and misleading commercial speech.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: We noted that the question of advertising of illegal transactions and the special problems of the electronic broadcast media were not presented.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Concluding with a restatement of the type of restraint that is not permitted, we said: "What is at issue is whether a State may completely suppress the dissemination of concededly truthful information about entirely lawful activity, fearful of that information's effect upon its disseminators and its recipients.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: [W]e conclude that the answer to this [question] is in the negative."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Id., at 773.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Virginia Pharmacy Board did not analyze the State's interests to determine, whether they were "substantial."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Obviously, preventing professional dereliction and low quality health care are "substantial," legitimate, and important state goals.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Nor did the opinion analyze the ban on speech to determine whether it "directly advance[d]," ante, at 566, 569, these goals.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: We also did not inquire whether a "more limited regulation of .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: commercial expression," ante, at 570, would adequately serve the State's interests.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Rather, we held that the State "may not [pursue its goals] by keeping the public in ignorance."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: (Emphasis supplied.)
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Until today, this principle has governed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: In Linmark Associates, Inc. v. Willingboro, 431 U.S. 85 (1977), we considered whether a town could ban "For Sale" signs on residential property to further its goal of promoting stable, racially integrated housing.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: We did note that the record did not establish that the ordinance was necessary to enable the State to achieve its goal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: The holding of Linmark, however, was much broader.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text:
[3] We stated:
"The constitutional defect in this ordinance, however, *577 is far more basic.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: The Township Council here, like the Virginia Assembly in Virginia Pharmacy Bd., acted to prevent its residents from obtaining certain information .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: which pertains to sales activity in Willingboro.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: The Council has sought to restrict the free flow of these data because it fears that otherwise homeowners will make decisions inimical to what the Council views as the homeowners' self-interest and the corporate interest of the township: they will choose to leave town.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: The Council's concern, then, was not with any commercial aspect of "For Sale" signswith offerors communicating offers to offereesbut with the substance of the information communicated to Willingboro citizens."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Id., at 96.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: The Court in Linmark resolved beyond all doubt that a strict standard of review applies to suppression of commercial information, where the purpose of the restaint is to influence behavior by depriving citizens of information.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: The Court followed the strong statement above with an explicit adoption of the standard advocated by Mr. Justice Brandeis in his concurring opinion in Whitney v. California, 274 U.S. 357, 377 (1927): "If there be time to expose through discussion the falsehood and fallacies, to avert the evil by the processes of education, the remedy to be applied is more speech, not enforced silence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Only an emergency can justify repression."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Carey v. Population Services International, 431 U.S. 678, 700-702 (1977), also applied to content-based restraints on commercial speech the same standard of review we have applied to other varieties of speech.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: There the Court held that a ban on advertising of contraceptives could not be justified *578 by the State's interest in avoiding "`legitimation' of illicit sexual behavior" because the advertisements could not be characterized as "`directed to inciting or producing imminent lawless action and .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: likely to incite or produce such action,'" id., at 701, quoting Brandenburg v. Ohio, 395 U.S. 444, 447 (1969).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Our prior references to the "`commonsense differences'" between commercial speech and other speech "`suggest that a different degree of protection is necessary to insure that the flow of truthful and legitimate commercial information is unimpaired.'"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Linmark Associates, 431 U. S., at 98, quoting Virginia Pharmacy Board, 425 U. S., at 771-772, n. 24.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: We have not suggested that the "commonsense differences" between commercial speech and other speech justify relaxed scrutiny of restraints that suppress truthful, nondeceptive, noncoercive commercial speech.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: The differences articulated by the Court, See ante, at 564, n. 6, justify a more permissive approach to regulation of the manner of commercial speech for the purpose of protecting consumers from deception or coercion, and these differences explain why doctrines designed to prevent "chilling" of protected speech are inapplicable to commercial speech.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: No differences between commercial speech and other protected speech justify suppression of commercial speech in order to influence public conduct through manipulation of the availability of information.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text:
The Court stated in Carey v. Population Services International:
"Appellants suggest no distinction between commercial and noncommercial speech that would render these discredited arguments meritorious when offered to justify prohibitions on commercial speech.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: On the contrary, such arguments are clearly directed not at any commercial aspect of the prohibited advertising but at the ideas conveyed and form of expressionthe core of First Amendment values."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: 431 U. S., at 701, n. 28 (emphasis added).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: *579 It appears that the Court would permit the State to ban all direct advertising of air conditioning, assuming that a more limited restriction on such advertising would not effectively deter the public from cooling its homes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: In my view, our cases do not support this type of suppression.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: If a governmental unit believes that use or overuse of air conditioning is a serious problem, it must attack that problem directly, by prohibiting air conditioning or regulating thermostat levels.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Just as the Commonwealth of Virginia may promote professionalism of pharmacists directly, so too New York may not promote energy conservation "by keeping the public in ignorance."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Virginia Pharmacy Board, 425 U. S., at 770.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: MR. JUSTICE STEVENS, with whom MR. JUSTICE BRENNAN joins, concurring in the judgment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Because "commercial speech" is afforded less constitutional protection than other forms of speech,[1] it is important that the commercial speech concept not be defined too broadly lest speech deserving of greater constitutional protection be inadvertently suppressed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: The issue in this case is whether New York's prohibition on the promotion of the use of electricity through advertising is a ban on nothing but commercial speech.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: In my judgment one of the two definitions the Court uses in addressing that issue is too broad and the other may be somewhat too narrow.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: The Court first describes commercial speech as "expression related solely to the economic interests of the speaker and its audience."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Ante, at 561.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Although it is not entirely clear whether this definition uses the subject matter of the speech or the motivation of the speaker as the limiting factor, it seems clear to me that it encompasses speech that is entitled to the maximum protection afforded by the First Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Neither a labor leader's exhortation to *580 strike, nor an economist's dissertation on the money supply, should receive any lesser protection because the subject matter concerns only the economic interests of the audience.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Nor should the economic motivation of a speaker qualify his constitutional protection; even Shakespeare may have been motivated by the prospect of pecuniary reward.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Thus, the Court's first definition of commercial speech is unquestionably too broad.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text:
[2]
The Court's second definition refers to "`speech proposing a commercial transaction.'"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Ante, at 562.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: A saleman's solicitation, a broker's offer, and a manufacturer's publication of a price list or the terms of his standard warranty would unquestionably fit within this concept.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: [3] Presumably, the definition is intended to encompass advertising that advises possible buyers of the availability of specific products at specific prices and describes the advantages of purchasing such items.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Perhaps it also extends to other communications that do little more than make the name of a product or a service more familiar to the general public.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Whatever the precise contours of the concept, and perhaps it is too early to enunciate an exact formulation, I am persuaded that it should not include the entire range of communication that is embraced within the term "promotional advertising."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: This case involves a governmental regulation that completely bans promotional advertising by an electric utility.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: This ban encompasses a great deal more than mere proposals to engage in certain kinds of commercial transactions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: It prohibits all advocacy of the immediate or future use of electricity.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: *581 It curtails expression by an informed and interested group of persons of their point of view on questions relating to the production and consumption of electrical energyquestions frequently discussed and debated by our political leaders.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: For example, an electric company's advocacy of the use of electric heat for environmental reasons, as opposed to wood-burning stoves, would seem to fall squarely within New York's promotional advertising ban and also within the bounds of maximum First Amendment protection.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: The breadth of the ban thus exceeds the boundaries of the commercial speech concept, however that concept may be defined.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text:
[4]
The justification for the regulation is nothing more than the expressed fear that the audience may find the utility's message persuasive.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Without the aid of any coercion, deception, or misinformation, truthful communication may persuade some citizens to consume more electricity than they otherwise would.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: I assume that such a consequence would be undesirable and that government may therefore prohibit and punish the unnecessary or excessive use of electricity.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: But if the perceived harm associated with greater electrical usage is not sufficiently serious to justify direct regulation, surely it does not constitute the kind of clear and present danger that can justify the suppression of speech.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text:
*582 Although they were written in a different context, the words used by Mr. Justice Brandeis in his concurring opinion in Whitney v. California, 274 U.S. 357, 376-377, explain my reaction to the prohibition against advocacy involved in this case:
"But even advocacy of violation, however reprehensible morally, is not a justification for denying free speech where the advocacy falls short of incitement and there is nothing to indicate that the advocacy would be immediately acted on.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: The wide difference between advocacy and incitement, between preparation and attempt, between assembling and conspiracy, must be borne in mind.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: In order to support a finding of clear and present danger it must be shown either that immediate serious violence was to be expected or was advocated, or that the past conduct furnished reason to believe that such advocacy was then contemplated.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: "Those who won our independence by revolution were not cowards.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: They did not fear political change.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: They did not exalt order at the cost of liberty.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: To courageous, self-reliant men, with confidence in the power of free and fearless reasoning applied through the processes of popular government, no danger flowing from speech can be deemed clear and present, unless the incidence of the evil apprehended is so imminent that it may befall before there is opportunity for full discussion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: If there be time to expose through discussion the falsehood and fallacies, to avert the evil by the processes of education, the remedy to be applied is more speech, not enforced silence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Only an emergency can justify repression.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Such must be the rule if authority is to be reconciled with freedom.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Such, in my opinion, is the command of the Constitution."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: (Footnote omitted.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text:
)[5]
*583 In sum, I concur in the result because I do not consider this to be a "commercial speech" case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Brennan
case: Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n of NY
text: Accordingly, I see no need to decide whether the Court's four-part analysis, ante, at 566, adequately protects commercial speechas properly defined in the face of a blanket ban of the sort involved in this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: This case presents the question, not fully answered in Hamling v. United States, 418 U.S. 87 (1974), whether the *189 standards announced in Miller v. California, 413 U.S. 15 (1973), are to be applied retroactively to the potential detriment of a defendant in a criminal case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: We granted certiorari, 424 U.S. 942 (1976), to resolve a conflict in the Circuits.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text:
[1]

I
Petitioners were charged with several counts of transporting obscene materials in interstate commerce, in violation of 18 U.S. C. § 1465, and with conspiracy to transport such materials, 18 U.S. C. § 371.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: The conduct that gave rise to the charges covered a period through February 27, 1973.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: *190 Trial did not begin until the following October.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: In the interim, on June 21, 1973, this Court decided Miller v. California, supra, and its companion cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: [2]Miller announced new standards for "isolat[ing] `hard core' pornography from expression protected by the First Amendment."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: [3] That these new standards would also guide the future interpretation of the federal obscenity laws was clear from United States v. 12 200-ft. Reels of Film, 413 U.S. 123, 129-130, and n. 7 (1973), decided the same day as Miller.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: See Hamling v. United States, supra, at 105, 113-114.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Petitioners argued in the District Court that they were entitled to jury instructions not under Miller, but under the more favorable formulation of Memoirs v. Massachusetts, 383 U.S. 413 (1966) (plurality opinion).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: [4]Memoirs, in their *191 view, authoritatively stated the law in effect prior to Miller, by which petitioners charted their course of conduct.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: They focused in particular on the third part of the Memoirs test.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Under it, expressive material is constitutionally protected unless it is "utterly without redeeming social value."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Under Miller the comparable test is "whether the work, taken as a whole, lacks serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Miller, petitioners argue, casts a significantly wider net than Memoirs.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: To apply Miller retroactively, and thereby punish conduct innocent under Memoirs, violates the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendmentmuch as retroactive application of a new statute to penalize conduct innocent when performed would violate the Constitution's ban on ex post facto laws, Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: The District Court overruled these objections and instructed the jury under the Miller standards.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Petitioners were convicted,[5] and a divided Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: We now reverse.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text:
II
The Ex Post Facto Clause is a limitation upon the powers of the Legislature, see Calder v. Bull, 3 Dall.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: 386 (1798), and does not of its own force apply to the Judicial Branch of government.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Frank v. Mangum, 237 U.S. 309, 344 (1915).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: But the principle on which the Clause is basedthe notion that persons have a right to fair warning of that conduct which will give rise to criminal penaltiesis fundamental to our concept of constitutional liberty.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: See United States v. *192 Harriss, 347 U.S. 612, 617 (1954); Lanzetta v. New Jersey, 306 U.S. 451, 453 (1939).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: As such, that right is protected against judicial action by the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text:
In Bouie v. City of Columbia, 378 U.S. 347 (1964), a case involving the cognate provision of the Fourteenth Amendment, the Court reversed trespass convictions, finding that they rested on an unexpected construction of the state trespass statute by the State Supreme Court:
"[A]n unforeseeable judicial enlargement of a criminal statute, applied retroactively, operates precisely like an ex post facto law, such as Art.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: I, § 10, of the Constitution forbids.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: If a state legislature is barred by the Ex Post Facto Clause from passing such a law, it must follow that a State Supreme Court is barred by the Due Process Clause from achieving precisely the same result by judicial construction."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Similarly, in Rabe v. Washington, 405 U.S. 313 (1972), we reversed a conviction under a state obscenity law because it rested on an unforeseeable judicial construction of the statute.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: We stressed that reversal was mandated because affected citizens lacked fair notice that the statute would be thus applied.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Relying on Bouie, petitioners assert that Miller and its companion cases unforeseeably expanded the reach of the federal obscenity statutes beyond what was punishable under Memoirs.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: The Court of Appeals rejected this argument.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: It notedcorrectlythat the Memoirs standards never commanded the assent of more than three Justices at any one time, and it apparently concluded from this fact that Memoirs never became the law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: By this line of reasoning, one must judge whether Miller expanded criminal liability by looking not to Memoirs but to Roth v. United States, 354 *193 U. S. 476 (1957), the last comparable plenary decision of this Court prior to Miller in which a majority united in a single opinion announcing the rationale behind the Court's holding.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: [7] Although certain language in Roth formed the basis for the plurality's formulation in Memoirs, Roth's test for distinguishing obscenity from protected speech was a fairly simple one to articulate: "whether to the average person, applying contemporary community standards, the dominant theme of the material taken as a whole appeals to prurient interest."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: If indeed Roth, not Memoirs, stated the applicable law prior to Miller, there would be much to commend the apparent view of the Court of Appeals that Miller did not significantly change the law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: But we think the basic premise for this line of reasoning is faulty.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: When a fragmented Court decides a case and no single rationale explaining the result enjoys the assent of five Justices, "the holding of the Court may be viewed as that position taken by those Members who concurred in the judgments on the narrowest grounds .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Gregg v. Georgia, 428 U.S. 153, 169 n. 15 (1976) (opinion of STEWART, POWELL, and STEVENS, JJ.).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Three Justices joined in the controlling opinion in Memoirs.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Two others, Mr. Justice Black and Mr. Justice Douglas, concurred on broader grounds in reversing the judgment below.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: They reiterated their well-known position that the First Amendment provides an absolute shield against governmental action aimed at suppressing obscenity.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: MR. JUSTICE STEWART also concurred in the judgment, based on his view that only "hardcore pornography" may be suppressed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Id., at 421.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: See Ginzburg v. United States, 383 U.S. 463, 499 (1966) *194 (STEWART, J., dissenting).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: The view of the Memoirs plurality therefore constituted the holding of the Court and provided the governing standards.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Indeed, every Court of Appeals that considered the question between Memoirs and Miller so read our decisions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: [8] Materials were deemed to be constitutionally protected unless the prosecution carried the burden of proving that they were "utterly without redeeming social value," and otherwise satisfied the stringent Memoirs requirements.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Memoirs therefore was the law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Miller did not simply clarify Roth; it marked a significant departure from Memoirs.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: And there can be little doubt that the third test announced in Millerwhether the work "lacks serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value"expanded criminal liability.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: The Court in Miller expressly observed that the "utterly without redeeming social value" test places on the prosecutor "a burden virtually impossible to discharge under our criminal standards of proof."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Clearly it was thought that some conduct which would have gone unpunished under Memoirs would result in conviction under Miller.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: *195 This case is not strictly analogous to Bouie.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: The statutory language there was "narrow and precise," 378 U.S., at 352, and that fact was important to our holding that the expansive construction adopted by the State Supreme Court deprived the accused of fair warning.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: In contrast, the statute involved here always has used sweeping language to describe that which is forbidden.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: [9] But precisely because the statute is sweeping, its reach necessarily has been confined within the constitutional limits announced by this Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Memoirs severely restricted its application.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Miller also restricts its application beyond what the language might indicate, but Miller undeniably relaxes the Memoirs restrictions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: [10] The effect is the same as the new construction in Bouie.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Petitioners, engaged in the dicey business of marketing films subject to possible challenge, had no fair warning that their products might be subjected to the new standards.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text:
[11]
*196 We have taken special care to insist on fair warning when a statute regulates expression and implicates First Amendment values.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: See, e. g., Buckley v. Valeo, 424 U.S. 1, 40-41 (1976); Smith v. Goguen, 415 U.S. 566, 573 (1974).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Section 1465 is such a statute.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: We therefore hold, in accordance with Bouie, that the Due Process Clause precludes the application to petitioners of the standards announced in Miller v. California, to the extent that those standards may impose criminal liability for conduct not punishable under Memoirs.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Specifically, since the petitioners were indicted for conduct occurring prior to our decision in Miller, they are entitled to jury instructions requiring the jury to acquit unless it finds that the materials involved are "utterly without redeeming social value.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: "[12] At the same time we reaffirm our *197 holding in Hamling v. United States, 418 U. S., at 102, that "any constitutional principle enunciated in Miller which would serve to benefit petitioners must be applied in their case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text:
"[13]
Accordingly, the judgment is reversed, and the case is remanded for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text:
[14]
So ordered.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: MR. JUSTICE BRENNAN, with whom MR. JUSTICE STEWART and MR. JUSTICE MARSHALL join, concurring in part and dissenting in part.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: I join the opinion of the Court insofar as it holds that the retroactive application of the definition of obscenity announced in Miller v. California, 413 U.S. 15 (1973), to the potential detriment of a criminal defendant, violates the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: See Bouie v. City of Columbia, 378 U.S. 347 (1964).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: I cannot join, however, in the judgment remanding the case for a new trial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Petitioners were convicted of transporting obscene materials in interstate commerce in violation of 18 U.S. C. § 1465.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: I adhere to the view that this statute is "`clearly overbroad and unconstitutional on its face.'"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: See, e. g., Cangiano v. United States, 418 U.S. 934, 935 (1974) (BRENNAN, J., dissenting), quoting United States v. Orito, 413 *198 U. S. 139, 148 (1973) (BRENNAN, J., dissenting).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: I therefore would simply reverse.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: MR. JUSTICE STEVENS, concurring in part and dissenting in part.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: There are three reasons which, in combination, persuade me that this criminal prosecution is constitutionally impermissible.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: First, as the Court's opinion recognizes, this "statute regulates expression and implicates First Amendment values."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Ante, at 196.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: However distasteful these materials are to some of us, they are nevertheless a form of communication and entertainment acceptable to a substantial segment of society; otherwise, they would have no value in the marketplace.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Second, the statute is predicated on the somewhat illogical premise that a person may be prosecuted criminally for providing another with material he has a constitutional right to possess.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: See Stanley v. Georgia, 394 U.S. 557.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Third, the present constitutional standards, both substantive and procedural,[*] which apply to these prosecutions are so intolerably vague that evenhanded enforcement of the law is a virtual impossibility.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Indeed, my brief experience on the Court has persuaded me that grossly disparate treatment of similar offenders is a characteristic of the criminal enforcement of obscenity law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Powell
text: Accordingly, while I agree with everything said in the Court's opinion, I am unable to join its judgment remanding the case for a new trial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court of Appeals disposed of this case as if a critical question to be decided were which of three clearly defined standards of equal protection review should be applied to a legislative classification discriminating against the mentally retarded.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [1] In fact, our cases have not delineated three  or even one or two  such well-defined standards.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [2] Rather, our cases reflect a continuum of judgmental responses to differing classifications which have been explained in opinions by terms ranging from "strict scrutiny" at one extreme to "rational basis" at the other.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: I have never been persuaded that these so-called "standards" adequately explain the decisional process.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [3] Cases involving classifications based on alienage, *452 illegal residency, illegitimacy, gender, age, or  as in this case  mental retardation, do not fit well into sharply defined classifications.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: "I am inclined to believe that what has become known as the [tiered] analysis of equal protection claims does not describe a completely logical method of deciding cases, but rather is a method the Court has employed to explain decisions that actually apply a single standard in a reasonably consistent fashion."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Craig v. Boren, 429 U.S. 190, 212 (1976) (STEVENS, J., concurring).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: In my own approach to these cases, I have always asked myself whether I could find a "rational basis" for the classification at issue.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The term "rational," of course, includes a requirement that an impartial lawmaker could logically believe that the classification would serve a legitimate public purpose that transcends the harm to the members of the disadvantaged class.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [4] Thus, the word "rational"  for me at least  includes elements of legitimacy and neutrality that must always characterize the performance of the sovereign's duty to govern impartially.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
[5]
The rational-basis test, properly understood, adequately explains why a law that deprives a person of the right to vote because his skin has a different pigmentation than that of other voters violates the Equal Protection Clause.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: It would be utterly irrational to limit the franchise on the basis of height or weight; it is equally invalid to limit it on the basis of skin color.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: None of these attributes has any bearing at all *453 on the citizen's willingness or ability to exercise that civil right.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: We do not need to apply a special standard, or to apply "strict scrutiny," or even "heightened scrutiny," to decide such cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: In every equal protection case, we have to ask certain basic questions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: What class is harmed by the legislation, and has it been subjected to a "tradition of disfavor" by our laws?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [6] What is the public purpose that is being served by the law?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: What is the characteristic of the disadvantaged class that justifies the disparate treatment?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [7] In most cases the answer to these questions will tell us whether the statute has a "rational basis."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The answers will result in the virtually automatic invalidation of racial classifications and in the validation of most economic classifications, but they will provide differing results in cases involving classifications based on alienage,[8] gender,[9] or illegitimacy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [10] But that is not because we *454 apply an "intermediate standard of review" in these cases; rather it is because the characteristics of these groups are sometimes relevant and sometimes irrelevant to a valid public purpose, or, more specifically, to the purpose that the challenged laws purportedly intended to serve.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
[11]
Every law that places the mentally retarded in a special class is not presumptively irrational.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The differences between mentally retarded persons and those with greater mental capacity are obviously relevant to certain legislative decisions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: An impartial lawmaker  indeed, even a member of a class of persons defined as mentally retarded  could rationally vote in favor of a law providing funds for special education and special treatment for the mentally retarded.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: A mentally retarded person could also recognize that he is a member of a class that might need special supervision in some situations, both to protect himself and to protect others.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Restrictions on his right to drive cars or to operate hazardous equipment might well seem rational even though they deprived him of employment opportunities and the kind of freedom of travel enjoyed by other citizens.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: "That a civilized and decent society expects and approves such legislation indicates that governmental consideration of those differences in the vast majority of situations is not only legitimate but also desirable."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Ante, at 444.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Even so, the Court of Appeals correctly observed that through ignorance and prejudice the mentally retarded "have been subjected to a history of unfair and often grotesque mistreatment."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The discrimination *455A against the mentally retarded that is at issue in this case is the city's decision to require an annual special use permit before property in an apartment house district may be used as a group home for persons who are mildly retarded.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The record convinces me that this permit was required because of the irrational fears of neighboring property owners, rather than for the protection of the mentally retarded persons who would reside in respondent's home.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
[12]
Although the city argued in the Court of Appeals that legitimate interests of the neighbors justified the restriction, the court unambiguously rejected that argument.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Id., at 201.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: In this Court, the city has argued that the discrimination was really motivated by a desire to protect the mentally retarded from the hazards presented by the neighborhood.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Zoning ordinances are not usually justified on any such basis, and in this case, for the reasons explained by the Court, ante, at 447-450, I find that justification wholly unconvincing.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: I cannot believe that a rational member of this disadvantaged class could ever approve of the discriminatory application of the city's ordinance in this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Accordingly, I join the opinion of the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: *455B JUSTICE MARSHALL, with whom JUSTICE BRENNAN and JUSTICE BLACKMUN join, concurring in the judgment in part and dissenting in part.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court holds that all retarded individuals cannot be grouped together as the "feebleminded" and deemed presumptively unfit to live in a community.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Underlying this holding is the principle that mental retardation per se cannot be a proxy for depriving retarded people of their rights and interests without regard to variations in individual ability.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: *456 With this holding and principle I agree.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Equal Protection Clause requires attention to the capacities and needs of retarded people as individuals.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: I cannot agree, however, with the way in which the Court reaches its result or with the narrow, as-applied remedy it provides for the city of Cleburne's equal protection violation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court holds the ordinance invalid on rational-basis grounds and disclaims that anything special, in the form of heightened scrutiny, is taking place.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Yet Cleburne's ordinance surely would be valid under the traditional rational-basis test applicable to economic and commercial regulation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: In my view, it is important to articulate, as the Court does not, the facts and principles that justify subjecting this zoning ordinance to the searching review  the heightened scrutiny  that actually leads to its invalidation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Moreover, in invalidating Cleburne's exclusion of the "feebleminded" only as applied to respondents, rather than on its face, the Court radically departs from our equal protection precedents.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Because I dissent from this novel and truncated remedy, and because I cannot accept the Court's disclaimer that no "more exacting standard" than ordinary rational-basis review is being applied, ante, at 442, I write separately.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
I
At the outset, two curious and paradoxical aspects of the Court's opinion must be noted.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: First, because the Court invalidates Cleburne's zoning ordinance on rational-basis grounds, the Court's wide-ranging discussion of heightened scrutiny is wholly superfluous to the decision of this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: This "two for the price of one" approach to constitutional decisionmaking  rendering two constitutional rulings where one is enough to decide the case  stands on their head traditional and deeply embedded principles governing exercise of the Court's Article III power.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Just a few weeks ago, the Court "call[ed] to mind two of the cardinal rules governing *457 the federal courts: `One, never to anticipate a question of constitutional law in advance of the necessity of deciding it; the other never to formulate a rule of constitutional law broader than is required by the precise facts to which it is to be applied.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: " Brockett v. Spokane Arcades, Inc., 472 U.S. 491, 501 (1985) (WHITE, J.)
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens

Williams, 457 U.S. 55, 60-61 (1982) (same); cf.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Second, the Court's heightened-scrutiny discussion is even more puzzling given that Cleburne's ordinance is invalidated only after being subjected to precisely the sort of probing inquiry associated with heightened scrutiny.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: To be sure, the Court does not label its handiwork heightened scrutiny, and perhaps the method employed must hereafter be called "second order" rational-basis review rather than "heightened scrutiny."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: But however labeled, the rational-basis test invoked today is most assuredly not the rational-basis test of Williamson v. Lee Optical of Oklahoma, Inc., 348 U.S. 483 (1955); Allied Stores of Ohio, Inc. v. Bowers, 358 U.S. 522 (1959), and their progeny.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court, for example, concludes that legitimate concerns for fire hazards or the serenity of the neighborhood do not justify singling out respondents to bear the burdens of these concerns, for analogous permitted uses appear to pose similar threats.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Yet under the traditional and most minimal version of the rational-basis test, "reform may take one step at a time, addressing itself to the phase of the problem which seems most acute to the legislative mind."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Williamson v. Lee Optical of Oklahoma, Inc., supra, at 489; see American Federation of Labor v. American Sash Co., 335 U.S. 538 (1949); Semler v. Dental Examiners, 294 U.S. 608 (1935).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The "record" is said not to support the ordinance's classifications, ante, at 448, 450, but under the traditional standard we do not sift through the record to determine whether policy decisions are squarely supported by a firm factual foundation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Exxon Corp. v. Eagerton, 462 U.S. 176, 196 (1983); Minnesota v. Clover Leaf Creamery Co., 449 U.S. 456, 461-462, *459 464 (1981); Firemen v. Chicago, R. I.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Finally, the Court further finds it "difficult to believe" that the retarded present different or special hazards inapplicable to other groups.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: In normal circumstances, the burden is not on the legislature to convince the Court that the lines it has drawn are sensible; legislation is presumptively constitutional, and a State "is not required to resort to close distinctions or to maintain a precise, scientific uniformity with reference" to its goals.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Allied Stores of Ohio, Inc. v. Bowers, supra, at 527; see New Orleans v. Dukes, 427 U.S. 297, 303 (1976); Metropolis Theatre Co. v. City of Chicago, 228 U.S. 61, 68-70 (1913).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: I share the Court's criticisms of the overly broad lines that Cleburne's zoning ordinance has drawn.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
