text: But if the ordinance is to be invalidated for its imprecise classifications, it must be pursuant to more powerful scrutiny than the minimal rational-basis test used to review classifications affecting only economic and commercial matters.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The same imprecision in a similar ordinance that required opticians but not optometrists to be licensed to practice, see Williamson v. Lee Optical of Oklahoma, Inc., supra, or that excluded new but not old businesses from parts of a community, see New Orleans v. Dukes, supra, would hardly be fatal to the statutory scheme.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The refusal to acknowledge that something more than minimum rationality review is at work here is, in my view, unfortunate in at least two respects.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [4] The suggestion that *460 the traditional rational-basis test allows this sort of searching inquiry creates precedent for this Court and lower courts to subject economic and commercial classifications to similar and searching "ordinary" rational-basis review  a small and regrettable step back toward the days of Lochner v. New York, 198 U.S. 45 (1905).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Moreover, by failing to articulate the factors that justify today's "second order" rational-basis review, the Court provides no principled foundation for determining when more searching inquiry is to be invoked.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Lower courts are thus left in the dark on this important question, and this Court remains unaccountable for its decisions employing, or refusing to employ, particularly searching scrutiny.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Candor requires me to acknowledge the particular factors that justify invalidating Cleburne's zoning ordinance under the careful scrutiny it today receives.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
II
I have long believed the level of scrutiny employed in an equal protection case should vary with "the constitutional and societal importance of the interest adversely affected and the recognized invidiousness of the basis upon which the particular classification is drawn."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: San Antonio Independent School District v. Rodriguez, 411 U.S. 1, 99 (1973) (MARSHALL, J., dissenting).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: See also Plyler v. Doe, 457 U.S. 202, 230-231 (1982) (MARSHALL, J., concurring); Dandridge v. Williams, 397 U.S. 471, 508 (1970) (MARSHALL, J., dissenting).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: When a zoning ordinance works to exclude the retarded from all residential districts in a community, these two considerations require that the ordinance be convincingly justified as substantially furthering legitimate and important purposes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Plyler, supra; Mississippi University for Women v. Hogan, 458 U.S. 718 (1982); Frontiero v. Richardson, 411 U.S. 677 (1973); Mills v. Habluetzel, 456 U.S. 91 (1982); see also Buchanan v. Warley, 245 U.S. 60 (1917).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: *461 First, the interest of the retarded in establishing group homes is substantial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The right to "establish a home" has long been cherished as one of the fundamental liberties embraced by the Due Process Clause.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: See Meyer v. Nebraska, 262 U.S. 390, 399 (1923).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: For retarded adults, this right means living together in group homes, for as deinstitutionalization has progressed, group homes have become the primary means by which retarded adults can enter life in the community.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
The District Court found as a matter of fact that
"[t]he availability of such a home in communities is an essential ingredient of normal living patterns for persons who are mentally retarded, and each factor that makes such group homes harder to establish operates to exclude persons who are mentally retarded from the community."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Excluding group homes deprives the retarded of much of what makes for human freedom and fulfillment  the ability to form bonds and take part in the life of a community.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
[5]
Second, the mentally retarded have been subject to a "lengthy and tragic history," University of California Regents v. Bakke, 438 U.S. 265, 303 (1978) (opinion of POWELL, J.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: ), of segregation and discrimination that can only be called grotesque.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: During much of the 19th century, mental retardation was viewed as neither curable nor dangerous and the retarded were largely left to their own devices.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [6] By the latter part of the century and during the first decades of the new one, however, social views of the retarded underwent a radical transformation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Fueled by the rising tide of Social Darwinism, the "science" of eugenics, and the extreme *462 xenophobia of those years,[7] leading medical authorities and others began to portray the "feebleminded" as a "menace to society and civilization .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: responsible in a large degree for many, if not all, of our social problems.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: "[8] A regime of statemandated segregation and degradation soon emerged that in its virulence and bigotry rivaled, and indeed paralleled, the worst excesses of Jim Crow.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Massive custodial institutions were built to warehouse the retarded for life; the aim was to halt reproduction of the retarded and "nearly extinguish their race.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: "[9] Retarded children were categorically excluded from *463 public schools, based on the false stereotype that all were ineducable and on the purported need to protect nonretarded children from them.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [10] State laws deemed the retarded "unfit for citizenship.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
"[11]
Segregation was accompanied by eugenic marriage and sterilization laws that extinguished for the retarded one of the "basic civil rights of man"  the right to marry and procreate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Skinner v. Oklahoma ex rel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Marriages of the retarded were made, and in some States continue to be, not only voidable but also often a criminal offense.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [12] The purpose of such limitations, which frequently applied only to women of child-bearing age, was unabashedly eugenic: to prevent the retarded from propagating.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [13] To assure this end, 29 States enacted compulsory eugenic sterilization laws between 1907 and 1931.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: J. Landman, Human Sterilization 302-303 (1932).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: See Buck v. Bell, 274 U.S. 200, 207 (1927) (Holmes, J.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Plessy v. Ferguson, *464 163 U.S. 537 (1896); Bradwell v. Illinois, 16 Wall.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: 130, 141 (1873) (Bradley, J., concurring in judgment).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Prejudice, once let loose, is not easily cabined.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: See University of California Regents v. Bakke, 438 U. S., at 395 (opinion of MARSHALL, J.).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: As of 1979, most States still categorically disqualified "idiots" from voting, without regard to individual capacity and with discretion to exclude left in the hands of low-level election officials.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [14] Not until Congress enacted the Education of the Handicapped Act, 84 Stat.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: 175, as amended, 20 U.S. C. § 1400 et seq., were "the door[s] of public education" opened wide to handicapped children.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Hendrick Hudson District Board of Education v. Rowley, 458 U.S. 176, 192 (1982).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [15] But most important, lengthy and continuing isolation of the retarded has perpetuated the ignorance, irrational fears, and stereotyping that long have plagued them.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
[16]
In light of the importance of the interest at stake and the history of discrimination the retarded have suffered, the Equal Protection Clause requires us to do more than review the distinctions drawn by Cleburne's zoning ordinance as if they appeared in a taxing statute or in economic or commercial legislation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [17] The searching scrutiny I would give to restrictions *465 on the ability of the retarded to establish community group homes leads me to conclude that Cleburne's vague generalizations for classifying the "feeble-minded" with drug addicts, alcoholics, and the insane, and excluding them where the elderly, the ill, the boarder, and the transient are allowed, are not substantial or important enough to overcome the suspicion that the ordinance rests on impermissible assumptions or outmoded and perhaps invidious stereotypes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: See Plyler v. Doe, 457 U.S. 202 (1982); Roberts v. United States Jaycees, 468 U.S. 609 (1984); Mississippi University for Women v. Hogan, 458 U.S. 718 (1982); Mills v. Habluetzel, 456 U.S. 91 (1982).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
III
In its effort to show that Cleburne's ordinance can be struck down under no "more exacting standard .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: than is normally accorded economic and social legislation," ante, at 442, the Court offers several justifications as to why the retarded do not warrant heightened judicial solicitude.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: These justifications, however, find no support in our heightened-scrutiny precedents and cannot withstand logical analysis.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court downplays the lengthy "history of purposeful unequal treatment" of the retarded, see San Antonio Independent School District v. Rodriguez, 411 U. S., at 28, by pointing to recent legislative action that is said to "beli[e] a continuing antipathy or prejudice."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Ante, at 443.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Building on this point, the Court similarly concludes that the retarded *466 are not "politically powerless" and deserve no greater judicial protection than "[a]ny minority" that wins some political battles and loses others.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Ante, at 445.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The import of these conclusions, it seems, is that the only discrimination courts may remedy is the discrimination they alone are perspicacious enough to see.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Once society begins to recognize certain practices as discriminatory, in part because previously stigmatized groups have mobilized politically to lift this stigma, the Court would refrain from approaching such practices with the added skepticism of heightened scrutiny.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Courts, however, do not sit or act in a social vacuum.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Moral philosophers may debate whether certain inequalities are absolute wrongs, but history makes clear that constitutional principles of equality, like constitutional principles of liberty, property, and due process, evolve over time; what once was a "natural" and "self-evident" ordering later comes to be seen as an artificial and invidious constraint on human potential and freedom.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Compare Plessy v. Ferguson, 163 U.S. 537 (1896), and Bradwell v. Illinois, supra, at 141 (Bradley, J., concurring in judgment), with Brown v. Board of Education, 347 U.S. 483 (1954), and Reed v. Reed, 404 U.S. 71 (1971).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Shifting cultural, political, and social patterns at times come to make past practices appear inconsistent with fundamental principles upon which American society rests, an inconsistency legally cognizable under the Equal Protection Clause.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: It is natural that evolving standards of equality come to be embodied in legislation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: When that occurs, courts should look to the fact of such change as a source of guidance on evolving principles of equality.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
In an analysis the Court today ignores, the Court reached this very conclusion when it extended heightened scrutiny to gender classifications and drew on parallel legislative developments to support that extension:
"[O]ver the past decade, Congress has itself manifested an increasing sensitivity to sex-based classifications *467 [citing examples].
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Thus, Congress itself has concluded that classifications based upon sex are inherently invidious, and this conclusion of a coequal branch of Government is not without significance to the question presently under consideration."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Frontiero v. Richardson, 411 U. S., at 687.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
[18]
Moreover, even when judicial action has catalyzed legislative change, that change certainly does not eviscerate the underlying constitutional principle.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court, for example, has never suggested that race-based classifications became any less suspect once extensive legislation had been enacted on the subject.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: See Palmore v. Sidoti, 466 U.S. 429 (1984).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: For the retarded, just as for Negroes and women, much has changed in recent years, but much remains the same; outdated statutes are still on the books, and irrational fears or ignorance, traceable to the prolonged social and cultural isolation of the retarded, continue to stymie recognition of the dignity and individuality of retarded people.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Heightened judicial scrutiny of action appearing to impose unnecessary barriers to the retarded is required in light of increasing recognition that such barriers are inconsistent with evolving principles of equality embedded in the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court also offers a more general view of heightened scrutiny, a view focused primarily on when heightened scrutiny does not apply as opposed to when it does apply.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [19] Two *468 principles appear central to the Court's theory.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: First, heightened scrutiny is said to be inapplicable where individuals in a group have distinguishing characteristics that legislatures properly may take into account in some circumstances.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Ante, at 441-442.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Heightened scrutiny is also purportedly inappropriate when many legislative classifications affecting the group are likely to be valid.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: We must, so the Court says, "look to the likelihood that governmental action premised on a particular classification is valid as a general matter, not merely to the specifics of the case before us," in deciding whether to apply heightened scrutiny.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Ante, at 446.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: If the Court's first principle were sound, heightened scrutiny would have to await a day when people could be cut from a cookie mold.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Women are hardly alike in all their characteristics, but heightened scrutiny applies to them because legislatures can rarely use gender itself as a proxy for these other characteristics.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Permissible distinctions between persons must bear a reasonable relationship to their relevant characteristics, Zobel v. Williams, 457 U. S., at 70 (BRENNAN, J., concurring), and gender per se is almost never relevant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Similarly, that some retarded people have reduced capacities in some areas does not justify using retardation as a proxy for reduced capacity in areas where relevant individual variations in capacity do exist.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court's second assertion  that the standard of review must be fixed with reference to the number of classifications to which a characteristic would validly be relevant  is similarly flawed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Certainly the assertion is not a logical one; that a characteristic may be relevant under some or even many circumstances does not suggest any reason to presume it relevant under other circumstances where there is reason to suspect it is not.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: A sign that says "men only" looks very *469 different on a bathroom door than a courthouse door.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: But see Bradwell v. Illinois, 16 Wall.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Our heightened-scrutiny precedents belie the claim that a characteristic must virtually always be irrelevant to warrant heightened scrutiny.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Plyler, for example, held that the status of being an undocumented alien is not a "constitutional irrelevancy," and therefore declined to review with strict scrutiny classifications affecting undocumented aliens.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: While Frontiero stated that gender "frequently" and "often" bears no relation to legitimate legislative aims, it did not deem gender an impermissible basis of state action in all circumstances.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Indeed, the Court has upheld some gender-based classifications.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Rostker v. Goldberg, 453 U.S. 57 (1981); Michael M. v. Superior Court of Sonoma County, 450 U.S. 464 (1981).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Heightened but not strict scrutiny is considered appropriate in areas such as gender, illegitimacy, or alienage[20] because the Court views the trait as relevant under some circumstances but not others.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [21] That view  indeed the very concept of heightened, as opposed to strict, scrutiny  is flatly inconsistent with the notion that heightened scrutiny should not apply to the retarded because "mental retardation is a characteristic that the government may legitimately take into account in a wide range of decisions."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Because the government also may not take this characteristic into account in many circumstances, such as those presented here, careful review is required to separate the permissible from the invalid in classifications relying on retardation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: *470 The fact that retardation may be deemed a constitutional irrelevancy in some circumstances is enough, given the history of discrimination the retarded have suffered, to require careful judicial review of classifications singling out the retarded for special burdens.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Although the Court acknowledges that many instances of invidious discrimination against the retarded still exist, the Court boldly asserts that "in the vast majority of situations" special treatment of the retarded is "not only legitimate but also desirable."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: That assertion suggests the Court would somehow have us calculate the percentage of "situations" in which a characteristic is validly and invalidly invoked before determining whether heightened scrutiny is appropriate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: But heightened scrutiny has not been "triggered" in our past cases only after some undefined numerical threshold of invalid "situations" has been crossed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: An inquiry into constitutional principle, not mathematics, determines whether heightened scrutiny is appropriate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Whenever evolving principles of equality, rooted in the Equal Protection Clause, require that certain classifications be viewed as potentially discriminatory, and when history reveals systemic unequal treatment, more searching judicial inquiry than minimum rationality becomes relevant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Potentially discriminatory classifications exist only where some constitutional basis can be found for presuming that equal rights are required.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Discrimination, in the Fourteenth Amendment sense, connotes a substantive constitutional judgment that two individuals or groups are entitled to be treated equally with respect to something.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: With regard to economic and commercial matters, no basis for such a conclusion exists, for as Justice Holmes urged the Lochner Court, the Fourteenth Amendment was not "intended to embody a particular economic theory .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Lochner v. New York, 198 U. S., at 75 (dissenting).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: As a matter of substantive policy, therefore, government is free to move in any *471 direction, or to change directions,[22] in the economic and commercial sphere.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [23] The structure of economic and commercial life is a matter of political compromise, not constitutional principle, and no norm of equality requires that there be as many opticians as optometrists, see Williamson v. Lee Optical of Oklahoma, Inc., 348 U.S. 483 (1955), or new businesses as old, see New Orleans v. Dukes, 427 U.S. 297 (1976).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: But the Fourteenth Amendment does prohibit other results under virtually all circumstances, such as castes created by law along racial or ethnic lines, see Palmore v. Sidoti, 466 U. S., at 432-433; Loving v. Virginia, 388 U.S. 1 (1967); McLaughlin v. Florida, 379 U.S. 184 (1964); Shelley v. Kraemer, 334 U.S. 1, 23 (1948); Hernandez v. Texas, 347 U.S. 475 (1954), and significantly constrains the range of permissible government choices where gender or illegitimacy, for example, are concerned.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Where such constraints, derived from the Fourteenth Amendment, are present, and where history teaches that they have systemically been ignored, a "more searching judicial inquiry" is required.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: United States v. Carolene Products Co., 304 U.S. 144, 153, n. 4 (1938).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: That more searching inquiry, be it called heightened scrutiny or "second order" rational-basis review, is a method of *472 approaching certain classifications skeptically, with judgment suspended until the facts are in and the evidence considered.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The government must establish that the classification is substantially related to important and legitimate objectives, see, e. g., Craig v. Boren, 429 U.S. 190 (1976), so that valid and sufficiently weighty policies actually justify the departure from equality.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Heightened scrutiny does not allow courts to second-guess reasoned legislative or professional judgments tailored to the unique needs of a group like the retarded, but it does seek to assure that the hostility or thoughtlessness with which there is reason to be concerned has not carried the day.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: By invoking heightened scrutiny, the Court recognizes, and compels lower courts to recognize, that a group may well be the target of the sort of prejudiced, thoughtless, or stereotyped action that offends principles of equality found in the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Where classifications based on a particular characteristic have done so in the past, and the threat that they may do so remains, heightened scrutiny is appropriate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
[24]
*473 As the history of discrimination against the retarded and its continuing legacy amply attest, the mentally retarded have been, and in some areas may still be, the targets of action the Equal Protection Clause condemns.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: With respect to a liberty so valued as the right to establish a home in the community, and so likely to be denied on the basis of irrational fears and outright hostility, heightened scrutiny is surely appropriate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
IV
In light of the scrutiny that should be applied here, Cleburne's ordinance sweeps too broadly to dispel the suspicion that it rests on a bare desire to treat the retarded as outsiders, pariahs who do not belong in the community.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court, while disclaiming that special scrutiny is necessary or warranted, reaches the same conclusion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Rather than striking the ordinance down, however, the Court invalidates it merely as applied to respondents.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: I must dissent from the novel proposition that "the preferred course of adjudication" *474 is to leave standing a legislative Act resting on "irrational prejudice" ante, at 450, thereby forcing individuals in the group discriminated against to continue to run the Act's gauntlet.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court appears to act out of a belief that the ordinance might be "rational" as applied to some subgroup of the retarded under some circumstances, such as those utterly without the capacity to live in a community, and that the ordinance should not be invalidated in toto if it is capable of ever being validly applied.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: But the issue is not "whether the city may never insist on a special use permit for the mentally retarded in an R-3 zone."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Ante, at 447.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The issue is whether the city may require a permit pursuant to a blunderbuss ordinance drafted many years ago to exclude all the "feeble-minded," or whether the city must enact a new ordinance carefully tailored to the exclusion of some well-defined subgroup of retarded people in circumstances in which exclusion might reasonably further legitimate city purposes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: By leaving the sweeping exclusion of the "feebleminded" to be applied to other groups of the retarded, the Court has created peculiar problems for the future.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court does not define the relevant characteristics of respondents or their proposed home that make it unlawful to require them to seek a special permit.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Nor does the Court delineate any principle that defines to which, if any, set of retarded people the ordinance might validly be applied.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Cleburne's City Council and retarded applicants are left without guidance as to the potentially valid, and invalid, applications of the ordinance.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: As a consequence, the Court's as-applied remedy relegates future retarded applicants to the standardless discretion of low-level officials who have already shown an all too willing readiness to be captured by the "vague, undifferentiated fears," ante, at 449, of ignorant or frightened residents.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Invalidating on its face the ordinance's special treatment of the "feeble-minded," in contrast, would place the responsibility for tailoring and updating Cleburne's unconstitutional *475 ordinance where it belongs: with the legislative arm of the city of Cleburne.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: If Cleburne perceives a legitimate need for requiring a certain well-defined subgroup of the retarded to obtain special permits before establishing group homes, Cleburne will, after studying the problem and making the appropriate policy decisions, enact a new, more narrowly tailored ordinance.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: That ordinance might well look very different from the current one; it might separate group homes (presently treated nowhere in the ordinance) from hospitals, and it might define a narrow subclass of the retarded for whom even group homes could legitimately be excluded.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Special treatment of the retarded might be ended altogether.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: But whatever the contours such an ordinance might take, the city should not be allowed to keep its ordinance on the books intact and thereby shift to the courts the responsibility to confront the complex empirical and policy questions involved in updating statutes affecting the mentally retarded.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: A legislative solution would yield standards and provide the sort of certainty to retarded applicants and administrative officials that case-by-case judicial rulings cannot provide.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Retarded applicants should not have to continue to attempt to surmount Cleburne's vastly overbroad ordinance.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court's as-applied approach might be more defensible under circumstances very different from those presented here.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Were the ordinance capable of being cleanly severed, in one judicial cut, into its permissible and impermissible applications, the problems I have pointed out would be greatly reduced.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: United States v. Grace, 461 U.S. 171 (1983) (statute restricting speech and conduct in Supreme Court building and on its grounds invalid as applied to sidewalks); but cf.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: id., at 184-188 (opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: But no readily apparent construction appears, nor has the Court offered one, to define which group of retarded people the city might validly require a permit of, and which it might not, in the R-3 zone.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court's as-applied holding is particularly inappropriate here, *476 for nine-tenths of the group covered by the statute appears similarly situated to respondents, see ante, at 442, n. 9  a figure that makes the statutory presumption enormously overbroad.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645 (1972) (invalidating statutory presumption despite State's insistence that it validly applied to "most" of those covered).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: To my knowledge, the Court has never before treated an equal protection challenge to a statute on an as-applied basis.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: When statutes rest on impermissibly overbroad generalizations, our cases have invalidated the presumption on its face.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: [25] We do not instead leave to the courts the task of redrafting the statute through an ongoing and cumbersome process of "as applied" constitutional rulings.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: In Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur, 414 U.S. 632 (1974), for *477 example, we invalidated, inter alia, a maternity leave policy that required pregnant schoolteachers to take unpaid leave beginning five months before their expected due date.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The school board argued that some teachers became physically incapable of performing adequately in the latter stages of their pregnancy, and we accepted this justification for purposes of our decision.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Assuming the policy might validly be applied to some teachers, particularly in the last few weeks of their pregnancy, id., at 647, n. 13, we nonetheless invalidated it in toto, rather than simply as applied to the particular plaintiff.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The Court required school boards to employ "alternative administrative means" to achieve their legitimate health and safety goal, id., at 647, or the legislature to enact a more carefully tailored statute, id., at 647, n. 13.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Similarly, Caban v. Mohammed, 441 U.S. 380 (1979), invalidated a law that required parental consent to adoption from unwed mothers but not from unwed fathers.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: This distinction was defended on the ground, inter alia, that unwed fathers were often more difficult to locate, particularly during a child's infancy.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: We suggested the legislature might make proof of abandonment easier or proof of paternity harder, but we required the legislature to draft a new statute tailored more precisely to the problem of locating unwed fathers.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The statute was not left on the books by invalidating it only as applied to unwed fathers who actually proved they could be located.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: When a presumption is unconstitutionally overbroad, the preferred course of adjudication is to strike it down.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: See also United States Dept.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: of Agriculture v. Moreno, 413 U.S. 528 (1973); Stanley v. Illinois, supra; Vlandis v. Kline, 412 U.S. 441, 453-454 (1973); Carrington v. Rash, 380 U.S. 89 (1965); Sugarman v. Dougall, 413 U.S. 634, 646-649 (1973); Weber v. Aetna Casualty & Surety Co., 406 U.S. 164 (1972); Levy v. Louisiana, 391 U.S. 68 (1968).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: In my view, the Court's remedial approach is both unprecedented in the equal protection area and unwise.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: This doctrinal *478 change of course was not sought by the parties, suggested by the various amici, or discussed at oral argument.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Moreover, the Court does not persuasively reason its way to its novel remedial holding nor reconsider our prior cases directly on point.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Instead, the Court simply asserts that "this is the preferred course of adjudication."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Given that this assertion emerges only from today's decision, one can only hope it will not become entrenched in the law without fuller consideration.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text:
V
The Court's opinion approaches the task of principled equal protection adjudication in what I view as precisely the wrong way.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: The formal label under which an equal protection claim is reviewed is less important than careful identification of the interest at stake and the extent to which society recognizes the classification as an invidious one.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Yet in focusing obsessively on the appropriate label to give its standard of review, the Court fails to identify the interests at stake or to articulate the principle that classifications based on mental retardation must be carefully examined to assure they do not rest on impermissible assumptions or false stereotypes regarding individual ability and need.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: No guidance is thereby given as to when the Court's freewheeling, and potentially dangerous, "rational-basis standard" is to be employed, nor is attention directed to the invidiousness of grouping all retarded individuals together.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Moreover, the Court's narrow, as-applied remedy fails to deal adequately with the overbroad presumption that lies at the heart of this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: Rather than leaving future retarded individuals to run the gauntlet of this overbroad presumption, I would affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals in its entirety and would strike down on its face the provision at issue.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
case: Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Center, Inc.
text: I therefore concur in the judgment in part and dissent in part.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: While I agree that a pledge of stock to a bank as collateral for a loan is an "offer or sale" of a security within the meaning *432 of § 17 (a) of the Securities Act of 1933, 15 U.S. C. § 77q (a), I reach that conclusion by a slightly different route than does the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: The Court holds that a pledge confers an "interest in a security," and that therefore a pledge of shares of stock as collateral for a loan constitutes a "disposition of [an] interest in a security, for value" within the meaning of § 2 (3) of the Act, 15 U.S. C. § 77b (3).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: Ante, at 429.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: I would hold simply that a pledge of stock as collateral is a type of "disposition" within the meaning of § 2 (3).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: See United States v. Gentile, 530 F.2d 461, 466 (CA2), cert.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: denied, 426 U.S. 936 (1976) (interpreting § 2 (3) of the 1933 Act).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Blackmun
text: § 3 (a) (14) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, 15 U.S. C. § 78c (a) (14) ("[t]he terms `sale' and `sell' each include any contract to sell or otherwise dispose of"); Mansbach v. Prescott, Ball & Turben, 598 F.2d 1017, 1029 (CA6 1979) (interpreting § 3 (a) (14) of the 1934 Act).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The writ of certiorari is dismissed as improvidently granted
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In Oklahoma the defendant in a criminal prosecution is presumed to be competent to stand trial unless he proves his incompetence by clear and convincing evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Under that standard a defendant may be put to trial even though it is more likely than not that he is incompetent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The question we address in this case is whether the application of that standard to petitioner violated his right to due process under the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
I
In 1989 petitioner was charged with the brutal killing of an 86-year-old man in the course of a burglary.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: After an Oklahoma jury found him guilty of first-degree murder and recommended punishment by death, the trial court imposed the death penalty.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals affirmed the conviction and sentence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Petitioner's competence was the focus of significant attention both before and during his trial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: On five separate occasions a judge considered whether petitioner had the ability to understand the charges against him and to assist defense counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: On the first occasion, a pretrial judge relied on the opinion of a clinical psychologist employed by the State to find petitioner incompetent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Based on that determination, he committed petitioner to a state mental health facility for treatment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: *351 Upon petitioner's release from the hospital some three months later, the trial judge heard testimony concerning petitioner's competence from two state-employed psychologists.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: These experts expressed conflicting opinions regarding petitioner's ability to participate in his defense.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The judge resolved the dispute against petitioner, ordering him to proceed to trial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: At the close of a pretrial hearing held one week before the trial was scheduled to begin, the lead defense attorney raised the issue of petitioner's competence for a third time.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Counsel advised the court that petitioner was behaving oddly and refusing to communicate with him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Defense counsel opined that it would be a serious matter "if he's not faking."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: After listening to counsel's concerns, however, the judge declined to revisit his earlier determination that petitioner was competent to stand trial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Petitioner's competence was addressed a fourth time on the first day of trial, when petitioner's bizarre behavior prompted the court to conduct a further competency hearing at which the judge observed petitioner and heard testimony from several lay witnesses, a third psychologist, and petitioner himself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [1] The expert concluded that petitioner was *352 presently incompetent and unable to communicate effectively with counsel, but that he could probably achieve competence within six weeks if treated aggressively.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: While stating that he did not dispute the psychologist's diagnosis, the trial judge ruled against petitioner.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
In so holding, however, the court voiced uncertainty:
"Well, I think I've used the expression .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: in the past that normal is like us.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Anybody that's not like us is not normal, so I don't think normal is a proper definition that we are to use with incompetence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: My shirtsleeve opinion of Mr. Cooper is that he's not normal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Now, to say he's not competent is something else.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: "But you know, all things considered, I suppose it's possible for a client to be in such a predicament that he can't help his defense and still not be incompetent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: I suppose that's a possibility, too.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: "I think it's going to take smarter people than me to make a decision here.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: I'm going to say that I don't believe he has carried the burden by clear and convincing evidence of his incompetency and I'm going to say we're going to go to trial."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: *353 Incidents that occurred during the trial,[2]as well as the sordid history of petitioner's childhood that was recounted during the sentencing phase of the proceeding, were consistent with the conclusions expressed by the expert.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In a final effort to protect his client's interests, defense counsel moved for a mistrial or a renewed investigation into petitioner's competence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: After the court summarily denied these motions, petitioner was convicted and sentenced to death.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In the Court of Criminal Appeals, petitioner contended that Oklahoma's presumption of competence, combined with its statutory requirement that a criminal defendant establish incompetence by clear and convincing evidence, Okla.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 22, § 1175.4(B) (1991),[3] placed such an onerous burden on him as to violate his right to due process of law.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The appellate court rejected this argument.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: After noting that it can be difficult to determine whether a defendant is malingering, given "the inexactness and uncertainty attached to [competency] proceedings," the court held that the standard was justified because the "State has great interest in assuring its citizens a thorough and speedy judicial process," and because a "truly incompetent criminal defendant, through his attorneys and experts, can prove incompetency with relative ease."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: We granted certiorari to review the Court of Criminal Appeals' conclusion that application *354 of the clear and convincing evidence standard does not violate due process.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
II
No one questions the existence of the fundamental right that petitioner invokes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: We have repeatedly and consistently recognized that "the criminal trial of an incompetent defendant violates due process."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Medina v. California, 505 U.S. 437, 453 (1992); Drope v. Missouri, 420 U.S. 162, 171 172 (1975); Pate v. Robinson, 383 U.S. 375, 378 (1966).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Nor is the significance of this right open to dispute.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
As Justice Kennedy recently emphasized:
"Competence to stand trial is rudimentary, for upon it depends the main part of those rights deemed essential to a fair trial, including the right to effective assistance of counsel, the rights to summon, to confront, and to cross-examine witnesses, and the right to testify on one's own behalf or to remain silent without penalty for doing so.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Riggins v. Nevada, 504 U.S. 127, 139-140 (1992) (opinion concurring in judgment).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[4]
The test for incompetence is also well settled.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: A defendant may not be put to trial unless he "`has sufficient present ability to consult with his lawyer with a reasonable degree of rational understanding .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [and] a rational as well as factual understanding of the proceedings against him.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: " Dusky v. United States, 362 U.S. 402, 402 (1960) (per curiam).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[5]
*355 Our recent decision in Medina v. California, 505 U.S. 437 (1992), establishes that a State may presume that the defendant is competent and require him to shoulder the burden of proving his incompetence by a preponderance of the evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Id., at 449.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In reaching that conclusion we held that the relevant inquiry was whether the presumption "`offends some principle of justice so rooted in the traditions and conscience of our people as to be ranked as fundamental.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: " Id.,  at 445 (quoting Patterson v. New York, 432 U.S. 197, 202 (1977)).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: We contrasted the "deep roots in our common-law heritage" underlying the prohibition against trying the incompetent with the absence of any settled tradition concerning the allocation of the burden of proof in a competency proceeding.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Our conclusion that the presumption of competence offends no recognized principle of "fundamental fairness" rested in part on the fact that the procedural rule affects the outcome "only in a narrow class of cases where the evidence is in equipoise; that is, where the evidence that a defendant is competent is just as strong as the evidence that he is incompetent."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[6]
The question we address today is quite different from the question posed in Medina.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Petitioner's claim requires us to consider whether a State may proceed with a criminal trial after the defendant has demonstrated that he is more likely than not incompetent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Oklahoma does not contend that it may require the defendant to prove incompetence beyond a reasonable doubt.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [7] The State maintains, however, that the clear and convincing standard provides a reasonable accommodation *356 of the opposing interests of the State and the defendant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: We are persuaded, by both traditional and modern practice and the importance of the constitutional interest at stake, that the State's argument must be rejected.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
III
"Historical practice is probative of whether a procedural rule can be characterized as fundamental," Medina, 505 U. S., at 446.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In this case, unlike in Medina, there is no indication that the rule Oklahoma seeks to defend has any roots in prior practice.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Indeed, it appears that a rule significantly more favorable to the defendant has had a long and consistent application.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: We turn first to an examination of the relevant commonlaw traditions of England and this country.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The prohibition against trying the incompetent defendant was well established by the time Hale and Blackstone wrote their famous commentaries.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 4 W. Blackstone, Commentaries *24 ("[I]f a man in his sound memory commits a capital offence .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [a]nd if, after he has pleaded, the prisoner becomes mad, he shall not be tried: for how can he make his defence?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: "); 1 M. Hale, Pleas of the Crown *34-*35 (same).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The English cases which predate our Constitution provide no guidance, however, concerning the applicable standard of proof in competency determinations.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See Trial of Charles Bateman  (1685), reported in 11 How.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 464, 467 (1816), and Hawles, Remarks on the Trial of Mr. Charles Bateman, 11 How.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 474, 476 (1816) (noting that the court in the 1685 trial incurred "censure" for proceeding to trial with a doubt as to the defendant's competence); Kinloch's Case (1746), 18 How.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 395, 411 (1813); King v. Steel, 1 Leach 452, 168 Eng.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Beginning in the late 18th century, cases appear which provide an inkling of the proper standard.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In King v. Frith,  22 How.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 307 (1790), for example, the court instructed *357 the jury to "diligently inquire .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: whether John Frith, the now prisoner at the bar .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: be of sound mind and understanding or not .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Some 50 years later the jurors received a nearly identical admonition in Queen v. Goode, 7 Ad.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Rep. 572 (K. B.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 1837): "`You shall diligently inquire, and true presentment make .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: whether John Goode .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: be insane or not .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [8] Similarly, in King v. Pritchard, 7 Car.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Rep. 135 (1836), the court empaneled a jury to consider "whether the prisoner is mute of malice or not; secondly, whether he can plead to the indictment or not; thirdly, whether he is of sufficient intellect to comprehend the course of proceedings on the trial .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See also King v. Dyson, 73 Car.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Rep. 825, 838 (1865); Queen v. Berry, 1 Q.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[9]
These authorities, while still speaking less clearly than we might wish, are instructive.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: By phrasing the inquiry in a simple disjunctive, Frith, Goode, and Pritchard suggest that traditional practice required the jury to determine whether the defendant was "more likely than not" incompetent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Nothing in the jury instructions of these cases will bear the interpretation of a clear and convincing standard.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: What is more, the cases contain no indication that the use of a preponderance *358 standard represented a departure from earlier (pre-Constitution) practice.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[10]
Modern English authority confirms our interpretation of these early cases as applying a preponderance standard.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Relying on "principles .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: laid down in a number of cases," including Pritchard and King v. Dyson, 7 Car.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Rep. 135, n. (a) (1831), the court in Queen v. Podola, 43 Crim.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
220, 3 All E. R. 418 (1959), ruled:
"If the contention that the accused is insane is put forward by the defence and contested by the prosecution, there is, in our judgment, a burden upon the defence of satisfying the jury of the accused's insanity.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In such a case, as in other criminal cases in which the onus of proof rests upon the defence, the onus is discharged if the jury are satisfied on the balance of probabilities that the accused's insanity has been made out."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Id., at 235, 3 All E. R., at 429.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[11]
*359 Likewise, we are aware of no decisional law from this country suggesting that any State employed Oklahoma's heightened standard until quite recently.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Rather, the earliest available sources typically refer to English authorities, see, e. g., Freeman v. People, 47 Am.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 1847), State v. Harris, 78 Am.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Dec. 272, 272-275 (N. C. 1860) (adopting procedures outlined in King v. Dyson,  7 Car.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Rep. 135, n. (a) (1831), and King v. Pritchard, 7 Car.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Rep. 135 (1836)), and employ the disjunctive language used by the English courts, see, e. g., Commonwealth v. Hathaway, 13 Mass.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 299 (1816); People v. Kleim, 1 N.Y. 13, 15 (1845); Harris, 78 Am.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Dec., at 275; United States v. Chisolm, 149 F. 284, 290 (SD Ala.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [12] By the turn of the 20th century, however, American courts were explicitly applying a preponderance standard.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In 1896, Ohio juries were instructed that "[t]he burden is upon the prisoner to show by a preponderance of the proof that he is insane."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: State v. O'Grady, 5 Ohio Dec. 654, 655 (1896).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [13] Some 15 years later, the Tennessee Supreme Court described the competency determination as *360 "controlled by the preponderance of the proof," Jordan v. State, 124 Tenn. 81, 89, 135 S.W.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 327, 329 (1911), and the highest court of Pennsylvania held that competence is "decided by a preponderance of the evidence," Commonwealth  v. Simanowicz, 242 Pa. 402, 405, 89 A.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [14] These early authorities are bereft of language susceptible of supporting a clear and convincing evidence standard.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[15]
Contemporary practice demonstrates that the vast majority of jurisdictions remain persuaded that the heightened standard of proof imposed on the accused in Oklahoma is not necessary to vindicate the State's interest in prompt and orderly disposition of criminal cases.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Only 4 of the 50 States presently require the criminal defendant to prove his incompetence by clear and convincing evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [16] None of the remaining *361 46 jurisdictions imposes such a heavy burden on the defendant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [17] Indeed, a number of States place no burden on the defendant at all, but rather require the prosecutor to *362 prove the defendant's competence to stand trial once a question about competency has been credibly raised.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [18] The situation is no different in federal court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Congress has directed that the accused in a federal prosecution must prove incompetence by a preponderance of the evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The near-uniform application of a standard that is more protective of the defendant's rights than Oklahoma's clear and convincing evidence rule supports our conclusion that the heightened standard offends a principle of justice that is deeply "rooted in the traditions and conscience of our people."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Medina v. California, 505 U. S., at 445 (internal quotation marks omitted).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: We turn next to a consideration of whether the rule exhibits "`fundamental fairness' in operation."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Id., at 448 (quoting Dowling v. United States, 493 U.S. 342, 352 (1990)).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
IV
Contemporary and historical procedures are fully consistent with our evaluation of the risks inherent in Oklahoma's practice of requiring the defendant to prove incompetence by clear and convincing evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
In Addington v. Texas,  441 U.S. 418, 423 (1979), we explained that:
"The function of a standard of proof, as that concept is embodied in the Due Process Clause and in the realm of factfinding, is to `instruct the factfinder concerning the degree of confidence our society thinks he should have in the correctness of factual conclusions for a particular type of adjudication.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In re Winship, 397 U.S. 358, 370 (1970) (Harlan, J., concurring)."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The "more stringent the burden of proof a party must bear, the more that party bears the risk of an erroneous decision."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: *363 Cruzan v. Director, Mo.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: For that reason, we have held that due process places a heightened burden of proof on the State in civil proceedings in which the "individual interests at stake .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: are both `particularly important' and `more substantial than mere loss of money.'
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: " Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 756 (1982) (termination of parental rights) (quoting Addington, 441 U. S., at 424).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[19]
Far from "jealously guard[ing]," Jacob v. New York City,  315 U.S. 752, 752-753 (1942), an incompetent criminal defendant's fundamental right not to stand trial, Oklahoma's practice of requiring the defendant to prove incompetence by clear and convincing evidence imposes a significant risk of an erroneous determination that the defendant is competent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In Medina we found no comparable risk because the presumption would affect only the narrow class of cases in which the evidence on either side was equally balanced.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: *364 "Once a State provides a defendant access to procedures for making a competency evaluation," we stated, there is "no basis for holding that due process further requires the State to assume the burden of vindicating the defendant's constitutional right by persuading the trier of fact that the defendant is competent to stand trial."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Unlike the presumption at issue in Medina, however, Oklahoma's clear and convincing evidence standard affects a class of cases in which the defendant has already demonstrated that he is more likely than not incompetent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: For the defendant, the consequences of an erroneous determination of competence are dire.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Because he lacks the ability to communicate effectively with counsel, he may be unable to exercise other "rights deemed essential to a fair trial."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Riggins v. Nevada, 504 U. S., at 139 (Kennedy, J., concurring in judgment).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
After making the "profound" choice whether to plead guilty, Godinez v. Moran, 509 U.S. 389, 398 (1993), the defendant who proceeds to trial
"will ordinarily have to decide whether to waive his `privilege against compulsory self-incrimination,' Boy-  kin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238, 243 (1969), by taking the witness stand; if the option is available, he may have to decide whether to waive his `right to trial by jury,' ibid.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: ;  and, in consultation with counsel, he may have to decide whether to waive his `right to confront [his] accusers,' ibid., by declining to cross-examine witnesses for the prosecution."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: With the assistance of counsel, the defendant also is called upon to make myriad smaller decisions concerning the course of his defense.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The importance of these rights and decisions demonstrates that an erroneous determination of competence threatens a "fundamental component of our criminal justice system"[20]the basic fairness of the trial itself.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: *365 By comparison to the defendant's interest, the injury to the State of the opposite errora conclusion that the defendant is incompetent when he is in fact malingeringis modest.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: To be sure, such an error imposes an expense on the state treasury and frustrates the State's interest in the prompt disposition of criminal charges.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: But the error is subject to correction in a subsequent proceeding and the State may detain the incompetent defendant for "the reasonable period of time necessary to determine whether there is a substantial probability that he will attain [competence] in the foreseeable future."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Jackson v. Indiana, 406 U.S. 715, 738 (1972).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[21]
The Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals correctly observed that the "inexactness and uncertainty" that characterize competency proceedings may make it difficult to determine whether a defendant is incompetent or malingering.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: We presume, however, that it is unusual for even the most artful malingerer to feign incompetence successfully for a period of time while under professional care.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [22] In this regard it is worth reiterating that only four jurisdictions currently consider it necessary to impose on the criminal defendant the burden of proving incompetence by clear and convincing evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Moreover, there is no reason to believe that the art of dissimilation is new.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Eighteenth and nineteenth century courts, for example, warned jurors charged with making competency determinations that "`there may be great fraud in this matter,' " King v. Dyson,  7 Car.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Rep., at 136, n. (a) (quoting *366 1 Hale, Pleas of the Crown, at *35), and that "[i]t would be a reproach to justice if a guilty man .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: postponed his trial upon a feigned condition of mind, as to his inability to aid in his defense," United States v. Chisolm, 149 F., at 288.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [23] Although they recognized this risk, the early authorities did not resort to a heightened burden of proof in competency proceedings.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See Part III, supra.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: More fundamentally, while the difficulty of ascertaining where the truth lies may make it appropriate to place the burden of proof on the proponent of an issue, it does not justify the additional onus of an especially high standard of proof.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
As the Chisolm Court continued,
"[I]t would be likewise a reproach to justice and our institutions, if a human being .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: were compelled to go to trial at a time when he is not sufficiently in possession of his mental faculties to enable him to make a rational and proper defense.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The latter would be a more grievous error than the former; since in the one case an individual would go unwhipped of justice, while in the other the great safeguards which the law adopts in the punishment of crime and the upholding of justice would be rudely invaded by the tribunal whose sacred duty it is to uphold the law in all its integrity."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: A heightened standard does not decrease the risk of error, but simply reallocates that risk between the parties.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See Cruzan v. Director, Mo.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: of Health, 497 U. S., at 283.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In cases in which competence is at issue, we perceive no sound basis for allocating to the criminal defendant the large share of the risk which accompanies a clear and convincing evidence standard.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: We assume that questions of competence will arise in a range of cases including not only those in which one side will prevail with relative ease, but also those in which it is more likely than not that the defendant *367 is incompetent but the evidence is insufficiently strong to satisfy a clear and convincing standard.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: While important state interests are unquestionably at stake, in these latter cases the defendant's fundamental right to be tried only while competent outweighs the State's interest in the efficient operation of its criminal justice system.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
V
Oklahoma makes two additional arguments in support of its procedural rule that warrant discussion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: First, Oklahoma correctly reminds us that it is normally within the power of the State to establish the procedures through which its laws are given effect, including those related to the burden of producing evidence and the burden of persuasion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See Patterson v. New York, 432 U. S., at 201-202.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In Patterson we upheld New York's requirement that in a prosecution for second-degree murder the defendant must bear the burden of proving the affirmative defense of extreme emotional disturbance in order to reduce the crime to manslaughter.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: After observing that the rule was consistent with common-law practice, id., at 202, we held that "[t]he Due Process Clause .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: does not put New York to the choice of abandoning [statutory] defenses or undertaking to disprove their existence in order to convict of a crime which otherwise is within its constitutional powers to sanction by substantial punishment," id., at 207-208.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Although we found no violation in Patterson, we noted that the State's power to regulate procedural burdens was subject to proscription under the Due Process Clause if it "offends some principle of justice so rooted in the traditions and conscience of our people as to be ranked as fundamental," id., at 201-202 (internal quotation marks omitted).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: This case involves such a rule.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Unlike Patterson, which concerned procedures for proving a statutory defense, we consider here whether a State's procedures for guaranteeing a fundamental constitutional right are sufficiently protective *368 of that right.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The deep roots and fundamental character of the defendant's right not to stand trial when it is more likely than not that he lacks the capacity to understand the nature of the proceedings against him or to communicate effectively with counsel mandate constitutional protection.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Finally, Oklahoma suggests that our decision in Addington  v. Texas, 441 U.S. 418 (1979), in which we held that due process requires a clear and convincing standard of proof in an involuntary civil commitment proceeding, supports imposition of such a rule in competency proceedings.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The argument is unpersuasive because commitment and competency proceedings address entirely different substantive issues.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
