text: Although we have not had the opportunity to consider the outer limits of a State's authority to civilly commit an unwilling individual, O'Connor v. Donaldson, 422 U.S. 563, 573 574 (1975), our decision in Donaldson makes clear that due process requires at a minimum a showing that the person is mentally ill and either poses a danger to himself or others or is incapable of "surviving safely in freedom," id., at 573 576.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The test for competence to stand trial, by contrast, is whether the defendant has the present ability to understand the charges against him and communicate effectively with defense counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Dusky v. United States, 362 U. S., at 402.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Even if we were to uphold Oklahoma's imposition of the clear and convincing evidence rule in competency proceedings, the comparable standards in the two proceedings would not guarantee parallel results.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[24]
More importantly, our decision today is in complete accord with the basis for our ruling in Addington.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Both cases concern the proper protection of fundamental rights in circumstances in which the State proposes to take drastic action against an individual.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The requirement that the grounds for civil commitment be shown by clear and convincing evidence *369 protects the individual's fundamental interest in liberty.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The prohibition against requiring the criminal defendant to demonstrate incompetence by clear and convincing evidence safeguards the fundamental right not to stand trial while incompetent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Because Oklahoma's procedural rule allows the State to put to trial a defendant who is more likely than not incompetent, the rule is incompatible with the dictates of due process.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[25]

VI
For the foregoing reasons, the judgment is reversed, and the case is remanded to the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals for further proceedings not inconsistent with this opinion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: It is so ordered.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Respondent, a North Carolina corporation, brought this action in a North Carolina state court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: It sought $200,000 in damages for defamation alleged to have occurred during the course of the United Steelworkers' campaign to unionize respondent's employees.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: The Steelworkers, an unincorporated labor union whose principal place of business purportedly is Pennsylvania, removed the case to a Federal District Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: [1] The union asserted not only federal-question jurisdiction, but that for purposes of the diversity jurisdiction it was a citizen of Pennsylvania, although some of its members were North Carolinians.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: The corporation sought to have the case remanded to the state courts, contending that its complaint raised no federal questions and relying upon the generally prevailing principle that an unincorporated association's citizenship is that of each of its members.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: But the District Court retained jurisdiction.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: The District Judge noted "a trend to treat unincorporated associations in the same manner as corporations and to treat them as citizens of the state wherein the principal office is located."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Divining "no common sense reason for treating an unincorporated national labor union differently from a corporation," he declined to follow what he styled "the poorer reasoned but more firmly established rule" of Chapman v. Barney, 129 U.S. 677.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: On interlocutory appeal the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit reversed and directed that the case be remanded *147 to the state courts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Certiorari was granted, 379 U.S. 958, so that we might decide whether an unincorporated labor union is to be treated as a citizen for purposes of federal diversity jurisdiction, without regard to the citizenship of its members.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: [2] Because we believe this properly a matter for legislative consideration which cannot adequately or appropriately be dealt with by this Court, we affirm the decision of the Court of Appeals.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text:
Article III, § 2, of the Constitution provides:
"The judicial Power shall extend .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: to Controversies.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: between Citizens of different States .
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Congress lost no time in implementing the grant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: In 1789 it provided for federal jurisdiction in suits "between a citizen of the State where the suit is brought, and a citizen of another State.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: "[3] There shortly arose the question as to whether a corporationa creature of state lawis to be deemed a "citizen" for purposes of the statute.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: This Court, through Chief Justice Marshall, initially responded in the negative, holding that a corporation was not a "citizen" and that it might sue and be sued under the diversity statute only if none of its shareholders was a co-citizen of any opposing party.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: *148 Bank of the United States v. Deveaux, 5 Cranch 61.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: In 1844 the Court reversed itself and ruled that a corporation was to be treated as a citizen of the State which created it.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Louisville, C. & C. R. Co. v. Letson, 2 How.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Ten years later, the Court reached the same result by a different approach.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: In a compromise destined to endure for over a century,[4] the Court indulged in the fiction that, although a corporation was not itself a citizen for diversity purposes, its shareholders would conclusively be presumed citizens of the incorporating State.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Marshall v. Baltimore & O. R. Co., 16 How.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Congress re-entered the lists in 1875, significantly expanding diversity jurisdiction by deleting the requirement imposed in 1789 that one of the parties must be a citizen of the forum State.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: [5] The resulting increase in the quantity of diversity litigation, however, cooled enthusiasts of the jurisdiction, and in 1887 and 1888 Congress enacted sharp curbs.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: It quadrupled the jurisdictional amount, confined the right of removal to nonresident defendants, reinstituted protections against jurisdiction by collusive assignment, and narrowed venue.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text:
[6]
*149 It was in this climate that the Court in 1889 decided Chapman v. Barney, supra.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: On its own motion the Court observed that plaintiff was a joint stock company and not a corporation or natural person.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: It held that although plaintiff was endowed by New York with capacity to sue, it could not be considered a "citizen" for diversity purposes.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text:
[7]
In recent years courts and commentators have reflected dissatisfaction with the rule of Chapman v.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: [8] The distinction between the "personality" and "citizenship" of corporations and that of labor unions and other unincorporated associations, it is increasingly argued, has become artificial and unreal.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: The mere fact that a corporation is endowed with a birth certificate is, they say, of no consequence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: In truth and in fact, they point out, many voluntary associations and labor unions are indistinguishable from corporations in terms of the reality *150 of function and structure, and to say that the latter are juridical persons and "citizens" and the former are not is to base a distinction upon an inadequate and irrelevant difference.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: They assert, with considerable merit, that it is not good judicial administration, nor is it fair, to remit a labor union or other unincorporated association to vagaries of jurisdiction determined by the citizenship of its members and to disregard the fact that unions and associations may exist and have an identity and a local habitation of their own.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: The force of these arguments in relation to the diversity jurisdiction is particularized by petitioner's showing in this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Petitioner argues that one of the purposes underlying the jurisdictionprotection of the nonresident litigant from local prejudiceis especially applicable to the modern labor union.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: According to the argument, when the nonresident defendant is a major union, local juries may be tempted to favor local interests at its expense.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Juries may also be influenced by the fear that unionization would adversely affect the economy of the community and its customs and practices in the field of race relations.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: In support of these contentions, petitioner has exhibited material showing that during organizational campaigns like that involved in this case, localities have been saturated with propaganda concerning such economic and racial fears.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Extending diversity jurisdiction to unions, says petitioner, would make available the advantages of federal procedure, Article III judges less exposed to local pressures than their state court counterparts, juries selected from wider geographical areas, review in appellate courts reflecting a multi-state perspective, and more effective review by this Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: We are of the view that these arguments, however appealing, are addressed to an inappropriate forum, and that pleas for extension of the diversity jurisdiction to *151 hitherto uncovered broad categories of litigants ought to be made to the Congress and not to the courts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Petitioner urges that in Puerto Rico v. Russell & Co., 288 U.S. 476, we have heretofore breached the doctrinal wall of Chapman v. Barney and, that step having been taken, there is now no necessity for enlisting the assistance of Congress.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: But Russell does not furnish the precedent which petitioner seeks.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: The problem which it presented was that of fitting an exotic creation of the civil law, the sociedad en comandita, into a federal scheme which knew it not.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: The Organic Act of Puerto Rico conferred jurisdiction upon the federal court if all the parties on either side of a controversy were citizens of a foreign state or "citizens of a State, Territory or District of the United States not domiciled in Puerto Rico.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: "[9] All of the sociedad's members were nonresidents of Puerto Rico, and jurisdiction lay in the federal court if they were the "parties" to the action.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: But this Court held that the sociedad itself, not its members, was the party, doing so on a basis that is of no help to petitioner.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: It did so because, as Justice Stone stated for the Court, in "[t]he tradition of the civil law, as expressed in the Code of Puerto Rico," "the sociedad is consistently regarded as a juridical person."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Accordingly, the Court held that the sociedad, Russell & Co., was a citizen domiciled in Puerto Rico, within the meaning of the Organic Act, and ordered the case remanded to the insular courts.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: It should be noted that *152 the effect of Russell was to contract jurisdiction of the federal court in Puerto Rico.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text:
[10]
If we were to accept petitioner's urgent invitation to amend diversity jurisdiction so as to accommodate its case, we would be faced with difficulties which we could not adequately resolve.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Even if the record here were adequate, we might well hesitate to assume that petitioner's situation is sufficiently representative or typical to form the predicate of a general principle.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: We should, for example, be obliged to fashion a test for ascertaining of which State the labor union is a citizen.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: Extending the jurisdiction to corporations raised no such problem, for the State of incorporation was a natural candidate, its arguable irrelevance in terms of the policies underlying the jurisdiction being outweighed by its certainty of application.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: But even that easy and apparent solution did not dispose of the problem; in 1958 Congress thought it necessary to enact legislation providing that corporations are citizens both of the State of incorporation and of the State in which their principal place of business is located.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text: [11] Further, in contemplating a rule which would accommodate petitioner's claim, we are acutely aware of the complications arising from the circumstance that petitioner, like other labor unions, has local as well as national organizations and that these, *153 perhaps, should be reckoned with in connection with "citizenship" and its jurisdictional incidents.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text:
[12]
Whether unincorporated labor unions ought to be assimilated to the status of corporations for diversity purposes, how such citizenship is to be determined, and what if any related rules ought to apply, are decisions which we believe suited to the legislative and not the judicial branch, regardless of our views as to the intrinsic merits of petitioner's argumentmerits stoutly attested by widespread support for the recognition of labor unions as juridical personalities.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Fortas
text:
[13]
We affirm the decision below.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The petition for writ of certiorari is granted, as is leave to proceed in forma pauperis.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Court of Appeals denied petitioner leave to appeal in forma pauperis a conviction for housebreaking and larceny.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: 101 U. S. App.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Solicitor General concedes that leave to appeal should have been allowed unless petitioner's contentions on the merits were frivolous.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The only statutory requirement for the allowance of an indigent's appeal is the applicant's "good faith."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: In the absence of some evident improper motive, the applicant's good faith is established by the presentation of any issue that is not plainly frivolous.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Farley v. United States, 354 U.S. 521.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The good-faith test must not be converted *675 into a requirement of a preliminary showing of any particular degree of merit.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Unless the issues raised are so frivolous that the appeal would be dismissed in the case of a nonindigent litigant, Fed.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Rules Crim.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: 39 (a), the request of an indigent for leave to appeal in forma pauperis must be allowed.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Normally, allowance of an appeal should not be denied until an indigent has had adequate representation by counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Johnson v. United States, 352 U.S. 565.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: In this case, it appears that the two attorneys appointed by the Court of Appeals, performed essentially the role of amici curiae.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: But representation in the role of an advocate is required.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: If counsel is convinced, after conscientious investigation, that the appeal is frivolous, of course, he may ask to withdraw on that account.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: If the court is satisfied that counsel has diligently investigated the possible grounds of appeal, and agrees with counsel's evaluation of the case, then leave to withdraw may be allowed and leave to appeal may be denied.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: In this case, the Solicitor General concedes, and after examining the record we agree, that the issue presentedprobable cause to arrestis not one that "can necessarily be characterized as frivolous."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is vacated, and the case is remanded for reconsideration in light of this opinion
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Respondent Grace Olech and her late husband Thaddeus asked petitioner Village of Willowbrook (Village) to connect their property to the municipal water supply.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Village at first conditioned the connection on the Olechs granting the Village a 33-foot easement.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Olechs objected, claiming that the Village only required a 15-foot easement from other property owners seeking access to the water supply.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: After a 3-month delay, the Village relented and agreed to provide water service with only a 15-foot easement.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Olech sued the Village, claiming that the Village's demand of an additional 18-foot easement violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Olech asserted that the 33-foot easement demand was "irrational and wholly arbitrary"; that the Village's demand was actually motivated by ill will resulting from the Olechs' previous filing of an unrelated, successful lawsuit against the Village; and that the Village acted either with the intent to deprive Olech of her rights or in reckless disregard of her rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The District Court dismissed the lawsuit pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) for failure to state a cognizable claim under the Equal Protection Clause.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Relying on Circuit precedent, the Court of Appeals for the Seventh *564 Circuit reversed, holding that a plaintiff can allege an equal protection violation by asserting that state action was motivated solely by a "`spiteful effort to "get" him for reasons wholly unrelated to any legitimate state objective.'"
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: It determined that Olech's complaint sufficiently alleged such a claim.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: We granted certiorari to determine whether the Equal Protection Clause gives rise to a cause of action on behalf of a "class of one" where the plaintiff did not allege membership in a class or group.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Our cases have recognized successful equal protection claims brought by a "class of one," where the plaintiff alleges that she has been intentionally treated differently from others similarly situated and that there is no rational basis for the difference in treatment.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: See Sioux City Bridge Co. v. Dakota County, 260 U.S. 441 (1923); Allegheny Pittsburgh Coal Co. v. Commission of Webster Cty., 488 U.S. 336 (1989).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: In so doing, we have explained that "`[t]he purpose of the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment is to secure every person within the State's jurisdiction against intentional and arbitrary discrimination, whether occasioned by express terms of a statute or by its improper execution through duly constituted agents.'"
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Sioux City Bridge Co., supra, at 445 (quoting Sunday Lake Iron Co. v. Township of Wakefield, 247 U.S. 350, 352 (1918)).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: *565 That reasoning is applicable to this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Olech's complaint can fairly be construed as alleging that the Village intentionally demanded a 33-foot easement as a condition of connecting her property to the municipal water supply where the Village required only a 15-foot easement from other similarly situated property owners.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: See Conley v. Gibson, 355 U.S. 41, 45-46 (1957).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The complaint also alleged that the Village's demand was "irrational and wholly arbitrary" and that the Village ultimately connected her property after receiving a clearly adequate 15-foot easement.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: These allegations, quite apart from the Village's subjective motivation, are sufficient to state a claim for relief under traditional equal protection analysis.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: We therefore affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals, but do not reach the alternative theory of "subjective ill will" relied on by that court.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Justice Breyer, concurring in the result.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: The Solicitor General and the village of Willowbrook have expressed concern lest we interpret the Equal Protection Clause in this case in a way that would transform many ordinary violations of city or state law into violations of the Constitution.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: It might be thought that a rule that looks only to an intentional difference in treatment and a lack of a rational basis for that different treatment would work such a transformation.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: Zoning decisions, for example, will often, perhaps almost always, treat one landowner differently from another, and one might claim that, when a city's zoning authority takes an action that fails to conform to a city zoning regulation, it lacks a "rational basis" for its action (at least if the regulation in question is reasonably clear).
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: This case, however, does not directly raise the question whether the simple and common instance of a faulty zoning decision would violate the Equal Protection Clause.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: That is because the Court of Appeals found that in this case respondent *566 had alleged an extra factor as well  a factor that the Court of Appeals called "vindictive action," "illegitimate animus," or "ill will."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: And, in that respect, the court said this case resembled Esmail v. Macrane, 53 F.3d 176 (CA7 1995), because the Esmail plaintiff had alleged that the municipality's differential treatment "was the result not of prosecutorial discretion honestly (even if ineptly  even if arbitrarily) exercised but of an illegitimate desire to `get' him."
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: In my view, the presence of that added factor in this case is sufficient to minimize any concern about transforming run-of-the-mill zoning cases into cases of constitutional right.
label: RHETORIC

author: per_curiam
text: For this reason, along with the others mentioned by the Court, I concur in the result.
label: RHETORIC

label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: And he never developed a history of respondent's troubled childhood with his adoptive familya childhood marked by physical and emotional abuse, neglect by his adoptive parents, his own serious substance abuse problems (including an overdose in his eighth or ninth grade classroom), a stunted education, and recurrent placement in substance abuse rehabilitation facilities, a psychiatric ward, and police custody.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See Declaration by Shannon Sumpter, App.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Counsel's failure to develop this background evidence was so glaring that even the sentencing judge noted that she had "received very little information concerning the defendant's difficult family history."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [1] At the time of sentencing, counsel was only prepared to put on the testimony by respondent's ex-wife and birth mother.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: By any measure, and especially for a capital case, this meager investigation "fell below an objective standard of reasonableness."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Strickland, 466 U.S., at 688, 104 S. Ct. 2052.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: *1946 Given this deficient performance, the only issue is whether counsel's inadequate investigation prejudiced the outcome of sentencing.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The bulk of the Court's opinion argues that the District Court reasonably found that respondent waived his right to present any and all mitigating evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See ante, at 1940-1943.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: As I shall explain, this argument finds no support in the Constitution or the record of this case.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
II
It is well established that a citizen's waiver of a constitutional right must be knowing, intelligent, and voluntary.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: As far back as Johnson v. Zerbst, we held that courts must "`indulge every reasonable presumption against waiver' of fundamental constitutional rights.'"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Since then, "[w]e have been unyielding in our insistence that a defendant's waiver of his trial rights cannot be given effect unless it is `knowing' and `intelligent.'"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Illinois v. Rodriguez, 497 U.S. 177, 183, 110 S. Ct. 2793, 111 L. Ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Twenty-five years after Zerbst, our decision in Schneckloth v. Bustamonte added crucial content to our jurisprudence on the knowing and intelligent waiver of constitutional rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: That case considered whether Zerbst's requirement applied to a citizen's consent to a search or seizure.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In determining that it did not, our decision turned on the "vast difference between those rights that protect a fair criminal trial and the rights guaranteed under the Fourth Amendment."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
We explained:
"The requirement of a `knowing' and `intelligent' waiver was articulated in a case involving the validity of a defendant's decision to forgo a right constitutionally guaranteed to protect a fair trial and the reliability of the truth-determining process ....
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Almost without exception, the requirement of a knowing and intelligent waiver has been applied only to those rights which the Constitution guarantees to a criminal defendant in order to preserve a fair trial."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: We then ran through the extensive list of trial rights to which the knowing-and-intelligent-waiver requirement had already been applied.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [2] We further noted that the Zerbst requirement had been applied to the "waiver of trial rights in trial-type situations,"[3] and to guilty pleas, which we said must be "carefully scrutinized to determine whether the accused knew and understood all the rights to which he would be entitled at trial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
If our emphasis on *1947 trial rights was not already clear, we went on to state:
"A strict standard of waiver has been applied to those rights guaranteed to a criminal defendant to insure that he will be accorded the greatest possible opportunity to utilize every facet of the constitutional model of a fair criminal trial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Any trial conducted in derogation of that model leaves open the possibility that the trial reached an unfair result precisely because all the protections specified in the Constitution were not provided....
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The Constitution requires that every effort be made to see to it that a defendant in a criminal case has not unknowingly relinquished the basic protections that the Framers thought indispensable to a fair trial."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Given this unmistakable focus on trial rights, it makes little difference that we have not specifically "imposed an `informed and knowing' requirement upon a defendant's decision not to introduce evidence."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Ante, at 1942.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: A capital defendant's right to present mitigating evidence is firmly established[5] and can only be exercised at a sentencing trial.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: For a capital defendant, the right to have the sentencing authority give full consideration to mitigating evidence that might support a sentence other than death is of paramount importancein some cases just as important as the right to representation by counsel protected in Zerbst or any of the trial rights discussed in Schneckloth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Our longstanding precedentfrom Zerbst to Schneckloth to the only waiver case that the majority cites, Iowa v. Tovar, 541 U.S. 77, 124 S. Ct. 1379, 158 L. Ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 2d 209 (2004)[6]requires that any waiver of the right to adduce such evidence be knowing, intelligent, and voluntary.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: As such, the state postconviction court's conclusion that respondent completely waived his right to present mitigating evidence involved an unreasonable application of clearly established federal law as determined by this Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See 28 U.S.C.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Respondent's statements at the sentencing hearing do not qualify as an informed waiver under our precedents.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: To understand why, it is important to remember the context in which the waiver issue arose.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In all of his postconviction proceedings, respondent has never brought a freestanding claim that he failed to knowingly or intelligently waive his right to present mitigating evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See Keeney v. Tamayo-Reyes, 504 U.S. 1, 112 S. Ct. 1715, 118 L. Ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 2d 318 (1992) (considering a claim that a defendant's guilty plea was not knowing and intelligent).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: That is because respondent believes he never waived his right to present all available mitigating evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See Brief for Respondent 20 ("Landrigan has alleged that ... he intended at most to forgo his right to put on his ex-wife and birth mother as witnesses"); Part III, infra.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Respondent's only claim is that his counsel was ineffective for failing to investigate and present mitigating evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In light of this posture, the Court's conclusion that respondent cannot make a knowing-and-intelligent-waiver argument *1948 because he failed to present it in the Arizona courts is nothing short of baffling.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See ante, at 1942-1943.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Respondent never intended for waiver to become an issue because he never thought it was an issue.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Waiver only became a concern when he was forced to answer: (1) the State's argument that he could not establish prejudice under Strickland because he waived the right to present all mitigating evidence; and (2) the state postconviction court's conclusion that "[s]ince the defendant instructed his attorney not to bring any mitigation to the attention of the court, he cannot now claim counsel was ineffective because he did not `explore additional grounds for arguing mitigation evidence.'"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: It is instructive that both the State and the postconviction court considered the waiver issue within the context of the prejudice prong of respondent's ineffective-assistance-of-counsel claim.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Even now, respondent's only "claim" within the meaning of 28 U.S.C.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: § 2254(e)(2) is that his counsel was ineffective for not adequately investigating and presenting mitigating evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: An argumentparticularly one made in the alternative and in response to another party is fundamentally different from a claim.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Yee v. Escondido, 503 U.S. 519, 534, 112 S. Ct. 1522, 118 L. Ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[7]
Turning back to that claim, respondent's purported waiver can only be appreciated in light of his counsel's deficient performance.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: To take just one example, respondent's counsel asked a psychologist, Dr. Mickey McMahon, to conduct an initial interview with respondent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: But Dr. McMahon has submitted an affidavit stating that his experience was "quite different from the working relationship [he] had with counsel on other death penalty cases in which the psychological study went through a series of steps."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Declaration by Mickey McMahon, App.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: In this case, Dr. McMahon was "not authorized to conduct the next step in psychological testing that would have told [him] if ... there were any cognitive or neuropsychological deficits not observed during just an interview."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Id., at 246.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Even though Dr. McMahon told respondent's counsel that "much more work was needed to provide an appropriate psychological study for a death penalty case," ibid., counsel refused to let him investigate any further.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[8]
*1949 A more thorough investigation would have revealed that respondent suffers from an organic brain disorder.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See Abdul-Kabir, 550 U.S., at ___, 127 S.Ct.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: at 1673-74 (recognizing that "possible neurological damage" is relevant mitigating evidence).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Years after Dr. McMahon's aborted examination, another psychologist, Dr. Thomas C. Thompson, conducted a complete analysis of respondent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Based on extensive interviews with respondent and several of his family members, a review of his family history, and multiple clinical tests, Dr. Thompson diagnosed respondent with Antisocial Personality Disorder.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See Declaration by Thomas C. Thompson, App.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
Dr. Thompson filed an affidavit in the District Court describing his diagnosis:
"[Respondent's] actions did not constitute a lifestyle choice in the sense of an individual operating with a large degree of freedom, as we have come to define free will.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The inherited, prenatal, and early developmental factors severely impaired Mr. Landrigan's ability to function in a society that expects individuals to operate in an organized and adaptive manner, taking into account the actions and consequences of their behaviors and their impact on society and its individual members.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Based on evaluation and investigation along with other relevant data, this type of responsible functioning is simply beyond Mr. Landrigan and, as far back as one can go, there is no indication that he ever had these capacities."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Id., at 160.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: On the day of the sentencing hearing, the only mitigating evidence that respondent's counsel had investigated was the testimony of respondent's birth mother and ex-wife.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: None of this neuropsychological information was available to respondent at the time of his purported waiver.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Yet the Court conspicuously avoids any mention of respondent's organic brain disorder.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: It instead provides an incomplete list of other mitigating evidence that respondent would have presented and incorrectly assumes that respondent's birth mother and ex-wife would have covered it all.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See ante, at 1941, 1943.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Unless I missed the portion of the record indicating that respondent's ex-wife and birth mother were trained psychologists, neither could have offered expert testimony about respondent's organic brain disorder.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: It is of course true that respondent was aware of many of the individual pieces of mitigating evidence that contributed to Dr. Thompson's subsequent diagnosis.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: He knew that his birth mother abandoned him at the age of six months, see App.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 147; that his biological family had an extensive criminal history, see id., at 146-147; that his adoptive mother had "affective disturbances and chronic alcoholism," id., at 148; that she routinely drank vodka until she passed out, see id., at 184; that she would frequently strike him, once even "hit[ting him] with a frying pan hard enough to leave a dent," id., at 183, 185; that his childhood was difficult and he exhibited abandonment and attachment problems at an early age, see id., at 148; that he had a bad temper and often threw violent tantrums as a child, see id., at 182; and that he "began getting into trouble and using alcohol and drugs at an early age and, by adolescence, he had begun a series of placements in juvenile detention facilities, a psychiatric ward, and twice in drug abuse rehabilitation programs," id., at 148.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Perhaps respondent also knew that his biological mother abused alcohol and amphetamines during her pregnancy, and that in utero exposure to drugs and alcohol has deleterious effects on the child.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See id., at 155-156.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: But even if respondent knew all these things, we cannot assume that he could understand their consequences the way an *1950 expert psychologist could.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Without years of advanced education and a battery of complicated testing, respondent could not know that these experiences resulted in a serious organic brain disorder or what effect such a disorder might have on his behavior.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: And precisely because his counsel failed to conduct a proper investigation, he did not know that this important evidence was available to him when he purportedly waived the right to present mitigating evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: It is hard to see how respondent's claim of Strickland prejudice can be prejudiced by counsel's Strickland error.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 58-59, 106 S. Ct. 366, 88 L. Ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Without ever acknowledging that respondent lacked this information, the Court clings to counsel's discussion with respondent about "the importance of mitigating evidence."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Ante, at 1943.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The majority also places great weight on the fact that counsel explained to respondent that, as counsel, he had a "duty to disclose `any and all mitigating factors ... to th[e][c]ourt for consideration regarding the sentencing.'"
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Leaving aside the fact that counsel's deficient performance did not demonstrate an understanding of the "importance of mitigating evidence"let alone knowledge of "`any and all'" such evidencecounsel's abstract explanation cannot satisfy the demands of Zerbst and Schneckloth.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Unless respondent knew of the most significant mitigation evidence available to him, he could not have made a knowing and intelligent waiver of his constitutional rights.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See Battenfield v. Gibson, 236 F.3d 1215, 1229-1233 (C.A.10 2001) (holding a defendant's waiver invalid where there was "no indication [counsel] explained ... what specific mitigation evidence was available"); Coleman v. Mitchell, 268 F.3d 417, 447-448 (C.A.6 2001); see generally Tovar, 541 U.S., at 88, 124 S. Ct. 1379.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
III
Even if the putative waiver had been fully informed, the Arizona postconviction court's determination that respondent "instructed his attorney not to bring any mitigation to the attention of the [sentencing] court" is plainly contradicted by the record.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The Court nevertheless defers to this finding, concluding that it was not an "unreasonable determination of the facts" under 28 U.S.C.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: "[I]n the context of federal habeas," however, "deference does not imply abandonment or abdication of judicial review."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Miller-El v. Cockrell, 537 U.S. 322, 340, 123 S. Ct. 1029, 154 L. Ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: A careful examination of the "record material and the transcripts from the state courts," ante, at 1941, does not indicate that respondent intended to make a waiver that went beyond the testimony of his birth mother and ex-wife.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The Court reads the following exchange as definitive proof that respondent "informed his counsel not to present any mitigating evidence," ibid.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
:
"THE COURT: Mr. Landrigan, have you instructed your lawyer that you do not wish for him to bring any mitigating circumstances to my attention?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: "THE DEFENDANT: Yeah.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: "THE COURT: Do you know what that means?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: "THE COURT: Mr. Landrigan, are there mitigating circumstances I should be aware of?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: "THE DEFENDANT: Not as far as I'm concerned."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: D-3 to D-4.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The Court also infers from respondent's disruptive behavior at the sentencing hearing that he "would have undermined the *1951 presentation of any mitigating evidence that his attorney might have uncovered."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Ante, at 1941.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: But this record material does not conclusively establish that respondent would have waived his right to present other mitigating evidence if his counsel had made it available to him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The brief exchange between respondent and the trial court must be considered in the context of the entire sentencing proceeding.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
The above-quoted dialogue came immediately after a lengthy colloquy between the trial court and respondent's counsel:
"MR. FARRELL: Your Honor, at this time ...
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: I have two witnesses that I wished to testify before this Court, one I had brought in from out of state and is my client's ex-wife, Ms. Sandy Landrigan.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The second witness is my client's natural mother, Virginia Gipson.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: I believe both of those people had some important evidence that I believed the Court should take into mitigation concerning my client.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: However, Mr. Landrigan has made it clear to me ... that he does not wish anyone from his family to testify on his behalf today.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: "I have talked with Sandra Landrigan, his ex-wife.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: I have talked a number of times with her and confirmed what I thought was important evidence that she should present for the Court.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: And I have also talked with Ms. Gipson, and her evidence I think is very important and should have been brought to this Court's attention.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Both of them, after talking with Jeff today, have agreed with their, in one case son and the other ex-husband, they will not testify in his behalf.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: "THE COURT: Why not?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: "MR. FARRELL: Basically it's at my client's wishes, Your Honor.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: I told him that in order to effectively represent him, especially concerning the fact that the State is seeking the death penalty, any and all mitigating factors, I was under a duty to disclose those factors to this Court for consideration regarding the sentencing.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: He is adamant he does not want any testimony from his family, specifically these two people that I have here, his mother, under subpoena, and as well as having flown in his ex-wife."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: D-2 to D-3 (emphasis added).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Respondent's answers to the trial judge's questions must be read in light of this discussion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: When the judge immediately turned from counsel to respondent and asked about "any mitigating circumstances," the entire proceeding to that point had been about the possible testimony of his birth mother or ex-wife.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Counsel had only informed the court that respondent did not want any testimony "from his family."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Id., at D-3.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Neither counsel nor respondent said anything about other mitigating evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: A fair reading of the full sentencing transcript makes clear that respondent's answers referred only to the testimony of his ex-wife and birth mother.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
[9]
What is more, respondent's answers were necessarily infected by his counsel's failure to investigate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Respondent does *1952 not dispute that he instructed his counsel not to present his family's testimony.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Brief for Respondent 47 ("Landrigan contends that his intent was not to effect a broad waiver but, instead, merely to waive presentation of testimony from his mother and his ex-wife").
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: But his limited waiver cannot change the fact that he was unaware that the words "any mitigating circumstances" could include his organic brain disorder, the medical consequences of his mother's drinking and drug use during pregnancy, and his abusive upbringing with his adoptive family.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [10] In respondent's mind, the words "any mitigating circumstances" just meant the incomplete evidence that counsel offered to present.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: As the en banc Court of Appeals explained, "[h]ad his lawyer conducted an investigation and uncovered other types of mitigating evidence, Landrigan might well have been able to direct the court to other mitigating circumstances."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: It is therefore error to read respondent's simple "Yeah" and "Not as far as I'm concerned" as waiving anything other than the little he knew was available to him.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Accordingly, the state postconviction court's finding that petitioner waived his right to present any mitigating evidence was an unreasonable determination of the facts under § 2254(d)(2).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: While the Court is correct that the postconviction judge was the same judge who sentenced respondent, we must remember that her postconviction opinion was written in 1995five years after the sentencing proceeding.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Although the judge's memory deserves some deference, her opinion reflects many of the same flaws as does the Court's opinion.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Instead of reexamining the entire trial transcript, she only quoted the same two-question exchange with respondent.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: And unlike this Court's repeated reference to respondent's behavior at sentencing, she did not mention it at all.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Her analysis consists of an incomplete review of the transcript and an unsupported summary conclusion that respondent told his attorney not to present any mitigating evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: While I believe that neither the Constitution nor the record supports the Court's waiver holding, respondent is at least entitled to an evidentiary hearing on this question as well as his broader claim of ineffective assistance of counsel.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Respondent insists that he never instructed his counsel not to investigate other mitigating evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Even the State concedes that there has been no finding on this issue.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See, e.g., Brief for Respondent 37 ("`[Judge Kozinski]: There's no [state court] finding at all even by inference as to investigation?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: There's ... no finding that... the trial court made that goes to Landrigan's attitude about allowing his lawyer to investigate?
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: ... [Counsel for State]: I would agree'" (quoting Ninth Circuit Oral Argument Audio 43:55-44:30)).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: He has long maintained that he would have permitted the presentation of mitigating evidence if only counsel was prepared to introduce evidence other than testimony *1953 from his birth mother and ex-wife.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See, e.g., App.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Respondent planned to call his counsel at an evidentiary hearing to testify about these very assertions.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Because counsel is in the best position to clarify whether respondent gave any blanket instructions not to investigate or present mitigating evidence, the Court is wrong to decide this case before any evidence regarding respondent's instructions can be developed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text:
IV
Almost as an afterthought, the Court holds in the alternative that "the District Court did not abuse its discretion in finding that Landrigan could not establish prejudice based on his counsel's failure to present the evidence he now wishes to offer."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: It of course does this on a cold and incomplete factual record.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Describing respondent's mitigation case as "weak," and emphasizing his "exceedingly violent past" and "belligerent behavior" at sentencing, the Court concludes that there is no way that respondent can establish prejudice with the evidence he seeks to introduce.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: This reasoning is flawed in several respects.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: First, as has been discussed above but bears repeating, the Court thoroughly misrepresents respondent's mitigating evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: It is all too easy to view respondent's mitigation case as "weak" when you assume away his most powerful evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The Court ignores respondent's organic brain disorder, which would have explained not only his criminal history but also the repeated outbursts at sentencing.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [11] It mistakenly assumes that respondent's birth mother and ex-wife could have testified about the medical consequences of fetal alcohol syndrome.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: And it inaccurately states that these women could have described his turbulent childhood with his adoptive family.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: We have repeatedly said that evidence of this kind can influence a sentencer's decision as to whether death is the proper punishment.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See, e.g., Wiggins, 539 U.S., at 535, 123 S. Ct. 2527 ("[E]vidence about the defendant's background and character is relevant because of the belief, long held by this society, that defendants who commit criminal acts that are attributable to a disadvantaged background [or to emotional and mental problems] may be less culpable than defendants who have no such excuse" (internal quotation marks omitted)); Eddings v. Oklahoma, 455 U.S. 104, 115, 102 S. Ct. 869, 71 L. Ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 2d 1 (1982) ("[T]here can be no doubt that evidence of a turbulent family history, of beatings by a harsh father, and of severe emotional disturbance is particularly relevant").
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The evidence here might well have convinced a sentencer that a death sentence was not appropriate.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: Second, the aggravating circumstances relied on by the sentencing judge are not as strong as the Court makes them out to be.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: [12] To be sure, respondent had already committed two violent offenses.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: But so *1954 had Terry Williams, and this Court still concluded that he suffered prejudice when his attorney failed to investigate and present mitigating evidence.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: See Williams v. Taylor, 529 U.S. 362, 368, 120 S. Ct. 1495, 146 L. Ed.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: 2d 389 (2000) (noting that Williams confessed to "two separate violent assaults on elderly victims," including one that left an elderly woman in a "`vegetative state'"); id., at 398, 120 S. Ct. 1495 ("[T]he graphic description of Williams' childhood, filled with abuse and privation, or the reality that he was `borderline mentally retarded,' might well have influenced the jury's appraisal of his moral culpability.").
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: The only other aggravating factor was that Landrigan committed his crime for pecuniary gain[13]but there are serious doubts about that.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Stevens
text: As the en banc Court of Appeals explained, "[t]here was limited evidence regarding the pecuniary gain aggravator.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: We brought this case here on certiorari to the Court of Claims under 28 U.S.C.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: § 1255 (1) because it seemed to present constitutional issues important in the award *337 of compensation for vessels requisitioned by the Government during the recent national emergency under § 902 (a) of the Merchant Marine Act of 1936.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text:
[1]
The following facts are the basis of the claim that the scope and validity of that section of the Merchant Marine Act call for adjudication.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: The steam tug Guthrie was owned by the United States and operated by the Coast Guard continuously from 1895, when she was built, until 1941.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: In that year a special Board of Survey appointed to determine her condition found her in need of a new boiler and extensive repairs.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: In view of "the present emergency and the great need of vessels," the Board recommended that the necessary reconditioning be undertaken.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: The Coast Guard, however, directed that she be sold to the highest bidder.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: Respondent's was the highest bid received, and on March 19, 1942, the Guthrie was sold to him for $2,875.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: He *338 proceeded to carry out the repairs that had been indicated by the Coast Guard survey, doing most of the work himself with the aid of a crew of four; the rest was done by a shipyard at Portland.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: His total expenditure on labor and materials was $5,699.78 but would have been substantially greater had he not been experienced in this type of work.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: On April 20 and 21, the Department of Commerce licensed the Guthrie as a "towing steam vessel" permitted to navigate in "bays, sounds, rivers and harbors" and also authorized respondent to employ her in the coasting trade.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: Respondent then brought her under her own power to New York where she was rechristened the MacArthur and where she remained inactive until September, 1942, when the Navy surveyed her for use as a steam-heating plant for heating and pumping fuel oil from barges into combat vessels.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: On October 15, 1942, the War Shipping Administration requisitioned the MacArthur for the Navy and later offered respondent $9,000 as compensation for her.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: This figure was based upon the Coast Guard survey, the Navy survey, and the rules adopted by the Advisory Board on Just Compensation which had been appointed to clarify the measure of compensation payable by the War Shipping Administration under § 902 (a) of the Merchant Marine Act.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: [2] Respondent protested against *339 the award and, as he was entitled to do under § 902 (d) of the Act, accepted 75% of it, and brought suit in the Court of Claims for the difference between the amount he had been offered and the amount he alleged to be due as just compensation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: The Court of Claims found that the market value of the MacArthur on the date of taking was $15,500.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: 110 Ct. Cl.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: The Government does not dispute that there was a market nor that value on the market was as found, but insists that there should have been deducted from it an amount representing enhancement "by the causes necessitating the taking" under the terms of § 902 (a).
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: It bases this contention on two findings of the Court of Claims.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: The first is that "At the time of the requisition, there existed in and about the Port of New York a rising market and a strong demand for tugs of all types, including the MacArthur.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: This situation was due to the greatly increased traffic in the harbor during the period of the war, to the fact that the Government had been requisitioning tugs and to the resulting shortage of tugs."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: The second is that the market value of the MacArthur had been enhanced between September 8, 1939, when the President proclaimed a *340 limited national emergency, and October 15, 1942, when she was requisitioned, by the sum of $5,000, part of which, after proclamation of a general national emergency on May 27, 1941, "was due to the Government's need for vessels, which necessitated the taking of many vessels.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: But the Court of Claims concluded that "It is not possible to allocate to the [Government's need] a definite part of the increase in market value, but even if it were possible to do so, we do not think the defendant is entitled to a deduction from market value on this account."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: The Government's arguments in support of its claim that all or part of the $5,000 enhancement in market value of the MacArthur should be deducted in computing just compensation to respondent ultimately reduce to two.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: The first is that there should be deducted any speculative increase of value due to the probability of the taking.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: It is clear that such a deduction must be made where the increase is traceable to the probability that the Government would take the particular property for which compensation is sought.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: United States v. Miller, 317 U.S. 369.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: But the application of this principle is impossible here in the face of the Court of Claims' explicit finding that "prior to the time the defendant requisitioned the MacArthur there was no reasonable prospect that she would be requisitioned, and no part of the enhancement in her value was due to such a prospect."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: It is arguable, however, that the rationale of the Miller case should be extended to property of a less unique character than land  property of a class any member of which would fulfill the taker's need more or less equally well.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: As to such property there may be speculative increase in value because of the dual expectation that some members of the class will be taken and that the taker may be forced to pay, *341 when the time comes for the award of compensation, something more than what would have been market value had not speculation occurred.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: See McGovern v. New York, 229 U.S. 363, 372.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: And this might be true even though it could not be said that it was probable that a particular member of the class  in this case a particular tug  would be taken.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text:
[3]
But this is a question we do not need to pass on now because, in addition to the finding that it was not probable that the MacArthur would be taken, the record *342 contains evidence of the most conclusive kind that a taking was improbable: the Government had got rid of the tug only seven months before the taking, with complete awareness that she was capable of being adequately reconditioned.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: Among those whose dealings in tugs established market value, therefore, whatever may have been the tendency of their activities to bring about speculative increase in the value of tugs generally, it must have seemed so unlikely that the Government would reverse itself and take the MacArthur back that the market value found by the Court of Claims for this particular tug could hardly have reflected enhancement due to speculation at the expense of the Government's need for her.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: It may be suggested, to be sure, that the need which prompted this reversal might have been anticipated by one shrewd enough to foresee a growing shortage of tugs more accurately than those responsible for the Government's decisions in these matters.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: But whatever might conceivably be the effect on the market of the operations of such persons, it would be an effect so far beyond the possibility of measurement that it would be futile in the extreme to remand for a finding on the point, especially when it is remembered that the MacArthur was requisitioned not for use as a tug but as a heating plant.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: We must reject, therefore, speculation by purchasers of tugs at the expense of the Government's need as a factor contributing to the market value of the MacArthur at the time she was requisitioned.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: The only other way that has been suggested in which her market value could have been increased by the Government's need is as a result of the increase in demand presumably brought about by previous Government seizures of tugs during a period when, as the Court of Claims found, there was a shortage of tugs due to a great "increase in shipping and *343 harbor traffic."
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: In this indirect way, the Government's need can be regarded as a "cause" of the increase in the MacArthur's market value.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: Because this need could be foreseen at least by the time of the declaration of limited national emergency on September 8, 1939, the Government argues that all enhancement in the value of vessels since that date should therefore be deducted from their market price in determining just compensation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: In the alternative, it urges that there should be deducted that proportion of this increase which is allocable to the Government's intervention in the market.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: Whether regarded as founded upon § 902 (a) of the Merchant Marine Act or upon judicial principles of just compensation, both these contentions, in my judgment, must be rejected.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: When the Government first took out of commercial operation some of the tugs which had been thus employed, it could requisition them at a price uninfluenced by its own need.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: A subsequent increase in the market value, though precipitated by the shortage caused by the earlier taking, could be a direct result only of the tug operators' need for the remaining tugs, not of the Government's for those it had taken.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: Leaving enhancement attributable to speculation out of account, as the record obliges us to do, the Government could then requisition still more tugs at a market value at most no higher that the level at which the new price had settled.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: Unlike an increase due to speculation by buyers of tugs that awards for requisitioned tugs would exceed the price likely to be paid by commercial operators purchasing tugs for their own use, an increase due to shortage would affect the price to any purchaser and enhance value to any owner even though no further requisitions were anticipated and even though none were made.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: Exactly the same increase would result whether the shortage were induced by the expanded business of a commercial operator *344 or by Government requisition.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: It simply is not true, therefore, that the enhanced price resulting from shortage is a price which the need necessitating the taking, as opposed to need of the tug operators, created.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: The need of the tug operators, moreover, not merely for the tugs that had been taken, but for additional tugs, was in its turn only one factor in the complex which makes up demand in a period of high costs, high wages, shortages, and inflation.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: We speak, in referring to the interacting forces of such a period, of the "inflationary spiral," and although a requisition by the Government in the midst of this dynamic process undoubtedly has some effect in accelerating it, it is an effect which loses its ascertainable significance by being merged with countless other factors.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: Whatever may be the proper scope of the declaration in § 902 (a) that the value of vessels taken during the national emergency shall not "be deemed enhanced by the causes necessitating the taking or use," the wartime economy itself cannot be regarded as such a cause.
label: RHETORIC

author: Justice Frankfurter
text: Even assuming that there may be other circumstances than those of gambling on the result of an award in which a connection between the taker's intervention in the market and an enhancement of price might be traced, on this record it would be asking for the impossible to insist on an attempt to trace one.
